Theologicals. 2. Historicals. 3. Heterogeneals. 4. Bryto-Anglicals. 5. Miscellaneals. 6. Mutuatitials. Beside a fardel of 76 fragments. / Doon [sic] by Rob. Vilvain of Excester. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Enchiridium Epigrammatum: AN EPITOME Of Eſſais.

l.hi: CArmina dum recinis veluti Philomela ſonora,
Parve Liber; Vox es praetereaque nihil.
Vade puſille Liber, nee inania ſcommata Vulgi
Reſpice: cenſurae ſors tibi certamanet.

lg.l: While like ſhril Nightingal thou Rythms dooſt ſing,
Smal Book; thou art a Voice, and elſ Nothing.
Go forth Babe Book, vain vulgar ſcoffs defy:
Sharp cenſure is thy certain deſtiny.

div.p: Enchiridium Epigrammatum LATINO-ANGLICUM. An Epitome of ESSAIS, Engliſhed out of Latin: without elucidat Explications.

p.hi: Containing ſix Claſſes or Centuries of

div.p: Beſide a Fardel of 76 Fragments.

l.hi: Sunt quibus ampla libet verſare volumina valde:
Sunt quibus ar cta magis volvere ſcripta placet.

lg.l: Som on large Volumes greatly lov to muſe:
Som rather like leſſ Pamphlets to peruſe.

div.p: Doon by ROB: VILVAIN of Exceſter.
Price at Preſſ unbound 1 s. 6 d.
London, Printed by R: Hodgkinſonne (for the Author) and are to be ſold at his Houſe in Thamesſtreet, neet Baynards Castle. A. D. 165 • .

div.head: Ad Lectores omnifarios: To al ſorts of Surveiors.
div.p: THis Toy is a meer Table of 676 Eſſais on ſeveral Subjects: which are more copiouſly contained in two Folio Tomes intended for the Preſſ, with larger or leſſer Explications on ech: But my hand is illegible and much interlined; ſo they muſt al be new tranſcribed, which wil take up one yeers time at leaſt, if God Grant life ſo long. In which regard, to ſatisfy many Mens earneſt expectations, I hav publiſhed hand in hand eght Theological Theorems, and two ſubnected Eſſais explicated in quarto, which he that liſts may peruſe.

Virgil is ſaid to play the part of a Shepherd in his Eclogs, a Farmer in his Georgics, and a Warrier in his Aeneids.: So I preſuming to print three Pamphlets, act the Perſon of a Poetaſter in this firſt, to vent the dregs of Youthly delights: being a bare bag of bones or Sceleton (like a Nutſhel without kernel) denuded of skin, fleſh, ligaments,
and other lineaments: Of a Theologiſt in the next (which is a rich casknet of ſublime Speculations) to jet like a long eard Animal in a Lions skin: being peeced out with collections taken from deep Divines. And of a general Scioliſt or Smatterer in the laſt (which ſhal folow ſo ſoon as Lucina can bring it to birth) to venditat ſundry ſorts of liberal literature in ſhreds, being the rotten withered fruits of Academic ſtudies, now almoſt antiquated or out of date by long deſuetud.

To tel truth this pety pocket peece (firſt intitled memorativ Verſes) is printed a part in policy, purpoſly to beſtow on Friends; being but a Catalog of Contents belonging to the larger Volume; which is grown to ſo big a bulk beyond du bounds, as wil mount to a far higher valu (that every one may hav one) then my ruined Fortune can bear; hoping that al ſuch as know my poverty wil accept this ſmal mite in lieu of a richer preſent. My memory cannot reach to remember every Patient or Party of my antient acquaintance, to whom I am ingaged in amity or courteſy: but my deſire is to gratiſy ech, and ſend 400. Copies (ſom bound, ſom unbound) to diſperſ in free gift (without any fee to ſender or bri • ger) that none may be forgotten. Thoſ that are omitted, may repair to Mr. Hooper Apothecary
in Exceter neer S. Martins Lane; who wil deliver one gratis to any man of quality my familiar Friend.

l.hi: Nemo erit è priſcis mihi non donatus amicis,
Quin unum excipiet pro meo amore Librum

lg.l: For lovs ſake none of antient Friends ſhal be,
But he one Book ſhal hav for boon from me.

div.p: The Eſſais or Epigrams run in one tenor throughout: for though the matter be diverſ, yet the method or maner (moſtly Diſtichs, which is the pithieſt parcel of Poetry, compriſing the ful ſenſ in two Verſes) is uniform: know one, know al. Al Latin Verſes whether new coined or borowed are freſh tranſlated neer the letter, which ſom naſut Critics cenſure as too Pedantic; when their Libertin guiſe is in very Antick diſguiſe: who render their own ſenſ ſo far varying from the Authors meaning, as he wil ſcarſ own it: but the engliſh Verſions flowed forth ex tempore.

l.hi: Sponte ſua carmen numeros veniebat ad aptos:
Et quod tentabam ſcribere Verſus erat.

lg.l: Metres of free accord to fit feet came:
And what I tried to write, in Verſ did frame.

div.p:
For the Latin hav al juſt feet, but ſom Engliſh one too many; which may be clipped off
by corrept pronouncing. Al proper names (Adam, Abel) being ſquared by no rule, are made long or ſhort by Poetical liberty: but thoſ with Dipthongs, duple Conſonants, or the like (Caeſar, Xerxes, Tullius) are long by Nature or Poſition: Yet in moſt Roman names (Roma, Romulus) I obſerv cuſtom and authority ſo curiouſly as can be, wch may be a good Leſſon for Grammar Scholars to doo the like. If any profeſt Poet ſhal ſift the whol Pile, he wil find ſom ſuch Crabtree peeces of knotty Subjects, as may haply gal his hand to cleav them, or trouble his head-peece to reduce them into ſmooth Metres: therfore no marvel if many of the Puzlers here be not ſo wel planed, poliſhed, or perfected as is expected, or as they ſhould be.

l.hi: Carbaſa ſiſte, Ratis: mihi Cynthia vellicat aures

lg.l: Barque, ſtop thy ſails: Cynthia bids ſtay,
Leſt ſhe ſhould ſole my Ears away.

div.p: Nor wil I ſet a large Porch before a litle Pile, leſt the houſ run out at dore.
Adieu.

l.hi: Scribere ſcribendo diſces, promptū efficit uſus:
Sic cudendo itidem cudere quiſque poteſt.

lg.l: By writing or Printing one ſhal learn to write
And likewiſe Print: uſe makes men prompt t' indite.

div.head: Delicta improviſa.
div.p: THe Errats eſcaped are not many, nor much material; being moſtly literal, not verbal nor real to mar the ſenſ: which every man may eaſily emend as they occur: therfore ſuch ſlight ſl • ps are let paſſ without any animadverſion. Only one Latin title is caſualy omitted (Intellectus & voluntas, Cl. 1. Theol. Epig. 41. p. 12.) which is inſerted in the Table, and ſpace ſufficient left in the Enchiridion to interpoſe it, if any one liſt. The Author hath ſuddenly ſet forth a Compend of Chronography (price at Preſſ 3 d.) worth peruſing, intended for a previous Precognit to the two inſuing Tomes.

l.hi: Carminibus nihil eſt niſi mera Errata repertum:
Attamen bocce libro pauca relicta patent.
Pluribus Erratis abnoxia Carmina constant:
Maxima queis minime cura carere potest.

lg.l: Verſes nought elſ ſav Errats meer contain:
Yet in this Book few viſible remain.
Verſes with ſundry Errats are diſtended:
Which cannot be by greateſt care amended.

div.head: Theological Eſſays. The firſt century of ſacred matters, under four chronical heads.

argument.p:
The Deity in three Perſons coequal, coeſſential, A • aetern •
coeternal exiſting.

l.hi: IN Triade eſt miranda monas ſanctiſſima: nempe
Perſonis Deitas in tribus una viget.

lg.l: High Holy Unity is in Trinity:
For in three Perſons exiſts one Deity.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Lux Radii fons eſt, lumen dependet ab iſtis:
Solus item fons eſt in Deitate Pater.

lg.l: Light's the Beams ſource, ſhine doth on them rely:
So is the Father, Fountain in Deity.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Sicut idem in Sole eſt, in Luna, & in Aëre lumen:
Perſonis Deitas ſic patet una tribus:

lg.l: As in Sun, Moon & Air, one ſhine conſiſts:
So in three Perſons one-God-head exiſts.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: A Sole una micans in Luna & in Aere lux eſt:
Perſonis Deitas ſic tribus una nitet.

lg.l: One light from Sun to Moon and Air is darted:
So to three Perſons one God-head is imparred.

argument.p: The three Perſons in one God, Inviſible, Indiviſible, Incomprehenſible ſubſiſting.

l.hi: Lux, Lumen, radius Sole aſpiciuntur eodem:
Perſonae ſic tres in Deitate patent.

lg.l: Light, Brightnes, Beam in one ſelf-Sun appear,
So in one God-head Perſons three cohere.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Lux, Radius, Lumen tria ſunt, aſt unicus eſt Sol:
Sic tret Perſone, ſed Deus unus ineſt.

lg.l: Light, Ray and Shine, are three; the Sun but one:
So Perſons three ſubſiſt in God alone.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Eſt animae humanae triplex innata facultas,
Sic Perſonae triplex in Deitate manet.

lg.l: Man's Soul hath three chief faculties in bred:
So Perſons three ſubſiſt in one Godhead.

lg.head: Doxologia.Doxologia.

l.hi: Gloria tota Deo in coelis ſit dedita Patri,
Verbo incarnato, Spirituique Sacro.

lg.l: All Glory to God the Father, in Heav'n:
To th'Word, made Fleſh, and holy Ghoſt be giv'n.

argument.p: The 9. Orders of good Angels, or Heavenly A. M. 1. Hierarchy; fathered on Denys Areopagit.

l.hi: Angelicae in claſſes triplici ſtant ordine turmae
Diviſae, veteri traditione, novem.

lg.l: Into nine ranks good Angels ſorted be,
By old tradition, in three fold degree.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ter tres Angelici memorantur in ordine firmi,
Qui ſemper ſteterant integritate, gradus.

lg.l: Thriſe three ranks of good Angels reckned be,
Which ſtill ſtood firm in their integritie.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: In tribus agminibus diſtinctos ordine ter tres,
Theiologi Angelicos conſtituere choros.

lg.l: Divines nine quires of Angels have ordained;
Which are in three diſtinct troops fitly trayned.

div.head: EPIG. IV. Daemoniorum gradus, ſeu turmae.

argument.p: The 9 degrees or troops of Devils, with their leaders, as Agrippa ſtates them.

l.hi: Daemonibus quidam ter tres tribuere Cohortes,
Spiritibus ſimiles, diſpare ſorte, bonis.

lg.l: Some men, 'mongſt helliſh-fiends, nine ſquadrons find,
Like to good Angels, but of unlike kind.

lg.head: Aliter,

l.hi: Agmina per ter tres diſpenſant Infera turmas
Scriptores varii: dant to tidemque duces.

lg.l: Infernal Spirits ſom writers doe divide
Into nine Troops, and leaders nine beſide.

l.hi: Ter tria cum ducibus [ſic vulgi fama remonſtrat)
Daemoniorum extant agmina dira ſuis.

lg.l: Nine Troops are extant (ſo ſaith vulgar fame)
Of foul fiends, with their Captains cal'd by name.

argument.p: The 2 parts or branches of divine Predeſtination; Election and Reprobation.

l.hi: Jacta prius quam ſunt mundi primordia, quoſdam
Eligit, at reliquos rejicit ipſe Deus.

lg.l: Before the world was laid, God ſom did chuſe,
But from eternity the reſt refuſe.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: An Deus ex lâpſu praeviſo reprobet Adae,

l.hi: Aut puro ex placito, lis violenta fuit.

lg.l: Whether God reprobat for Adam's fal foreſeene
Or of pure pleaſure? bitter ſtrifc hath bin.
Damnat Luther ait, quia lapſum praeſcit Adami:
Pro placito at Calvin perdere velle Deum.
God damns, ſaith Luther, for Adam's fal foreknown,
But Calvin of free-wil, his power t'have ſhown.

argument.p: The 6 days viſible works of Creation deſcribed by Moſes the man of God.

l.hi: Maxima ſex mundi eſt moles fabricata diebus:
Gratia, Laus & Honos debita danda Deo.

lg.l: The World's vaſt frame was finiſh'd in ſix days:
Thanks, Praiſe and Honor be due to God alwais.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Lux, Coelum, Tellus, Stellae, Piſces, volucreſque;

Beſtia tunc omnis, poſt
que creatus homo eſt.

lg.l: Light, Heav'n, Earth, S • ars, Fiſhes and Fowls were fram'd
Then Beaſts al kinds, & Man, made laſt there nam'd

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Machina ſic mundi eſt ſex tota peracta diebus:
Gloria in excelſis attribuenda Deo.

lg.l: Thus was the world's whol pile in ſix days ended.
Glory to God on high be ever rendred.

argument.p: The 7 day of God's reſt ſtiled Sabbath, in whoſe ſtead the Lord's-day ſucceded.

l.hi: Singula ſex perages opera efficienda diebus,

Septima quae
que dies ſanctificanda Deo eſt,

lg.l: All works to doo thou ſhalt end in ſix dayes
Each ſev'nth muſt halowed be to God alwais.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sabbathum erat primo impoſitum velut arrha quietis
Tranſlatum in Domini quod fuit inde diem.

lg.l: The Sabbath firſt as token of reſt's impoſed,
Which into the Lords-day was ſince tranſpoſed.

lg.head: Cataſtrophe.

l.hi: Ergo dies Domini proprio eſt cognomine dicta.

Quippe cui
que rei nomina recta dabis.

lg.l: Therefore the Lords-day by tru name's ſo ſtiled,
For right names to all things ſhould be aſſigned.

argument.p: The 2 ſigns and ſeaſons, in one of which the world probably was created.

l.hi: Mundum alii credunt in Vere fuiſſe creatum;
Aſt alii Autumno verius eſſe putant.

lg.l: Som, that the world in ſpring was fram'd, eſteem;
But ſom in Autumn formed truer deem.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Veris dux Aries natalem vendicat Orbis,

l.hi: Sed Domina Autumni jus ſibi libra petit.

lg.l: Aries, as Lord of Spring, the world's birth claims,
But Libra Autumn's dame, at hir right aims.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Plaerique attribuunt mundi incunabula veri,
Sed pauci Autumnum principium eſſe volunt.

lg.l: Moſt men the worlds birth to the Spring impute,
But ſom few Autumn for the ſource repute.

div.head: EPIG. IX. Natura, Fatum, Fortuna, Caſus.

argument.p: The 4 chief cauſes of ſeveral effects or events in the whol univers.

l.hi:
Natura in rebus Fatum, Fors, Sorſ
que creatis,
Divina liquidò lege ſtatuta vigent.

lg.l: Nature, Fate, Fortune, Chance in things created,
Cleerly appear by Law divine ſubſtrated.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Natura & Fatum, Sors & Fortuna gubernant
Res, acta, eventus, quicquid in Orbe ſubeſt.

lg.l: Nature, Fate, Chance and Fortune govern al
Things, Acts, Events what in the world befal.

argument.p: The 24 rarities in Nature, or wonderful works of God in the World.

l.hi: Multa Dei toto renitent magnalia mundo:
Quae natura homini conſpicienda dedit.

lg.l: Gods great works many in the world appeer,
Which Nature to man's view exhibits cleer.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Sex quater hic celebrata Dei magnalia conſtant:
Quae natura homini conſpicienda refert.

lg.l: God's twenty four great works are here deſcribed:
Which Nature ſhews to be by man admired.

argument.p: The 4 general cauſes of al things, as antient Philoſophers poſitivly define.

l.hi:
Quatuor in Natura extant Cauſae, Ar • e
que Forma,

Efficiens, Finis, Materieſ
que ſatae.

lg.l: Four Cauſes, to produce things in Art tend;
And Nature: Matter, Form, Efficient, End,

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quatuor antiqui Cauſas ſtatúere Sophiſtae,
Finis at in numero vix recitandus erit.

lg.l: Four Cauſes old Philoſophers hav cited,
But final in the number's ſcarce recited.

argument.p: The 11 Celeſtial Spheres, as late Aſtronomers ſtate them, but the Antient fewer.

l.hi: Ʋndecimum in coelis Orbem certo ordine ſummum,
Aſtronomi (ſed vix vere) poſuere recentes.

lg.l: Som late Aſtronomers an elev'nth Orb hav placed
Higheſt in Heav'ns courſ, but ſcarce truly ſtated.

l.hi: Ʋndecimum celſis Coeli ſtationibus orbem
Aſtronomi ſtatuunt (falſo numerando) moderni.

lg.l: Modern Aſtronomers in the Heav'ns high ſpace,
An clev'nth Sphere doo falſly reck'ning place.

l.hi: Prima beatorum ſedes immobile Coelum,
Mobile primum aliud, Cryſtallinum in ordine ſubſtat:

Tum Firmamentū ſequitur; ſep • em
que Planetae
Actronomi hunc numerum undecimum poſuere recentes.

lg.l: Firſt the fix'd Heav'n, the Saints firm ſeat, in order,
Firſt mover next, then Cryſtal Orb ſet under,
Firmament folows, and ſev'n Planets laſt,
This number of elev'n late Artiſts caſt.

argument.p: The 3 divers delineations of Heaven, according to Copernicus, Kepler, and Tycho.

l.hi: Aſtronomi inſignes coeleſtis ſchemata Sphaerae,
Tres tria diverſo conſtituere modo.

lg.l: Three learn'd Aſtronomers three fit Schems propoſed
Of Heav'nly Orbs in diffring ſort diſpoſed.
Subtilis ſtatuit ſibi ſchema Copernicus Orbis,
Keplerus varium, Tycho ab utroque novum.
Acute Copernicus his worlds frame deviſed,
Kepler another, Tycho from both divided.

div.head: EPIG. XIV. Circuli in Coelis conficti.

argument.p: The 6 greater and 4 leſſer imaginary Circles in the Heavenly bodies.

l.hi: Ter duo majores ſtatuuntur ab Arte minores
Bis duo ſupremi Circuli in Arce poli.

lg.l: Six greater Circles, Art in Heav'n conceivs,
And four cal'd leſſer, high above receivs.

l.hi: Merridies, Coluri, Aequator, Signator, Horizon

Sex magni, exigui Tropici, gemini
que Polares.

lg.l: Meridian, Colurs, Line, Zodiac, Horizon are
Six great, leſſ Tropics two, and two Polar.

argument.p: The 48 Conſtellations or Cluſters of Stars diſperſed in the Firmament.

l.hi: Plurima ſunt variis ſpatiis cumulata ſeorſim
Sydera; quae coelis conspicienda micant.

lg.l: Many fix'd Stars in diſtinct places be,
Which in the Heavens ſhine moſt bright to ſee.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quadraginta octo numerantur Sydera Coelo,
Quaelibet ordinibus concamerata ſuis.

lg.l: In Heav'n are fix'd forty-eight Conſtellations,
Each ordered in their ſet Concamerations.

div.head: EPIG. XVI. Stellae fixae in Firmamento.

argument.p: The 1225 Stars in the Firmament, ſited under the 48 Conſtellations.

l.hi:
Innumeris fulget facies coeli undi
que Stellis,
Quae rutilante ſuo lamine nocte nitent.

lg.l: Numberleſs Stars in Heav'n throughout giv light:
Which with their ſparkling beams ſhine cleer by night.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Mille ducenta extant, viginti & quin
que notata
Astra; ſed obſcurè plura minora latent.

lg.l: Twelv hundred twenty fiv known Stars appear,
But many leſſer, hid, not ſeen ſo cleer.

argument.p: The 12 parts or portions, commonly caled the 12 ſigns of the Zodiac.

l.hi: Signa quater tria Zodiaco memorantur in amplo:

Quorum cui
que patent nomina nota ſatis.

lg.l: In the large Zodiac Signs ful four times three
(Whoſe names are t' al wel known) remembred be.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Dux Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo,

Libra
que Scorpius, Arcitenens, Caper, Amphora, Piſces,

l.hi: Nominibus propriis quae conſtant carmina metris
Angliacis facile nemo referre poteſt.

lg.l: Verſes which are of p • oper names compacted,
In Engliſh rithms can hardly be tranſacted.

argument.p: The 4 ſet ſeaſons of a Solar yeer, three of thoſ Signes making each quarter.

lg.l: Ver, Aeſtas, Autumnus, Hyems, ſunt quatuor anni

l.hi: Partes, quas curſu Sol facit ipſe ſuo.

lg.l: Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter, four parts are
Of a yeer, which Sol makes by courſ circular.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ver nitidum, deformis Hyems, Autumnus & Aeſtas

l.hi: Bis duo ſunt anni tempora nota ſatis.

lg.l: Neat-Spring, rough-Winter, Autumn, Summer frame
The yeers four current Seaſons of known fame.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi:
Tempora ſunt anni nota cui
que viro.

lg.l: Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter t' all appear,
Four reaſons known to each of Solar yeer.

argument.p: The 2 Equinoxes, (Vernal, Autumnal) and 2 Solſtices (Eſtival, Hyemal,) in each yeer.

lg.l: Bis Libra atque Aries Soles cum noctibus aequant
Lux longaeſt Cancro, ſed brevis orta Capro.
The Ram and Ballance equal nights with days,
The Crab brings long days, but Goat ſhort alwais.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Sole ſuum aſſiduè curſum peragrante per annum

l.hi:
Bis datur Aequiduum Solſtitium
que duplex.

lg.l: While Sol his race runs daily through the yeer.
Twice Equinox, and two Solſtices appear.

div.head: EPIG. XX. Stellae novae in Coelis.

argument.p: The 2 famous new Stars (a beardleſs and bearded) late obſerved in the Heavens.

l.hi: Caſſiopeia olim nova ſtella ſub Aethere viſa eſt

lg.l: Atque Cometa novus ſub Jove natus erat.
A new Star not long ſince i'th Chair appeared. A C. 1572 A. 1618.
And late a Comet next Jove his courſ ſteered.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: In Firmamento dudum eſt nova ſtella ſuborta,
Viſus & in coelis deinde Cometa fuit.

lg.l: Whilom a new Star in Firmament hath been:
And ſince, a Comet in the Heav'ns was ſeen.

argument.p: The 7 erratic-Stars or Planets, as their ſeverall ſpheres ſtand ſubordinat.

l.hi:
Sunt ſeptem errones Coelis, dicti
que Planetae:
Qui proprios orbes obtinuêre ſibi.

lg.l: Sev'n wandrers, Planets cal'd, in Heav'ns are ſited,
Which hav their proper Orbs to each aſſigned.

l.hi: Saturnus, Jupiter, Mars, Sol, Venus, Hermes, & ima
Luna, Planetarum ſeptem numerum or dine cōplent.

lg.l: Saturn, Jove, Mars, Sol, Venus, Mercury, Moon,
Sev'n Planets make in rank til world be doon.

argument.p: The 2 great Lights (ſo ſtyled by Moſes) of the univers, viz. the Sun and Moon.

l.hi: Lumina facta duo: Sol Archidynasta diei;
Et noctis Rectrix Luna creata fuit.

lg.l: God made two Lights, the Sun to rule the day,
And pale bright Moon over the night to ſway.

l.hi: Lux a Sole fluit, velut unda a fonte perenni.
A quo Luna ſuum mutuo lumen habet.

lg.l: Light from the Sun, as ſtreams from quick ſpring flow,
Of whom the Moon borrows her light below.

argument.p: The 4 main quarters of Heaven (Eaſt, Weſt, North, South) wel known to al.

l.hi: Ortus & Occaſus, Septentrio & Auſter in Orbe.
Quadruplici coeli cardine nomen habent.

lg.l: Eaſt, Weſt, North, South, four quarters be,
Cal'd Heav'ns four points in their degree.
Flat Boreas, ridet Zephyrus, calet Auſter & Eurus: fait,

l.hi: Hi variis venti partibus Orbe vigent.

lg.l: The North-wind rough, Weſt mild, South and Eaſt
In the Worlds ſeveral parts theſ four ſway bear.

argument.p: The 5 Zones or Girdles, into which or whereby the Earth is antiently divided.

l.hi: Torrida-zona tenens medium, eſt habitalis, Orbem,

Temperie
que duae florent, totidem
que rigeſcunt.

lg.l: The burnt-Zone, ſet in midſt, is habitable,
Two temperat next; but two ſcarce ſufferable.

l.hi: Torrida-zona calet, torpeſcunt frigore binae,
Mitior aſt reliquis temperat aura duas.

lg.l: The middle-Zone's hot, two with cold annoy;
But th'other two a milder aire enjoy.

argument.p: The 2 Coſmographic Globes of Heaven and Earth invented by Archimedes.

l.hi:
Coelieus inferior
que Globus ſtant ordine bini
Distincti, aſt unum cum Mare Terra facit.

lg.l: Heav'n and the lower world two Globes prefine,
But Sea and Earth into one Orb combine.

l.hi: Ampla Globis geminis ex vitro Schematae Coeli

lg.l: Et terrae Siculus conficit arte Senex.
Heav'n and Earth Scheam in two great Globes of glaſſe,
By Archimedes Art preſented was.

argument.p: The 4 ſimple Elements of the ſublunar World, as Philoſophars ſtate them.

l.hi: Terra, Aqua deſcendunt, aſcendunt Ignis & Aer:
E quibus exiſtunt corpora mixta ferunt.

lg.l: Earth, Water downward tend, Fire and Air mount:
From which, they ſay, all mixtils doe ſurmount.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Terra, Aqua praegravitant, levitant contra ignis & Aer,
Quatuor haec Mundi pura Elementa vocant.

lg.l: Earth, Water, heavy be, Fire and Air light;
Theſ four the Worlds pure elements are hight.

argument.p: The 6 reciprocal changes or converſions of the Elements from one to another.

l.hi: Terra in Aquas rareſcit, Aquae attenuantur in Auras,
Ardeſcitque Aer rapidum extenuatus in ignem;
Ordine retrogrado, ſpiſſatur in Aera Flamma:

in
que undas Aer, Terra & generatur ab unda

lg.l: Earth thins to Water, Water int' Air turns,
Air rarifi'd to Fire moſt fiercely burns:
Backward again, Fire Air by thickning breeds,
Air Water makes, of Water Earth proceeds.

argument.p: The 2 heavy Elements (Earth, Water) held by Peripatetics to tend downwards.

l.hi:
Terram Aqua principio tegit undi
que postea at unum

Ʋtra
que conficiunt conſociata Globum.

lg.l: The Water firſt hid th' Earth: but both ſoon after
Made one joynt Globe, being eſpous'd together.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Finxit Ariſtotiles duo ſolum Elementa deorſum

l.hi:
Tendere quae
que unum conſtituere Globum.

lg.l: Ariſtotle fain'd two only Elements tend
Downward, and they both into one Globe bend.

argument.p: The 2 light Elements (Fire Air) ſaid by the ſame Philoſophers to mov upwards.

l.hi: Ignis sponte ſua ſurſum attolluntur & Aer:
Nam levitate ſua roſtra ſuprema petunt.

lg.l: Of free accord, Fire and Air aſpire:
For being light, they th' higheſt Seats acquire.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Corpora ſimpliciter levia an ſint Ignis & Aer
Ambigitur: reliquis ſed leviora patent.

lg.l: Whether Fire and Air light bodies ſimply be?
'T is doubt, but lighter then the reſt we ſee.

argument.p: The four ſimple Qualities aſcribed one to ech Element in intenſ degree.

l.hi: Frigida cum calidis, cum ficcis humida certant:
His Elementa ſibi mutua bella cient.

lg.l: Cold ſtrives with heat, moiſt & dry ech with either,
Hence t'h Elements 'twixt themſelfs wage war together.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Oppoſiti humores Elementis quatuor inſunt
Intenſis gradibus, queis ſibi bella ferunt.

lg.l: Four advers qualities in th' Elements in here
Intenſly one, whence war with ech they bear.

argument.p: The 3 ſorts of choler in al perfect animals bodies, both of Men and Beaſts.

l.hi: Atra, Citroſa, triplex ſpecies & Praſſina in omni
Humaeno & Bruto corpore bilis ineſt.

lg.l: Three kinds of choler, yelow, black and green:
In bodies of al Men and Beaſts are ſeen.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Flava benigna ſatis Naturae: noxia nigra eſt:
Sed viridis longe peſſima damna trahit.

lg.l: Yelow is Naturs frend: Black noiſom ſtil:
But Green far greateſt harms doth oft inſtil.

argument.p: The 2 diſtinct motions aſcribed by many Moderniſts to the Earth.

l.hi:
Ad Centrum proprium Terrae pars quae
que deorſum
Tendit, & orbiculo volvitur ipſa ſuo.

lg.l: Th' Earths parts if ſever'd to her Center tend,
And the whol frame doth round in her orb trend.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Vertitur & vertetur in omne volubilis aevum
Terra Polis geminis, Axe librata ſuo,

lg.l: Th' Earth with rwo Pols pois'd by her Axel ever
Turns and ſhal ſtil turn: but ceaſ wheeling never,

argument.p: The 60 Climats or portions of the Earth between the North and South Poles.

l.hi: Sexaginta ſolo terreſtri Climata conſtant.
Queis Aquilo ac Auſter diſſecuere plagas.

lg.l: Sixty diſtinct Climes in th' Earth's globe reſide,
By which the North & South their Coaſts divide.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ʋltra Aequatorem Boreali parte triginta,

Tot
que ſub Auſtrali Climata parte jacent.

lg.l: Beyond th'Equator thirty Climes abide
Northward, and thirty mo on the South ſide.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Sexaginta pa • ent per totam climata terram
Diſſita temperie, tempore, luce, ſitu.

lg.l: Through the whol Earth ly threeſcore Climes in ſtation,
Diffring in temper, time, light, ſituation.

argument.p: The 2 ſorts of Earths Inhabiters, diſtinguiſhed by ſite and ſhadow.

l.hi: In varias claſſes homines per Climata & umbras
Qui terras habitant; diſtribuere Sophi.

lg.l: Artiſts have ſorted ſuch as on Earth dwel,
By ranks and files of Climes and ſhadows fel.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Quotquot ubi
que manent, quos Coeli circulus ambit.

Diſtinguit variis umbra ſituſ
que modis.

lg.l: Shadow and ſite doo diverſly divide
Such as inhabit on the Earth's ech ſide.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi:
Per
que ſitum terras qui coluere modis.

lg.l: The Earth's Inhabiters divers wais doo differ,
By ſhades and ſites, in al parts ech from either.

argument.p: The four chief parts of the World, which are moſt diſcovered to Navigators.

l.hi: Non niſi tres terrae per plurima ſecula Partes
Notae: at nuperius quarta reperta fuit.

lg.l: Three only parts of th'Earth were firſt renownd
For many ages, but a fourth later found.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Tres veteres partes, Europa, Aſia, Africa habentur
Mundi, ſed regio eſt Americana recens.

lg.l: Europ, Aſia, Affric were the firſt parts three
Of the old World: but America fourth may be.

argument.p: The 4 Ages of the World, aptly applied by Ovid to men waxing wors and wors.

l.hi: Aurea prima ſata eſt Aetas: Argentea ſurgit:
Aenea ſubſequitur: Ferrea deinde ſubit.

lg.l: The golden Age cam firſt: the ſilver roſe,
The braſen folows: th' iron maks the cloſe.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quatuor Aetates Homini in pejore ruenti
Applicat ingenio Naſo Poeta ſuo.

lg.l: Ovid the Poet four Ages doth apply
To men which ſtill wax wors, moſt wittily.

argument.p: The 4 Rivers of Eden Paradiſe: or rather one divided into divers heads.

l.hi: Flumina terreſtri Paradiſo quatuor extant,
Hiddekel, Euphrates, Piſhon, Gihon Inſula in Edē

lg.l: Four ſtreams in earthly Paradiſe of Eden
Spring: Tigris, Euphrates, Piſhon and Gihon.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Sunt Tigris, Euphrates, Paardiſi flumina: Piſhon
Et Gihon, ut ramos Inſula jactat Eden.

lg.l: Tigris, Euphrates, Piſhon, Gihon riſe
Neer Eden Iſle, the place of Paradiſe.

argument.p: The 2 Parents or Progenitors of Mankind, by name Adam and Eve.

lg.l: E terra humani eſt generis caput • rtus Adamus:

At
que ex oſſe viri tota creatur Eva.
Mankinds-head Adam was of earth compounded,
And of his bone Dame Eve was wholy founded.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Conditur ex limo genitor primaevus Adamus,
Ecoſta eus ejrat condita mater Eva.
Our firſt Sire Adam was of clay created,
Our Mother Eve was of his Rib conflated.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Primus Adam pater eſt factus de pulvere terrae,
Foemina ab oſſe viri prima creatur Eva.
Firſt Father Adam ſprung from d • ſt of th'earth:
And mother Eve from his bone had hir birth.

argument.p: The 3 Perſons that had a ſupernatural production, differing from al other.

lg.l: Primus in Orbe Pater ſine Patre creatus Adamus,
Et ſine matre fuit condita mater Eva.
Adam our Sire no fleſhly Father had:
And mother Eve was without mother made.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Abſ
que Parente Pater, Mater fine matre creatur:
Ex matre at verbum fit ſine Patre Caro.

lg.l: Our Sire no parent had, Mother no mother,
But Chriſt took fleſh of Mother without other.

l.hi: Sunt Anima & Corpus divina Lege creatae
Pracipuae partes, e quibus omnis homo est.

lg.l: Both Soul and Body by divine Decree,
Were form'd man's chief parts which build him, to be

argument.p: The 2 chief faculties of a rational Soul, viz. Mind or Intellect, and Wil.

l.hi:
Virtutes Animae duplices, mens at
que voluntas:
Quae reliquas ſuperant nobilitate ſua.

lg.l: Two Powers of Man's Soul (Mind and Wil) ther be,
Which far excel the reſt in Soveraignty.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Mens Homini propria eſt Animae vis, at
que voluntas.
Queis longo ſuperat ſingula Bruta gradu.

lg.l: Mans proper Powers of Soul, Mind, & Wil, are:
By which al ſorts of Beaſts he tranſcends far.

argument.p: The 9 ſimilar or homogeneal parts in the body of Men, and Beaſts.

l.hi: Sunt novem in humano ſimilares Corpore partes,
E quibus efficitur diſſimilare melos.

lg.l: Nine ſimilar parts Man's body beautify:
Of which is made the Organs harmony.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ter tres conſimiles Animalibus omnibus inſunt
Partes: Organicae conficiuntur ab his.

lg.l: Nine ſimple Parts in Animals al are found,
Which doo the Inſtrumental Parts compound.

argument.p: The 10 Ages of Man ſorted by 7 yeers to ech into ten ſeptenaries.

l.hi: Aetates Hominis, per ſeptem quaeſlibet annos
Antiqui Authores conſtituere decem.

lg.l: Ten Ages were of old to men aſcribed,
Wherof ech is by ten ſet yeers divided.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Aetatum decades Homini aſcribuntur amuſſim:
Quarum ex ſeptenis conflatur quaelibet annis.

lg.l: Sev'n Decads and ten ſevennets of yeers
In the ſ • t Ages of Mans life appeers.

argument.p: The 3 interior or inward Senſes in Men, & al perfect living creatures.

l.hi: Tres Homini Senſus reſident, dicti interiores,

In Cerebro: totidem Bruta
que participant.

lg.l: Three inward Senſes in Man's brain reſide:
To Beaſts likwiſe no fewer doo betide.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
In Cerebro poſitos perfecta Animalia quae
que

Internos Senſus tres, Homineſ
que tenent.

lg.l: Three inward Senſes ſited in the Brain
T'al perfect Animals, and to Men pertain.

argument.p: The 5 external or outward Senſes, belonging to al complet living Creatures.

l.hi: Olfactus cum Guſtu, Auditus, Viſio, Tactus,
Quinque extra Senſus Animalibus omnibus inſunt:

lg.l: Hearing, Sight, Smel, Taſt, Touch, fiv external
Senſes to perfect Animals al befal.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Hi Senſus ſi non plures Animalibus inſunt:

Nomina ſunt quorum nota cui
que ſatis.

lg.l: Theſ Senſes if not mo are in Animals ſited:
Whoſ names to al wel known are not recited.

argument.p: The 4 duple Organs of ſeveral ſenſes (Hearing, Sight, Smel, Touch) one like another.

l.hi: Auditus Aures, Viſus oculi Organa, Nares
Olfactus, Tactus (ſingula bina) manus.

lg.l: Ears Organs be of hearing, Eys of ſeeing.
Noſtrils of ſmelling, Hands (al Twins) of feeling.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Organa bina itidem Gustus, Lingua at
que Palatum:
Sunt autem inter ſe diſſita membra duo.

lg.l: Two Organs too (Palat and Toung) of Taſt be:
But they two diſtinct members diſagree.

argument.p: The two firſt born ſons of our protoparents mentioned by Moſes, Cain & Abel.

lg.l: Invidus innocuum fratrem Cain mactat Abelem:

l.hi: Quod magis ejus erat victima grata Deo.

lg.l: Through envy Cain ſlu Abel his juſt brother.
'Cauſ God prefer'd his Offring to the other.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Impius enocuit Frater ſine crimine Fratrem,
Quod mage grata Deo victima Fratris erat:

lg.l: A wicked brother his harmleſs brother ſlai'd,
'Cauſ God his brothers offring beſt effai'd.

div.head: EPIG. XLVIII. Sancti in Coelos tranſlati.

argument.p: The 2 holy men (one before the Flood another after) tranſlated bodily into Heaven.

lg.l: In ſuperas aedes rapiuntur Enochus, Elias,

l.hi:
Cum
que , Deo vivunt gratus uter
que , Deo.

lg.l: Enoch and Elias were to Heav'n removed,
And liv with God, being both of God beloved.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: In Coelos tranſlatus Enoch, tranſvectus Elias

l.hi:
Ignito curru eſt: charus uter
que , Deo.

lg.l: Enoch was rais'd to Heav'n, Elias mounted
In firy Car: both dear to God accounted.

div.head: EPIG. XLIX. Perſonae in Arca ſervati.

argument.p: The 8 Perſons, or 4 couples of mankind preſerved in Noah's Arc from periſhing.

l.hi: Diluvium generale Noae, genus obruit omne
Humanum in terris: octo ſuperſtitibus.

lg.l: Noah's great Flood of at Mankind left none
Aliv on Earth, eight perſons ſav'd alone.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Diluvio dominante Noah, nati
que , fuerunt

l.hi: Tres ſervati Arca, ſponſis cum quatuor una.

lg.l: When the Flood fell, Noah and his ſons three,
With their four wifs in th'Arc preſerved be.

argument.p: The 10 Protopatriarchs of the old World, in Chriſts lineal Genealogy.

l.hi: Sunt his quinque Patres, qui Chriſti progenitores

lg.l: Diluvium praeiere Nohae, recto ordine creti.
Ten Fathers Chriſts Progenitors they ſtood
In right line of deſcent, before the Flood.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
In Chriſti geneallogia bis quin
que , beati
Diluvium anteiere Patres: queis nomina ſubſunt.

lg.l: Ten bleſſed Patriarchs in Chriſts Pedegree,
Forewent the Flood, whoſe names ſet under be.
Adam, Seth, Enos, Cainan, Mahalaleel, pro Jared Ired,
Enoch, Methuſelah, Lamech, Noah ordine primo.
Theſ hebrew names doo il agree
Int' engliſh meter turn'd to be.

argument.p: The 10 Poſt-Patriarchs in the ſame line of Chriſt, next after Noah's Flood.

l.hi:
SSunt bis quin
que Patres ab eodem ſtemmate nati:
Qui poſt Diluvium per ſaecula multa vigebant.

lg.l: Ten Fathers mo from the ſame ſtock extracted,
Who ſundry ages after th' Flood peracted.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Sem, Arphaxad, Salah, dein Heber, poſtmodo Peleg,
Reu, Sarug, Nachor, Terah, Abram claſſe ſecunda.
Such proper names here found,
Tranſlated make harſh ſound.

argument.p: The 3 ſons of Noah that repeopled the Earth, after the univerſal Deluge.

lg.l: Japhetus, Sem, Cham, numeroſa prole replebant

l.hi: Orbem, Diluvium poſt generale novum.

lg.l: Japhet, Sem, Cham, the new world ſoon increaſed
With their large Iſſues, when the Deluge ceaſed.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Terras Japhetus, Sem, Cham, cum Patre replebant

l.hi: Diluvium ſobole, poſt generale ſua.

lg.l: Japhet, Sem, Cham, fil'd th' earth with their old Sire,
By their large ofspring, when Flood did expire.

argument.p: The 2 firſt Kings in the World after the general inundation of the Earth.

lg.l: Primus in Aſſyria Nimrod regnū extruit: & Cham,

l.hi: Proximus Aegypti Rex fuit, ejus avus.

lg.l: Mimrod in Aſſur the firſt Kingdom reared:
Next Cham his Grandſire Aegypts King appeared.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Jactat in Aſſyriae regno ſe Nimrod, & ejos

l.hi: Aegypti Imperium conſtituebat avus.

lg.l: Nimrod as King himſelf in Aſſyria bore,
And Aegypts royal Crown his Grandſire wore.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi:
Aſſyria, Aegyptuſ
que duos ſibi vendicat olim
Diluvio exacto quod perdidit omnia, Reges.

lg.l: Aſſur and Aegypt of old claim two firſt Kings,
When the Flood cea • 'd, which had deſtroy'd al things

argument.p: The 5 Canaanit Kings, which darraind battle with 4 Forreners in Siddim Valley.

l.hi:
In Canaan quin
que ingeniti cum quatuor extra
Regibus oppoſitis, bella-tulere Duces.

lg.l: Fiv nativ Kings in Canaan waged war
With four of forren lands, that cam from far.

lg.head: Alias

l.hi:
Bella gerunt Reges Cananitae quin
que minores
Cum reliquis peragrè qui coiere, procis.

lg.l: Fiv petty Canaanit Kings Battle conjoin'd
With forren Rivals four, who their ſtrengths join'd,

argument.p: The 2 Seals of Gods Covenant in the old Teſtament, & 2 Sacraments in the new.

l.hi: Foederis ut veteris duo ſunt ſub lege ſigilla,
Sic ſub Evangelio Symbola bina patent.

lg.l: Under the Law two Cov'nant Seals God gav,
Under the Goſpel two Sacraments we hav.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Circumciſa caro cum Paſchate bina Sigilla:
Baptiſma & Domini Coena fuere ſacra.

lg.l: The foreskin cut, and Paſchal two Seals were:
Baptiſm, Lords Supper, Sacraments name did bear.

argument.p: The 2 firſt ſons of Abraham by the bond woman Hagar, and his wife Sarai.

lg.l: Ex Famula & ſponſa geminos Abrahamus habebat

l.hi: Natos; praeter eos, poſtea quos genuit.

lg.l: Abraham had two ſons by's maid and wife rendred,
Beſide ſom mo, which after he ingendred.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Iſmael è Famula genitus derifit Iſachum,

l.hi: Qui promiſſi haeres a Patre factus erat.

lg.l: Iſamel the bondmaids ſon Iſaac derided,
Whom to the Promiſſ his Sire Heir deſigned.

argument.p: The 2 ſons of Iſaac being twin-Brothers, who ſtrov together in the womb.

lg.l: Filiolos Iſaac ſimul ex uxore Rebecca

l.hi: Progenuit geminos, qui viguere diu:

lg.l: Iſaac by's wife Rebecca two ſons 'gendred
Together born, who long after floriſhed.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Sunt gemini fratres nati, Jacobus & Eſau:

l.hi: Hic Domino exoſus, charus at ille fuit.

lg.l: Jacob and Eſau two Brothers born together,
This hated was of God, that lov'd for ever.

argument.p: The 12 ſons of Jacob (cald Iſrael's leſſer Patriarchs) ſet in ſeniority of birth.

lg.l: Bis ſex Jacobo (Patriarchae nomine) nati

Per varias ſponſas • amulaſ
que apud Iſrael orti.
Jacob twelv ſons on ſundry women got
(Cald Iſrael's Patriarchs) which was his blot.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Jacobus his ſex (Patriarchas nomine dictos)

l.hi: Filiolos genuit diverſis matribus ortos.

lg.l: Jacob's twelv ſons (cald Patriarchs by name)
Begot, which from their ſeveral mothers came.
Reubenus, Simeon, Levi, Juda, Zebulon, pro Iſſachar. Iſſchar,
Dan, Gad, Aſher, Nephtal, Joſephus, Benjamin imus.
'Tis hard theſ Names to couch in Latin vers,
Much more in engliſh metre to rehers.

argument.p: The 2 differing interpretations of Jacob's Prediction touching the Meſſias.

lg.l:
Non Sceptrum a Juda, ne
que Legiſlator abibit.
Iſrael ait, donec venerit ipſe Shiloh.
Nor Sceperr, nor Law-giver ſhal reced
From Juda ſaid Jacob, til Shiloh ſucced.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: De Chriſti adventu loquitur Patriarcha Jacobus,

l.hi: Quod varii variis expoſuere modis.

lg.l: Jacob of Chriſts coming did fore propheſy:
Which divers men expounded variouſly.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ʋltima Jacobi eſt bene nota Prophetia: verum,

l.hi: Theiologi variant, quid ſibi verba velint.

lg.l: Jacob's laſt Prophecie's known, but Divines vary
What ſens or meaning ſom words therin cary.

argument.p: The 2 dreams of Joſeph in Canaan, before he was ſold by his brethren into Aegypt.

lg.l: Somnia concepit conformia bina Joſephus, A. M. 2277.
Antequam in Aegyptum venditus ille fuit.
Joſeph conceiv'd two dreams like ech to others,
Ye • he was ſold int' Aegypt by his brothers.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Somnia bina habuit Joſephus: quae ſibi Fratres

l.hi: Affore ſubjectos explicuere ſuos.

lg.l: Joſeph had two like dreams: which did portend
That al his Brethren t' him ſhould bow and bend.

argument.p: The 2 Officers (Pharaohs Butler & Baker) their dreams in Priſon with Joſeph.

lg.l:
Pincerna & Piſtor referunt ſua quae
que
Joſepho,

l.hi: Omine hic infauſto, ſomnia, at ille bono.

lg.l: Butler and Baker dreams to Joſeph told.
Which good luck t'one, bad did to th' laſt unfold.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Somniat in vinclis Promus Piſtor
que : Joſephus

l.hi:
Diſpare fata modo narrat utri
que ſua.

lg.l: The Butler bound in chains and Baker dreamed:
Joſeph to both their unlike fates reveled.

div.head: EPIG. LXII. Pharaonis vaccae in ſomno.

argument.p: The 7 fat and 7 lean kine of which Pharaoh Orus dreamed and Joſeph expounded.

lg.l: Aegypti Regi ſeptem inter ſomnia vaccae

l.hi:
Praepingues viſae ſunt totidem
que macrae.

lg.l: To Pharaoh ſev'n fat kine in dream appeered,
And ſev'n il favord lean thoſ fat caſheered.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Septenas Pharaoh vaccas aſpexit opimas

l.hi: Et totidem tenues, queis eſca fuere priores:

lg.l: Pharaoh ſev'n goodly fat kine ſeem'd to ſee,
And ſev'n lean, which made thoſ their food to be.

argument.p: The 7 ful ears of Corn & 7 ſtarved, which Pharaoh dreamed, and Joſeph interpreted.

l.hi: Idem iterum in ſomno ſeptem Rex vidit ariſtas

Perpulchras, tritico expertes, totidem
que vietas.

lg.l: The ſame King ſaw in ſleep ſev'n goodly ears
Of Corn, and ſev'n ſtarv'd which no good wheat bears.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Rex ſeptem gravidas (ſolidi ſub imagine ſomni)
Et totidem graciles fine pondere cernit ariſtas.

lg.l: Pharaoh ſev'n brav ful ears in ſleep beheld,
And ſev'n without weight witherd, dry, and queld.

argument.p: The 2 cruel Kings of Egypt which afflicted the Iſraelits after Joſeph's deceaſ.

lg.l: Obruit amne mares Nili Buſiris Hebraeos:

l.hi: At Cenchres rubro eſt obrutus ipſe mari.

lg.l: Buſiris drownd the Hebrew males in Nile
But Cenchres drench'd was in the red Sea wile.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Deſtruit Hebraos pueros Buſiris in amne:

l.hi: At Cenchres mediis ipſe ſepultus aquis.

lg.l: Buſiris th' Hebrew babes in the Flood drowned:
But Cenchres was 'midſt the Sea wav's confounded

argument.p: The 2 Brothers that brought Iſrael out of bondage, and made them a Nation.

lg.l: Par Fratrum Hebraeos, Moſes conflavit & Aaron
In Gentem validam Aegypti feritate ſolutos.
Moſes and Aaron ſet the Hebrews free
From Aegypts Yoke, one Nation ſtrong to be.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Germani fratres gemini, Moſaeus & Aaron,
Servitio exolvunt miſeros Aegyptico Hebraeos.
Two Brothers, Moſes and Aaron by name,
From Egypt 's thral the Hebrews freed with fame.

argument.p: The 10 Plagues inflicted by God on Egypt, for afflicting his people Iſrael.

l.hi: Sanguis, Rana, Snipes, muſcae, peſtis pecorum, Anthrax
Grande Locuſta, Caligo, & mors Primogenitorum

lg.l: Blood-waters, frogs, goats, flies, beaſts-murrain, blain,
Hail, locuſts, darknes: and the firſt-born ſlain.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sanguis, Rana, Culex, muſcae, pecus, ulcera, grando,
Vermiculae, tenebrae, ſtrages Primogenitorum.

lg.l: Blood, frogs, gnats, flies, murrain of beaſts, biles, hail,
Worms, darknes, firſt borns death did Egypt quail.

argument.p: The 12 Tribes or Septs of Iſrael, iſſued from Jacobs ſons or Grand-ſons, whoſ names they bear.

lg.l: Sex gemini viguere Tribus ex Iſrael ortae

l.hi: Quae Fundatorum aſſumunt ſibi nomina nota.

lg.l: Twelv Tribes ther were from Jacobs loins extracted
Wch from their founders wel known names contracted

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Reubenus, Simeon, Juda, Zebulon, Iſſachar & Dan,

Gad, Aſher, Nephtal, Benijn pro Benjamin., Ephraim at
que Manaſſe,
Such hard names make harſh harmony
In Latin or Engliſh Symmetry.

argument.p: The 10 Commandements or Decalog of the Moral Law in general.

lg.l: HƲmano generi Deus offert Moſe Miniſtro,

l.hi: Moralis legis verba ſacrata decem.

lg.l: God ſpake ten ſacred words of Law moral,
By Moſes to mankind in general.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Praecepta Humano generi bis quin
que
Jehovah,

l.hi: Conſona naturae legibus ipſe dedit.

lg.l: God to mankind ten Precepts did command,
Conform to Natures Law, by Moſes hand.

argument.p: The 10 Commandements divaricated into particular Precepts in du order.

l.hi: Me ſolum venerare Deum: fuge Numina ſculpta:
Ne jura incaſſum: reminiſcere Sabbata ſerves:

Tu reverere Patrem, Matrem
que : Occidere noli:

Ne ſis Maechator; ne
que Fur: ne
que Teſtis iniquus:
Ne cupias aedes nec quae bona poſſidet alter.

lg.l: Worſhip no Gods but me: carv'd Idols fly:
Swear not in vain: the Sabbath ſanctify;
Honor thy Parents: kil none wilfully:
No lecher: nor theef: nor falſ witnes be.
Wiſh not thy neighbors hous nor goods to thee.

argument.p: The 2 Precepts of Chriſt, compriſing a compend. or ſum and ſubſtance of the ſaid Decalog.

l.hi: Chriſtus Diſcipulis duo dat ſolummodo juſſa:

Dilige corde Deum toto; Fratrem
que velut te.

lg.l: Chriſt gav his folowers two ſole Law's kept to be:
Lov God with al thy Soul, and Neighbor lik to thee.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quae juſſa ut melius ſervent, haec verba locutus:
Hoc fac & vives: brevis eſt data regula talis

lg.l: Then that they might, a ſhort rule he did giv, Luk. 10. 27.
The better keep't, Doo this and thou ſhalt liv.

argument.p: The Lawes of Nature (a Negativ and Poſitiv) cōmended or cōmanded by Chriſt.

l.hi: Cordibus humanis inſcultae ab origine Leges,
Numine Divino flante fuere duae.

lg.l: Natures two Laws from the beginning framed,
Were by God's Spirit into mens hearts ingraved.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quod tibi non velles fleri, ne feceris ulli:
Fac aliis, fieri quod cupis ipſe tibi.

lg.l: Doo not t'others, what thou wouldſt not men doo
To thee: but doo as thou wouldſt be don to.

div.head: EPIG. LXXII. Duces ſeu Ductores Iſraelis.

argument.p: The 2 chief Captains or Conductors of the Iſraelits into the land of Canaan.

lg.l: Jacobi ex ſobole multa inter millia tantum
In terram Canaan introire duo.
'Mongſt many thouſands of Jacobs Progeny
Two into Canaan land did enter only.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Joſua promiſſam terram introit at
que
Calebus,

l.hi: At reliquos ſterili condit Eremus humo.

lg.l: Joſua and Caleb entred the promiſs'd Land.
The reſt ly buried in dry Deſans Sand.

argument.p: The 2 moſt famous and fortunat Judges of Iſrael for martial matters.

lg.l: Quaeſtores varios habuit Judaea ſupermos:

l.hi: Aſt inter reliquos, eminuere duo.

lg.l: In Iſrael ſundry Judges bore chief ſway:
But 'mongſt the reſt two got the prize away.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Magnanimus Gideon, praecellens robore Samſon

l.hi: Hoſtibus externis plurima damna ferunt.

lg.l: Stout Gideon, and ſtrong Samſon many harms
Wrought to their forren Foes by force of arms.

argument.p: The 2 raſh Fathers, which made vain vows to ſacrifice the firſt they met after victory.

l.hi:
Hiſtoria ſacra memorantur item
que prophana
Patros, qui temerè vota tulere, duo.

lg.l: Inſacred ſtory, and profane are named
Two haſty Fathers, which vows raſhly framed.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Jephta ſuam temere vovet igni offerre puellam:

l.hi:
Atrideſ
que ſuam ſacrificare vovet.

lg.l: Jephta vows raſhly t'offer up his daughter:
King Agamemnon made the ſame vow after.

argument.p: The 2 firſt Kings or Monarchs, that ruled over the 12 Tribes of Iſrael.

lg.l: Rex fuit immitis Saul primus in Iſrael unctus:
Proximus at David, ſic ſtatuente Deo.
Fierce Saul firſt King in Iſrael annointed:
But David was the next, as God appointed.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Iſrael a Domino Regem Petit: unde Propheta
Saulem & Davidem juſſus inunxit ibi.
Iſrael crav'd a King: whence Samuel annointed
Firſt Saul, next David ther, as God appointed.

argument.p: The 2 corrival Kings, which diſſevered Iſraels 12 Tribes into two Kingdoms.

lg.l: Sub Salomone Tribus omnes coiere fideles:

l.hi: Poſtea ſed Natum deſtituere decem.

lg.l: To Salomon al the Tribes faithful adhered:
But after, ten of twelv his ſon caſhiered.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Excutiit bis quin
que Tribus feritate Roboam:
Quas Jeroboamus comparat arte ſagax.
Rehoboam loſt rwelv Tribes with cruelty:
Which wiſe Jeroboam won by ſubtlety.

argument.p: The 4 greater (Iſaiah, Jeremy, Ezekiel, Daniel) & 12 leſſer Prophets in the O. T.

l.hi:
Bis duo majores Vates, bis ſex
que minores:
Ordine quos proprio Biblia ſacra locant.

lg.l: Four greater Prophets, and twelv leſſer be:
Which holy Bible ſets in du degree.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Iſaiah, Jeremi, Ezechiel, Daniel
que
Prophetae

l.hi:
Majores: minimi ſex duo ſunt
que ſacri.

lg.l: Four great Prophets, Iſai, Jeremy, cal'd by name
Ezekiel, Daniel: and twelv of leſs fame.

argument.p: The 4 Beaſts with mens faces preſented to Ezek. 1. 5. 6. 8. Ezechiel in viſion neer Chebar River.

lg.l: Quatuor Ezechiel vidiſſe Animalia forma
Humana, ad Chebar flumina viſus erat.
Ezechiel ſeemd four living things to ſee
In face like men, neer Chebar ſtreams to be.

l.hi: Quatuor omne habuit facies & quatuor alas:

Sub
que alis geminae de lituere manus.

lg.l: Ech had four faces, and four wings combined:
And under their wide wings two hands intwined.

argument.p: The 2 dreams of Nebuchadnezar had in bed, being interpreted by Daniel.

lg.l: Viſa Icon Regi Babylonis maxima ſomno eſt,

l.hi: Corpore cui cocunt multa metalla ſimul.
Regi itidem viſa eſt in ſomnis Arbor eidem,
Cujus apex Coelos attigit ampla ſatis.

lg.l: Nebuchadnezar of a great Image dreamed,
Whoſ Body was of many metals framed.
That King in's ſleep a great Tree ſeem'd to ſee:
Whoſ top touch'd Heav'n; ſo huge it ſeem'd to be.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Apparet variis Icon compacta metallis

lg.l: Somnia dum ſomno Rex Babylonis habet.

l.hi: Viſa etiam, ſummos tetigit quae culmina Coelos,

Quae
que patet terris omnibus, Arbor erat.

lg.l: While Babels King, had dreams, in ſleep appeared
An Image huge of many metals reared.
A Tree eke ſeem'd, whoſ heighr reach'd Heavens high,
And whoſ fight open t' al the Earth did ly.

argument.p: The 4 ſtrange Beaſts which appeared to Daniel in a dream, or by divine viſion.

l.hi: Quatuor horribiles, celebris per ſomnia vates

lg.l: Viſus erat Daniel cernere nocte feras.
The Prophet Daniel dreamd he ſaw by night,
Four hideous Beaſts, whoſ view did him affright.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Bellua prima Leo eſt, Urſa altera; ſed Leopardus

Tertia: deformis quarta vorax
que magis.

lg.l: Lion firſt Beaſt was, next Bear, but Leopard
A third, the fourth for al the reſt too hard.

argument.p: The 2 Beaſts a Ram and Goat purporting Darius and Alexander, preſented to Daniel in a Viſion.

lg.l: In ſomnis Aries Danieli eſt viſus, & Hircus:

l.hi:
Illius hie frangit cornua, eum
que fugat.

lg.l: A Ram and Goat in Daniels ſleep appeared:
The Goat the Rams horns broke and him caſhiered.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Hircus Alexandrum praefert, Arieſ
que
Darium:

l.hi: Extitit hic Victor, victus at ille fuit.

lg.l: The Goat Alexander, Darius Ram prefigured:
The firſt was Victor but the laſt ſubjected.

argument.p: The 3 Jews miraculouſly freed from the firy fornace at Babylon.

l.hi: Tres vincti igni vomo juvenes fornace ſuperſunt:
Nec potuit veſtes urere flamma ſuas.

lg.l: Three youths faſt bound in firy fornace caſt
Eſcap'd, nor were their cloths burnt with flames blaſt

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Percolere auroſam Shadrach, Abednego, Meſech,

l.hi: Detrectant ſtatuam, pro pietate ſua.

lg.l: Shadrach, Abednego, Meſhach for piety,
The golden Image refus'd to Deify.

argument.p: The 70 yeers of the Jews or Iſraelits grand captivity under 3 Kings of Babylon.

l.hi: Judaei expoſiti ſunt ſeptuaginta per annos,

lg.l: Epatria extorres in Babylone ſolo.
The Jews brought from their Country, ſeventy yeers
Were captivs held in Babylon, as appeers.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Aſſyriae Reges captos tenuere Judaeos,

lg.l: Quos tandem vinclis liberat ipſe Cyrus,
Th' Aſſyrian Kings captivs the Jews compriſed;
Whom Cyrus from their bonds at length remiſed.

argument.p: The 72 Interpreters (ſtiled ſeptuagints) which tranſlated the O. T. into greek.

l.hi: Olim ex Haebreo vertêre idiomate Graece
Septuaginta duo Biblia ſacra viri.

lg.l: From Hebrew, Greek, by ſeventy two tranſlated
Th'holy Bible; as 'tis for truth related.
Ʋt Teſtamenti veteris Philadelphus haberet

l.hi: Biblia, conduxit ſeptuaginta Sophos.

lg.l: Ptolomeet' hav the books of the old Teſtament
Greecly transferd, for ſevnty learnd men ſent.

argument.p: The 5 valiant Brethren caled Machabees) ſons to Mathias Aſmoneus.

l.hi:
Fratres quin
que Syris ſeſe oppoſuere Tyrannis,
Pro patria cupidi Reeligione mori.

lg.l: Fiv brothers bold the Syrian Kings withſtood,
Glad for their Countries Laws to ſpend their blood.
Prae pietate, diu Judas Machabaeus, & ejus
Fratres, cum Syriis bella tulere lupis.
Through meer zeal Judas Machabee, and his bold
Brethren, with Syrian Wolfs wars long did hold.

argument.p: The 7 ſons of a zealous Jewiſs, moſt truculently butchered with their mother.

lg.l: Dūm furit Antiochus, Mater pia reſtitit irae

l.hi: Cum ſeptem natis qui periere ſimul.

lg.l: A zealous Mother with ſevn ſons oppoſed
Antiochus rage: who were to death expoſed.

argument.p: The 3 wiſemen that cam from Arabia, or rather Perſia, to worſhip Chriſt.

l.hi: TRanſierant magi tres ex oriente remoto:
Qui Chriſto in ſtabulo munera magna ferunt.

lg.l: Three wiſe men cam from th'Eaſt far disſited:
Who to Chriſt in the Cratch great gifts offred.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Aurum, Thus, Myrrham, magi ex oriente profecti
Tres Chriſto in cunis exhibuere pii.

lg.l: Three Eaſtern Wiſemen offred with zealous hands,
Gold, Incenſe, Myrrhe, to Chriſt in's ſwathing bands.

argument.p: The 3 Herods of one name, who were Kings or ſoveraign Tetrarchs in Paleſtine.

lg.l: Enecuit magnus Pueros: Tetrarcha Johannem:
Rex Jacobum Herodes: Petrumo, in carcere clauſit.
Great Herod th' Infants ſlu: the Tetrarch John:
King Herod James: and Peter put in Priſon.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Primus erat verus Rex, ſed Tetrarcha ſecundus:

lg.l: Rex etiam extremus, ſed falſo Agrippa vocatus.
The firſt was tru King, but next Tetrarch clyped:
The laſt King too, but falſly Agrippa ſtiled.

argument.p: The 12 inſpired Apoſtles, who were called by Chriſt to preach & propagat the Goſpel

lg.l: Petrus Apoſtolici Princeps gregis: ambo Jacobi:
Andraeas, Thomas, Matthaeus, Bartholomaeus:

Judas, Matthias, Philipus, Simon, at
que
Joannes:

l.hi: Diſcipulorum haec ſunt ſummorum nomina bis ſex.

lg.l: Peter Apoſtle chief: two James of one
Name: Andrew Thomas, Bartholmew, Simon:
Matthew, Matthias, Jude, Philip, and St. John:
Theſ of twelv chief Diſciples names are known.

argument.p: The 72 Diſciples of inferior degree, whom Chriſt ſent from City to City.

l.hi: Praeter Apoſtolicos, fibi ſeptuaginta minores
Chriſtus Diſcipulos eligit ipſe viros.

lg.l: Beſid th'Apoſtles Chriſt himſelf aſſigned
Sevnty Diſciples of leſs rank eſteemed.

argument.p: The 4 Evangeliſts, who wrot Chriſts life, words, works, and manifold miracles.

l.hi: Bis duo Evangelium Chriſti retulere per Orbem,

Diſcipuli calamis, geſta
que mira ſuis.

lg.l: Twiſe two Diſciples through th'world with their pen
Chriſts Gospel ſpred, and wondrous gifts to men,

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Bis duo Evangelii Scriptorum nomina conſtant:

lg.l:
Mattheus, Marcus, Lucas, divuſ
que
Joannes.
The four Evangeliſts names are t'al wel known:
Saint Mathew, Mark, Luke and beloved John.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Matthaeus ſpeciem humanam, Marcuſ
que
Leonem.

Sed Vitulum retulit Lucas, Aquilam
que
Joannes.
Matthew a Man, a Lion Marc preſented,
But Luke a Calf, an Eagle John reſembled.

argument.p: The 2 different eſtats of a rich glutton unnamed, and a begger cald Lazarus.

lg.l: Dives in hoc mundo laute, nunc luget in orco:
Lazarus hic miſere vixit, num gaudet Olympo
Dives far'd fully here, now wails in Hel:
Lazarus liv'd poor here, now in Heav'n doth dwel.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Divitis Hiſtoria haec cum paupere recta videtur:

l.hi: Chriſtus enim tales eminuiſſe refert.

lg.l: This ſtory of Dives and Lazarus ſeems right:
For Chriſt ſaith ſuch there were in the ſame plight.

argument.p: The 2 Parabol men that went up into the Temple to pray, a Phariſe & Publican.

l.hi: Bini Templa petunt: Phariſaeru lumina jactat,
Aſt alter vultu ſupplice ſpectat humum.

lg.l: Two in the Temple praid: a Phariſe proud,
And humble Publican whoſ heart ſpake loud.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Non haec Hiſtoria eſt, ſed rite Parabola dicta:
Dogmata ſic Chriſtus ſeria ſaepe dedit.

lg.l: This is no ſtory but meer Parabol caled:
So Chriſt his ſacred Doctrins oft declared.

argument.p: The 3 laſt Suppers (termed Tricoenium) which Chriſt made the night before his Crucifixion.

l.hi: Tres cum Diſcipulis coenas celebravit eadem
Nocte prius Chriſtus, quàm crucifixus erat.

lg.l: Chriſt with 's Apoſtles three ſet ſuppers held,
That night before he on the Croſs was queld.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Paſcha fuit primo, communis Coena ſecundò,
Poſtremò Domini Coena vocata fuit.

lg.l: The Paſchal firſt, the Common next ſucceded,
Laſt that which the Lords Supper ſtil is cleped.

argument.p: The 2 moſt unjuſt wicked Judges, which condemned and contemned our Saviour.

lg.l:
Mutuo conveniunt Herodes at
que
Pilatus,

l.hi:
Ʋt Chriſtum Dominum morte probro
que premant.

lg.l: Herod and Pilat jointly did accord
With ſhame and death to chaſtiſe Chriſt our Lord.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Herodes probris recipit, vinctum
que remittit:
Opprimit at rigida morte Pilatus eum.
Herod him baſely mock'd, and ſent back bound:
But Pilat did with cruel death confound.

argument.p: The 4 devout women caled Maries, which were moſt obſequious to our Saviour.

l.hi: Quatuor in Chriſtum vera pietate refertae

lg.l: Aſtabant M • riae; dum crucifixus erat.
Four Maries with tru lov to Chriſt indued,
Stood weeping by, when his blood was imbrued:

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Prima fuit mater, Cleopae uxor proxima, deinde
Peccatrix, Salome Zebedae ſponſa Maria.
His Mother fi • ſt, Cleopas next, Maudlin alſo,
Fourth Salome Zebedees wife cal'd Mary too.

argument.p: The 2 Jews of eminent mark, who ſtood beſt affected to be Chriſts Diſciples.

lg.l:
Chriſti Diſcipuli Nicodemus; iter
que
Joſephus

Ex Arimathea: ſanctus uter
que fuit.
Two holy men Nicodem and Joſeph were
Of Arimathea; who Chriſt did lov and f • ar

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Fumere pro Chriſti Nicodemus aromata confert:
Joſephus tumulum comparat ipſe novum.
Nicodem brought ſpices for Chriſts funeral,
Joſeph a new Tomb gav for burial.

argument.p: The 2 firſt Founders of Epiſcopal function, As the Antients aver.

lg.l: Primus Epiſcopifex Paulus fuit, inde Joannes:

l.hi: Ordine tunc alii: ſic cecinere Patres.

lg.l: Paul Founder was, next John of Prelacy;
Whom others folowed: ſo the Fathers cry.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Pontifices Paulus primo ordinat, at
que
Joannes:

l.hi: Inter Apoſtolicos qui valuere viros.

lg.l: Saint Paul and ſaint John Prelats firſt ordained:
Whoſ patern 'mongſt Apoſtolic men prevailed.

argument.p: The 4 laſt things which betide to al mortals at parting out of this frail life.

l.hi: Mortem Judicium ſequitur, tunc gaudia Coeli
Vel dolor inferni, tempus in omne manent.

lg.l: Death, Judgment, Hea'vn or Hel befal at laſt
Not to be ſhun'd: therfore repent in haſt.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Mors primo, mox judicium, tunc gaudia Coeli,

Vel tormenta Erebi certa cui
que cadunt.

lg.l: Firſt Death, next Judgment, then Heav'ns jois to al,
Or pains of Hel moſt certainly befal.

argument.p: The 2 final Manſions for mens Souls after death, both of good and bad.

l.hi:
Electos, Reproboſ
que manent poſt fata ſuprema.

Coelum at
que Infernus: nec locus alter erit.

lg.l: Two manſions after death reſt, Heav'n and Hel.
(No third place left) wher ſheep and Goats ſtil dwel.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Arbor uti recidit, jacet: atqui poſtmodo fruſtra
Peccati venia eſt expetienda tibi.

lg.l: As the Tree fals it lies: but after in vain
Men Pardon ſeek for ſin or eaſ of pain.

lg.head: Poſtſcript.

l.hi: Pars prima haec celebrat centum ſublimia gesta:
Quae methodo Hiſtorica Biblia ſacra tenent.

lg.l: This firſt part of high Acts brings a Century:
Which holy Writ holds forth by way of Story.

lg.head: Another.

l.hi: Cautè haud illicitum praeponere ſacra prophanis:
Verum ſedulitas eſt adhibenda magis.

lg.l: Men may with heed ſet ſacred things before
Profane: But diligence muſt be us'd the more.

div.head: Hiſtorical Eſſays. The ſecund Claſsis or Century of Hiſtoricals, under fiv branches.

argument.p: The 3 general kinds of Polity, or Civil Government in the World.

l.hi: PRima Monarchia eſt: Procerum vis: Democratia.
E tribus his Regimen conſtat in Orbe triplex.

lg.l: Firſt Monarchy: Peers rule: and Democraty:
On theſ three ſtands the Worlds trine P • lity.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Jus Regum Politia bona eſt, Procerum
que poteſtas
Pejor: ſed populi peſſima forma furor.

lg.l: Kings rule is good, wors the Peers optimacy:
But Peoples fury worſt, cal'd Democraty.

argument.p: The 4 firſt great Monarchies ſucceding one another, before Chriſts coming.

l.hi: Anteaquam in terras Chriſtus deſcenderat, olim
Regna inter Gentes quatuor Orbis erant.

lg.l: Before Chriſt cam into the Earth, of old
Four mighty Monarchies in the World were told.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Imperium Aſſyriae primum: quod Perſia fudit:

Subdidit hoc Macedo: Rom •
que cuncta premit.
Aſſur firſt Reignd: Perſia next inſued:
This Macedon won, and Rome them al ſubdued.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Aſſyrios Perſae, Perſas vicere Pelaſgi:
Subdita Romano corpora Graja jugo.
Perfics Aſſyria got, Greecs Perſia queld:
And Greecs Romes yoke on ſturdy necks did weld.

argument.p: The 2 firſt Kings of Aegypt after Cham, of whom it was caled Chamia, or the land of Ham.

lg.l: Regnum Aegyptiacum poſt Chamum, Oſiris & Orus

l.hi: Subditione ſua detinuere diu.

lg.l: Oſiris after Cham, and Orus reigned,
Who Aegypts Realm long in their pow'r retained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Mizraim erat Chami natus vocitatus Oſiris:

Cujus ſucceſſor filius Orus erat.
A. M. 2277.
Mizraim was ſon to Cham, Oſiris named:
Whoſ ſon cald Orus did ſucced much famed.

argument.p: The 2 moſt miſerable Mamaluk Sultans, 1501. 1516. which reigned laſt in Aegypt.

lg.l:
Morte Tomombeius Campſon
que
obiere cruenta,
Aegypti Imperium qui tenuere ferax.
Campſon and Tomombey in war deceaſed,
Who Aegypts fertil Realm or Land poſſeſſed.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Sceptra
• omombeius, Gauruſ
que Aegyptica geſtant:
A Selymo victi qui cecidere truci.
Gaurus and Tomombey Egypts Scepter held,
Who were by cruel Selym ſlain and queld.

argument.p: The 2 firſt Founders or Raiſers of the Aſſyrian 1848. Monarchy, which was tranſlated to Babylon.

lg.l:
Aſſyrium Nimrodus avus, Ninuſ
que
ſuper bus

l.hi: Viribus Imperium conſtituere ſuis

lg.l: Nimrod the Grandſire and proud Ninus hight,
S • t up great Aſſurs Empire by their might.
Nimrod in Aſſyriam fuit e Babylone profectus: 1967.
Aſt ibidem Ninus natus & altus erat.

From Babylon
• ' Aſſur Nimrod removed,
But Ninus was ther born and foſtered.

argument.p: The 2 monſters of Mankind, for luxury, lechery, and al licentiouſnes.

lg.l:
Sardanapalus iners, at
que
Heliogabalus excors: 3200.

l.hi: Ambo aevo Veneris monſtra fuere ſua.

lg.l: Baſe Sardanapal, and Heliogabal obſcene,
Were in their times Luſts monſters both unclean.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ʋltimus Aſſyriae fuit ille Monarcha, ſed alter
Inter Romanos Induperator erat.
The firſt was Aſſurs laſt King, but the laſt
In Romes Imperial throne a while was plac't.

argument.p: The 2 great Governors, who conſpired and combined to depoſe their liege Lord.

l.hi: Proditione mala, ſecreto foedere facto;

lg.l: Perditus a Satrapis Sardanapalus erat.
Sardanapal was by his Lieftenents betrayed,
Who ſecret plots for his deſtruction laid.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Imperium Aſſyrium Belochus & Arbaces inter

l.hi: Se cuncti in partes diſtribuere duas.

lg.l: Beloch and Arbaces (ſo wel they fared)
Th'Aſſyrian Realm in two parts twixt them ſhared.

argument.p: The 2 Kings of Babylon and Perſia, which had hoſtility one with another. 3493:

lg.l:
Balthaſar at
que
Cyrus mortalia bella gerebant:

l.hi: Sed tandem hic Victor, caeſus at ille fuit.

lg.l: Balthaſar and Cyrus did fel war darrain:
But one at length was Victor, th'other ſlain.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Balthaſar imbellis Babylonica regna revulfit:
Aſtruit at celebris Perſica Regna Cyrus.
Weak Balthaſar threw Babels kingdom down,
But noble Cyrus rais'd the Perſian crown.

argument.p: The 2 Monarchs (of Media & Perſia) who with joynt forces ſubdued Babylon.

lg.l: Regna Cyaxares Medus Babylonica vicit,
Illuſtri Genero conſoeiante Cyro.
The Mede Darius Babylons kingdom won,
By Cyrus help his noble legal Son.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Morte Cyaxares Babylonica regna ſubegit,

At
que
Cyrus, vieibus quae tenuere ſuis.
Cyrus and Cyaxares Babylon queld
By war, which in ſucceſſiv turns they held.

argument.p: The 2 Kings of like fame and fortun, that A. M. 3484. made war one againſt another.

lg.l: CRoeſus in arma ruit, Cyrus impeger obſtitit armis:

l.hi: Sic ambo hoſtiles conſeruere manus.

lg.l: Craeſus makes war, Cyrus haſts to withſtand,
So both in hoſtil arms joyn hand in hand.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Croeſus divitiis celebris, Cyrus inclytus armis:

l.hi: Inter ſe rapidi mutua bella ſtruunt.

lg.l: Croeſus renound for wealth, Cyrus for wars;
Moſt fiercely twixt them raiſed mutual jars.

argument.p: The 2 ſole ſons of great Cyrus, that cam to diſaſtrous deaths.

lg.l: Cambyſes fratrem innocuum crudeliter occat: 3504. 3509

l.hi: Poſtea ſed gladio perditur ipſe ſuo.

lg.l: Cambyſes his good brother cruely ſlu:
But by's own ſword ſoon after paid death's du.

argument.p: The 2 magi (Patezites and Smerdis) who were Counſelors of State to Cambyſes.

l.hi: Mentiti Smerdim, ſolium tenuere ſupremum,

lg.l: Fictitii magi Perſide fraude duo.
Two falſ Perſian Magi faining to be
Smerdis, by guile poſſeſt the Soveraignty.

argument.p: The 7 chief Princes of Perſia, deſcended from roial blood of their firſt King Archemenes. 3510.

lg.l: Perſarum Proceres regali e ſanguine ſeptem

l.hi: Progeniti Patriam reſtituere ſuam.

lg.l: Sevn Perſian Peers of regal blood deſcended,
Their Countries Crowns from Conterfets defended.
Ottanes, Aſphatines, Gobrias, Megabyſus, Hidarnes,
Jntphernes, Darius, nomina nota manent.
Their names were Ottan, Gobrias, Intophern,

l.hi: Darius, Megabyſe, Aſtaphin, Hidern.

argument.p: The 2 chief Protectors or Benefactoss of the 3516. 3573. Jews, when they lived under the Perſians.

lg.l: Judaico populo mire indulſere Darius,

At
que
Artaxerxes, pro pietate ſua.
Darius and Artaxerxes wondrouſly
Favord the Jews out of pure piety.
Filius Hiſtaſpis primus cognomine dictus.
Atqui Longimanus nobilis alter erat.
The firſt Hiſtaſpes Son was cald by name;
The other Longhand termd, both of high fame.

argument.p: The 2 greateſt Kings of Macedon, that raiſed and ruled the ſaid Monarchy.

lg.l:
REs ſub Alexandro Macedonica ſub
que
Philippo

l.hi: Floruit egregie, regna perampla domans.

lg.l: The State of Macedon under Sire and Son, Aliter. 3686. 370 •
Paſſingly floriſh'd. and large kingdoms won.
Perlate extendit Macedonica regna Philippus:
Orbis Alexander Rex Orientis erat.
Philip inlarg'd the Macedon kingdom far:
Alexander ſubdu'd the Eaſtern world by war.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Magnus Alexander Domitor cognomine Mundi,

l.hi: Vix decimam partem ſubdidit enſe ſuo.

lg.l: Great Alexander the worlds Conqueſtor caled,
Scars the tenth part by force of Arms inthraled.

argument.p: The 4 chief Captains of Alexander, which ſhared moſt part of his vaſt Dominions.

lg.l: Bis duo Alexandri, regna omnia ſubdita bello

l.hi: Praecipui inter ſe diſtribuere, Duces.

lg.l: Alexanders four chief Captains al divided
The Kingdoms ' • wixt themſelfs, by war acquired.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Antigonus, Prolomes, Caſſander item
que
Seleucus,

l.hi: Haec habuere Duces nomina certa ſibi.

lg.l: Thoſ Captains were cald Ptolome, Antigonus
(By ſevral names) Caſſander and Seleucus.

argument.p: The 2 laſt Captains of Alexander who outlived 3751. al their corrivals.

lg.l:
Ʋltimi Alexandri, Lyſimachus, at
que
Seleucus,

l.hi: Mutua pro Imperio bella iniere Duces.

lg.l: Lyſimachus and Seleucus mutualy
Alexanders laſt Captains fought for maſtery,

Pro ſummo Imperio, Lyſimachus at
que
Seleucus
Ʋltimi Alexandri bella tulere Duces,
Alexanders laſt Captains for Soverainty:
Lyſimach and Seleucus wars did try.

argument.p: The 3 principal kingdoms of Alexander, which dured longeſt after his death.

lg.l: Aegyptus, Syria, & Macedon, ceu cornua Capri
Sunt tria Alexandri Regna relicta ſuis.
The Goat t'his friends, his horns as gifts let free,
Aegypt, Syria▪ and Macedon, kingdoms three.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Aegypius, Syria, & Macedon, tria Regna fuere,
Quae ſibi Marte fero ſubjuga Roma tulit.
Macedon, Syria, Egypt, three kingdoms were,
Which Rome by war brought under ſervil fear,

argument.p: The 2 moſt uſual names of a large fertil Country in Europ.

lg.l: ITalia & Latium Regionis nomina conſtant:

l.hi: Ʋnius hoc Partis, totius illa fuit.

lg.l: Italy and Latium a Countries names were:
This of one part, that of the whol did bear.

argument.p: The 4 firſt Nations that poſſeſſed ſeveral parts of Heſperia now Italy.

lg.l: Quatuor Italicum gentes ſunt (Arcades, Umbri,
Pelaſgi, Oenotrii) quae coluere ſolum.
Four Nations were▪ which firſt held Italy.
Arcads, Pelaſgi, Ʋmbri and Oenotri.

argument.p: The 2 famous Princes falſly fained by Virgil 2858. 3137. to be contemporars.

lg.l: Bis centum Aeneas deceſſit & amplius annos.
Anteaquam Dido nata pudica fuit.
Eneas died abov two hundred yeers.
Yer Dido liv'd, as by Record appeers.

argument.p: The 2 raiſers of Athens in Greece, and Rome 2791. 3 • 80. in Italy, being both Baſtards.

lg.l: Theſeus illuſtre Imperium fundavit Athenis:
Condidit & Romam Romulus ipſe ſuam.
Theſeus a noble State at Athens founded:
And Romulus eke his City Rome compounded.

argument.p: The 2 emnlous Brethren that began jointly To build the City of Rome.

lg.l: Sanguine fraterno maduerunt maenia Romae

Nam
que
Remum, ut regnet Romulus enſe ferit.
Romes wals had Brothers blood tempred with clay:
For Romulus for ruleſhip did Remus ſlay.

div.head: EPIG. XXIV. Romanor • m ordines varii.

argument.p: The 5 diſtinctions or diviſions of the Roman People into ſeveral Claſſes.

lg.l:
In quin
que , Imperium Romae juſto ordine Claſſes

l.hi: Diviſum: & quaevis jus habuere ſuum.

lg.l: Romes State into fiv Orders was divided:
And ech had proper rights to them aſſigned.

argument.p: The 6 Brothers (3 Horaſti and 3 Curiatii) ech Twins, which fought a Combat.

lg.l: Tres Romae nati, totidem cum Fratribus Albae,

l.hi: Pro patriae Imperio, conſeruere manus.

lg.l: Three Brethren born at Rome, with Albans three,
A Combat fought for Countries ſoveraignty.

div.head: EPIG. XXVI. Tarquinii Romae Reg • s.

argument.p: The 2 Tarquins of Greec extraction, who by their wily wits becam Kings of Rome.

l.hi: Romani Imperii, Gra • o de ſtemmate creti

lg.l: Regia Tarquinii Sceptra tulere duo.
Two Tarquins ſprung from Greekiſh proſapy
The Scepters held of Roman royalty.

argument.p: The 2 famous Ladies of Greece and Rome, moſt renowned for tried chaſtity.

lg.l: Graecula Penelope, Romana Lucretia, forma

l.hi:
Ʋtra
que praecellens, at
que pudicitia.

lg.l: Penelope the Greec, Lucrece Roman dame
For beauty both and chaſtity bore fame.

argument.p: The 5 Conſuls choſen the firſt yeer after Tarquins expulſion or Regi-fuge.

lg.l: Tarquinio ejecto Romae (res mira relatu)

l.hi:
Ʋno quin
que anno Conſuluere viri.

lg.l: At Rome in one yeer, Tarquin then ejected,
(Strange things to tel) fiv Conſuls were elected.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tarquinio expulſo, ſucceſſivo ordine Romae,

l.hi:
Quin
que anno primo conſuluere viri.

lg.l: Tarquin being baniſh'd at Rome, that firſt yeer
Fiv Conſuls did ſucceſſivly appear.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Brutus, Tarquinius, Lucretus, Horatius at
que
Publicola uno anno Conſuluere ferunt.
Brute, Tarquin, Lucrece, Horaoe in one yeer;
And eke Publicola ('tis ſaid) choſen were.

argument.p: The 2 Cozens (jun. Brutus Conſul, & Aruns Tarquin) who ſlu ech other in combat.

lg.l:
Brutus, Arunſ
que
fero dum certavere duello,

l.hi: Enſibus alter utris mortem obiere trucem.

lg.l: Brutus and Aruns fighting a fierce duel,
By one the others Sword, felt death moſt cruel.

argument.p: The 2 enemies which intended ech others deſtruction, yet both eſcaped death. A. U. 246.

lg.l: Scaevola tentabat Porſennam occidere Regem,

l.hi: Sed vana illuſus ſpe, cremat ipſe manum.

lg.l: Scaevola to kil Porſenna did eſſay,
But his own hand (hope failing) burnt away.

div.head: EPIG. XXXI. Lis inter Membra & Ventriculum.

argument.p: The 2 parts of Mans body (Lims and Stomach 260.) mythologicaly fained to fal at debat

l.hi: Membra negant ſtomacho aſsiduos ſupplere labores:
Ventriculo at pereunt Membra ruente ſuo.

lg.l: The Members to their Belly help deny:
But they, their Stomach failing, pine and dy.

div.head: EPIG. XXXII. Matronae erga Patriam piae.

argument.p: The 2 pious Matrons (Mother and Wife to Coriolanus) which preſerved Rome from 264. ruin.

lg.l: In Roma duae erant mulieres, mater & uxor,

l.hi: Quae patriam aſſervant, clade premente gravi.

lg.l: Two Matrons, Rome then like to be invaded,
Mother and Wife, from ſpoil their Country ſaved:

argument.p: The 306 Fabii of one name and family, who were ſlayn at the ſiege of Veii.

lg.l: Ter centum cum ſex Fabiis Veientibus arvis

l.hi: Dum fera bella cient, deperiere ſimul.

lg.l: Three hundred and ſix Fabii raiſed war
In Veien fields, wher they at once ſlain are.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ter centum & bis tres Fabii Veientibus agris

l.hi: Pro Patriae cauſa ſuſtinuere necem.

lg.l: Three hundred and ſix Fabii in Vein field,
For their ſweet Countries ſake, to death did yeeld.

argument.p: The 10 chief Officers choſen to collect Laws, who bore ſuprem ſway at Rome.

lg.l: Plebiſcita decem Romae, renuente Senatu,

l.hi: Qui leges facerent conſtituere viros.

lg.l: The peoples votes at Rome 'gainſt Senats wil,
Choſten men to make Laws that ſhould dure ſtil.

argument.p: The 2 Cities (Troy & Veii) which ſtood out A. M. 2873. A. V. 360. their Sieges for 10 yeers ſpace ech.

lg.l: Troja decennali, Veii quoque fortiter Urbes.

l.hi: Cum ſatis obſtiterant, obſidione cadunt.

lg.l: When Troy and Veii ſtoutly had repelled
Ful ten yeers Siege, both taken were and quelled.

argument.p: The 2 chief Champions (Manlius & Camillus) who reſcued Rome from the Gals. 364.

lg.l: Dum Roma opprimitur, defendit Manlius arcem:
Aſt hoſtes Furius pellit ab urbe procul.
At Siege of Rome, Manlius the Capitol ſaved:
But Furius far from Rome the Fomen chaced.

argument.p: The 2 popular men, that aſpired to get Soveraign preeminence at Rome. 316. 372.

lg.l: Dum Melius regnum, dum Manlius ambit honorem,

l.hi: Supplicium meritis par capitale luunt.

lg.l: While Melius reign, while Manlius greatnes ſought
Both for their crimes to death deſerv'd were brought.

argument.p: The Decii (Father and Son) which wilfully 494. 459. or vainly ſought their deaths.

l.hi: Vt ſuperent hoſtes, ſuſtinuere necem.

lg.l: The Decii (Sire and Son) for Victory;
Of free accord a wilful death did dy.

argument.p: The 2 laſt Nations of Italy, which buckled longeſt with the Romans for Maſtery.

lg.l: Gens fuit, Auſoniae, Samnites ultima Romae, 440. 471.

At
que
Tarentini ſub juga miſſa truci.
Samnits and Tarentins laſt Nations were
Of Italy, which Romes cruel yoke did bear.

argument.p: The 2 potent City States which waged wars 489. many yeers for ſuprem Soverainty.

lg.l: Pro mundi imperio Carthago & Roma potenti

l.hi: Conſeruere manu mutua bella diu.

lg.l: Carthage and Rome with ſtrong hand mutualy:
For the Worlds rule fierce wars long time did try.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Roma potens armis, Carthago ſuperba trophaeis.

l.hi: Geſſere inter Vetetrica bella diu.

lg.l: Rome ſtrong in Arms, Carthage puft up with pride,
Moſt cruel wars for long ſpace 'twixt them tried.

argument.p: The 2 notorious and nefarious Rebels or A. M. 3791. A. V. 512. Ringleaders of mutinous mercenaries.

lg.l:
Spendius at
que
Matho pretio a Carthagine ducti,

l.hi: Adverſus Dominos bella tulere ſuos.

lg.l: Spendius and Matho men by Carthage hired
For pay, againſt their Maſters war conſpired.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Spendius at
que
Matho, mercedc ad bella parati
A Paenis, in eos lurida bella cient.
