Spendius and Matho by Paenians wag'd to wars,
Againſt them raiſd moſt fel and deadly jars.

argument.p: The 2 chief Commanders for Carthage and Rome, which ſwayed the ſecond Punic war.

lg.l:
Annibal & Scipio, Romae hic, Carthagenis ille
It began A U 534. ended 551

l.hi: Praecipui hoc bellum compoſuere Duces.

lg.l: Great Annibal Carthage, Scipio Rome defended,
Chief Captains both this war by battle ended.

argument.p: The 2 eminent Chieftains in the ſecund Punic war, commonly caled Romes Shield and Sword.

lg.l: Romae olim Fabius clypeus, Marcellius enſis

l.hi:
Dictus erat, Patriae fortis uter
que Pater.

lg.l: Fabius Romes Shield, Sword Marcellus hight,
Were both ſtout Patrons of their Countries right.

argument.p: The 2 laſt Kings of Macedon, whom the Roman ſubdued, reducing it to a Province.

lg.l: Ʋltima Romanis inierunt bella Philippus
Et Perſeus, Latium ſed ſubiere jugum.
Philip and Perſous the laſt wars did make
With Romans, but were forc'd their yoke to take.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Philippus Pater & ſucceſſor Perſeus ejus

l.hi: Victi a Romuleis Marte fuere fero.

lg.l: Philip the Sire, and Perſeus next his Son,
By Roman wars were vanquiſh'd and undoon.

argument.p: The 3 great wars between the Penians and Romans, which ended with Carthages ruin.

lg.l: Pro mero Imperio Carthago & Roma furenter,

l.hi: Temporibus variis bella tulere tria.

lg.l: Carthage and Rome held three wars furiouſly
At ſeveral times, meerly for Soveraignty.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Inter Romanos Paenoſ
que recuſſa potenti.
Sanguinolenta animo, bella fuere tria.

lg.l: Romans and Penians, 'twixt themſelfs in rage,
Three bloody wars with ſtrenuous mind did wage.
Punica gens, & gens Romana ter arma capeſſunt,

l.hi: Tandem Romano decori eſt Carthago triumpho.

lg.l: Penians with Romans three grand wars darrained
Carthage at laſt the Romans Triumphs raiſed.

div.head: EPIGR. XLVI. Ʋrbes a Romanis dirute.

argument.p: The 3 glorious Cities, which the greedy Romans deſtroyed within 14 yeers ſpace.

lg.l: Ʋno a Romuleis aevo Carthago, Corinthus,

At
que
Numantina urbs obruta clara fuit.
Brav Carthage, Corinth, Numance, in one age
The Romans brought to ruin with fel rage.

argument.p: The 2 brav brothers (both Gracchi) doon to death, for imputed or pretended ſedition.

lg.l:
Tiberius Caiuſ
que
duo de ſtemmate Gracchi,

l.hi: Pro tenui penas ſeditione luunt.

lg.l: Tiberius and Caius Gracchi by extraction,
Were both deſtroid for ſowing ſlight diſtraction.

argument.p: The 2 noble Roman Ladies, moſt admired for conjugal chaſtity.

lg.l: Quam genuit Scipio, Cornelia, nata Catonis.

Poteia, Romanae foeminae utrae
que graves.
At Rome dwelt noble Scipio's Cornelia,
And Cato's daughter (both grav Matrons) Porcia.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Gracchorum mater Cornelia, Porcia Bruti

l.hi:
Conjux, prae reliquis utra
que clara fuit.

lg.l: Cornelia the Graccbies mother wiſe,
Brutus wife Porcia; whom times eternize.

argument.p: The 2 ſons of King Micipſa; trecherouſly & truculently ſlain by Jugurth.

lg.l: Fraude male fratres jugulātur Adherbal, Hyempſal
Queis Jugurtha ferox regna paterna rapit.
Adherbal and Hyempſal Brothers were ſlain
By Jugurths fraud, their Fathers realms to gain.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Jugurthae manibus truculenter Adherbal, Hyempſal

l.hi: Innocui Fratres occubuere duo.

lg.l: Adherbal and Hyempſal Brethren twain,
Were harmleſs both by Jugurth cru'ly ſlain.

argument.p: The 2 firſt firebrands which began the bloody civil combuſtions at Rome.

lg.l: Civilis Sylla & Matius duo fulmina belli,
Romulea humano tecta cruore replent.
Sylla and Marius brands of civil wars,
Romes houſes fild with mens blood by their jars.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Sylla ferox, Mariuſ
que
m • vent civilia bella:
Queis Romae gladio millia multa cadunt.
Sylla and Marius with civil wars Rome filled:
Whence many thouſand Citizens were killed.

argument.p: The 2 brav Commandess (a Grecian and Roman) which ſympathized in conditions.

lg.l: Graecia Cimonem produxit, Roma Lucullum:

l.hi: Qui fama celebres, ſorte fuere pares.

lg.l: Greece Cimon bred, Rome brought Lucullus forth:
Whos fame, facts, fortun, prov'd them of like worth.

argument.p: The 2 notable miſcreants, who conſpired to kil the Conſul and Senators,

lg.l: Perdere dum cupiant Catilina & Lentulus hoſtes,

l.hi: Detecta intereunt proditione ſua.

lg.l: Catilin and Lentulus while they intend
To ſlay their foes, came to a bloody end:

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Foedere conjuncti Catilina & Lentulus arcto,

l.hi: Pro meritis mortem ſuſtinuere ſuis.

lg.l: Catilin and Lentulus in ſtrict league chained,
According to their merits death ſuſtained.

argument.p: The 3 potent Princes of Rome, which made a mutual combination to ſway the State.

lg.l: Craſſus, Pompeius, Caeſar, ſub foedere nexi
Vi Romae Imperium diſtribuere ſibi.
Craſſus, Pompey, Caeſar in league combined.
Romes Empire to themſelfs by force aſſign'd.

Pompeius, Craſſus Romae, Caeſar
que
Triarchi

l.hi: Imperii regimen corripuere ſibi.

lg.l: Romes Rulers Pompey, Craſſus, Ceſar high,
Took to themſelfs the Empires regency.

argument.p: The 2 perturbers of public Peace at Rome, being ſuccedanei to Sylla and Marius.

lg.l: Syllae Pompeius, Marii fuit aſſecla Caeſar:
Qui Romae innocuo ſanguine cuncta replent.
Pompey was Sylla's, Caeſar Marius brood:
Who al things fild at Rome with harmles blood.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Pompeius bella, & Caſar Civilia geſtant:

l.hi: In quibus enſe fero millia multa cadunt.

lg.l: Pompey and Caſar Civil wars upheld,
Wherin by Sword were many thouſands queld.

argument.p: The 3 Patritians (father and two ſons) who having lived gloriouſly died diſaſtrouſly.

lg.l: Africa dat magno, dat Cneo Europa ſepulcbrum:
Aſt Aſiae Sexti finibus oſſa cubant
Afric the great, Europ did Cneus bury:
But Sextus bones in Aſia's borders ly.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Magnus in Aegypto, Cneuſ
que Hiſpania obibat:
Sextus apud Lesbum poſt tumulatus erat.
The Great in Egypt, Cneius in Spain fel:
Sextus at Lesbos ſlain hath his laſt Cel.

div.head: EPIG. LVI. Pater & Filia ſe necantes,

argument.p: The 2 Perſons that ſlu themſelfs to ſhun infamy & captivity.

lg.l: Viſceribus fixo Cato ſepugione peremit:
Ignibus exhauſtis Porcia nata perit.
Cato his bowels pierc'd with Sword, expired:
His daughter Porcia cat down fire and died.

argument.p: The 2 firſt erectors and eſtabliſhers of Romes Empire or Soveraign Monarchy.

lg.l: Julius Imperium inſtituit cognomine Caeſar:
Magnus at Auguſtus perficit iſtud opus.
Julius cald Caeſir th'Empire firſt erected:
But great Auguſtus that ſame work perfected.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Julius Imperium Caeſar Romae inchoat, at qui
Perficit Auguſtus; quod caput Orbis erat.
Julius Romes Empire which the worlds head was,
Began: but it Auguſtus brought to paſs.

argument.p: The 2 chief Conſpirators which combined to kil Caeſar in the Senat-houſ, as a ſlaughter-houſ.

lg.l: Caſſius & Brutus ſcelerato faedere juncti
Sanguine Caeſareo commaduere manus.
Caſſius and Brutus in vile league combined,
With Caeſars blood their wicked hands defiled.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Caſſius & Brutus cum ſeptuaginta homicidis,
Caeſaris exagitant publica in aede necem.
Caſſius and Brutus with ſevnty men conſpired,
Who Caeſars death in Senat houſ contrived,

argument.p: The 3 friends of Caeſar who conjoined to revenge his death and ſhare the Dominions.

lg.l:
Poſt Julium Octavius Caeſar Romae, Antoniuſ
que ,
Cum Lepido Imperium ſorte tulere potens.
Octavius Caeſar, Lepidus and Antony,
When Julius fel, held Romes vaſt Trinarchy.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Antonius, Lepidus; Juven • ſ
que
agnomine Caeſar▪

l.hi: Romanum imperium diſtribuere ſibi.

lg.l: Antony, Lepidus, and yong Caeſar caled
Among themſelfs the Roman Empire ſhared.

argument.p: The 2 Emperors that ruled the Roman world, while Chriſt lived on Earth.

lg.l: Imperium Auguſtus tenuit, Tiberius inde,

l.hi: Dum Chriſt •• natus, dum crucifixus eart.

lg.l: Auguſtus th' Empire rul'd when Chriſt was born,
Tiberius reignd, when 's fleſh on Croſs was torn.

argument.p: The 3 ſucceſſiv Emperors, which ſprung from the loins or linage of Triumvir Antony.

l.hi: Tres ſucceſſive Imperii potiuntur habenis,

lg.l:
E celebri Antonii ſtemmate qui
que ſati.
Three Emp'rors in order the Throne aſcended.
Of noble Antony's linage ech deſcended.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Induperatores tres, ſunt de ſtirpe creati

lg.l: Antonii, Romae qui tenuere jugum.
Ther were three Emp'rors ſprung from Antony,
Who Rome held under yoke ſucceſſivly.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Filia ab Antonia Antonii de ſanguine tres ſunt

Progeniti: Caius, Claudius, at
que
Nero.
Of Antoni's blood by's daughter iſſued three,
Caius, Claudius, and Nero orderly.

argument.p: The 2 uterin german brothers which differed diametraly in diſpoſitions.

l.hi: Sunt gemini fratres Flavia de gente creati
Moribus abſimiles qui viguere ſimul.

lg.l: Ther were two brothers of Flavian family,
Unlike in maners who floriſhd roialy.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Titus erat placidus Princeps, pius, almus, amanus:

Domitianus atrox, trux, ferus, at
que ferox.
Titus a good Prince was, ſweet, pleaſing, mild:
Domitian cruel, wicked, fierce and wild.

argument.p: The 2 renouned Emperors of Spaniſh deſcent: one by birth the other in blood.

lg.l: Induperatores Hiſpana gente profecti,
Romae olim regimen ſuſtinuere duo.
Whilom two Emprors of Spaniſh deſcent,
Attained ech Romes royal Government.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Trajanus celebris bonitate, Adrianus honore eſt:

l.hi:
Atqui ex Hiſpano ſanguine uter
que fuit.

lg.l: Trajan in goodnes, Adrian for fame tranſcended:
But both of them from Spaniſh blood deſcended,

argument.p: The 2 lewd brothers (ſons to Septimius Severus) who ſought ech others deſtruction.

lg.l: Germani fratres Caracalla & Geta fuerunt:

l.hi:
Ut vitam alterius tollat, uter
que petit.

lg.l: Caracal and Geta were two bloody brothers:
Both ſought to take the life ech one of th' others.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Enecuit Getam fratrem Caracalla minorem:

l.hi:
Sed ſcelerum plenus Frater uter
que fuit.

lg.l: Caracal his yonger brother Geta killed:
But brethren both with wickednes were filled.

argument.p: The 2 Coſen Germans that ſucceded one another, being of far differing diſpoſitions.

lg.l: Vano Heliogahalo ſucceſſit Alexo Severus

l.hi: Juſtus: diſſimiles moribus ambo ſuis.

lg.l: Severus juſt to Heliogabal vain,
Succeded: both in maners unlike ſtrain.

argument.p: The 2 ſucceſſiv Emperors which were of contrary affections or profeſſions in Religion.

lg.l: Nominis Oſor erat Julianus Apoſtata Chriſti:
Profeſſor validus ſed Jovianus erat
Julian Apoſtat hated Chriſts great name:
But Jovian conſtantly profeſs'd the ſame.

argument.p: The 2 ſucceding Emperors of the Eaſt, moſt miſerably murthered by their Souldiers.

l.hi: Induperatorem perimit cum conjuge ſervus

Qui conſanguineos filioloſ
que necat.

lg.l: A ſlav the Empror with his wife did ſlay,
Who al his ſons and kindred made away.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Mauritium dominum vita & Diadematae Phocas

l.hi:
Privat, & uxorem filioloſ
que ſuos.

lg.l: Phoeas his maſter Maurice and his wife,
With al his ſons depriv'd of Crown and Life.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Ipſe a militibus poſt eſt Homicida necatus:

Dignam pro meritis ſuſtinuit
que necem.

lg.l: The ſame baſe Traitor was by ' • Souldiers ſlain,
And afterward deſerv'd death did obtain.

argument.p: The 2 antient renouned Poets of Greece (Heſiod & Homer) reputed contemporars.

l.hi:
Exuperant reliquos tempore quoſ
que ſuo.

lg.l: Heſiod and Romer Poets chieftain counted:
Al Poets in their time or ſince ſurmounted.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Heſiodus celebris vates & magnus Homerus
Thebarum & Trojae bella cruenta canunt.
Heſiod and Homer Poets of high fame,
Thebes bloody wars, and Troys, in verſ did frame.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: The banum Heſiodus, Trojanum ſcripſit Homerus

l.hi:
Bellum: aevo vates ſummus uter
que ſuo.

lg.l: Heſiod Thebes war, Homer Trois ſiege prociamed:
Both in their age being the beſt Poets famed.

argument.p: The 2 iudubitat places of Homers original byrth and his final burial.

lg.l: Natus erat Smyrnae Ioniae prope flumen Homerus,

Cujus
• o •
recubant oſſa ſepulta ſolo.
Homer was born at Smyrna River nigh,
Whoſ bones in Ios Ile interred ly.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Smyrna locus natalis erat praeluſtris Homeri:
Oſſa ſed Iolico littore tecta jacent.
Smyrna was Birth-place t' Homer, moſt renowned;
But on Ile Ios ſtrand his bones ly ſhrowded.

argument.p: The 2 eminent excellent Men (both blind) that lived on alms of bounteous Benefactors.

lg.l: Quaefiit oſtiolis victum mendicus Homerus,
Et Belliſarius (coecus uterque) ſuum.
Homer and Belliſar (both of ſight d • prived)
By begging alms at doors their food acquired.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Saepe ſuum victum eſt per compita adactus Homerus,
Et Belliſarius quaerere, perque vias.
Homer was driv'n to beg his bread abroad,
And Belliſarius his on high way road.

argument.p: The 7 chief Cities or Commonwealths, which claimed moſt Intereſt in Homer.

lg.l: Smyrna, Samos, Ithaca, oſtentant natalia vatis;
Cuma, Chios, Colophon certat, itemque Phocae.
Smyrna Samos, Ithaca Homer's birth place claim,
Chuma, Chios, Colophon, Phocae ſay the ſame.
Centendêre urbes vatis pro ſtirpe, Phocaea
Smyrna, Samos. Colophon, Ithaca, Cuma, Chios.
Phocae, Samos, Colophon, Homer's birth pretended,
Smyrna, Cuma, Ithaca, Chios eke contended.

div.head: EPIG. LXXII. Viri habentes corda hirſuta.

argument.p: The 3 valiant Greecs, who being embalmed had their hearts covered with hair.

l.hi: Tres habuere duces validi circumdata pilis
Corda, innata quibus vis animoſa fuit.

lg.l: Three valiant men had hearts with hair al thatched,
Whoſe inbred courage hardly could be matched.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Crinibus hirſutis valde obfita corda feroces
Grajugenae quondam tres habuere ſua.

lg.l: Whilom three Grecs for valour much renowned
Had their hearts found with rough hairs ful ſurrounded.

div.head: EPIG. LXXIII. Duces in foveas jacti.

argument.p: The 2 condemned Commanders, who were caſt into vaſt vaults to ſuffer death.

l.hi: Projecti in foveas duo Greeci Marte potentes:
Eripit hunc Vulpes, ille venena bibit,

lg.l: Two Greecs were into vaults flung to be killed:
A Fox ſav'd one, poiſon the other ſpilled

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Jactus Ariſtomenes fuit, & Philopaemen in antra:

l.hi: Eruit hunc Vulpes, ille cicuta obiit.

lg.l: Two ſtout Commanders into Caves were caſt:
The firſt a Fox freed, Hemloc kild the laſt.

argument.p: The 30 Legiſlativ Rulers or Tyrants of Athens, which uſurped ſuprem Soveraignty.

lg.l: Ʋrbis Athenarum Domini triaconta Tyranni,

l.hi: Imperium ſummum continuere diu.

lg.l: The thirty Tyrans Lords of Athens long;
Held ſuprem ſway or rule by forces ſtrong.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ter decem Athenarum ſimul obtinuere Tyranni

l.hi: ſupremum regimen, qui mala multa patrant,

lg.l: At Athens thirty Tyrans were admitted
Jointly to rule, who many harms committed.

div.head: EPIG. LXXV. Bella Judaeorum cum Dominis.

argument.p: The grand wars which the Rebellious Jews waged with their imperious Lords.

lg.l: Judaei expoſiti variis ſub Gentibus acri

l.hi: ſervitio, in Dominos bella cruenta cient.

lg.l: The Jews in bondage brought to ſundry Nations,
Raiſd 'gainſt their Lords fierce wars & fel cōmotions.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Judaei adverſus Syrios fera bella gerebant:
Sed cum Romanis aſperiora diu.
The Jews 'gainſt Syrians held long bloody war:
But with the Romans waged fiercer far.

argument.p: The 3 moſt memorable vaſtations and renovations of Jeruſalem City.

l.hi: Ʋrbs antiqua Salem vicibus fuit obruta teruls,

At
que iterum toties aedificata recens.

lg.l: Old Salem City was three times demoliſh'd,
And no leſs often was again new poliſh'd.

lg.head: Alias
lg.l: Ʋrbs Hieroſolymae ter diruta funditus olim eſt:

l.hi:
Denuo
que in melius ter renovata fuit.

lg.l: Whilom Jeruſalem was thrice confounded,
And thrice again in better beauty founded.

argument.p: The 2 principal people which antiently inhabited Albania in Caledonia, now Scotland.

lg.l: Secula continuit per multa Albania Gentes

(Pictos at
que
Scotos) terra gelata duas.
For many yeers Albanies Country cold,

Two Nations (Pict •
and Scots) at once did hold.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Pictos at
que
Scotos borcali Albania plaga
Olim •• uit gentes terra Brytanna duas.
Whilom North-Britiſh Albany, two Nations,
(Picts and Scots] foſtred diſtring far in faſhions.

argument.p: The 2 rarities or ſingularities of Scotland, both cauſed by extrem petrifying cold.

l.hi: Batra ſuas vertit guttas in ſaxa gelatas:

lg.l:
Lomunduſ
que
lacus ſaxea ligna facit.
Ratra his Icy drops to ſoft ſtones turneth: Ratra River. Logh Lomund.
And Lomund Lake ſticks to hard ſtones transformeth

argument.p: The 108 Scotiſh Kings (as Hector Boetius reckons) wherof half cam to misfortuns.

lg.l:
Poſt Gathelum centum Reges octo
que citantur:

l.hi: Quorum vix medii ſicco obiere toro.

lg.l: One hundred eight Scots kings ſince Gathel reigned
Wherof ſcars half dry death in bed obteined.

argument.p: The 2 Scots courtiers, who met three Wierds or Witches which foretold their fortuns.

lg.l: Dum Scotiae occurrunt Satrapis tres mutuo binis,

l.hi: Sagae, praenarrant fata futura brevi.

lg.l: When three Wierds met two Scotiſh Lords, they al
Foretold their Fates, what ſhortly ſhould befal.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Dum Scotico in Saltu tres Sagae mutuo binis
Obveniunt Satrapis fata futura docent.

lg.l: Three Wierds met two Scots Lords in Foreſt wide,
Who told what future Fates ſhould them betide.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Tres Scotiae in Sylvis dum occurrunt mutuò Sagae,
Praedicunt Satrapis fata futura brevi.

lg.l: Three Witches meeting in Scots woods by chance,
Foretold two Lords of future high advance.

argument.p: The 2 metrical verſes inſcribed on the back of the Scots fatal Chair by Kenneth.

lg.l:
Ni fallant Fatum, Scoti hunc quocun
que locatum

l.hi: Invenient lapidem, regnare tenentur ibidem.

lg.l: Unleſs Fate fail the Scots ſhall ſway,
Where ere this ſtone, they find men ſay.

l.hi: Fatalem Cathedram, cui facta ex marmore ſedes,

lg.l: A Gathelo acceptam Scoti habuere, ferunt.
A fatal Chair with Marble ſeat Scots hav,
Or had, which Gathel (as they fain) them gav:

argument.p: The 2 ſtrange men which uttered their Meſſages from God to great Monarchs.

l.hi: Ignoti cecinere duo prae Regibus olim,
Quae ſubito acciderent fata futura, viri.

lg.l: Whilom two ſtrange men future Fates did tel
Before great Kings, which ſhortly to them fel.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Nuntii ab ignotis venientes deſuper oris,
Regibus edicunt quae ſibi fata velint.

lg.l: Two Meſſengers coming from whence none knew,
Told Kings what Fates to them ſhould ſoon inſu.

argument.p: The 2 greateſt Giants that any antient Anthors cite or celebrat on Earth.

l.hi: In mundo extiterant duo vaſta mole Gigantes:

lg.l: Hic ferus Antaeus ferreus alter Ochus.
The world two Giants had of immens might:
One fierce Anteus, th'other fel Ochus hight.

Maximus Antaeus, vaſte
que procerus Orion

l.hi: Longe alti ante omnes eminuere virot.

lg.l: Anteus huge, and Ochus vaſtly • al,
In height far paſſed before others al.

argument.p: The 3 common Courtezans moſt famous through the world in their times.

lg.l: Lamia, Flora, Lais, tria ſcorta notata per Orbem:

l.hi: Singula prae reliquis claruit arte ſua.

lg.l: Three Harlots through the world bore al the bel:
Which in their skil al others did excel.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Tres fuerant variis meretrices partibus Orbis;
Quaelibet excellens quamlibet arte ſua.

lg.l: In the Worlds ſundry parts three ſtrumpets traded,
Which in their Art ech others fame invaded.

argument.p: The 9 old worthies of the World (3 Jews, 3 Pagans, 3 Chriſtians) with 3 Mahometans.

lg.l: Joſua, Davides, Judas Machabeius, Hector,
Caeſar, Alexander, Carolus, Godfridus & Arthur,

Haumarus, Tamberlanus, Mahomet
que
ſecundus.
Jews and Mahometans in juſt rank are placed.
But Pagans and Chriſtians one in ech miſplaced. In tribual Seniority: A Sarraſen, Tartar, & True
Hector, Alex, Caeſar: Joſuah, David, Machabaeus.
Arthurus, Carolus, Godfridus Bolonienſis:

Haumarus, Tamberlanus, Mahomet
que
ſecundus.
Here al the Worthies are ſet orderly,
Ech in their Tribes with du Antiquity.

argument.p: The 9 women worthies (3 Jeweſſes, 3 Ethnics, 3 Chriſtians) like the men.

lg.l: Heroinae infignes ter tres viguere per Orbem,

l.hi: Quarum fama hominum bellica geſta canit.

lg.l: Nine female Worthies through the world are crowned,
Whoſ warlik geſts by mens fame are renowned.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Diſperſae variis mulieres Gentibus olim,
Percelebres paſſim Marte fuere novem.

lg.l: Whilom nine women famous were for war,
Diſpes'd in divers Nations neer and far.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Foeminae erant celebres Elfleda, Matilda, Joanna,
Pentheſiles, Tomyris, Bodua, Eſther, Debora, Judith.

l.hi: Pentheſil, Tomyris, Judeth, Eſther, Debora,

lg.l: Were famous women; Elfled, Mawd, Joan, Bodua.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Debora, Iudethes, Eſther, Judea propago:
Pentheſiles, Tomyris, Bonduca e Gentihus ortae:
Chriſtica Progenies Elfleda, Matilda, Joanna.
Debora, Judeth, Eſther, of Jews pedigree:
Penthifil, Tomyris, Bodua Gentils be:
Elfled, Maud, Joan, of Chriſtian proſapy.

argument.p: The 2 renowned men (one for Arts, another for Arms) born in Pannonia or Hungary.

lg.l: Pannonica oſtentat Gens Arte & Marte celebres,

l.hi: Olim aevis variis qui viguere viros.

lg.l: Pannony boaſts men, whom ſhe whilom nouriſh'd,
Renown'd for arts and arms, that long ſince floriſh'd.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Jeronymum genuit nemoroſa Hungaria ſanctum:

Huniadeſ
que
ibidem poſtea natus erat.
The woody Hungary Saint Jerom bred:
And Huniad after was ther foſtered.

argument.p: The 2 chief Conquerors of America (Mexicana and Peruana) to the Crown of Spain.

lg.l: Corteſio Hiſpanis Duce, M • xico ſubdita dudum:
Dein Duce P • zarro eſt aurea victa Peru.
Firſt Captain Cortes Mexico won to Spain:
Pezarro next did golden Peru gain.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Mexica Corteſius regna acquiſivit Iberis:
Pezarrus domuit vi Peruana brevi.
Cortes the Mexican kingdoms for Spain gained:
And Pezar Peru by force ſoon obtained.

argument.p: The 2 damnable deceivers that invented and intruded a new form of falſ worſhip.

lg.l: Falſi Impoſtores ſparſim Mahometica fundunt

l.hi: Dogmata per Mundi Climata cuncta duo.

lg.l: Two falſ Impoſtors Mahomet's doctrin ſpred
Through al Coaſts of the World far ſcattered.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Pſeudo Prophetarum par Sergius & Mahometes

l.hi: Decipiunt populum Relligione nova.

lg.l: Sergius and Mahomet two pſeudo Prophets vile,
With a new Sect poor people did beguile.

argument.p: The 5 Popes that ſat in S. Peters Chair ſucceſſivly within two yeers ſpace.

lg.l:
Papalem Romae tenuerunt quin
que Cathedram

Romani intra annum dimidium
que Patres.
Five Popes of Rome the Papal Chair poſſeſſ'd,
Who were within one yeer and half inveſted.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Innocuus Sextus, Clemens, Gregorius, Urban;

l.hi: Papatum intra aunos obtinuere duos.

lg.l: In two yeers Sextus, Ʋrban; Innocent died,
And Gregory Popes: Clement the place ſupplied.

lg.head: Alias

l.hi: Papae intra binos obierunt quatuor annos,
Quintus & in Cathedram deinde ſacratus erat.

lg.l: Four Popes within the ſpace of two yeers died,
And afterward a fifth the Chair ſupplied.

argument.p: The 19 Perſons, or 20 ſucceſſions of Oguzian Ottoman Sultans, in order of reign.

lg.l: Ottoman, Orchanes, Amurat, Bajazet, Mahometes:
Amurathes, Mahomet, Bajazet, Selymus, Solymannus.
Selymus, Amurathes: Mamet, Achmet, Muſtapha & Oſman,

Muſtapha his, Amurath, Ibriim, jam
que ultimus Achmet.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Theſ mighty Monarchs raiſed their Dominions
On Chriſtians ruins, and fel diviſions:
Whoſ thundring names cannot wel Engliſh'd be:
If any elſ can, he may doo it free.

l.hi:
Turcica regna decem at
que novem ſtruxere Monarchae:
Quorum ſunt tabula nomina ſcripta prius.

lg.l: Ninteen great Monarchs the Turciſh Realms raiſed:
Whoſ names are in the Catalog fore-related.

argument.p: The 2 mighty Mahometan Monarchs, who ſtruck a bloody battle for maſtery.

lg.l: Geſſerunt Reges (Mahometis iniqua propago)

l.hi: Prae mortali odio mutua bella, duo.

lg.l: Two Kings (falſ Mahomets ſpaun) fel at debate,
And mutual wars maintaind through mortal hate.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Tartariae illuſtris Rex, Turcicus at
que Tyrannus,

l.hi: Sanguinea pugna conſeruere manus.

lg.l: Great Tartars king, and Turciſh Tyran fel,
Ingag'd their Hoſts in bloody fight pelmel.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Tamberlanus atrox Baj • zet
que
ſuperbus inibant,

l.hi: Alter in alterutrum, bella cruenta ſimul.

lg.l: Fierce Tamberlain, and proud Bajazet together,
A bloody battle joynd, ech againſt either.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Pugnam planitie ſub ſtellae monte praealto

lg.l: Tamberlanus init cum Bajazete truci.
In plains of high mount Stellae a fierce fight,
Tamberlain joyn'd with cruel Bajazet's might.

argument.p: The 2 contemporar Chriſtians, which gav the Turcs many overthrows.

lg.l:
Caſtriot, Huniadeſ
que
uno ſub tempore clari,
Turcigena variis impetiere modis.
Caſtriot and Huniad in one age renowned,
By many means the bloody Turcs confounded.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Caſtriot, Huniadeſ
que
ferox (duo fulmina belli)
Praelia in Amurathem multa cruenta ferunt.
Caſtriot and Huniad (thunderbolts of war)
'Gainſt Amurat waged many bloody jar.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Caſtriot, Huniadeſ
que
gerunt (duo Martis alumni)
Plurima in Amurathem proſpera bella trucem.
Caſtriot and Huniad (two warlike wights)
Made againſt Amurat many happy fights.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons who were lamentably flaied divers dais together til they died.

l.hi: Afflicti gravibus duo ſunt cruciatibus olim,
Qui cute ſubſecta deperiere, viri.

lg.l: Whilom two men with grievous torments tired,
Having their Hides par'd off, wretchedly died.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Detracta cute doperiit Siſygambus iniquus:

Moſeſ
que
a Turcis excoriatus erat.
Siſygamb a bribing Judg alive was flaied: By Cambyſes. By Mahomet.
And Moſes had by Turcs his skin diſplaied.

argument.p: The three baleful battles, which Charls duke of Burgundy cauſteſly had with the Switſers

lg.l: Carolus Imperii male ſano ardore tumeſcens,
Lurida in Helvetios praelia ſponte ciet.
Charls with inſatiat rage of Reign inflamed,
Againſt the Switſers cauſleſs war mainrained.

l.hi: Crevit amor regni, quantum ipſa potentia crevit:
Limes nullus enim eſt ambitionis ei.

lg.l: So faſt grew lov of Reign, as power abounded,
For his ambition with no liſts was bounded.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Gentibus Helveticis tria praelia Carolus infert:
Sed tandem Italica proditione cadit.
Charles to th' Helvetians three ſet battles gav,
But by Italian treaſon cam t'his grav.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi:
Primo amiſit opes, dein arma, viroſ
que fideles:

Poſt vitam, famam, divitiaſ
que ſimul.

lg.l: At firſt his wealth, next Arms and men he loſt,
At laſt Life, Fame, Treaſur and al it coſt.

div.head: EPIG. XCVI. Reges in Africa commorientes.

argument.p: The 3 Kings who died at Alcazar (one by ſicknes, and two by ſword) in one day. Aug, 4. 1578.

lg.l: Dudum apud Alcazar tres una luce potentes

l.hi: Finierant Reges fata ſuprema ſimul.

lg.l: Three great kings in one day together of late
In torrid Barbary finiſhd their laſt Fate.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Tres varii Reges (Mahomet, Sebaſtian, Abdal.)

l.hi: Marte feroci uno competiere die.

lg.l: Three ſeveral kings by fierce war died away:
(Sebaſtian, Mahomet, Abdal) in one day.

argument.p: The 5 rival Potentats which claimed Portugals Crown by hereditary right of ſucceſſion.

lg.l:
Quin
que ſimul ſummis nervis Luſitanica regna

l.hi: Jure ſuo eximii competiere proci.

lg.l: Fiv great corrivals ſought at once by might
Portugals kingdoms, claiming them of right.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Rivales ſitrapae Lufitanica regna petebant,

l.hi:
Praetenſis titulis undi
que quin
que ſuis.

lg.l: Two Rival Peers for Portugal Crown contended:
And ech tru titles to the Realms pretended.

argument.p: The 2 great Perſons or Potentats who were baſely butchered by vile Varlets.

lg.l: Ta • tarei geminis homicidae caede nefanda

l.hi: Principibus ſubitam conſeruere necem.

lg.l: Two helliſh Homicids moſt impiouſly,
Two late great Princes murdred ſuddenly.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Morte duo Heroes (Princeps Aurantius, at
que
Francorum celebris Rex) periere mala.
Two warlik wights (Oranges Prince renowned,
And peerles French King) baſely were confounded.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Naſſaviae Princeps ſoloppo Gulielmus obibat:
Rex cultro Henricus Francicus ictus erat.
Prince Wiliam Naſsaw was vily piſtoled,
And Henry French king with knife murdered.

argument.p: The 2 Counts or Earls in the Netherlands that were unjuſtly beheaded.

lg.l: Sunt duo apud Belgas Comites qui abſciſsa ſecuri
Impie ab Hiſpanis colla habuere ſua.
Two Earls in Belgia by Spaniſh cruelty,
Their harmleſſ heads had ſtruck off wickedly.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Hornus & Egmondus Satrapae alto ſtemmate creti,
Perfidia Hiſpana comperiere duo.
Horn. Egmond two Peers of high proſapy,
Together died by Spaniſh perfidy.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Belgiaci Comites duo clari Egmundus & Hornus

l.hi: Addicti Hiſpalica fraude fuere neci.

lg.l: Egmond and Horn, two Belgic Counts of fame,
By Spaniſh guile were doon to death with ſhame.

argument.p: The 2 ſucceſſiv Kings of France, who were traitrouſly murdered by popiſh Proſelyts.

lg.l: Francorum duo ſunt, Henrici nomine, Reges

l.hi: Caeſi a Papicolis proditione mala.

lg.l: Two Kings of France, cald Henries traitrouſly
Were ſlain by Popiſh cut throats villany:

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Tertius Henricus, quartuſ
que Monarcha, cruentis

Gallorum a canibus caeſus uter
que fuit.
Henry the third and fourth, ſo cald by name,
French Monarchs both, to death by blood-hounds came

lg.head: Poſtſcript.

l.hi: Occinit haec Claſſis clariſſima geſta virorum,
Et res: Hiſtorick utilis ecce labor.

lg.l: Lo this work uſeful for Hiſtorians ſings
The glorious geſts of men, and famous things.

lg.head: Another.

l.hi: Si fis Hiſtoricus, forte haec tibi ſcripta placebunt:
Hic quae non alibi ſunt patefacta, patent.

lg.l: If thou be Hiſtoric, theſ perhaps wil pleaſ:
Things not found elſwher, are unveild in theſ.

lg.head: Another.

l.hi: Centuria hac mundi primaeva ab origine ducta eſt:
Omnigena Hiſtoria quae ſaturata ſcatet.

lg.l: From the worlds cradle is drawn this Century:
Which is fild with al kind of Hiſtory.

div.head: Heterogeneal Eſſays. The third Centuriat Claſsis of Heterogeneals, under three Columns.

argument.p: The 2 worlds (this and that to com) as they are uſualy ſtiled in Scripture.

l.hi: VIſibilis Mundus proprio cognomine Coſmos
Dicitur: aſt alim vita futura ſubit.

lg.l: This viſible World is properly ſo ſtiled:
But that hereafter life to com is filed.

l.hi: Dicitur hic Mundus, venturum dicimus Aevum:
Conditus hic dudum eſt, ſemper at illud erit.

lg.l: This is termd World, that to come Age we cal:
This whilom framd, but that ſhal be eternal.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Mundus viſibilis Coſmos cognomine conſtat:
Dici inviſibilis vita futura ſolet.

lg.l: The World ſo rightly cald is viſible:
But life to com wont to be termd inviſible.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Hic praſeus Mundus, venturus dicitur Aevum:
Hic perit, aſt illud tempus in omne manet.

lg.l: This preſent is cald World, that to com Age:
This periſh ſhal, that keep eternal ſtage.

argument.p: The 2 chief Creatures which God made after his own Image, indued with Intellect.

l.hi: Angelicas turmas Intellectu imbuit alto
Omnipotens: Homines ſed Ratione beat.

lg.l: God th'Angels Hoſt with Intellect endowed▪
But underſtanding Reaſon to Man allowed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Angelus eſt & Homo intellectu praeditus acri,

Quem bonitate ſua donat utri
que Deus.

lg.l: Angels and Men ſharp underſtanding hav,
Which God of 's goodnes to both Creatures gav.

argument.p: The 2 proto-Rebels againſt God, which were immediatly after the worlds creation

lg.l: Lucifer e Caelis in Tartara decidit ima:
E Paradiſo autem pulſus Adamus erat.
Lucifer from Heav'n fel into deepth of Hel:
But God from Paradiſe Adam did expel.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Lucifer Angelicas turmas abduxit in Orcum:
Et genus Humanum praecipitavit Adam.
Lucifer th' Angels troops into Hel drew,
And Adam mankind into perdition threw.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Lucifer e Coelo prae faſtu decidit alto:

Contemptu
que Dei lapſus Adamus erat.
Lucifer through pride fel from the Heavens high,
And Adam fel from God contemptuouſly.

argument.p: The 3 ſorts or acceptions of Heaven, as uſed in ſacred Scripture.

l.hi: Tres notat implicite, aut liquido ſcriptura remōſtrat
Eſſe ſuo Coelos ordine, ſacra Dei.

lg.l: Gods holy Writ implies three Heavens to be,
Or ſhews it in their Order evidently.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Aerium, Aetherium Coelum, Aeternum
que citantur.
Sic Coelum eſſe triplex pagina ſancta docet.

lg.l: Three Heavens are cited Aery, Ethereal,
(So holy Writ ſalth) and Gods ſeat Eternal.

argument.p: The 4 ſimple Elements (which concur to al compounds) as ſom late Writers define.

lg.l: Finxit Ariſtoteles Ignem quartum eſſe Elementum:

l.hi: Aſt alii ſtatuunt Aethera ſtare magis.

lg.l: Ariſtotle faind Fire fourth Element to be:
But others held the Sky more probably.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Bis duo ſunt Elementa, videlicet Aether & Aer,
Ʋnda & terra; unum quae ſtatuere Globum.

lg.l: Four Elements are, Sky and Air, as ſom take,
Water, and Earth; both which one Globe doo make

argument.p: The 3 Faculties of Free-wil (to wil ſimply, to wil wel, to wil il) by Nature & Grace.

l.hi:
Velle cui
que ſuum eſt, datur & bene velle beatis:
Contingit Reprobis nil niſi velle male.

lg.l: Al men Wil freely, But Good wel can wil:
The wicked can doo nought but wil naught ſtil.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Velle Homini commune bonum: ſed Gratia donat

Velle bonum: lapſus velle cui
que malum.

lg.l: To Wil's Mans common gift: but to Wil wel
Grace givs: al hav to Wil il ſince man fel.

argument.p: The 3 great Manſions alotted to Mankind, both here and hereafter.

l.hi: Sunt tria Filiolis hominum loca condita: Tellus,

Coelum, at
que Infernus; quae
que parata ſuis.

lg.l: Three places are prepar'd, Earth. Heav'n and Hel,
Wherin men here, and from henceforth muſt dwel.

lg.head: Aliter:

l.hi: Infernus Reprobis, Electis Coelica regna,
Humano generi Terra parata manet.

lg.l: For Reprobats Hel, Heavn for th'Elect prepared,
But Earth 'mongſt al the Sons of men is ſhared,

argument.p: The 3 Evils or Diſeaſes inevitably incident to al Mankind by corrupt Nature.

l.hi:
Tres ſunt morbi Hominū (geneſis, mors, vita) tribuſ
que
His fuit a Chriſto facta medela triplex.

lg.l: Mens birth, life, d • ath's a threefold malady:
And Chriſt to theſe brought triple remedy.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Tres Hominum morbi (Natalis, Vita
que , Morſ
que ),
Sunt generi Humano non fugienda mala.

lg.l: Mens three diſeaſes (birth, life, death) ſo ſtiled,
Are mankinds evils not to be declined.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi:
Sic Natali Homines, Vita
que & Morte redemit
Chriſtus: uti viſum eſt pro pietate ſua.

lg.l: So Chriſt by 's birth, life and death men redeemed:
As for his lov toward Mankind beſt ſeemed.

argument.p: The 3 inceſſant Adverſaries to Mankind, which giv no truce nor ceaſ to aſſail.

l.hi: Tres Hoſtes Hominum (Doemon, Caro, Mundus) ineſcant
Humana illecebris corda perenne ſuis.

lg.l: The World, Fleſh▪ Devil, Foes to Mankind be,
Which with their lures ſtil catch mens hearts al three

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Mundus adeſt, Caro ineſt, Cacodaemon undi
que circū eſt:
Sic generi Humano retia terna ſtruunt.

lg.l: World tempts without, Fleſh within, Fiend about.
So for Mankind they threefold Nets ſpread out.

argument.p: The 3 Creatures which God arraigned, accuſed and condemned in Eden garden.

l.hi: Vir, Mulier, Serpens, acciti a Judice ſummo,
Pro meritis poenas ſuſtinuere graeves.

lg.l: Man, Woman, Serpent, by th' higheſt Judg arraigned,
For their deſerts great puniſhments ſuſtained.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Serpens ſeduxit Mulierem, foemina Sponſum:
Quaelibet hinc poenas tres habuere pares.

lg.l: Satan th. Woman, her husband ſhe alured:
Hence they al three like puniſhments endured.

argument.p: The 2 wicked Perſons which conſulted to raiſ Samuels ghoſt from his place of reſt.

lg.l: Ʋt Samuelem agitet poſt mortem, Saul petit Endor:

l.hi: Conſulit & Sagam, quid fibi fata velint,

lg.l: Saul went to Endor Samuels ghoſt to ſee:
And from a Witch ſought what his Fates ſhould be.

argument.p: The 2 Harlots which ſtrov or ſcolded which of them ſhould enjoy the living Son.

lg.l: Jurgia Scorta duo coram Salomone gerebant,

l.hi: Cui vivum Puerum redderet ille ſuum.

lg.l: Two Harlots before Salomon ſcolded hard.
To whom the living child he would award.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Pro Puero Salomon litem inter ſcorta diremit,

l.hi: Et propriae Matri tradidit ille ſuum.

lg.l: Salomon a ſtrife 'twixt Strumpets two decided,
And t's right Mother the life Son aſſigned.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Jurgia Rex Salomon bina inter ſcorta reſolvit,

l.hi:
Filiolum Matri reſtituit
que ſuae.

lg.l: King Salomon 'twixt two Punks a brawl compoſed,
And the young Son to his tru Dame diſpoſed.

argument.p: The 2 principal Pagan Prophets that of old foreſhewed Chriſts coming in the fleſh.

lg.l: Gentiles Vates (Balaam & ter maximus Hermes)

l.hi: De Chriſti adventu mira tulere duo.

lg.l: Two Pagan Prophets (Balaam, Hermes) told
Of Chriſts firſt coming, wonders manifold.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Praedixit Balaam, ventura eſt ſtella Jacobi:
Paſtor at adveniet ter bonus, Hermes ait.
Balaam ſaid, a ſtat of Jacob ſhal riſe, Num. 24. 17. In Paemā dro.
A ſhepherd good ſhal com, ſaid Hermes wiſe.

argument.p: The 10 Pagan Propheteſſes of moſt mark, which foretold many things touching Chriſt

lg.l:
Varro alii
que decem celebres cecinere Sibyllas.

l.hi: Quae cogente Deo, ſacra futura ferunt.

lg.l: Varro and others ten chief Sibyls ſtated,
Who ſacred things inforc'd by God related.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Praeteritis avis variae viguere Sibyllae,
Quae de Chriſti aditu multa futura canunt.

lg.l: Ther hav bin diverſ women Wierds of old,
Which of Chriſts coming ſundry things foretold.

l.hi:
Foemineae extiterant Vates bis quin
que per Orbem
Chriſtum incarnandum quae ſtatuere Deum.

lg.l: Ten Prophetic women through the World ther were,
Who ſhewd that God-Chriſt ſhould in fleſh appear

argument.p: The 2 proper Parents of Mary the bleſſed Virgin commonly caled Mother of God.

lg.l: Eliachim genitor, Mater fuit Anna Mariae

l.hi:
Virginis, haud dubie verus uter
que Parens.

lg.l: Eli was Maries father, Anna Mother:
The Virgins both two Parents and no other.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Verus Eli pater eſt, mater verò Anna Mariae,
Maries tru Sire was Eli, but mother An,
(Virgin and Parent) who bore Chriſt God-man.

argument.p: The 21 moſt memorable Acts done by Chriſt or which concern him deſcribed in 56 verſes.

l.hi: De Chriſto, bis Acta decem recitantur & unum,
omnia carminibus dinumerata prius.

lg.l: Concerning Chriſt Acts twenty one are cited
In former Verſes being al recited.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Viginti at
que unum Chriſti Scriptura recenſet
Praecipua Acta prius, quae tribuuntur ei.

lg.l: The Scripture twenty one Acts hath imputed
To Chriſt of moſt mark, which are fore-computed.

argument.p: The 3 diverſ kinds of Chriſts coming (ad Homines, in Homines, contra Homines) cited by S. Bernard.

l.hi:
Chriſtus adeſt ad nos, in nos, contra
que malignos:
Sic Domini adventus dicitur eſſe triplex.

lg.l: Chriſt to us coms, into us, and 'gainſt the bad,
So ther's a threefold Advent, good, glad, ſad.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Dicitur Adventus Chriſti Incarnatio primus,
Alter ſanctificat, poſtremus judicat omnes.

lg.l: Chriſts coming in the fleſh men the firſt cal,
Next ſom to ſanctify, laſt to judg al.

argument.p: The 3 appearances or manifeſtations of our bleſſed Saviour Chriſt among men.

l.hi: Carne prius Chriſtus comparuit: inde ſupremo

lg.l: Judicio: in Caelis poſtmodo ſemper erit.
Chriſt firſt in fleſh appeerd: next at laſt day
Of Judgment: after ſhalbe in Heav'n alway.

argument.p: The 3 moſt miraculous mixtures or conjunctions at Chriſts Incarnation.

l.hi: Ʋt Deus eſt & Homo Chriſto conjunctus in uno:
Sic Virgo & Mater, ſic Caro & alma Fides.

lg.l: As God and Man in one Chriſt is combined:
So Maid and Mother, ſo Fleſh and Faith conſpired.

argument.p: The 3 marvelous or miraculous myſteries of Chriſts Conception and Birth.

l.hi:
Natum Virgo Deum peperit vera abſ
que dolore,
Clauſo Ʋtero, remanens intemerata Parens:

lg.l: A Virgin tru bore God t' hir Son ſans pain,
Hir Womb ſtil ſhut, pure Mother did remain.

argument.p: The 3 Theological Graces or ſpiritual Virtues, belonging to al Chriſtians.

l.hi: Gratia ſacra Fides, Spes, & Dilectio trina eſt,
Symbola Chriſticolis appropriata piis.

lg.l: Faith, Hope and Lov are goſpel-Graces three;
Sure marks that men Chriſts tru diſciples be.

argument.p: The 4 Parts and 6 Petitions of the Lords Praier preſcribed by Chriſt our Saviour.

lg.l:
Qui Pater in Coeloes, 1 Nomen tuum ubi
que ſacretur,
Adveniat 2 Regnum, 3 in terris tua ſancta Voluntas
Fiat, ut in Coelis: 4 Da nobis panem hodiernum:
Debita 5 dimittas, offenſa remittimus ut nos:
Nos 6 noli tentare, malo ſed libera ab omni.

l.hi:
Gloria nam
que tua eſt, Regnum, & ſine fine Poteſtas

lg.l: Our Father in Heav'n, thy name be ſanctified:
Thy kingdom com: thy wil on Earth complied,
As 'tis in Heav'n: Our daily bread us giv:
Forgiv our debts, as others we forgiv:
Let's not be tempted: but from il us deliver.
For thine is kingdom, Pow'r and Praiſ for ever:

lg.head: Epiphonema.

l.hi:
Chriſtus Diſcipulos orare docebat, eiſ
que ,

At
que aliis formam, quae modo ſcripta, dedit.

lg.l: Chriſt his Diſciples and others taught to pray,
And gav the fore-writ form which they ſhould ſay.

argument.p: The 12 ſeveral ſorts of men, who conſpired againſt Meſſias their king to kil him.

lg.l: Conjuratores varii de Gente Judaea,

l.hi: In Chriſtum Dominum retia multa ſtruunt.

lg.l: Som Jews of al ſorts ſundry nets did lay.
'Gainſt Chriſt the Lord, to take his life away.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Diverſi bis ſex homines, qui foedere nexi
Communi iu Chriſtum proditione ruunt.

lg.l: Twelv ſorts of men were link'd in Covenanty,
Who join'd 'gainſt Chriſt in one Conſpiracy.

argument.p: The 2 great luminaries and whol Heavens, which were covered with much darknes.

l.hi: Dum patitur Chriſtus, tres Sol & Luna per horas.
Lumine privantur lumina magna prius.

lg.l: The great lights Sun and Moon three hours did loſe
Their light, while Chriſt on Croſſ di's life depoſe.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sol, Luna, & Coeli facies tres orba per horas,
Dum Chriſtus patitur, lumine tota fuit.

lg.l: Sun, Moon was darkned, and the Heav'ns whol face:
While Chriſt hung on the Croſſ, for three hours ſpace

argument.p: The 2 miraculous metaphyſical darkneſſes of al lucid bodies which befel of old.

lg.l: Per triduum Aegypto fuit olim craſſa Caligo:

l.hi: Sed per tres horas major in Orbe fuit.

lg.l: In Egypt once thick darknes three dais held:
But for three hours one o're al th' Earth exceld.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Contigit Aegypto per Moſen ſpiſſa caligo:

l.hi: Major item Chriſtus cum crucifixus crat.

lg.l: Darkn • s in Aegypt by Moſes did betide:
And farther ſpred when Chriſt was crucified.

argument.p: The 2 chief and laſt Commandements commended by Chriſt after his Reſurrection.

l.hi: Edere Evangelium & Baptiſmi tingere lympha,

Diſcipulos mandat Chriſtus ubi
que ſuos.

lg.l: Chriſt his Diſciples bids to Catechize
Or teach through al the world, and to baptize.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ite, docete mco univerſas nomine Gentes,

Baptiſmc
que ſacro mergite, Chriſtus ait.

lg.l: Go, teach al Nations, ſaith Chriſt in my name:
And dip with ſacred Baptiſm in the ſame,

argument.p: The 3 diſtinct degrees or diverſ kinds of Chriſtian Martyrs cited by Authors.

l.hi: Re ſimul & voto; voto ſolummodo, non Re:

At Re Martyrium eſt, non quo
que ſponte triplex.

lg.l: In Fact and Faith, three ſorts of Martyry,
In Wiſh, not Act, in Deed, not Wil ther be.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l:
Actu Martyrium Stephanus, Voto
que
Joannes:

l.hi: Re ſolum Infantes ſuſtinuere ſuum.

lg.l: In Deed and Deſire Stephan Martry ſuffred,
John only in Vote, in Act the Babes were murdred.

argument.p: The 3 Orders, Degrees or Dignities in the Church of Chriſt among Clergy men.

l.hi:
Praesbyteri duplices ſunt, Suppoſiti at
que Regentes

Juris Apoſtolici: ſunt
que hiſce Diaconi adaucti.

lg.l: The ruling Elders and Subordinat,
With Deacons are by right Apoſtolat.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Juris Apoſtolici ſunt Suppoſiti at
que Regentes:

Hiſ
que miniſtrarunt curae quibus indiga turba.

lg.l: The ruling and inferior Elders be,
And thoſ that ſerv the Poor, of divine degree.

argument.p: The 10 primitiv Perſecutions of Chriſtian Profeſſors by Pagan Emperors of Rome.

l.hi: Chriſticolae variis agitati cladibus olim,
Pro Chriſti cauſa mille fuers modis.

lg.l: Chriſtians of old being much perſecuted,
Were thouſand wais for Chriſts Cauſ executed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Chriſticolas varia Romani morte Tyranni
Afficiunt, verum quòd coluere Deum.

lg.l: The Roman Tyrans Chriſtians undeſerved
Slu divers wais, 'cauſ they the tru God ſerved.

argument.p: The 4 ſeveral ſorts of men, which ſtriv to enter or poſſeſs the kingdom of Heaven.

l.hi:
Coelum alii rapiunt, alii mercantur, idem
que

Furtim alii acquirunt, pauperie
que alii.

lg.l: Som raviſh Heav'n by ſtrength; ſom buy with mony
Som ſteal it ſlily, ſom gain't by poverty.

argument.p: The 3 various ſemblances of forms and faces which Hypocrit • outwardly bear.

l.hi: Hypocritae ſunt veſte ut Oves; ſed dente malign •
Aſtuti Vulpes; & feritate Lupi.

lg.l: Hypocrits in clothing Sheep, in ſubtlety
Are biting Foxes; Wolfs in cruelty.

argument.p: The 5 ſorts of ſeeming repugnances in ſacred Scripture, which realy and exactly agree.

l.hi:
Quin
que modis adverſa ſibi Scriptura videtur:

Quae tamen eſt concors ſemper ubi
que ſibi.

lg.l: Scripture to 't ſelf ſeems fiv wais contrary;
Yet ſtil holds with it ſelf ſweet Harmony.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quae re conveniunt, ſibi diſſentire videntur,

Divini verbi dogmata quin
que modis.

lg.l: The Texts of Gods word which in truth agree,
Seem fiv wais diffring 'twixt themſelfs to be,

argument.p: The 30 holy men mentioned in the Bible, which made many peregrinations.

l.hi: Per varias terras iter effecere triginta
Sancti: quos memorant Biblia ſacra Dei.

lg.l: Through ſundry lands juſt thirty juſt men journied:
Whom ſacred Scriptures hav by name recorded.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Per Mare, per Terras Sancti, per Saxa profecti,
Quos Scriptura citat, ſunt triaconta Viri.

lg.l: Through Sea, Lands, Rocks thirty devout men went
Their journeys far, whom Scriptures repreſent.

argument.p: The 3 kinds of kingdom aſcribed to God (of Power, Grace, Glory) being in it ſelf but one.

l.hi: Sunt tria Regna Deo ſacris ſignata libellis,
Nominibus variis indigitata ſupra.

lg.l: Three kingdoms are to God in Scripture ſigned,
Which hav diſtinct names t' ech abov aſligned.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Diverſa ratione triplex, veruntamen unum
Regnum in Scripturis dicitur eſſe Dei.

lg.l: Gods kingdom one, but diverſin degree;
In ſacred Writ is threefold ſaid to be.

argument.p: The 2 Worlds (Superior and Sublunar) which ſhalbe conſumed with fire at laſt day.

l.hi:
Ille dies veniet, cum Mundus uter
que , ſupernus

Ʋſtus erit flammis inferior
que ſimul.

lg.l: The day wil com, when both worlds, that on high
And this beneath in flames ſhal jointly fry.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Coeli, Elementa, Homines, volucres, Animalia, piſces:

Omnia
que in cineres iginbus uſta ruent.

lg.l: Heavns, Elements, Men, birds, fiſhes, beaſts ſhal burn
With fire, and al things elſ int'aſhes turn.

div.head: EPIG. XXXVI. Ʋniverſi excidium ſeu diſſolutio.

argument.p: The 2 general means or wais, wherby this viſible Univerſ ſhalbe diſſolved or deſtroied

l.hi: Judicio extremo, vix tum renovabitur Orbis:
Sed potius (viſum eſt) igne peruſtus erit.

lg.l: The World at laſt day ſcarſ ſhal be renewed:
But rather (it ſeems) with fire muſt be conſumed.

lg.head: Aliter:

l.hi: Non renovatus erit Mundus, nec conditu • alter:
Sed potius flammis annihilatus erit.

lg.l: This World ſhal not renewed be, nor new founded,
But rather ſhal in flames be quit confounded.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Judicio exacto, nunquam renovabitur Orbis:
In nihilum recidet, quod fuit ante nihil.

lg.l: When Judgment ends, the world ne'r renew ſhal:
What's firſt of nought made, into nought ſhal fal.

argument.p: The 4 univerſal Religions compared together for extent of poſſeſſions and Profeſſors.

l.hi: Quatuor in Terris extant modo Relligiones:
Quae ſparſae in Mundi Climata cuncta jacent.

lg.l: Four new Religions on Earth extant are,
Which ly through al the worlds Climes ſcatred far.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ethnica Relligio, Mahometica, Chriſtica, necnon
Judaica in Terris obtinuere locum.

lg.l: Heathen Religion. Jewiſh, Chriſtian,
On Earth are current and Mahometan.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Chriſtica diſperſim, Mahometica, deinde Judaea
Relligio, necnon Ethnica in Orbe vigent.

lg.l: Chriſtians, Mahometiſts, Jews diſperſedly,
And Ethnics in the World bear up jointly:

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Maxima Paganis, Mahomiſtis proxima Mundi:
Chriſticolis minima eſt: Pars propria nulla Juda ••

lg.l: Pagans are Worlds moſt part, next Mahomets race,
Chriſtians the leaſt, Jews hold no proper place.

argument.p: The 3 chief Principles, wherby al points or propoſitions in any Science are beſt proved

l.hi: En tria ſunt (Senſus, Ratio, Scriptura) probandi
Principia, his mediis omnia clara patent.

lg.l: Three grounds of proof (Senſ, Reaſon, Scripture) are,
By which means al things appeer cleerer far.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Optima ſunt Senſus, Ratio, & Scriptura probata
Sic etenim punctum, qui tenet, omne probat.

lg.l: Senſ, Reaſon, and Gods Word the beſt Proofs be
For he the bel bears that ſo provs by three.

argument.p: The 3 ſet forms of public Prayers, antiently celebrated in Chriſtian Churches.

l.hi:
Temporibus primis inolevit ubi
que gradatim,
Inter Chriſtieolas, publica forma Precum.

lg.l: In the firſt times 'mongſt Chriſtians every wher
Began ſet forms of public Praier t'appeer.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Prima Liturgiae eſt tribus uſa Eccleſia formis,
Quae Fidei includunt dogmata multa ſuae.

lg.l: Three forms of Liturgy the firſt Church uſed,
Which divers doctrins of their Faith included.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Publicae apud veteres tres ſacris coetibus uſu
ſunt formae orandi; quas poſuere Patres.

lg.l: Three forms of ſet Praier th' old Fathers deviſed,
Which were at holy Aſſemblies exerciſed.

l.hi: Publiea forma Precum communi exercita coetu,
Doctrinas aperit, quas tenuere Patres.

lg.l: The Common Praier forms us'd in Church of old;
The Fathers doctrins of thoſ times unfold.

argument.p: The four famous learned Fathers of the weſtern Latin Church in ſet ſeniority of age.

l.hi: Quatuor Occiduo veteres memorantur in Orbe,
Doctrina celebres & pietate Patres.

lg.l: Four Fathers in the weſt world antiently,
Renownd for learning were and piety.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Bis duo Chriſticolae celebrantur in Orbe latino,
Artibus exculti qui viguere Patres.

lg.l: Four Chriſtian Fathers with learned Arts crowned.
Were chiefly in the Latin Church renowned.
Auguſtinus, & Ambroſius, Gregorius inde

Jeronymuſ
que
Patres quaſi lumina ſacra micabant.
The Fathers Auſtin, Ambroſ, Gregory,
And Jerom ſtand lik Lamps of ſanctity.

argument.p: The 66 books in holy Bible caled Canonical, to build Faith on, beſide 14 Apocryphal.

l.hi: Sexaginta & ſex Canone includuntur in ipſo
Libri: quos oculi • Pagina ſacra refert.

lg.l: Sixty ſix books in ſacred Canonly
Which th' holy Bible offers t' mens Ey.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Scripturae Canonem; ſex (praeter Apocrypha) complent

Sex
que ſimul decies Biblia ſancta Dei.

lg.l: Sixty ſix books the Scriptures Canon holds.
(Beſide Apocryphal) which Gods word unfolds.

div.head: EPIG. XLII. Promiſſa de Chriſti adventu.

argument.p: The 4 chief Prophecies and Promiſſes of Chriſts firſt coming into the World.

l.hi: Pollicita in veteri Teſtamento edita quaedam,
De Chriſto in terras adveniente patent.

lg.l: Som Promiſſes extant in th'old Teſtament,
Of Chriſts firſt coming into th' Earth are meant:

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Praevia Meſſiam Chriſtum, Promiſſa loquuntur
Tempore venturum quatuor eſſe ſuo.

lg.l: Four Promiſſes foregoing ſpeak out cleer,
That Chriſt Meſſias in 's time ſhal appeer.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Bis duo de Chriſti adventu data foedera primo,

Qui vere eſt Hominis, Filius, at
que Dei.

lg.l: Of Chriſts firſt coming four Covenants given be,
Who Gods and Mans Son is in verity.

argument.p: The 2 Imaginary Cities or Commonwealths of Policy Agethopolis and Babylon.

l.hi: FInguntur geminae Politiae Atlantide formae:
Ʋna referta bonis, altera plena malis.

lg.l: Two in Atlantic politic Stats are fained,
One ſtor'd with good men, with bad the other ſtained

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Incolae Agathopolis juſti, Babylonis iniqui:

l.hi:
Inſtruit hos Damon, ducit eoſ
que Deus.

lg.l: Agathopolis good men breeds, Babylon evil.
The firſt God prompts and guids, the laſt the Devil.

argument.p: The 3 uſual means or wais, which make mens actions nul or void in Law.

l.hi:
Quicquid agunt cedunt
que Homines formidine mortis
Sive minis, five in carcere: Lex prohibet,

lg.l: What men through deaths fear, threats or priſons pain
Do act and grant, the Law makes void or vain.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: irrita jure omni facta valore vacant.

lg.l: Facts which fear and threats wreſt, or Priſons aw
Compels, are void and of no force in Law.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Si qua facis, nullo pondere facta valent.

lg.l: What fear and Threats, or Priſon to paſs brought,
Such facts are of no weight, which force hath wrought

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi:
Irrita ſunt. cogant quod metus at
que minae.

lg.l: What fear, threats, or cold durance do conſtrain,
'Cauſ fear, threats, durance do inforce; are vain.

argument.p: The 3 diſtinct kinds or general heads of war, as Writers diverſificat them.

l.hi:
Cum contra externos Hoſtes, Regem, at
que Rebelles
Pagna agitur, Bellum dicitur eſſe triplex.

lg.l: When men 'gainſt foren foes, Rebels, and King
Doo fight; 'tis ſaid a triple war they bring.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Eſt Hoſtile genus Belli, Civile, Rebelle:
Bellandi ſpecies ſie ſolet eſſe triplex:

lg.l: Ther's Hoſtil, Civil, and Rebellious war:
So of warfare wontly three ſorts ther are.

argument.p: The 3 univerſal heads of Hiſtory, which are ſubdivided into ſeveral ſpecies.

l.hi: In tres Hiſtoria eſt generatim diſſita Claſſes:
Sic etenim in libris docta caterva docet,

lg.l: Hiſtory is in three general heads divided:
For ſo the learnd Cru in books hath decided.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Natura Hiſtoriae, Politia, Eccleſia donant
Nomina vulgatis partibus apta tribus.

lg.l: Hiſtory hath three parts cald in general.
Natural, Civil, Eccleſiaſtical.

argument.p: The 3 ſpecial ſupporters of Sciences, or ſuſtainers of liberal literature.

l.hi: Aſtruitur mediis veneranda Scientia ternis:
Artibus haec quaſi ſunt pabula ſacra bonis.

lg.l: Learning by three chief means is propagated,
Thef be as food to good Arts conſecrated.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Muſarum exiſtunt tria Suſtentacula: Sedes,
Proventus, necnon Bibliotheca ferax.

lg.l: The Muſes Place, Revenues of Piety,
Are learnings three helps with a large Library:

argument.p: The 3 renowned Inventions of late Ages, moſt behooful to mankind if wel uſed.

l.hi: Bombarda inventum Monachi, Verſoria Nautae.
Prelum Equitis: ſeclis qui viguere ſuis.

lg.l: Guns a dutch Frier, Sea-card a Sailor found,
Printing a Knight: men in their times renownd.

lg.head: Aliter:

l.hi: Artem invenit Eques (Muſis opus utile) Preli,

Bombardam Monachus, Nauta
que Pixidulam.

lg.l: A Knight found Printing the uſeful Muſes Art,
A Mone Guns, and a Sea-man the Sea-chart.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Tormentum Monachi, Generoſi inventio Prelum,
Sed Mercatoris Nautica Pixis erat.

lg.l: Guns was a Friers, Printing a Knights invention,
But Sea-card from a Merchant had commencion.

argument.p: The 52 chief Cities of Italy, with their particular characters in ſeveral Hexameters.

l.hi: Ʋnicus Hebdomadas quot continet integer annus,
Tot celebres urbes Itala terra tenet.

lg.l: So many Cities in Italy appeer
As weeks contained be in one whol yeer.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Italiae tot ſunt Ʋrbes, quot continet annus

l.hi: Hebdomadas: quarum nomina ſcripta patent.

lg.l: So many Cites, as one yeer weeks doth ſcore,
In Italy be, whoſ names are known of yore.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Italia infignes hoc tempore venditat urbes

l.hi: Quinquaginta duas, Oppida plura tenens.

lg.l: Italy now vaunts fifty two Cities of fame.
And Towns or Dorps ſans number of leſſ name:

l.hi: Quot vagus hebdomedas Annus, tot Gens habet urbes

lg.l:
Itala, praecipui nominis at
que nota.
So many Cities Italy hath by name,
As the yeer weeks, which are of chiefeſt fame,

l.hi: Quinquaginta duas Oenotria poſſidet urbes,
Percelebres: quarum nomina lata metris,

lg.l: Fifty two Cities Italy hath poſſeſſed
Of chief note, whoſ names are in verſ expreſſed.

argument.p: The 3 Languages derived from Latin, which are neerly allied one to another.

lg.l: Tres Linguoe Europae celebres modo finibus extant,

l.hi: Queis primum tribuit lingua Latina genus

lg.l: Thr • e famous Toungs in Europ now are found,
Which were from Latin language firſt compound.

Italica a Latio, necnon Hiſpanica, item
que

Francica lingua ſuum mutuat uſ
que genus.
Italian Spaniſh, and French toung al three,
From Latin language draw their pedegree.

argument.p: The 4 Initiations of a natural Day, at different times among Nations.

l.hi: Principia inſtituunt Gentes diverſa diei:
Quod faciunt varia pro ratione ſua.

lg.l: Beginnings of Day diverſ Naations take,
Which they for ſeveral reaſons ſo do make.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Mane Diem incipiunt aliqui, ſub veſpere quidam,

lg.l:
Nocte Angli media, meridie
que alii.
Som gin the day at morn, ſom at Twilight:
Others at high-noon, Engliſh at Mid-night.

argument.p: The 10 Scales or Stages (caled climacterical) into which mans life is ſorted.

l.hi: Aetates Hominis, per ſeptem quoſlihet annos
Antiqui Authores conſtituere decem.

lg.l: Old Authors ten Ages to Man aſſigned:
Wherof ech is by ſevn ſet yeers divided.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Aetatum decades Homini aſcribuntur amuſſim:
Quarum de ſeptem coaleſcit quaelibet annis.

lg.l: Sevn Decads or ten Sevenets of yeers,
In ech ſet Age ſevn of mans life appeers.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi:
Vitae ſcala decem greſſus complectitur at
que

Ex his ſeptem annos ordine quiſ
que tenet.

lg.l: The Ladder of our life ſevn ſteps contains,
And ech in order juſt ſevn yeers retains.

lg.head: Epiphonema.

l.hi: Eſt Homo bulla levis, Roſa ſemper labilis Aetas,

Forma Flavilla micans, umbra
que vita fugax.

lg.l: Man's a light bubble, Age a faling Flour,
Beauty bright blaſt, Life ſhade of flying hour.

argument.p: The 10 diſtinct degrees of women in the world, as commonly computed by men.

l.hi:
Diſtincti bis quin
que gradus numorantur amuſſim

Foeminei Sexus, Ordine qui
que ſuo.

lg.l: Ten diſtinct Orders juſtly numbred be,
Of Female ſex, ech one in their degree.

argument.p: The 3 common Peſts of lewd licencious Youths, which procure their perdition.

l.hi: Damna Juventutis tria ſunt teterrima mollis,
Quae mores vitiant: Alea, Vina, Venus.

lg.l: Diet, Drink, and Drabs moſt baleful banes al three
Of tender youth, which mar their maners, be.

l.hi: Alea, Vina Venus ſunt peſſima damna Juventoe,
Et Peſte omnimodo deteriora tria.

lg.l: Dice, Drink, and Drabs Youths worſt of evils be,
And every way worſ then the Plague al three.

argument.p: The 3 ſorts or kinds of Nobility, which are common or current in moſt Countries.

l.hi:
Naſcitur, & precio datur, eſt quo
que quaeſta labore
Nobilitas: triplex ſic Data, Nata, Sata eſt.

lg.l: Nobility's born, bought, and acquir'd by merit,
So three ſorts be Got, Giv'n, and what w' inherit.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Nobilitas nata eſt, pretio data, parta periclo:
Sed praeſtat proprio marte patratus honos.

lg.l: Som buy Nobility, ſom born ſo, ſom inherit.
But honor's beſt, whats won by perſonal merit.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Sanguine quid geſtis? Nummis incumbere turpe eſt:
Praecellit propria Gloria parta manu.

lg.l: Boaſt not of blood: 'tis ſhame on pelf to ſtand:
Glory excels that's got by ones proper hand.

argument.p: The 2 half Spheres of the Geographic Globe dividing it into two equal parts.

l.hi: Dividit in geminas Aequator Praedia terrae

Partes, quae reſident inter utrum
que Polum,

lg.l: Into two parts th'Equator doth divide
The Earth, which doo betwixt both Poles reſide.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Continet in medio bina Haemiſphaeria Coelum,
Et Terra in partes ſcinditur haſce duas.

lg.l: Heav'n doth two Hemiſpheres in midſt contain:
And th'Earth divided is into thoſ twain.

argument.p: The 2 parts or pa • cels of the Earth neer both Poles, which men cannot convenienlty inhabit.

l.hi: Non eſt vitalis, niſi ſit bene vivere, Vita:

Invitam Vitam degere, nam
que mori eſt.

lg.l: Life is not lifely, ſav to liv cheerfully:
For to lead a loathd life, is but to dy.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Plaera
que pars Terrae parſſim hic & ubi
que vizitim
Incolitur: ſed pars non habitanda jacet.

lg.l: Moſt part of th'Earth men dwel in here and ther:
But ſom part lies not habitable elſwhere:

lg.head: Alias

l.hi:
Verſus utrum
que Polum eſt glacialis inhoſpita Tellus:
Qua nequeunt homines belle habitare diu.

lg.l: Neer both Poles th'Icy Earth's inhoſpitable:
Which cannot long by men be habitable.

argument.p: The 10 firſt voyages attēpted or atchived after invention of ſailing by the Loadſtone.

l.hi: Cum fauſto auſpicio fuit edita Nautica pixis,
Capere hinc varii velificare Viri.

lg.l: When Nautic Compaſſ was found happily,
Som men began to ſet their ſails therby.

l.hi: Magnetis Flavius quum primum invenerat uſum,
Longe & late homines vela dedere decem.

lg.l: So ſoon as Flavy the Load ſtones uſe found out,
Ten Sea men far and wide ſet ſail about.

argument.p: The 3 principal reputed Rulers of the vaſt Univerſ, as Poets antiently predicated.

l.hi: Tres ſuperi Satrapae toto dominantur in Orbe,
Quos priſci veluti Numina ſacra colunt.

lg.l: Three ſuprem States in the whol world are ſcored,
Whom Pagans as three Deities adored.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Jupiter in Coelo, in
que
Solo regit omnia Caeſar,

Neptunuſ
que Salo: ſic vaga fama canit.
Jove rules in Heav'n, Caeſar on Earth bears ſway,
Neptune at Sea; ſo flying fame doth ſay.

argument.p: The 16 Heroic Hexamiter verſes, containing 32 Sevenets in general, two in ech verſ.

l.hi:
SƲnt ſeptem in Coelis Pleiades: totidem
que Planetae:

Hebdomadae ſeptem Feriae: totidem
que Triones.

lg.l:
Monticuli ſeptem Romae: totidem quo
que Reges:
Artes ingenuae ſeptem: totidem oſtia Nili.

Septem Thebarum portae: totidem
que metalla:

l.hi: Septem Orbis Nautae: totidem magnalia mundi.

lg.l: Saxona Regna olim ſeptem: tot numina Templis:
Septem Saxonici Reges: totidem Anglica mira.
Septem Ʋrbes vatis: Proceres tot Perſia clamat:

l.hi: Tot Satrapae Imperii: totidem Graii Sapientes.

lg.l: Europae Reges: Capitalia crimina ſeptem:

l.hi: Cornua ſeptem Agni: tot Protodiaconi inuncti.

Vindictae Phialae ſeptem: totidem
que Sigilla:
Tot rutilae Stellae: candelabra & aurea ſeptem.

Agni ſeptem oculi: totidem
que Chariſmata ſacra:

Tot Dormitores habiti: totidem
que Agoniſtae.

lg.l: In Heavn ſevn Pleiads, and ſevn Planets be,
Sevn dais of a week, ſevn Trions bright to ſee,
Sevn Hils at Rome, Sevn kings likwiſe of old,
Sevn l • beral Arts, ſevn mouths of Nile were told,
Thebes had ſevn Gates, ſevn ſimple metals are.
The Worlds ſevn Sailors, and ſevn wonders rare.
Sevn Saxon Realms, ſevn Gods their Temples hanted
Sevn Saxon kings, England 7 ſtrange things vanted
Homers ſevn Cities, Perſias Princes ſevn.
Sevn Mootmen th'Empire had, Greece ſevn wiſemen.
Sevn kings of Europ, ſevn ſins cald Capital.
The Lamb ſevn horns, ſevn Deacons principal.
Sevn Phials of Gods wrath, ſevn Seals are told,
Sevn ſparkling ſtars, ſevn Candleſticks of gold.
The Lambs ſevn eyes, ſevn gifts of th' holy-Ghoſt.
Sevn Sleepers held, ſevn Champions famous moſt.

l.hi: Bis octo hac ſerie numerantur Carmina ſupra,
In quibus hic totidem duplicata Epigrāmata conſtant.

lg.l: Sixteen ſlight verſes abov writ are ſet here,
In which twiſe ſixteen Eſſais doo appeer.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sexdecim habent verſus hi ſeptenaria ſparſim,

Talia plura quibus licet addere cui
que Poetae.

lg.l: Theſ ſixteen verſes hav Sevnets ſcatringly,
Wherto ech Poet may more like apply.

argument.p: The 7 Stars ſited in the Ey of ſign Taurus termed Pleiades, Vergiliae, & Hyades.

l.hi:
Septem Oculo Tauri poſitae Pleideſ
que vocatae
Stant Stellae aſt • oculis Hominum ſex amodo viſae.

lg.l: In the Buls Ey ſevn Stars cald Pleiads cleer
Stand, but ſix only to mens Eys appeer.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Halcyone, Aſterope, Taygete, Electra, Celaene,
Cum Maia & Merope ſunt ſeptem Pleiades Aſtra.

l.hi: Maia, Electra, Celen, Tayget, Merope,

lg.l: Make the 7 Stars, with Halcyon and Aſterope.

argument.p: The 7 Planets or Errones (Vagrants) ſet in order of their orbicular ſtations downward

l.hi: Orbibus Errantes diſtinctis ordine Stellae

Sunt ſeptem in Coelis poſitae, dictae
que Planetae.

lg.l: Sevn wandring Stars in diſtinct Spheres are framed,
With order in the Heavens, and Planets named.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Saturnus, Jupiter, Mars, Sol, Venus, Hermes & Ima,
Luna Planetarum ſeptem numerō ordine complent.
Saturn, Jov, Mars, Sun, Venus, Merc'ry, Moon,
Stand ſevn in order, til the world be doon:

argument.p: The 7 dais of a week denomined by Planets, ech of which reigns the firſt hour of his own day.

lg.l: Luna die primo, Mars, Hermes, Iupiter, inde
Clara Venus, Saturnus, Sol, propriam inchoat horam

l.hi: Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jov, Venus, Saturn, Sun,

lg.l: Ech the firſt hour of his own day begun

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Cynthia, Mars, Hermes Jupiter, Venus alma, Saturnus.
Et Sol Hebdomadae dant nomina nota diebus.
The week dais from ech Planet take their name,
Which Artiſts for fit ends in ſuch ſort frame.

argument.p: The 7 Stars ſtiled Trions, ſited in the great Bear (greecly Arctos) cald Charlmaigns Wain.

lg.l:
Septem Aquilone micant Stellae, dict •
que
Triones

l.hi: Quae procul extrema diffundunt lumen in Arcto.

lg.l: Sevn Stars ſhine in the North, and Trions hight,
Which in the great Bear far off caſt their light.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Septem Stellae inſunt Urſa majore Triones,

l.hi: Dictae: quae noctu rutilanti j • bare fulgent.

lg.l: In the great Bear are ſevn ſtars Trions hight,
Which with bright beams moſt cleerly ſhine by night

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Arctica ſtellarum ſtat concameratio ſeptem,

lg.l: Quae Caroli Plauſtrum vulgato nomine conſtat.
Sevn Stars ſtand Northly in ſet cluſters framed,
Which are by vulgar term Charlmaigns wain named

argument.p: The 7 Hils on which Romulus firſt founded his City, ſince extended to Campus martius.

lg.l: Romulus excelſae primordia condidit Ʋrb • s,

l.hi: Quae fuerat ſeptem bene conſita collibus olim.

lg.l: Romulus at firſt a lofty City foun • ed,
Which whilom was with ſev'n Hils wel ſurrounded.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Collis Aventinus, Capitolius, at
que Quirinus,

Janiculus, Velius, Tarpeius, Eſquileuſ
que .

lg.l: Mount Aventin, Capitolin, and Quirin,
Janicle, Velian, Tarpeian, Eſquilin.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Hi ſunt monticuli vibrante cacumine tecti,

lg.l: In quibus alta fuit priſco aevo condita Roma.
Theſ were the Hils, with brandiſh'd tops high mounted,
On which proud Rome in priſtin age was founded.

argument.p: The 7 firſt Kings which reigned at Rome for 244 yeers ſpace, after the foundation was laid.

l.hi: Septeni Reges moderamina ſumma tenebant,

lg.l: Temporibus priſcis per plurima ſecula Romae.
Sevn Monarchs held Romes ſuprem Suveraignty;
For many ages in her firſt Infancy:

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Romulus, hinc Numa, Hoſtilius, tum Martius Ancus;

Ta • quinius, Priſcus, poſt Servius, at
que
Superbus.

Romulus Numa Tullus
• hen Ancus
•• igned,
Tarquin the firſt, Servius proud, Tarquin ended.

argument.p: The 7 learned liberal Arts ſtiled ſacred, to ſeclud them from Mechanical or ſervil Trades.

l.hi: Artes ingenuae ſeptem cognomine ſacrae,
Muſarum impenſe celebrantur in Aedibus almis.

lg.l: Sevn learned liberal Arts ſacred ſirnamed,
Are in the Muſes Palaces chiefly famed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Grammatici, Aſtronomi, Logici, Rhetores, Geometrae,
Muſici, Arithmetici ſeptem Artes ordine conflant.

lg.l: Sevn Arts are Grammar, Rhetoric Geometry,
Logic, Arithmetic, Muſic, Aſtronomy.

argument.p: The 7 Out-lets or Mouths of Nile into the midland Sea, but 3 choked up. The Heracleot, Balvitic, Schonitic, Patinic, Canitic, Mendeſium, Peluſiacum.

lg.l: Oſtia ſeptem habuit Nilus ſeptemfluus olim.

l.hi: Sed tria ſunt horum coeno oppediente repreſſa.

lg.l: Sevn mouths had ſevn fold flowing Nile of old,
But three of them ſince ſhut with muddy mould,

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Septem Fama refert antiquitus oſtia Nili,

l.hi: Quorum extincta diu ſunt nomina ſcripta ſuperne.

lg.l: Sevn antient mouths of Nile Fame doth reſound,
Whoſ names long ſince extinct, are abov writ found.

argument.p: The 7 Gates of Thebes City (caled Heptopolis) built by Cadmus in Baeotia of Greece

lg.l: Sunt Thebis ſeptem Portae queis nomina deſunt,

l.hi: Nec poterant ideo deſcribi verſibus hiſce.

lg.l: Thebes had 7 Gates, whoſ names are not promulged,
Nor can therfore in theſ Rythms be divulged.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Decapoli Thebis Portae olim quatuor & tres.
Quae fuit a Cadmo circundatae Principe muris.
Thebes ſevnfold City of old had ſevn Gates founded,
Which by Prince Cadmus was with wals ſurrounded.

argument.p: The 7 pure, ſimple Metals ſans mixture, wher of al others are compounded.

l.hi: Viſceribus Terrae latitant ſeptena Metalla,
Septenos referunt quae proprietate Planetas.

lg.l: In th' Earths bowels ſevn ſimple Metals ly,
Which to ſevn Planers are like in property.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Aes, Plumbū, Argentum, ſtannum his pretioſius Aurum,
Ferrum Hydrargyrium ſunt ſeptem pura Metalla.

lg.l: Braſſ, Tin, Lead, Silver, Gold more noble far,
Iron, Quicſilver ſevn pure Metals are.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Septem foſſilia exiſtunt immixta Metalla,
Quorum non recitanda patent agnomina ſupra.

lg.l: Sevn unmixt foſſil Metals are forecited,
Whoſ names bo • -filed muſt not be recited.

argument.p: The 7 famous Sailers or Seafarers, who gav a girdle to the Geographic Globe.

l.hi: Chriſticolae ſeptem Terram ambivere globoſam,
Quorum fama ſonat Gentes bene nota per omnes.

lg.l: 7 Chriſtian ſeamen th' earths Globe compaſſd round
Whoſ wel known fam doth through al nations ſound

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Prima Magellani ratis eſt, quae circuit Orbem,
Drake, Candiſh, Weert, Noort, Spilbergen, poſtmedo Schouthen,
Magellans ſhip was firſt which the world compaſt,

l.hi: Drake Candiſh, weert, noort ſpilbergen, Schouten laſt

argument.p: The 7 moſt magnificent Monuments, commonly caled the Worlds wonders.

l.hi: Structurae celebres aliquando fuere per Orbem
Septem, quas Vulgus vocitat miracula Mundi.

lg.l: Sevn ſtatly ſtructures ſomtim were far famed,
Which vulgar ſort the Worlds ſevn wonders named.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Septem magnifica exiſtunt monumenta Viritim,
Quae vulgo vocitant ſeptem magnalia Mundi.

lg.l: Sevn coſtly monuments al abroad doo ly,
Which the Worlds wonders men term vulgarly.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Pyramides, Pharos, Jovis, Icon, maenia Babel,

Templum Epheſi, Tumulus Cariae, Rhodiuſ
que , Coloſſus
Theſ wondrous works of Art and vaſt expenſ.
Great Monarchs made for their magnificence.

lg.head: Epiphonema.

l.hi: Corpora noſtra mori, nihil admirabile conſtat.
Cernimus exemplis altiſſima moenia fundi.

lg.l: 'Tis not worth wonder, that our Bodies dy:
Exemples ſhew high Towers in duſt doo ly.

lg.head: Aliud.

l.hi: Corpora noſtra mori divino jure neceſſe eſt:
Vertitur in cineres, quod primo ex pulvere factum eſt.

lg.l: Our bodies by divine Decree dy muſt,
That t'aſhes turns, which firſt was made of duſt.

argument.p: The 7 Kingdoms or Heptarchy, which the Engliſh Saxons raiſed on the ruins of extruded Brytans.

l.hi: Saxonici Satrapae, quos conduxere Brytanni,
Hoſpitibus pulfis, ſeptem ſibi Regna ſtruebant.

lg.l: The Saxon Nobles, whom poor Brytans hired,
Their Hoſt sdriv'n out, ſevn Realms to them acquired

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Angli Orientales, Auſtrales Saxones, & Kent:
Saxones ex Ortu, Northumbria, Mercia, Weſtſex.
Theſ Saxon ſevn Realms in Latin Verſ named,
Cannot ſo wel in Engliſh Rythms be framed.

div.head: EPIG. LXXIV. Saxonum Numina ſeu Idola.

argument.p: The 7 Idol Gods of our Saxon Anceſtors, ſet up in their Temples by turns ech day.

l.hi: Ethnica Saxonicae ſtatuebant numina Gentes,
Quae ſeptem Hebdomadae poſuere colenda diebus.

lg.l: Sevn Ethnic Gods the Saxons kept in ſtore,
Which in the weeks ſevn dais they put t' adore.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Cynthia, Tuiſco. Woden, Jupiter, Fria, Satterus & Sol

l.hi: Saxona ſunt ſeptem in Templis Idola colenda.
Moon, Tuiſco, Woden, Thor, Fria, Sater, Sun,

lg.l: Were Gods in Temples ſet t' hav worſhip doon.

argument.p: The 7 firſt Founders of ech Saxon kingdom in the Heptarchy of South-Brytain.

l.hi: Saxonici Proceres Brytonum in ditionibus olim,
Septem Regnorum fundamina prima locabant.

lg.l: Whilom the Saxon Peers in Brytiſh Nation,
Of ſevn ſmal kingdoms laid the firſt foundation.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Erchenwin, Hengiſt Ella & Cerdiccus, & Uffa,
Ella-Ida, Crida ſuo ſic ſunt cognomine dicti.
Theſ be the firſt ſevn Kings plac'd prepoſtrouſly,
Which firſt ſet up the Saxon Heptarchy.

l.hi: Sunt noſtri hi proavi, ſignati nomine tali,
Saxona quae ſeptem jamdudum Regna parabant.

lg.l: Thoſ were our Engliſh Anceſtors ſo named,
Who the ſevn Saxon kingdoms long ſince framed.

argument.p: The 7 Saxon kings, who firſt becam converts to Chriſtianity in ech Realm of the Heptarchy.

l.hi: Saxonici Heptarchae zelo & pietate repleti,
In propriis regnis Chriſtum coluere ſideles.

lg.l: The Saxon Heptarchs fild with zele and piety.
In their own Realms worſhipd Chriſt faithfully.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ethelbert, Edwin, Ethelwolf, Peda, Seberius,
Kingils, Redwaldus Chriſti documenta colebant.
Thoſ forenamd Kings firſt brought Chriſtianity
Into ech Realm to be taught generaly.

argument.p: The 7 natural Monuments ſtiled Englands wonders, as ſom ſtate them; but others otherwiſe.

l.hi: Naturae propria exiſtunt monumenta ſtupenda
Anglica, quae vulgo vocitant miracula ſeptem.

lg.l: Ther be ſom works of Nature much admired,
Which Englands wonders vulgarly are ſtiled.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Bathoniae, thermae, Peaki, Barathrum, Specus. Antrum
Buxtonae aquae, ſpelunca Ochiana, chorea gigantum
Hot baths at Bathe, Peaks gulf, Elden-hole, Den,
Buxtons wels, Ochy-hole, Stone-hinge reard by men

argument.p: The 7 chief Cities or Stats, which contend to be Homers country or Birth place by right.

l.hi: Septem urbes Vatis patriam jure eſſe popoſcunt,
Sed reliquae proprium non jus habuere dicatum:

lg.l: Sevn Stats by right claimd Homers home to be
But al the reſt had no juſt property.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Ʋrbes praecipuae dictae haeſunt nomine Vatis, Phocaea.
Cuma, Chios, Colophon, Samos, Ithaca, Smyrna,
Homers chief Cities which to b'his country clamed,
Are in the Latin verſ laſt abov named.

argument.p: The 7 Princes of Perſian blood roial, extracted from the firſt Achaemenian family.

l.hi: Septeni Satrapae Regali e ſanguine creti,

lg.l: Perſica poſt obitum Cambyſis regna petebant.
Sevn Perſic Peers from royal blood deſcended,
After Cambyſes for the Realms contended.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ottanes, Aſphatines, Gobrias, Megabyſus, Hidarnes,

at
que
Intaphernes, ſed regna Darius inibat.
The ſix firſt Princes for the kingdom ſtrained,
But it by a ſlight horſtrick Darius gained.

argument.p: The 7 Princes or Potentats of Germany, who hav Suffrages in electing the Emperor.

lg.l: Venditat illuſtres Satrapas Germania ſeptem,

l.hi: Quos penes Imperii ſuprema potentia perſtat.

lg.l: Sevn potent Princes are in Germany,
Who ſway the Empires chief Authority.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi:
Tres Laici Imperii, de Clero tot
que ſtatuti

Sunt Electores, praeter
que hos Arbiter alter.

lg.l: Three Laics and three Clergy men deſigned,
Th' Emperor chuſe, beſide one Umpire ſigned.
Moguntinenſis, Treverenſis, Colonienſis,

Marchio, dux, Princeps Laici ſunt, rex
que
Bohemus.
Biſhops of Meutz, Trierſ, Colein, Clerics three,
Marquis, Duke, Prince, and Bohems King Laics be.

argument.p: The 7 contemporar Sages or Wiſemen of Greece, famous in their generation.

l.hi: Eximios aluit Sapientes Graecia ſeptem,

lg.l: Ante Cyri Imperium, qui uno viguere ſub aevo.
Greecs ſevn Sages for wiſdom much praiſed,
Floriſhd at once, yer Cyrus th'Empire raiſed.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Cleobulus, Chylon, Solon, Bias, & Periander,

Pittacus at
que
Thales Graii ſeptem Sapientes:
The ſevn wiſe men of Greece far and neer famed,
Are in the Larin verſes rightly named.

argument.p: The 7 mighty Monarchs or Soveraign Chriſtian Princes in Europ.

lg.l: Europae ſeptem retinent diademate culti,

l.hi: Sub ditione ſua tantummodo Regna Monarchae.

lg.l: Sevn only Monarchs deckd with Crowns of Gold,
Al Europs kingdoms in their power doo hold.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Hiſpanus, Polanus, Regna Europaea capeſſunt.

l.hi: Empror, French King, Brytiſh, Dane, Sweden, Spain,

lg.l: And Polac, Europs chiefeſt Realms retain.

argument.p: The 7 capital or head-ſins (commonly caled Deadly) being the main roots of al the reſt

l.hi: Peccata (improprio mortalia nomine dicta)
Indigitate apte ſeptem Capitalia conſtant.

lg.l: Sevn Sins improperly termed mortal
Ther be, which aptly are cald capital.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Invidia, Ebrietas, Gula, Ira, Ignavia, Faſtus,
Ardor, Avaritiae, Mala ſunt Capitalia ſeptem.

lg.l: Drunkennes, Envy, wrath, Sloth, Gluttony,
Avarice and Pride are ſevn Sins cald deadly.

argument.p: The 7 Horns of the holy Lamb which ſtood Rev. 5. 6. in midſt of the Throne among the 24 Elders.

lg.l: Dum fuit in Pathmo meditans divina Joannes;

l.hi: De coelo Agnus ei Viſus, cui Cornua ſeptem.

lg.l: While John at Patmos was in mediation;
A ſevn-horn'd Lamb appeer'd from Heav'n in Viſion.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Septem oculos habuit, tot Mundi ab origine caeſus
Cornua; qui Librum in Coelis apperiverat, Agnus.

lg.l: Sevn Eys the Lamb from Worlds beginning ſlaied
And ſevn Horns had, who a Book in Heavn diſplaied

argument.p: The 7 primitiv Proto-Deacons, ordeined by Acts 6. 5. the Apoſtles laying on of hands.

l.hi: Caetus Apoſtolicus ſeptem inſervire Miniſtros
Elegit, ut Mſenas Eleemoſynaſque refundant.

lg.l: Th' Apoſtles ſevn ſubſervient Deacons choſe
To ſerv the Tables, and Mens Alms diſpoſe.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Parmenas: Procorus: Stephanus: Timon: atque Philippus:
Nicanor: Nicholaſque fuere Diaconi inuncti.
Thoſ forenam'd Deacons were firſt conſecrated,
By laying on of hands for uſes ſacred.

argument.p: The 7 Phials of Gods Wrath or Vengeance, Rev. 16. which 7 Angels poured out on the Earth.

l.hi: Divinae Angelicus Chorus irae pocula ſeptem
In Pelago, Sole, & Terris, Aqua, & Aere fudit.

lg.l: Sevn Angels ſevn Cups of Gods wrath poured out
On Sea, Sun, Earth, Water, Air al about.

argument.p: The 7 Seals of a ſacred Book, which he that Rev. 5. Rev. 6. ſat on the Throne held in his right hand.

l.hi: Septem habuit liber in Coelis occluſa ſigilla:
Quae tenuit ſuper Aſtra ſedens altiſsima dextra.

lg.l: A Book in Heav'n had ſevn Seals cloſly ſeald,
Which he that ſat on Throne in's right hand held.

lg.head: Aliter.
