l.hi: Eſt Liber in Coelo viſus, ſeptemque ſigillis
Signatus, quem ſolum eſt Agnus recludere dignus.

lg.l: A Book in Heav'n was ſeen with ſevn Seals fitted,
Which the Lamb ſoly t' open was admitted.

argument.p: The 7 bright Stars which the Son of Man held in his right hand, being the 7 Angels Rev. 1. 20. of the 7 Churches.

lg.l: Septem Aſiae Stellae (dictaeque fuere Miniſtri)

l.hi: Quas Chriſtus tenuit dextra, fulgore micabant.

lg.l: Sevn Stars of th'Aſian Churches (Angels ſtiled)
Which Chriſts right hand held forth, moſt brightly ſhined

argument.p: The 7 golden Candleſticks, in midſt of which Rev. 1. 13. Chriſt the Son of Man appeered to John.

lg.l: Candelabra videt ſomno ſeptem aurea Joh' • nes:

l.hi: In quorum medio caetu ſacer extitit Agnus.

lg.l: Sevn golden Candleſticks John ſaw in ſleep:
'Midſt which th'holy Lamb his abode did keep.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Aurea ſunt ſeptem Candelabra viſa Joanni:
Quae ſacros Aſiae caetus retulere minoris.
John ſevn gold Candleſticks in Viſion veiwed:
Which leſſer Aſia's Churches t' his fight renewed:

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Pergama: Smyrna, Epheſus: Philadelphia: Laodicea:
Sardis: & Thyatira Aſiae ſunt lumina ſeptem.
Sevn Aſian Lights, Smyrna, Sardis, Philadelphia,

l.hi: Pergamus, Thyatire, Epheſus, Laodicea.

argument.p: The 7 Eys of the foreſaid ſevn-hornd Lamb. ſlain for the ſins of the World or al Mankind. Rev. 5. 6. 9

l.hi: Luminae viſus erat ſeptem ſacer Agnus babere,
Pro nobis caeſus primaeva ab origine Mundi.

lg.l: Sevn Eys had th' holy Lamb appeeringly,
For us ſlain from the Worlds Nativity.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Agni ſeptem Oculi tot Pneumata ſacra remonſtrant:
Quae Deus emiſit per ſingula climata Terrae,

lg.l: The Lambs ſevn Eys ſevn Spirits repreſent:
Which God to al Climes of the Earth forth ſent.

argument.p: The 7 ſpecial Virtues or ſpiritual Graces, caled the Gifts of the holy Ghoſt.

l.hi: Spiritui ſancto ſunt ſacra Chriſmata ſeptem
Propria: quae Chriſtus dimiſſa Fidelibus indit.

lg.l: Sevn Heav'nly Graces by th' holy Ghoſt infuſed,
Chriſt hath into al faithful hearts diffuſed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sancto Spiritui ſignata Chariſmata ſ • ptem:
Queis hominum a Domino ſaturantur corda bonorū

lg.l: Ther be ſevn Graces ſigned to the Spirit:
Which good Mens hearts inſpir'd by God inherit.

argument.p: The 7 famous Sleepers ſo fained, vulgarly ſtiled in Almanacks, the ſevn Sleepers.

l.hi: Temporibus priſcis, uti garrula fama refingit;
Septem annis variis, Decio feriente, quierunt.

lg.l: Sevn Men of old ſevn Sleepers cal'd by name,
While Decius ſlu, ſlept ſundry yeers, ſaith Fame.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Septem Antro referunt latuiſſe ſopore ſepultos

lg.l: Chriſticolas▪ Decio totum furiente per Orbem.
Sevn Chriſtians, ſom ſay, lurk'd long in a Den;
When Decius ſhewd his rage 'gainſt God and Men.

div.head: EPIG. XCIII. Agoniſtae Europaei.

argument.p: The 7 Chriſtian Champions or Tutelar Saints of ſom chief Countries in Europ.

lg.l: Chriſticolas Europa Agoniſtas inclita ſeptem

l.hi: Venditat ut proprios: quorum dat nomina Fama.

lg.l: Sevn Chriſtie Champions Europ moſt renowned
Claims as his own whoſ names Fame hath reſounded.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Patricius: Jacobus: Dennys: David: Antoniuſ
que :
Georgias: Andraeas ſunt ſeptem Europae Agoniſtae.

l.hi: James: Andrew: David: Denys: Antony:

lg.l: Patric: and George Europs chief Champions be.

div.p: Here end the 32 particular Eſſais implied in the general: wherto ſeven mo ſhal be added.

argument.p: The 7 general Ages of the World, as diverſ Divines divide them from holy Writ.

l.hi: Aetates Mundi celebrantur in ordine ſeptem:
Quas patefecerunt divina Volumina nobis.

lg.l: The Worlds ſevn Ages are in order named:
Which ſacred Scriptures t' us hav plainly framed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Theiologi ſeptem ſtatuerunt ſecula Mundi:
Quae liquido nobis oracula ſacra remonſtrant.

lg.l: Divines the Worlds ſevn Ages hav aſſigned:
Which Gods Word cleerly hath to us defined.

argument.p: The 7 Parts or Portions of the Earth, as ſom lat Authors now State or ſubſect them.

l.hi: Praecipue partes ſtatuuntur quatuor Orbis:
Sed nimis ampla datur ſeptemplex ſectio nuper.

lg.l: The World into four chief Parts is confined:
But too large ſevnfold ſharing's lat aſſigned.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Pars Mundi nova nexa tribus ſubſcinditur: atqui

Verſus utrum
que Polū geminae vix cognitae adherent.

lg.l: The Worlds new part is into twain diſſected: Mexicana Peruana.
But neer both Poles two ſearſ known are ſubnected.

div.head: EPIG. XCVI. Entia omnigena in Ʋniverſo.

argument.p: The 7 Creatures or Entities extant in the Univerſ, as ſom Neoterics ſtate them.

l.hi: Diſtinctas ſpecie, Scriptores ordine ſeptem
Eſſe Creaturas certo ſtatuere Recentes.

lg.l: New Writers ſtate ſevn Creatures orderly,
To be of diſtinct Kinds, in their degree.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Res ſunt ſeptē Homines: Concreta: Elementa: Vapores:
(Sic referunt) ſtirpes: Animalia: & Angeli in or be

lg.l: Som ſay, • i'th World ſevn things (Plants: Elements here:
Vapors: Mixts: Animals: Angels: Men) appeer.

argument.p: The 7 Heads of a Beaſt cited in the Apocalypſ, Rev. 13. 1. &c. which had ten Horns and ten Crowns

lg.l: Beſtia ſeptemceps in ſomno Viſa Joanni;

l.hi: Purpurea Veſte, in dorſo muliere ſedente.

lg.l: John ſaw in Viſion a Beaſt that ſevn Heads had,
On whoſ back ſat a Woman in purple clad.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Beſtia nomen habet, numerumque, & ſtigma dicatum:
Quam cultu aſſiduo venerantur Numina terrae.

lg.l: The Beaſt a name hath, number, and mark reſerved:
Whom Kings of th' Earth with daily worſhip ſerved.

argument.p: The 7 uſual ſpiritual works of Mercy, which concern al Chriſtians to practiſ.

l.hi: Christica Virtutes dat commiſeratio ſeptem:
Acta hae dicuntur pietatis spiritualiis.

lg.l: Sevn Virtues are of Chriſtian clemency:
Theſ are cald works of ſpiritual piety.

argument.p: The 7 devout Deeds or Duties of Chriſtians compaſſion in Corporal things.

l.hi: Corporea acta adhibet miſeris clementia ſeptem:
Mandato Chriſti quae ſuppeditantur Egenis.

lg.l: Sevn Corpo • al works are doon with Charity.
By Chriſts command to men in miſery.

argument.p: The 7 chief Chriſtian Virtues, which are oppoſit to to the 7 Capital ſins cald Mortal.

l.hi: Septema Chriſticolis Virtutes rite colendae:
Quae cum peccatis capitalibus undique pugnant.

lg.l: Chriſtians are bound ſevn Virtues wel to obſerv:
Which from the ſevn ſins capital moſtly ſwerv.

l.hi: Haec qui cunque leges modulamina, ludicra dices:
Hic tamen obveniunt ſeria mixta jocis.

lg.l: Who ſhalt theſ Paſtimes read, them Tois wilt ſtile:
Yet ſerious things with ſports join in one Pile.

lg.head: Another.

l.hi: Apta hic invenies Epigrammata cuique palato:
Elige quae bona ſunt, rejice quae que mala.

lg.l: Here ſhal men find Eſſais fit for ech taſt:
Select what's good, reject what's bad as waſt.

div.head: Bryto-Anglical Eſſais. The fourth Claſsis or Century of Bryto-Anglicals: under four Branches.

argument.p: The 2 Countries of Celtic Galle and Brytain, antiently continented; but ſince ſevered.

l.hi: COnjiciunt aliqui, quod Magna Brytannia primò
Juncta fuit celtis, post modo ſciſſa tamen.

lg.l: Som gueſſ, that firſt Great Brytain was conjoined
To Celtic Continent, but at laſt diſjoined.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Celtarum regioni olim connexa per Iſthmum,
Ut perhibent docti, terra Brytanna fuit.
Brytain was whilom knit to th' Celtic Main,
By Iſthmian neck of land, as the learn'd fain.

argument.p: The 2 famous fortunat Iles in time paſt diſſevered from the Continent of Europ.

l.hi: Hic Terra arcet Aquas, illic Terram obruit unda:
Inſula ſic oritur, quae modo Terra fuit.

lg.l: Here Earth ſtops Waters, ther they are prevalent:
So Iles are made, wher yerſt was Continent.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Inſula Celtarum connexa Brytannica Terrae,

l.hi: Et ſicula Italico creditur eſſe Solo.

lg.l: 'Tis thought to Celt-Land Brytains Ile was cloſed,
And Sicil knit to Latiums Soil ſuppoſed.

argument.p: The 3 foreland Promontories of Brytain, butting brandis wiſe, like Sicil on the Seas.

lg.l: Terra Brytanna tenet tria Promontoria ſparſim:

l.hi: Nomine dicta illinc Terra triquetra novo.

lg.l: Brytain is with three diſpers'd Forelands framed:
Whence now 'tis the three cornerd Land new named

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Inſula ſic Sicula eſt vocitata Trinacria Tellus:

l.hi: Forma triſormis enim par utriuſque patet.

lg.l: So Sicils Ile Trinacria Land is ſtiled:
For a like three-ſhap'd form in both ſtands filed.

div.head: EPIG. IIII. Nomina noſtrae Inſulae data.

argument.p: The 2 ſpecial names of Note, wherby this our Ile hath bin known for many Ages.

l.hi: Ars eſt Grammatica appoſite recteque loquendi:
Nam dare cuique rei nomina vera decet.

lg.l: Grammar an Art is to ſpeak fit and right:
For meet 'tis t' al things their tru name to plight.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Inſulae huic duo nomina, nempe Brytannia priſce,
Anglia nuperius; ſunt data rite ſ • a.
Two names are to this Ile rightly aſcribed,
Brytain of old, England more latly ſtiled.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Inſula nostra fuit vocitata Brytannia pridem:
Anglia verum aevo poſteriore viget.
Of old our Ile was Brytain cald by name:
But in lat ages England of great fame.

argument.p: The 2 pretended Proto-planters of a large Iland now caled Great Brytain.

lg.l: Inſulam in Oceano Samothes atque Albion olim

l.hi: Incoluere diu: ſic vaga Fama canit.

lg.l: A Sea-girt Ile Samothes and Albion,
So Fame ſings, long held in poſſeſſion.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Has primo incoluit Samothes, dein Albion oras;
Quae modo ſunt dictae Terra Brytanna, ferunt.
Firſt Samothes, next Albion theſ Coaſts tamed;
Men ſay, which now Great Brytains Land are named.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Fictitius Samothes, dubius dein Albion: atqui
Hiſtorica est Brutus dignus in Orbe fide.
Samothes is forg'd, next Albion reſts in doubt:
But Brute worth human faith the World throughout

argument.p: The 6 famous Dynaſts, which tranſlated Brytains Scepter from one Nation to another.

l.hi: Temporibus priſcis bis tres viguere Dynaſtae,

lg.l: Linquentes Soboli Sceptra Brytanna ſuae.
Whylom ſix Dynaſts in Bryto-England reigned,
Who to their Of-ſpring Brytains Scepter gained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Celta Brututs: Caeſar Romanus: Saxonus Hengiſt:
Cnut Danus: Victor Norman: Scotuſque Jacobus.
Brute Celt: Caeſar Roman: Hengiſt Saxon Leader:
Cnut Dane: Conqu'ror Norman: James Scotlands Ruler

l.hi: Vera Dynastárum ſex isthaec Nomina conſtant.

lg.l: Thoſ Dynaſts tru names be
Of fix in their degree.

div.head: EPIG. VII. Corinaei cum Gigante lucta.

argument.p: The 2 ſturdy Champions ſaid to try an Athletic Wreſtling bout on Plymmouth Ho.

lg.l: Fama reſert Bruti Corinaeum ſanguine cretum,
Gogmagog in rabidum praecipitaſſe mare.
Corin by blood Brutes Coſen, Fame doth ſay
Caſt Gogmagog headlong into th' raging Sea.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Depulit eſcopulis Corinaeus Gogmagog altis:

l.hi: Qui ſubito aequoreo gurgite merſus erat.

lg.l: Corin from high Clifs Gogmagog did throw:
Who eftſoon drownd was in the Gulph below.

argument.p: The 3 tru Sons of Brute, amongſt whom he divided this Ile in Coperſigniory.

lg.l: Tres habuit Brutus Natos, quibus omnia donat:

l.hi: Inſulam & in partes dividit inter eos.

lg.l: Brute had three Sons, to whom he al betided:
And 'mongſt them into parts this Ile divided.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Optima Locrino pars dicta Loegria lata eſt:
Necnon Albanacto Albania: Cambro.
The beſt to Locrin fel, cald Loegry:
Cambry to Camber: t' Albanact Albany.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l:
Anglia Locrino, Albanacto Scotia, necnon
Per Prolepſin.
Cambro ortu medio Wallia ſorte data eſt.
Locrin had England, Albanact the Scot,
Camber the midſt Son Wales aſſign'd by lot.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Anglia Locrino fuit a Patre, Wallia Cambro,
Albanacto itidem Scotia sponte data.
Locrin had England, Camber Wales aſſignd,
Albanact Scotland by their Sires free mind.

lg.head: Sive.
lg.l: Anglia contingit Locrino, Wallia Cambro:
Albanactus habet ſub ditione Scotos.
England was Locrias ſhare, Wales Cambers fee:
Albanact had the Scots in his power free.

argument.p: The 2 unfortunat Women, which by command of a Vindicativ Queen were drowned in a River.

lg.l: Guindolena ſerox vindictae turbine tincta,

l.hi: Merſit aquis Matrem, Filiolamque ſ • am.

lg.l: Fierce Guindolen with fel revenge rage indowed,
A Mother and hir Infant Daughter drowned.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Mergitur in fluvio cum Eſtrelda Matre Sabrina:
uadaque qua periit, dicta Sabrian fuit.
Sabrin was drown'd with Estreld hir fair mother:
And hir death Severn name gav to that River.

argument.p: The 2 old Queen Mothers, which during their Sons minority ruled the State of Brytain.

lg.l: Guindolena ſuo pro Nato, & Martia Mater,

l.hi: donec erant validi, Sceptra tulere, Viri.

lg.l: Guindolen and Martia Queens of noble fame,
Brytains State ſwaid, til their Sons men became.

argument.p: The 2 joint Brother Kings, who fel at enmity til one ſlu the other in war.

lg.l: Poſtremi Brytonum reges de ſanguine Bruti

l.hi: Creti, ſanguinea morte obicre duo.

lg.l: Brytains two laſt Kings of Brutes blood deſcended,
By bloody death their dais untimely ended.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Marte fuit Po • rex a Fratre peremptus aperto:
A Widen nomine. Matre at Ferrex dilaniatus erat.
Porrex by his Brother in fair war was ſlain:
But Ferrex by their mother torn in twain.

argument.p: The 2 chief Sects of the Brytans, which learnd ſom liberal literature by heart.

l.hi: Priſco aevo Sectas (Druides Bardoſque) fovebat

lg.l: Doctrina celebres, Terra Brytanna duas.
Brytain in old time Druids and Bards did nouriſh,
Two famous Sects which did in learning floriſh.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sacra inter Brytones Druidae celebrare ſolebant:
Sed Bardi Hiſtorias commemorere ſuas.

lg.l: The Brytiſh Druids ſacred things attended:
But Bards their ſtories to mens ears commended.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Olim habuere ſuas (Druides Bardoſque) Brytanni

l.hi: Percelebres Sectas, quae viguere diu.

lg.l: Brytans two Sects whilom had of high fame.
Which floriſhd long, Druids and Bards by name.

argument.p: The 17 ſeveral Stats or Signiories, into which Brytain of old was divided.

lg.l: Sunt ſeptem atque decem, quos priſca Brytannia fovit,

l.hi: Distincti Populi, nomine quique ſuo.

lg.l: Old Brytain ſevn • een ſeveral Stats included,
Ech by diſtinct names from the reſt ſecluded.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Danmonii, Belgae, Durotriges nomina quaedam
Sunt: ſed difficile eſt carmine cuncta dare.

lg.l: The three ſaid names are ſome of thoſ ſo ſtiled:
But al the reſt can hardly in verſ be filed.

argument.p: The 2 Roman Emperors, who ſubdued and reduced South-Brytain to a Province.

lg.l: CAeſar inacceſſas Brytonum primo impetit oras:
Claudius at Gentes ſub juga dura trabit.
Caeſar the Brytiſh ſhores did firſt invade:
But Claudius ſince that Nation ſervil made.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Primus erat Caeſar, Brytones qui Marte ſubegit:
Claudius incaeptum poſtmodo claudit Opus.
Caeſar the firſt was, that Brytain vanquiſhed:
Claudius long after the conqueſt finiſhed.

argument.p: The 2 Brytans who fel to fierce war about a wicked Woman wedded to both.

lg.l: Venutius placidus Rex concitat arma Brigantum.
Velcatiuſque in eum bella maligna ciet.
Venuce mild King his Brigants fierce arms raiſed,
And Velcace 'gainſt him wars accurſed waged.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Amplexa eſt ſervum Regina libidine flagrans,
Et Regem dominum ſprevit iniqua ſuum.

lg.l: A luſtful Queen hir ſervants lov embraced,
And baſely from hir bed hir Lord King chaſed.

argument.p: The 2 Brytiſh Ladies or Queens, which managed wars upon different occaſions.

lg.l: Reginae geminae Brytonum de ſanguine, bella

l.hi: Perſonis propriis dispoſuere ſuis.

lg.l: Two Queens of Brytiſh blood did manage war
In their own perſons; but Cauſ diffring far.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l:
Impia Cartiſmanda ſuo fert bella marito:
Boadicea.
Sed Bodua externis hoſtibus arma parat.
Vile Cartiſmand war with hir Husband waged:
But Bodua forren Foes in arms ingaged.

argument.p: The 2 noted Emperors that founded the famous Fenſ, caled the Picts Wal or Bulwork.

lg.l: Induperatores (Ad • ianus itemque Severus)

l.hi: Mirificos muros compoſuere duo.

lg.l: Two Emp'rors (Adrian and Severus ſtout)
Built wondrous Wals, to keep the fierce Foes out.

argument.p: The 2 warlike Emperors who cloſed the Cataſtrophe of their lifes in York City.

lg.l: Eboraco mortem, Conſtantius atque Severus

l.hi: Induperatores oppetiere duo.

lg.l: Severus and Conſtantius at York died:
Two renoun'd Emp'rors, who both were Deified.

argument.p: The 2 Brytan Kings (not Kings of Brytain) which ruled this Province after the Romans receſſ.

lg.l: Romani miſeros cum deſeruere Brytannos

l.hi: Sponte ſua Imperium ſustinuere duo.

lg.l: When Romans the poor Brytans left deſerted,
Two Kings of free accord the rule accepted.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Vortiger imbellis Brytonum Rex, impius, excors:
Uortimer at validus Filius ejus erat.
Vortiger Bryts King was weak, wicked, dul:
But his ſon Vortimer of courage ful.

argument.p: The 2 Princes of Roman proſapy (both Brethren) which reigned over the oppreſſed Brytans.

lg.l: Acciti Armoricae Fratres e finibus olim,
Sceptra Brytanna armis obtinuere duo.
Whilom two brothers from Armoric invited,
The Brytiſh Scepter by arms force atchived.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Uter & Ambroſius Romano e ſtemmate creti,

l.hi: Marte ſuo Bryt • nes ſub ditione trabunt.

lg.l: Ambroſ and Uter from Romes ſtock derived,
The Bryts by war under their yoke contrived.

argument.p: The 3 Sea ſevered Nations of one linage and Language, ſprung from the old Brytans.

lg.l: Gentes Cornubii, Walli, Brytoneſque minores

l.hi: Ʋna e ſtirpe ſuum tres habuere genus.

lg.l: Corniſh, Welſh, Litle Brytans People three,
From one ſelf ſtock deriv their pedigree.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Cambri, Cornubii, Brytones Gens unica constant:
Communiſque eadem Lingua cuique manet.

lg.l: Welſh, Corniſh, Brytans had one original:
And the ſame Toungreſts common to them al.

l.hi: Tres ſunt Cornubii, Cambri, Brytoneſque minores
Gentes: quae de una stirpe fuere ſatae.

lg.l: Corniſh, Welſh, Litle Bryts three Nations be:
Which were extracted from one Proſapy.

argument.p: The 3 principal parts or portions of Great Brytain united into one Monarchy.

lg.l: Continet eximias tres magna Brytannia Partes:

l.hi: Quarum cuique patent nomina not a ſatis.

lg.l: Great Brytain doth three noble Parts compriſe:
Whoſ names are known enough to al the wiſe.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Anglia, cum Scotia, tres ſunt & Cambria Partes:
Quas ditione ſua Terra Brytannia tenet.
Great Brytains Ile is of three Parts compounded;
England, Wales, Scotland: al with Sea ſurrounded.

div.head: EPIG. XXIII. Lynguae in Brytannia variae.

argument.p: The 3 ſeveral diſtinct Toungs or Languages ſtil uſed or extant in Great Brytain.

lg.l: Bryttica in hoc noſtro Linguis tribus utitur aevo

l.hi: Inſula: quae vaflo est undique ſepta mari.

lg.l: Great Brytains Ile, which with vaſt Sea's included;
Three diverſ Toungs to this day hath long uſed.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tres modo apud Brytones ſunt Anglica, Wallica, Scota

l.hi: Linguae diſtinctae: quae viguere diu.

lg.l: In Brytain now three diffring Toungs are nouriſh'd:
Engliſh, Welſh, Scotiſh; which long here hav floriſhd

argument.p: The 3 chief Converſions of old Brytans and Engliſh Saxons to the Chriſtian Faith.

l.hi: Bis Brytones converſi, Angli ſemel auspice Chriſto
Sunt; qui ſalvificam percoluere Fidem.

lg.l: Brytans were twiſe, th' Engliſh once covnerted:
Who were in Chriſt by ſaving Faith inſerted.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Converſi ad Chriſtum Brytones bis, ſed ſemel Angli:
Sic ter aſſeruit Terra Brytanna Fidem.

lg.l: Bryts twiſe, but Engliſh once to Chriſt converted:
So Brytain-Land thriſe Chriſtian Faith aſſerted.

argument.p: The 2 Saxon Brothers linealy deſcended from their Deified King Woden by Queen Fria.

lg.l: SAxonici Fratres Hengiſtus & Horſa, Brytannis

l.hi: Fraude mala Dominis impoſuere jugum.

lg.l: Hengiſt and Horſa Saxon brothers ſtout,
By Faith-breach beat their Lords the Brytans out.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Sunt duo Saxonici Fratres Hengiſtus & Horſus:

l.hi: E Patria Dominos qui pepulere ſua.

lg.l: Two Saxon brethren Hengiſt and Horſa were:
Who drov their Lords from home by force and fear.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Germani Fratres Hengiſtus & Horſus, ad Anglos
Sceptra Brytanna dolo transpoſuere ſ • o.
Hengist and Horſa genuin brothers twain,
The Brytiſh Scepter did to th' Engliſh gain.

argument.p: The 7 diſtinct Kingdoms (caled Heptarchy) raiſed by Saxons on the Brytans ruins.

l.hi: Saxonici Proceres, expulſis fraude Brytannis;
Septem Regna ſimul conſtituere ſuis.

lg.l: Som Saxon Peers driving out Bryts falſly;
Sevn Realms in one age reard for their Progeny.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Kent, Suſſex, Weſtſex, Eſſex, Nor • humbria, Merci:
Eaſt-Angli ſeptem Saxona regna patent.
Theſ be ſ • vn Saxon Realms rang'd orderly.
In rank and file of tru Chronology.

argument.p: The 7 firſt Saxon Roitelets, who expeld the Bryts and erected the ſaid diſtinct Dominions.

l.hi: Saxoni apud Brytones ſeptem extruxere Monarchae,
Ej • ctis Dominis, regna pufilla ſuis.

lg.l: Sevn Saxon Roitelets, the Bryts Lords ejected,
For their own Of-ſpring pety Realms erected.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Crida, Uſſa, Ella, Hengiſt, Erchenwin, Ella-Ida, Cerdic

l.hi: Reguli erant primi, qui fibi regna ſtruunt.

lg.l: Thoſ be the firſt Kings plac'd prepoſtrouſly,
Who ſevn ſmal Realms rais'd for themſelvs therby.

div.head: EPIG. XXVIII. Heptarchae ad fidem converſi.

argument.p: The 7 Saxon Kings which firſt embraced Chriſtianity in ech ſeveral Realm of the Heptarchy.

l.hi: Ordine Saxonici ſumma pictate referti
Heptarchae Chriſti percoluere ſidem.

lg.l: The Saxon Heptarchs with great zele inflamed,
The Faith of Chriſt in their ſet turns embraced.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ethelbert, Kingils, Ethelwolf, Peda, Sebertus,
Edwin, Redwaldus Chriſti aluere fidem.
Theſ ſevn Kings firſt firmly Chriſts Faith embraced:
But by neceſſity their names are miſplaced.

argument.p: The 33 moſt eminent Saxon Kings, commonly caled Monarchs of the Engliſh Men.

l.hi: Anglo-Saxoni erant tres atque triginta Monarchae,
Antequam eis regnum praecipuere Daci.

lg.l: Here Engliſh-Saxon Kings were thirty three,
Before the Danes bereav'd their Monarchy.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Anglorum Reges tres & triaconta fuere,
Geſtavere prius quam Diadema Daci.

lg.l: Thirty three Kings of Engliſh men ther were,
Before the Danes the Engliſh Crown did wear:

argument.p: The 2 Weſt-Saxon Kings, which drov the poor Bryts from their Holds, Homes, and Habitations.

l.hi: Extrudunt Brytones propriis de ſedibus olim,
Saxonici Reges Marte feroce duo.

lg.l: Two Saxon Kings thruſt out the Brytiſh Nations.
By cruel war from their own Habitations.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Cerdicus exagitat Brytones, quos expulit Ina;

l.hi: A Patriis aris aedibus atque ſuis.

lg.l: Cerdic the Brytans beat, whom Ina quel'd;
From Country both and dwellings them expeld.

argument.p: The 2 Weſt-ſex Kings that quited their Crowns and entred or embraced Moncs Cloiſters.

l.hi: Heptarchae Angliaci zelo fervente repleti,
Regna, ut ſint Monachi, depoſucre duo.

lg.l: Two Engliſh Heptarchs, with pure zele inflamed,
To becom Moncs, their Regal rights diſclamed.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Saxonici Reges Diademata, Ceadwal & Ina

l.hi: Aurea prae zelo depoſuere ſua.

lg.l: Ceadwal and Ina, two Saxon Kings of old;
Meerly for zele reſign their Crowns of gold.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Exuit Ina ſuum & Ceadwal Diadema, cucullum

l.hi: Induat ut Monachi, pro pietate Dei.

lg.l: Ina and Ceadwal the Moncs Cowl to wear,
Caſt off their Crowns for Gods lov they did be • r.

argument.p: The 2 Saxon Heptarchs, who hated ech other deadly for difference in Religion.

l.hi: Saxonici gemini pro R • lligione Monarchae,
Mutuum in excidium lurida bella gerunt:

lg.l: Two Saxon Kings adverſ war againſt either
Made for Religion mutualy together.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Chriſticola Oſwaldus ſumma pietate refulgens,
Pagano a Penda dilaniatus erat.
Oſwald a Chriſtian ſhining in Piety,
Was peecemeal torn by Penda Heathniſhly.

argument.p: The four chief Saxon Monarchs, which reigned over England before the Norman Conqueſt.

l.hi: Bis duo praecipui tulerant Sceptra Anglica Reges,
Qui bello rabidis oppoſuere Danis.

lg.l: Four ſpecial Kings the Engliſh Scepter held,
Who 'gainſt the raging Danes long Wars did weld.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ethelſt • n, Egbert, Elfred, celeberrimus Edgar

l.hi: Praecipui Reges▪ qui domuere Dacas.

lg.l: Egbert, Elfred, Ethelſtan, Edgar renowned, Here al 4 are in right rank
Are four chief Monarchs, who the Danes confounded

argument.p: The 2 mighty Monarchs who lived long in loving league, being neer Neighbors.

l.hi: Vicini una aetate duo viguere Monarcha:
Qui inter ſe fidum foedus ameris alunt.

lg.l: Two Neighbor Monarchs in one age did floriſh:
Who 'twixt them faithful league of Lov did nouriſh.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Carolus Imperium Occiduo renovavit in Orbe:
Ʋniit Egbertus Saxona Regna ſimul.
The Weſtern Empire Charlemaign revived: A. C. 800. A. C. 819.
The Saxon Realms Egbert in one combined.

argument.p: The 3 warlike Engliſh Kings, who were of like ſhort ſtature, but high ſtout Spirits.

l.hi: Anglica geſtabant Homuli tres Sceptra feroces:
Qui vocitati apte Fulmina Martis erant.

lg.l: Three ſhort fierce Men did Englands Scepter bear:
Who Thunder-bolts of War term'd fitly were.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Corpore pumilii regnabant tres apud Anglos:
Aſt animo invicti praevalidique diu.

lg.l: Three Dwarfiſh Kings over th' Engliſh long:
But of moſt valiant minds, and hardy ſtrong

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Corpore erant Egbert, Edgar, Cnutuſque puſillo:

l.hi: Spiritu at excelſo magnanimoque Viri.

lg.l: Egbert, Cnut, Edgar were of ſtature ſmal;
But of high Spirit and ſtout hearted al.

argument.p: The 2 Kings of England, who moſtly diſtreſſed and dejected the Daniſh Depredators.

l.hi: Angliaci Reges antiqui Marte cruento,
Praedones gemini perdomuere Danos.

lg.l: Two antique Engliſh Kings in blood embrued,
The pilfring Daniſh Pirats oft ſubdued.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Fortiter Angligenae Reges, Egbertus & Elfred

l.hi: Graſſantes feriunt Marte furente Dacos.

lg.l: The Engliſh Kings, Egbert and Elfred ſtout,
By force of Arms the plundring Danes drov out.

argument.p: The 8 Princes which rowed King Edgars Roial Barge in Dee River, while he ſat at helm to ſteer.

lg.l: Regigium Edgaro Regi fecere Zygetae

l.hi: Regifici remis deſuper octo ſimul.

lg.l: Eight King-like Rowers did King Edgar cary,
With Owers forth and back, as ſtern did vary.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Rex clavum Edgarus tenuit, quando ultro citroque

l.hi: Naviculam Satrapae fluctibus octo vebunt.

lg.l: King Edgar held the helm, while to and fro
Eight Princes on the ſtream his Barge did row.

argument.p: The 2 Kings of Denmarc (Father and Son) who brought England into Bondage and ſubjection.

l.hi: Danorum gemini Reges fera bella gerebant,
Donec durum Anglis impoſuere jugum.

lg.l: Two Kings of Denmarc wars moſt cruel wrought,
Til they the Engliſh in • o hard bondage brought.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Angliacos Reges, Suainus Pater atque Canutus

l.hi: Filius, e ſolio vi pepulere duos.

lg.l: Suain and Canut, Sire and Son, by force beat
Two Kings of England from their Regal Seat.

argument.p: The 2 Corrival Kings of England, who fought a Duel or ſingle Combat for the Crown.

lg.l: Cnutus & Edmundus pro Regno, Marte potenti,

l.hi: Cominus Angliaco conſervere manus.

lg.l: Edmund and Cnut in warlike wiſe did band
For Englands Kingdom ſtoutly hand to hand.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Anglicus Edmundus, Danuſque Canutus inibant

l.hi: mutua pro Regno robore bella pari.

lg.l: Th' Engliſh Edmund, and Daniſh Canut ſtrov,
For Englands Realms their equal ſtrength to prov.

argument.p: The 2 Sons and Succeſſors of Canut, who for a very few yeers wore the Engliſh Diadem.

lg.l: Filioli gemini Succeſſoreſque Canu • i.

l.hi: Poſt Patrem arripiunt Anglica Sceptra brevi.

lg.l: Canuts two Sons and Succeſſors for ſhort ſpace
After their Sire did th' Engliſh Crown embrace.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Haroldus levipes dictus, validuſque Canutus

l.hi: Anglica poſt Patris funera Sceptra gerunt.

lg.l: Harold cald Harefoot, and Hardi-Canut held,
Th' Engliſh Scepter when death their Father queld.

argument.p: The 2 Engliſhmen Kings, which reigned next after the deaths of thoſ three Roial Danes.

l.hi: Sunt gemini Reges Anglorum e ſtirpe profecti:
Poſt Danorum obitum qui Diadema gerunt.

lg.l: Ther were two Kings of Engliſh ſtirp deſcended,
Who when thoſ Danes died to the Throne aſcended.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Anglica poſt obitum Danorum Edvardus & Harold

l.hi: Per fas atque nefas denuo Sceptra tenent.

lg.l: Edward and Harold, when the Danes deceaſed;
By right and wrong on th' Engliſh Scepter ſeiſed.

argument.p: The 2 Dukes Uſurpers, who without right or reaſon detained the Crown from Edgar Etheling.

lg.l: Poſt Edvardi obitum, rejecto Haerede fideli
Edgaro gemini Sceptra tulere Duces.
When Edward died, two Dukes: he Crown aſſumed,
Edgar the right Heir being unjuſtly extruded.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Anglica geſtabant duo falſo nomine Sceptra,

lg.l: (Goodwini hic ſoboles, Spurius ille) Duces.
Two Dukes by falſ claim th' Engliſh Scepter ſwaid,
Goodwins Son one, th' other a Baſtard ſaid.

argument.p: The 7 Dukes of Neuſtria (now named Normanny) that firſt ſucceded one another.

l.hi: SEx Normanniacum Satrapae obtinuere Ducatū:
Septimus Angliacum vi Diadema tulit.

lg.l: Six Peers ſucceſſiv Norman Dukedom bore:
A ſeventh th' Engliſh Crown by Conqueſt wore.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Sunt duo Roberti, Guilielmi nomine bini,
Tres Richardi itidem: qui viguere Duces.
Two Roberts were, two Williams cald by name,
And Richards three▪ who floriſh'd Dukes of Fame.

argument.p: The 25 Monarchs, which hav ſwaied Englands Scepter ſucceſſivly ſince the Norman Conqueſt.

lg.l:
Dux Victor: Rufus: prior Henricus: Stephanuſ
que :
Proximus Henricus 2: Richardus: Rexque Joannes.
Tertius Henricus 3: ſuccedunt tres Edovardi 1. 2. 3.:

Alter Richardus 2: tres 4. 5. 6. Henrici
que
ſequuntur:
Edvardus quartus: quintus: Nepocida Richardus 3:
Septimus: octavuſque Henricus Sceptra capeſſunt:
Edvardus ſextus: Maria: Elizabetha: Jacobus:
Carolus infoelix. propria haec ſunt nomina Regum.
Duke Conqu'ror: Rufus: firſt Henry: and Stephan:
Next Henry: the firſt Richard: and King John:
Henry the third: three Edwards com in order:
Richard the ſecund: three Henries 4. 5. 6. folow after.
Edward fourth: Fifth: Richard 3 who's Nephews kild:
Seventh: and eighth Henry did the Scepters wield:
Sixth Edward: Mary: Elizabeth: King James:
Unhappy Charls: theſ are the Kings right names.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Viginti eximii Normanna eſtirpe Monarchae
Et quinque Angliaco Sceptra tulere ſolo.

lg.l: Twenty fiv great Monarchs of Norman race were,
Who Englands Scepter did in order bear.

argument.p: The 2 Williams, who were nativ Normans by Name, Nature, Nation, and Nativity.

lg.l: Normanni Patria, Gulielmus uterque Monarchae
Angliae erant gemini, qui Diadema gerunt.
The two firſt Kings, both Williams, Normans were
By Country, who did Englands Diadem wear.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Anglica, Normanna Gulielmi nomine Reges,

l.hi: Qui de gente ſati, Sceptra tulere duo.

lg.l: Held th' Engliſh Scepter in their domination.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Normanni Reges geniti, Gulielmus uterque,

l.hi: Innumeris Anglos ſuppoſuere malis.

lg.l: Two Williams Kings, both born in Normanny,
Brought Engliſhmen t' al ſorts of ſlavery.

argument.p: The 3 Perſons iſſued from the Conquerors loins, who died diſaſterly in New Foreſt, founded by himſelf.

l.hi: Tres Normannici erant Victoris ſtemmate creti,
Qui Saltu infauſte deperiere novo.

lg.l: Three Imps of Norman Conqu'rors Progeny,
In Hantſhire Foreſt died unhappily.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Filioli duo ſunt, Gulielmus itemque Richardus:
Sed Nati Henricus filius alter erat.
Two were his Sons, William and Dick by name:
But third his Sons Son Henry Son to Robert. of ſmal fame.

argument.p: The 2 genuin Brothers, who infeſted one another with mutual mortal wars.

l.hi: Flagrantes odio, Germani aſperrima fratres
Pro ditione duo bella tulere diu.

lg.l: Two german Brethren with fel hate inraged,
For lov of rule moſt ſharp wars long ingaged.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Robertum Henricus fratrem Diademate fraudat,

l.hi: Et miſerum toto lumine privat eum.

lg.l: Henry his brother of the Crown deceived,
And his whol ſight moſt wretchedly bereaved.

argument.p: The 2 Corrival Monarchs, which contended many yeers for the Crown, and at laſt compounded.

lg.l: Matildam Stephanus violavit jure Paterno,

l.hi: Privavit Regno filiolumque ſuum.

lg.l: Stephan th' Empreſſ Mawd of birth right cheated,
And of the Kingdom hir young Son defeated.
Vi Stephanus Regno Henricum ſpoliavit Avito:

l.hi: Qui tandem proprio jure potitus erat.

lg.l: Stephan by force Henry from's Realm detained:
Who his tru Grandſires right at length attained.

argument.p: The 2 potent Perſons, who conteſted a long ſpace concerning Privileges and Preeminences.

l.hi: In dominum Regem fert Archiepiſcopus acer,
Prae faſtu, in Regno jurgia dira ſuo.

lg.l: A fierce Archbiſhop 'gainſt his Lord the King,
In his own Realm through pride baſe brawls did bring

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Acriter oppoſuit Praeſul cognomine Becket
Se Regi Henrico pro ditione ſua.
The Prelat Becket nam'd, ſtoutly contended
With Henry King, for priviledg pretended.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Dum licitis mediis Rex jura tuetur Avita;
Jure ſuo Praeſul deſpoliare petit.

lg.l: While by juſt means the King old Laws defended,
A Prelat to deſtroy his rights contended

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Henrico oppoſuit Thomas Antiſtes iniquus,

l.hi: Qui vitam amiſit pro feritate ſuam.

lg.l: Thomas proud Prelat Henry did oppoſe;
Who for his ſtubborn pranks his life did lofe.

argument.p: The 2 Noble Ladies of ignoble lewd life, who envied one the other even to death.

lg.l: Mortiferis odiis Roſamundam Elinora petebat:

l.hi: Aemula namque fuit, caſtior utra foret.

lg.l: Elinor did Roſamund deadly hate: for ſhe
Envied, which of the twain ſhould chaſter be.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Invida Rivalem Roſamundam Elinora coegit

l.hi: Pocula lethifero ſumere plena mero.

lg.l: Curſt El'nor hir Rival Roſamund compelled,
To drink a Cup with deadly poiſon filled.

argument.p: The 2 Engliſh Kings, who underwent long voiages to recover Jeruſalem.

lg.l: Angliaci Reges, Richardus itemque Edovardus
Ʋrbem Hieroſolymam vi petiere duo.
Richard and Edward, two Engliſh Kings ſtout,
To Salem City of ſtrong force went out.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Rex Richardus & Edvardus pietate referti,
Prae zelo Solymas olim adiere ſacras.
King Richard and Edward ful of piety,
To th' holy City went for ſanctity.

argument.p: The 2 Princes (Uncle & Nephew) which waged war for the Engliſh Crown or Diadem.

l.hi: Ambitioſus in hoc Epigrammaete Avunculus extat,
Regali e ſolio ſepoſituſque Nepos.

lg.l: In this Eſſay a lawleſſ Uncle is ſet,
And Nephew thruſt beſide his Roial ſeat.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Angliacum Arthuro eripuit Diadema Joannes,

l.hi: Et vita, ut perhibent, deſpoliavit eum.

lg.l: King John from Arthur th' Engliſh Crown ſurpriſed,
And him of life, as ſom report deprived.

argument.p: The 2 Monarchs; who with their two eldeſt Sons were captived by the Barons of England.

l.hi: Angliacos quidam captivos Marte, Barones
Filioloſque ſuos detinuere duos.

lg.l: Som Engliſh Barons two Kings in war attained,
With their two Sons, and Captivs them detained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Anglorum Henricus, Romanorumque Richardus

l.hi: Rex, cum Filiolis captus uterque fuit.

lg.l: Henry of England, Richard Romans King,
With their two Sons, Montfort did Priſoners bring.

argument.p: The 6 portentous prodigies hapning in the troublous times of King Henry 3.

lg.l: Multa ſub Henrico portenta fuere ſuborta,

l.hi: Quae Populo toti multa tulere mala.

lg.l: Many ſtrange things in Henry's time befel:
Which t'al the People did great ils foretel

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Bis tria regnante Henrico, portenta nefanda

l.hi: Maxima in Angliaco damna tulere ſolo.

lg.l: Six ſad Portents fel in King Henry's reign,
Wherby al England did grand harms ſuſtein.

argument.p: The 2 ſucceding Kings of one name, but far different Natures, diſpoſitions, or demeanors.

lg.l: Edvardi extiterant duo Reges nomine dicti:

l.hi: Inclytus hic Genitor, Filius ille malus.

lg.l: Ther were two Kings cald Edwards by one ſtile:
One a brav Father, th' other Son very vile.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Nomine erant ſimiles, Edvardus primus & alter:

l.hi: Natus hic invalidus, Nobilis ille Pater.

lg.l: Firſt and next Edward were, of ſelf ſame name:
One a Daſtard Son, the other Sire of fame.

argument.p: The 2 Corrival Kings, who ſtrov long with variable ſucceſſ by force of Arms for Scotlands Crown.

lg.l: Dispare praetextu, Scoticum Diadema Monarchae,
(Bruſeus & Baliol) competiere duo.
Two Kings to Scotlands Crown fairly pretended,
Baliol and Bruſe) for which they long contended.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Rivales Reges (Baliol Breuſeuſque) Scotorum,
Pro Scotiae regno mutua bella cient.
Scots Rival Kings (Baliol and Bruſe) did ſtrive,
By mu • ual War who ſhould the ſame atchive.

argument.p: The 2 proud Perſons, which fel from the top of human glory, to the depth of mortal miſery.

lg.l: Spenſerus Pater & Natus viguere potenter:

l.hi: Sed meritis poenas ambo tulere pares.

lg.l: The Spenſers (Sire and Son) ſwaid powerfully:
But both 'like pains ſuffred deſervedly.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ambo ſub Edvardo Spenſeri Sceptra gerebant:

l.hi: Ambo autem miſeram ſuſtinuere necem:

lg.l: Both Spenſers under Edward ruled al:
But both ſuſtaind a miſerable fal.

argument.p: The 2 Corrival Monarchs that waged long Wars very variably for the French Crown.

lg.l: Belligeri Reges, Edvardus itemque Philippus,

l.hi: Contendere ampla pro ditione duo.

lg.l: Two warlike Monarchs fel to fel contention,
Edward and Philip, for a fair Dominion.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Anglicus Edvardus Rex, Francicus atque Philippus

l.hi: Francorum imperium competiere diu.

lg.l: Edward th' Engliſh King, and Philip of France
For the French Empire long held variance.

argument.p: The 2 principal pretended Founders of the fundamenaal Salic Law in France.

lg.l: Carolus an Pharamond Leges Salicae Author habendus,

l.hi: Lis eſt: namque duplex dicitur eſſe Parens.

lg.l: Who (Charls or Pharamond) Salic Law began,
In ſtrife 'twixt two Sires, let him judg that can.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Dant alii Salicam Pharamondo ab origine Gentis
Legem alii Carolum conſtituere Patrem.
Som Pharamond Founder make of Law and Nation:
Som giv to Charls the Salic Laws foundation.

argument.p: The 2 Engliſh Monarchs, which mutualy and mortaly hated one the other.

lg.l: Filius infoelix Edvardi Principis atri,

l.hi: Imperio & vita despoliatus, erat.

lg.l: Th' unhappy Son of Edward, black Prince ſtiled,
Was of his life and Realm unjuſtly ſpoiled.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Mitis ab Henrico Patruele Richardus iniquo

l.hi: Depoſitu • Regno est, expoſituſque neci.

lg.l: Mild Richard by vile Henry was depoſed
From 's Realm, and wickedly to death expoſed.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Richardum Henricus miſerum Diademate privat:

l.hi: Posteaqui immani morte trucidat eum.

lg.l: Henry poor Richard of his Crown deprived:
And afterward his horrid death contrived.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Impie ab Henrico Richardus, crimine nullo,

l.hi: Regno & luce ſimul mox ſpoliatus erat.

lg.l: Richard by Henry, from crying crimes free,
Was ſoon of life and Realm ſpoild impiouſly.

lg.head: Secius.
lg.l: Rex Richardus ab Henrico, juvenilibus annis,

l.hi: E ſolio ejectus morteque plexus erat.

lg.l: King Richard in Youth, by his Coſen Henry
Dethroned was and murdred cruely.

lg.head: Sive.
lg.l: Richardum Henricus miſeranda morte peremit,

l.hi: (Authores varii ſic cecinere) fame.

lg.l: Henry by famin Richard made away,
A doleful death ſo diverſ Authors ſay.

argument.p: The 2 firſt famous Levellers in England, who ſought to ſuppreſſ Monarchy, Nobility, Clergy.

l.hi: Aequare egregii Populi de faece Rebelles
Singula tentabant ſacra, prophana duo.

lg.l: Two Rebels of vile vulgar ſcum deſcended,
To level ſordid and ſacred things contended.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Gualterus Tector dictus, Stramenque Joannes,

l.hi: Plebii in Regem bella ciere Duces.

lg.l: The Commons Captains them to war did draw.
Againſt the King; Wat Tyler and Jack Straw.

argument.p: The 2 Henries (Fifth and Sixth) after Henry the fourth, who ſucceded one another with very unlike ſucceſſ.

lg.l: Angliaca Henrici vocitati nomine Reges,

l.hi: Sceptra (ſed injuste) detinuere duo.

lg.l: Two Kings in England, Henries by name, reigned:
Who from tru Heirs the Scepter ſans right detained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Henrico Henrici ſubeunt gemini ordine Reges:

l.hi: Hic celebris Genitor, Natus & ille bonus.

lg.l: Two Henries ſucced Henry fourth in order:
This a good Son, that a renowned Father.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Henricus quintus, ſextus Sceptra Anglica gestant:
Martius ille Pater, Filius iste pius.
Henry fifth, ſixth: Sire Mars for Chivalry;
In England reign'd, Son Saint for Piety.

argument.p: The 2 illuſtrious Houſes, which raiſed cruel Civil Wars in competition for the Crown of England.

lg.l: Eboraci Tribus eximia, & Lancaſtria Proles
Pro regno Angliaco lurida bella gerunt.
Yorks Noble Tribe and Lancaster held war
For Englands Realm, with baleful mortal jar.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Eboraci illuſtris Lancaſtrenſiſque Propago
Sceptra repoſcebant Anglica jure ſuo.
Yorks Line and Lancaſters both of great might,
Claim'd th' Engliſh Crown as du by their own right.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Nobilis Eboraci Domus, & Lancaſtria dudum
Pro regno Angliaco mutua bella movent:
Yorks Princely Houſ, and Lancasters Family,
For Englands Kingdom raiſd wars mutualy.

argument.p: The 22 Children which the Lord Ralph Nevil a worthy Warrier had by two ſeveral Wifes.

lg.l: Conjugio duplici numeroſa propago Nevillo eſt:

l.hi: Quae ſuit egregie multiplicata brevi.

lg.l: Nevil twiſe marying had a large Progeny:
Which in ſhort ſpace increaſd excedingly.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ʋnus Homo foetus gemina ex uxore creabat
Viginti atque duos; qui viguere diu.

lg.l: One Man upon two Wifes begot and bred
Twenty two Children, who long floriſhed.

argument.p: The 14 ſeveral Dukes that lived and died diverſly in the dais of holy Henry the ſixth.

lg.l: Bis ſeptem, ſexto Henrico regnante, Dynaſtae

l.hi: Conſpicui variis deperiere modis

lg.l: Fourteen great Dukes, which while ſixth Henry reigned,
By ſundry uncouth means their deaths attained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Diverſis mediis, Henrici tempore ſexti,

l.hi: Bis ſeptem celebres, interiere Duces.

lg.l: Fourteen renown'd Dukes in ſixth Henries dais,
Cam to their ends by ſundry ſeveral wais.

argument.p: The 12 foughten fields betwixt the famous families of York and Lancaſter in England

l.hi: Eventu vario, Civili Praelia bello,
Bis ſex Angliacis percutiuntur agris.

lg.l: Twelv battels in the Civil war were ſtruck,
On Engliſh plains with good and evil luck.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Eboraci & Lancaſtrenſis ter quatuor arvis

l.hi: Angliacis pugnas conſeruere truces.

lg.l: Yorkiſts and Lancaſtriſts on Engliſh land,
Darraind twelv cruel conflicts hand to hand.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Eboracos Lancaſtreſque inter, lite cruenta,

l.hi: Bis ſex pugnantur Praelia utrinque fera.

lg.l: 'Twixt York and Lancaſter with bloody jar,
Twelv battels on both ſides were fought in war.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Ante obitum Henrici ſexti, Civilia noſtris

l.hi: Praelia terna quater facta fuere pagis.

lg.l: Twelv Civil Fights before King Henry died,
For the Crowns title in our Coaſts were tried.

lg.head: Secius.
lg.l: Dum fuit in vivis Henricus nomine ſextus;
Bis ſex Angliacis bella moventur agris.
Twelv Civil Fights, while Henry ſixth breathd air,
In Englands ſpacious fields datrained were.

argument.p: The 4 Kings of England ſince the Norman Conqueſt, which were depoſed and murderouſly deſtroied.

lg.l: Imperio Reges apud Anglos quatuor orbi.

l.hi: Sanguinea extincti morte fuere brevi.

lg.l: Four Kings of England ſtript from Roialty,
Were in ſhort ſpace deſtroid moſt bloodily.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: E ſolio amoti, cito ſunt ad Tartara miſsi
Angliaci Reges bis duo fraude mala.

lg.l: Four Engliſh Kings being from their Thrones depoſed,
Were ſoon by wicked wiles to death expoſed.

argument.p: The 2 Princeſſes, who living in one Age, ſuſtained ſundry grievous afflictions.

l.hi: Heroinae illuſtres, poſt fata beata, coaevae
Aerumnas geminae ſustinuere graves.

lg.l: Two noble Ladies after much felicity,
Living at once ſuſtaind great miſery.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Caecilia infoelix, atque Elizabetha miſella

l.hi: Ante ſupremum obitum multa tulere mala.

lg.l: Cecily and El'zabeth both moſt unhappy,
Before their deaths had much calamity.

lg.head: Alias
lg.l: Caecilia Edvardi Richardique unica Mater:
Edvardi at conjux Elizabetha fuit.
Cecily t' Edward and Richard was one Mother:
But Elzabeth Edwards wife, who was Richards brother.

argument.p: The 3 Kings iſſued from Richard Plantagenet Duke of York: who ſucceded 3 Henries of Lancaſter.

lg.l: Reges Anglorum Eboraci de ſtirpe creati,

l.hi: Imperium vicibus tres ſubiere ſuis.

lg.l: Th • ee Kings ſprung from Yorks Stock or Family,
Held in their turns the Engliſh Monarchy.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Edvardus quartus, quintus, gibberque Richardus

l.hi: Anglica geſtabant ordine Sceptra ſuo.

lg.l: Edward fourth, fifth; and Richard Crook-back vild,
Did th' Engliſh Scepter in their order wield.

argument.p: The 2 perſons cruely put to death without juſt cauſ, by meer miſpriſion of words.

lg.l: Sunt duo ab Edvardo ſine cauſa aut crimine caeſi
(Hic Walker dictus, Burdet at ille) Viri.
Edward put to death two men fans cauſ,
(One Walker, th' other Burdet cal'd) 'gainſt Laws.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: A Rege Edvardo, Walker Burdetque cruentae

l.hi: Expoſiti miſere ſunt ſine jure neci.

lg.l: King Edward put to death moſt bloodily
Walker and Burdet, ſans right or equity.

argument.p: The 3 cunning Concubins of K. Edward 4. which were of different degrees and diverſ diſpoſitions.

lg.l: Tres pro Concubitu Edvardus Rex quartus Amicas

l.hi: Diſsimiles aluit moribus, Arte ſua.

lg.l: Fourth Edward King t' his bed three Sweet-hearts trained
Unlike for maners in their Art maintained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tres ſimul Edvardus Rex est amplexus Amicas

l.hi: Moribus haud ſimiles, ingeniove pares.

lg.l: Three Concubins at once King Edward bred,
Who in conditions and wit much differed.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Etribus Edvardi meretricibus, altera vafra eſt;

l.hi: Altera ſancta ſatis; tertia plena jocis.

lg.l: Of Edwards three Harlots, one was wilieſt;
Another holieſt; and third the meryeſt.

argument.p: The 2 Lord Chamberlains under two ſucceceding Kings, cruely beheaded for ſmal cauſ, crime, or color.

lg.l: Plectitur Haſtingus ſubita feritate ſecuri,
Necnon Stanleius; crimine uterque vacans.
Haſtings in haſt was chopt off favagely,
And Stanley; both ſans crime unworthily.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tertius Haſtingum ſine culpa aut Lege Richardus,
Septimus Henricus Stanleiumque premit.
Third Richard headed Haſtings ſans crime or Laws,
And Henry ſevnth Stanley without juſt cauſ.

argument.p: The 2 Roial Imps (Sons to Edward 4.) bloodily butchered by their own Uncle Richard Crook-back.

l.hi: Ambitioſus in hoc Epigrammate Avunculus extat,
Regalie ſolio ſepoſituſque Nepos.

lg.l: In this Eſſay a lawleſſ Uncle is ſet
And Nephew thruſt beſide his Roial ſeat.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Richardus lanio truculenta morte Nepotes

l.hi: Suſtulit innocuos, ut diadema gerat.

lg.l: Richard his harmleſſ Nephews but cherly
Murdred that he might get the Soveraignty.

argument.p: The 2 Princeſſes, which after their Husbands deaths (that's no news) remaried to mean Men.

lg.l: Post Sponſorum obitum Catherina, Jaqueta Maritis

l.hi: Obſcuris aliis utraque nupta fuit.

lg.l: Catherin and Jaquet, when their Husbands died,
Were both to other baſer Pheers affied.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tudero Catherina fuit, Jaquelina renupta
Woodvillo, ex humili conditione viris.
Catherin to Tuder wedded was obſcurely,
Jaquet to Woodvil, men of mean quality.

argument.p: The 3 Succeſſiv Kings linealy deſcended from Owen Tuder, by Catherin Queen Dowager of England.

lg.l: Progenie Walli, Tuderi nomine dicti,

l.hi: Angliaco regimen tres habuere ſolo.

lg.l: Three Kings cald Tuders of Welſh Progeny,
In England had the ſuprem Soveraignty.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tres celebres Reges Tuderi ſtemmate creti,
Anglica geſtabant ordine Sceptra ſuo.
Three great Kings ſprung from Tuders Proſapy,
Bore th' Engliſh Rod in turn ſucceſſivly.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Nomine Tuderi, Wallorum e ſanguine nati;
Angliacum Reges tres Diadema gerunt.
Three Kings of Welſh blood born, Tuders by name;
Wore Englands Crown of late age with high fame.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Septimus Henricus, necnon Octavus, itemque
Edvardus ſextus Sceptra ſuprema ferunt.
Henry ſeventh, eigh • h, and Edward the ſixth reigned:
Who in ſucceſſion ſuprem power attained.

argument.p: The 2 notorious Impoſtors, who conterfeted themſelfs great Princes againſt Henry the ſeventh.

l.hi: Pſeudonymi egregii ſimulantes nomina Regum,

lg.l: Henrico excieunt aspera bella, duo.
Two famous Conterfets, 'gainſt Henry King,
Taking falſ Roial names, ſharp wars did bring.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Bini Impoſtores Lambert Perkin que ſceleſti,
Henricum variis implicuere malis.
Lambert and Perkin two Impoſtors vile,
With ſundry miſchiefs Henry did embroil.

argument.p: The 2 Noblemen unworthily beheaded by Henry the ſeventh, for very ſmal faults, or none at al.

lg.l: Septimo ab Henrico Satrapae duo ſanguine clari

l.hi: Immerito afflicti morte fuere mala.

lg.l: Sevnth Henry put to death deſervdleſly,
Two Noble men of birth and linage high.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Stanleius, Comes & Varveccius enſe reciſa.

l.hi: A Rege immerito colla habuere truci.

lg.l: Stanley, and Warwicks Earl undeſervdly
Beheaded were by the Kings cruelty.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Stanleius tenui pro cauſa, aut crimine nullo,

lg.l: Varveciuſque Comes ſustinuere necem.
Stanley for ſmal cauſ, or no crime at al;
And Earl of Warwick ſuffred fatal fal.

argument.p: The 2 Margarits (Mother and Daughter to Henry the ſeventh) which cauſed or occaſioned two unions.

lg.l: Margaritae uno vocitatae nomine, fauſtis

l.hi: Junxere auspiciis Regna Roſaſque duae.

lg.l: Two Marg'rits cald by one name, happily
Both Realms and Roſes join'd in unity.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Margarita Parens Henrici, & Filia dicta,

l.hi: Foedere nexerunt Regna Roſaſque pari.

lg.l: Mother and Daughter t' Henry, Marg'rits ſtiled;
The Realms and Roſes in like league compiled.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Margarita duos Regali e ſanguine Natos

l.hi: Protulit: hic Regna, aſt uniit ille Roſas.

lg.l: Two Marg'rits two Sons of blood Roial brought:
This Realms, that Roſes to firm union wrought.

argument.p: The 2 principal Polers, Promoters, Vipers, or Caterpillers; who proſecuted penal Statuts under Henry the ſeventh.

lg.l: Mille modis Populi (Henrico regnante) rapaces

l.hi: Praedones loculos diripuere duo.

lg.l: Two ravenous Polers, when ſeventh Henry reigned,
By thouſand means the Peoples Coffers drained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Depeculatores Henrici tempore bini,
Empſonus Populum Dudleiuſque verant.
Empſon and Dudley in ſeventh Henries dais,
Two Robbers ſpoild the Commons many wais.

argument.p: The 3 moſt potent and opulent Subjects of England, which floriſhed in ſeveral Ages aſunder.

l.hi: Propter opes, Procerum variis ditiſsima ſeclis,
Olim apud Angligenas, eſt celebrata trias.

lg.l: Whilom in England a Trinary of Peers
Renound for riches was in divers yeers.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tres Satrapae Angliaci, locupletes aeris acervos

l.hi: Aurique in loculis ſepoſuere ſuis.

lg.l: Three Engliſh Peers did in their Cloſets hold,
Abundant wealth in ready Coin and Gold.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Plantageniſt, Beaufort, Wolſey ſic nomine dicti

l.hi: Divitiis nimiis tres viguere Viri.

lg.l: Plantagenet, Beaufort, Wolſey cald by name,
Three mighty men to wealth exceſſiv came.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Repletas Proceres variis aetatibus, arcas
Innumeris opibus tres habuere ſuas.

lg.l: Three Peers in ſundry Ages had with Coin Rich. Earl of Cornwal Hen. Card. of Wincheſter. Tho. Cardinal of York.
Their Cheſts ful cram'd, which they bid ſtil purloin.

argument.p: The 6 Women which Henry the eighth ſucceſſivly wedded or eſpouſed by death, divorce, or diſſection.

lg.l: Sex habuit vicibus variis Henricus Amicas,

l.hi: Connubioque ſacro conſociavit eas.

lg.l: Henry ſix Sweet-hearts in ſet turns conſigned,
And them in ſacred Wedlocks bonds combined.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Induit Ʋxores Henricus, & exuit omnes

l.hi: Sex veluti veſtes pro feritate ſua.

lg.l: Henry put on and off al ſix Wifes juſt
As change of Garments, for his furious luſt:

lg.head: Alias
lg.l: Henricus Rex ſex mulieres ordine duxit:

l.hi: Plaeraſque abjecit, vel nece plexit cas.

lg.l: King Harry in order ſix Women wedded: Two divorced: two beheaded: one diſſected: one ſurvived.
But moſt of them rejected or beheaded
Conjugii Henricus Rex bis tres foedere ſancto,

l.hi: Ʋxores varias juxit, amore tori

lg.l: King Henry did in holy Wedlock take
Six ſeveral Wifes for carnal Bed-lovs ſake.

argument.p: The 2 emulous Brothers, whom their Wifes pidling Pride for place or priority confounded.

lg.l: Inter Seimaures diſcordia mutua Fratres,

l.hi: Amborum interetus maxima cauſa fuit.

lg.l: Two Seymors Brethren fel to fel contention,
Which was chief cauſ that brought both to confuſion.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ʋt Sponſis placeant, Seimauri jurgia Fratres,

l.hi: Alter in alterius dira ciere necem.

lg.l: The Brethren Seymors their proud Wifes to pleaſ.
One th' others ruin wrought by wrangling wais.

argument.p: The 2 Princely Perſonages which died untimely: the Mother by diffection, the Son by diſeaſe or Poiſon.

lg.l: Jana Puerperio truculenter perdita ſcalpro eſt:
Sed morte Edvardum poſt periiſſe patet.
With Launce in Child-birth Jane was cruely ſlain:
But ſicknes Edward after kild, 'tis plain.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Ex utero caeſo, pia Mater Jana peribat:
Filius Edvardus tabe peremptus erat.
Jane a good Mother died of hir Wombs diffection:
Edward hir Son languiſh'd in long conſumption.

argument.p: The 2 firſt Females that ever ſwaied Englands ſoveraign Scepter, ſince the Monarchies foundation.

lg.l: Nulla prior Maria geſtabat & Elizabetha
Regia in Angliaco Foemina Sceptra ſolo:
No Woman the Soveraign Scepter, before
Mary and Elizabeth in England yerſt wore.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Foemina prima fuit Maria, Elizabetha ſecunda:
Imperium Angliacum quae tenuere diu.
Mary firſt Woman, next Elizabeth reigned:
Who Englands Roial Empire long obtained.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Nulla apud Angligenas Maria & prior Elizabetha,

l.hi: Portabat Mulier Sceptra ſuprema manu.

lg.l: Til Mary and Elizabeth no Woman bore
The Engliſh Scepter in their hand before.

argument.p: The 2 Soveraign Queens caled Mary who reigned at once (both Papiſts) in Great Brytain.

lg.l:
Scotorum Anglorum
que
ſimul Regina Maria

l.hi: Inſula in hac uno nomine dicta fuit.

lg.l: In this Ile was a Scotſh and Engliſh Queen
Cald b' one name Mary, reigning at once ſeen.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Reginae Henrici ſepteni e ſtirpe Mariae

l.hi: (Ambae Papicolae) Sceptra tulere ſimul.

lg.l: Maries (both Papiſts) of ſeventh Henries race,
Englands & Scotlands Queens reign'd in one ſpace.

argument.p: The 2 potent Dukes, who loſt their heads in one and the ſame yeer for ſeveral Rebellions.

l.hi: Reginam adverſus pro proditione, ſecuri
Juſte habuere duo colla rejecta Duces.

lg.l: Two Dukes their heads had juſtly diſſevred
For Treaſon 'gainſt the Queen as they deſerved.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Dudleius Grainſque Duces meritò, arma ferentes

l.hi: Contra Reginam, ſuſtinuere necem.

lg.l: Dudley and Gray Dukes, for Hoſtility
Againſt the Queen ſuffred death worthily.

argument.p: The 2 Duchiſſes of Suffolk (a Stepdame and Daughter in Law) meanly married to ſecund Husbands.

l.hi: Eximia geminae de ſtirpe fuere Duciſſae:
Denuo at obſcuris utraque nupta Viris.

lg.l: Ther were two Duchiſſes of high Progeny;
Both did wed men of mean quality.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Franceſca & Catherina ſuo viduata Marito,

l.hi: Eſt alii indigno poſtmodo juncta Viro.

lg.l: Catherin and Franceſſ of their Mates widowed,
To other worthleſſ men were after wedded.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Franceſca orba viro, Catherinaque clara Duciſſa

l.hi: Eſt alii ex humili ſorte renupta novo.

lg.l: Cath'rin and Franceſſ Duchiſſes Husband-free,
Were reeſpouſd to new of low degree.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Ʋtraque constabat Suffolcia jure Duciſſa:

l.hi: Illa Noverca ferox, haec fuit alma Nurus.

lg.l: Both Suffolk Duchiſſes were by wonted right:
That Stepdame fierce, this legal Daughter bright.

lg.head: Secius.
lg.l: Franceſca & Catherino Viro primo orba, viciſſim

l.hi: Sponſo alii obſcuro conſociata fuit.

lg.l: Cath'rin and Franceſſ of firſt Pheers deprived,
With other mean men were in match combined.

argument.p: The 10 chief Inſurrections in Ireland under Queen Elizabeths reign: beſide ſom leſſer Tumults.

lg.l: Gens aluit furioſa feros Hybernica motus,

l.hi: Bis quinque hoc aevo temporibuſque Patrum.

lg.l: Fierce Ireland did t • n fel Rebellions • a • ſ,
In this laſt age, and in our Fathers dais.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Protulit infeſtos Hybernica Terra Tumultus,
Dum regnabat adhuc El • zabetha, decem.
Ireland once ſtird ten Tumults tough maintained,
While Englands Queen Elizabeth then reigned.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Sub regno, tetricas bis quinque Hybernica, Elizae

l.hi: Gens tempaſtates ſeditioſa ciet.

lg.l: The Iriſh People wild in Elizabeths reign,
Ten turbulent Commotions did maintain.

argument.p: The 8 clandeſtine Conſpiracies contrived by Traitors againſt Queen Elizabeths life.

lg.l: Conjuratores bis quatuor Elizabetham

l.hi: Tentabant tacite perdere, mille modis.

lg.l: Eight Traitors and their Conſorts thouſand wais,
To kil Queen El'zabeth made cloſe eſſ • is.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Elizabethae octo Patricide tollere vitam

l.hi: Sanguinei mediis conſtituere malis.

lg.l: Eight bloody Paricids by il means contrived,
Queen Elizabeth of life to hav deprived.

argument.p: The 10 ſundry Suitors for mariage (Forren and Engliſh) to the ſaid Queen Elizabeth in hir reign.

lg.l: Regina Angliacum poſtquam Diadema recepit,
Nacta eſt bis quinos Elizabetha Procos.
When Englands Crown Queen El'zabeth had gained
For lov therof ten Suitors ſhe obtained.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Reginae extiterat numeroſa propago Procerum:
Tanti pollet honos, & ditionis amor.

lg.l: The Queen of Wooers had a large rapſody:
Such force hath greatnes, and lov of Roialty.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Anglica Poſteaquam geſtabat Sceptra, potentes
Eſt ſibi nacta Procos Elizabetha decem.
While Elizabeth the Engliſh Scepter bore,
She had ten potent Suitors, none before.

argument.p: The 3 great Statſ-men caled William, who ſerved Henry the eighth, and his three Roial Children.

l.hi: Quatuor Imperii claro Diademate oincti,
Summo in Concilio tres habuere Sophos.

lg.l: Four Monarchs which our Roial Crown did wear,
Held three wiſe Statſ-men in their Council dear.

lg.head: Aliter:

l.hi: Conſiliis ſummis tres una aetate ſagaces
Bis binis Superis Conſuluere Viri.

lg.l: Three Counſilors for high affairs of State,
Four Soveraigns ſerved imone Age of late.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Poulettus, Petrus & Cecillius unico in aevo.

l.hi: Conſilio celebres tres viguere Sophi.

lg.l: Three (Poulet, Petre, Cecil) men moſt wiſe,
Renownd for Counſil, in one age did riſe.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Bis duo Conſiliis ſacris habuere Monarchae,
Tres atate una, qui viguere, Sophos.

lg.l: Four Monarchs had three Counſilors in one age;
Wiſe men, who State affairs long did manage.

argument.p: The 2 falſ, fraudulent, flagitious Scotiſh Earls who ſought by wicked wais to ſway their State.

l.hi: Falſiloqui Comites Scotici duo fraude referti,
Mille dolis dom nam depoſuere 〈◊〉 .

lg.l: Two falſ Scotſh Earls of Fox-craft fraud compoſed,
Their Soveraign Queen by thouſand wiles depoſed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Fraude doloque duo, Scotico ſunt femine nati,
Inſidias Dominae qui poſuere ſuae.

lg.l: Two born Scots were, who for their Queen traps laid,
And hir by ſubtle craft to de • th betraid:

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Morreius Mo conuſ que duo de Gente Scotorum,

l.hi: Aſtuti & pleni fraude fue-re Viri.

lg.l: Murrey and Morton, Scots by proſapy,
Were two men ful of fraud and ſubilety

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Murreius Satrapas, Mortonus itemque Dynaſta;

l.hi: Ambo Viri Scotica fraude fuere ſati.

lg.l: Murrey and Morton both Scots Earls by Nation:
Were wily men by Scotiſh education.

argument.p: The 2 peſtilent Polititians in England, who matched or overmatched thoſ two laſt Scots.

lg.l: Dedleius Genitor perquam ſceleratus habetur:

l.hi: Nequier at multo Filius ejus erat.

lg.l: Dudley the Sire moſt vile man was eſteemed:
But his Son Robert much more wicked deemed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Improbus eſt Genitor, mage filius impius illo.

lg.l: Dudleius proprium nomen utrique fuit.
A naughty Sire, Son was more vile then hee:
Dudleis hight both by name and pedigree.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Dudleius Genitor Dux, quo non nequior ullus:

l.hi: Filius at vitiis exuperabat eum.

lg.l: Father Duke Dudley, then whom none worſ was: Witnes Leiceſters Cōmonw.
But's Son in Villanies did him far ſurpaſſ.

argument.p: The 2 chief domeſtic Corrivals or Competitors of Englands Diadem in Queen Elizabeths dais.

l.hi: Rivales Diadema duo quaſi jure petebant

lg.l: Anglicum, at armata vi ſuperare parant.
Two Rivals Englands Crown claimd as by right,
But ſought to conquer it by armed might.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Regnum Hunting • oniae Comes, & Regina Scotorum
Angliacum, expeterant ambitione pari.
Huntingtons Earl, and Queen of Scotiſh Nation
Sought Englands Kingdom with a like ambition.

argument.p: The 2 lat Kings of England, who were Scots by Birth, Linage, Nature, and Nation.

lg.l: Angliacum Natu, Patria, Genioque Scotiſtae,

l.hi: Imperium Reges obtinuere duo.

lg.l: Two Kings by Birth, Country, and Proſapy
Pure Scots, attaind to Englands Soveraignty.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Jacobus Scotiae fuit & Rex Carolus ortu:
Qui Diadema Anglum jure tulere ſuo.
James was Scots King and Charls; being both born there:
Who the Engliſh Crown in their own right did wear.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Anglia cum Scotia juncta eſt regnante Jacobo:
Angliacum at Carolus vix Diadema tulit.
England with Scotland was joind in James reign:
But Charls the Engliſh Crown could ſcarſ contain.

argument.p: The 2 chief Conſpiracies contrived againſt King James life in Scotland and England.

lg.l: Abdita Gouraei in Regem fabricata Jacobum

l.hi: Turba & proditio dicta Nitroſa fuit.

lg.l: Gowries cloſe rout againſt King James was framed:
So was another, that's Powder-Treaſon named.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Rutheni in Regem conſpiravere Jacobum:

l.hi: Nitroſaque rei proditionis item.

lg.l: Two Ruthens Brethren 'gainſt King James conſpired:
And Powder-trai • ors eke his death contrived.

argument.p: The 2 Soveraigns (Grandmother and Grandſon) which were publickly beheaded in England.

lg.l: Mortemala Maria afficitur Regina Scotorum:
Carolus Anglorum Rex quoque paſſus idem eſt.
Mary Scots Queen beheaded was with ſhame:
Charls Englands King ſuffred likewiſe the ſame.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Scotorum nece plexa gravi eſt Regina Maria:
Rex itidem Carolus decapitatus crat.
With grievous death Mary Scots Queen was quelled:
And King Charls too with bloody Ax was felled.

argument.p: The 2 Engliſh Monarchs, who had a ſemblable ſymphony of degree, diſpoſition and deſtiny.

lg.l: Moribus Henricus ſimiles Caroluſque benignis,
Reges Angliaci morte obire truci.
Henry and Charls in maners mild allied,
Two Engliſh Kings a bloody moiſt death dyed.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Henricus ſextus Caroluſque fuere ſacrato

l.hi: Zelo, Juſtitia, Morte, fideque pares.

lg.l: Sixth Henry and Charls were like in Sanctity,
Zele, Juſtice, Death, and Faiths ſincerity.

div.head: EPIG. XCIX. Satrapae a Parlemento decollati.

argument.p: The 2 great Peers (a Spiritual and Temporal) condemned and beheaded by the Parlement.

lg.l: Straffordi celebris Comes, Archiepiſcopus atque

l.hi: Concilio a ſummo ſuſtinuere necem.

lg.l: Straffords great Earl by th' higheſt Court was tried,
And Archbiſhop too: who both by their doom died.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Straffordus Capite eſt, atque Archepiſcopus ictus,

l.hi: Concilii ad placitum: clarus uterque fuit.

lg.l: Strafford and Archbiſhop men moſt eminent,
Were doon to death by power of Parlement.

argument.p: The 3 Noblemen (a Duke, Earl, Baron) beheaded at one time or turn by the high Court of Juſtice.

l.hi: Tres Proceres uno praeſecti colla ſecuri,
(Dux, Comes, atque Baro) compericre die.

lg.l: Three Peers their Heads with Ax being chop'd away;
(Duke, Earl, Baron) together died in one day.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ʋno tres Satrapae vi cecidere die.

lg.l: Arrans Duke, Hollands Earl, and Capel of fame;
Three Peers to violent death in one day came.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Hammilton, Richius, Capel: hi tres pegmine plexi,

l.hi: Ʋno obiere die: Dux, Comes, atque Baro.

lg.l: Hamleton, Rich, Capel: three puniſh'd on Scaffold,
In one day died: Duke, Earl, and Baron bold.

l.hi: Anglorum & Brytonum primaeva ab origine Gentis,
Ad noſtra Hiſtoriae deductum eſt tempora filum.

lg.l: The Stories thred of Bryts and Engliſh Nation,
Is drawn down to our times from firſt foundation.

l.hi: Anglice, Civis habes ſeriem haec faragine textam,
Nativa Hiſtoriae quae canit acta tuae

lg.l: Countriman, thou haſt couch'd in this Rapſody,
The Nativ acts ſung of thy Hiſtory.

l.hi: Inſulae hic Hiſtorico, quae ſunt mage propria noſtrae,
Lector, ſcripta modò continet acta Liber.

lg.l: Reader, this Book in Story-wiſe contains,
What acts t' our Ile more properly pertains.

l.hi: Si Patriae Hiſtoriam oupis, haec erit amodò grata:
Corpus enim totum complicat iſta ſtrues

lg.l: This Pile, if thou thy Countries Story lov;
Which the whol Body folds▪ wil gratful prov.

l.hi: Hiſtorico noſtrae memoratur carmine Gentis
Geſta: quibus celebris tempus in omne fuit.

lg.l: In Story-verſ our Nations Geſts are crowned:
Wherby through al times it hath bin renowned.

div.head: Miſcellaneal Eſſais. The fifth Claſsis or Century of Miſcellaneals: under three grand Heads.

argument.p: The 2 diſtinct Realms (England, Scotland) belonging to the famous Ile now caled Great Brytain.

lg.l: ANglia cum Scotia fit Magna Brytannia, nuper
Rege a Jacobo; nomine dicta ſuo.
England and Scotland Great Brytain became,
Late by King James; ſo cald by hir own name.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Angligenae atque Scoti vocitati rite Brytanni:

lg.l: Rex Jacobus enim conſociavit eos.
Engliſh and Scors are rightly Brytans named:
For King James both into Great Brytain framed.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Anglia cum Scotia conjuncta a Rege Jacobo,
Magna Brytannorum eſt Inſula dicta recens.
England and Scotland by King James united,
Was the great Ile of Brytans late indited.

argument.p: The 40 Counties or Shires ſetled in England by Parlement under Henry the eighth, as Cambden claſſicats.

l.hi: Quadraginta ſuos diſtinguitur in Comitatus

lg.l: Anglia, circuitu tam ſpatioſa ſuo.
England contains fourty Shires by name ſtated
In hir large circuit, wherto yerſt 'tis ſhared.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sat spatio ſpecioſa ſuo, Comitatibus aucta eſt

lg.l: Quadraginta, viris Anglica terra potens.
England with fourty Counties is augmented:
A large fair Land with warlike men wel fenced.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Bis viginti amplas Satrapias Anglica tellus,

l.hi: Diſtinctas memorat ſub ditione ſua.

lg.l: England ful fourty ſpacious Shires contains
Diſtinct, which under hir precincts remains,

argument.p: The 26 chief Cities of name and note in England: as they are marſhaled by Cambden.

lg.l: Anglia bis tredecim celebres hodie exhibet Ʋrbes:

l.hi: Quae bene ſtructuris divitiiſque valent.

lg.l: Twiſe thirteen Cities England now doth ſhow:
Which with brav buildings & much wealth doo flow.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Urbes Angligenae ſex vigintique recenſent,
Pollentes opibus magnanimiſque Viris.

lg.l: Twenty ſix Cities th' Engliſh ſtil account,
which doo in riches and ſtout men ſurmount.

argument.p: The 2 goodly glorious Univerſities or general Studies extant in England, as the Eys thereof.

l.hi: Binae apud Angligenas extant Academiae amaenae:
Quae doctis studiis & pietate micant.

lg.l: England hath two fair Academies known wel:
Which doo in learning and godlines excel.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Vendicat Oxoniae primas Academia ſedes:
Cantabriae Angliacae jure ſecunda datur.
Oxford was Englands firſt univerſity:
Cambridg claims the next • ight of Antiquity.

lg.head: Alias
lg.l: Oxonii Henrici eſt Academia tertii in aevo;
Cantabria Edvardi tempore facta fuit.
Oxford an Academ in third Henries reign,
Cambridg in Edwards time did it attain.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Oxonium veluti eſt, fa •• um eſt Academia Grantum:

l.hi: Artibus ingenuis pollet utrumque ſ • i • .

lg.l: Grantam like Oxford, was made a • Academy:
Both famous places for Arts general ſtudy.

lg.head: Secius.
lg.l: Oxonium primo fundatum eſt, deinde ſecundum
Urbs Cantabrigiae vult ſibi jure locum.
Oxford firſt founded was, next by du right
The ſecund place that Town claims Cambridg hight.

lg.head: Sive.
lg.l: Oxonienſis habet primas Academia partes:
Cantabridgenſis proxima jure ſuo eſt.
Oxford's the prime ſtudy for antiquity:
And cambridg by du right next Academy.

argument.p: The 3 diſtinct Principalities, into which Cambry (now caled Wales) was of old diſtributed.

lg.l: In tres diſtribuit Rodericus Wallica partes

l.hi: Rura ſub imperio quando fuere ſuo.

lg.l: Rodric divided Wales-Principallty
Into three parts when al was in his Primacy.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: In tres diviſa eſt Satrapias Wallia magno
A Roderico olim, dum dominatus erat.
Into three Princedoms whilom Wales divided
Was by great Rodric, while he o're al preſided.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Intertres Natos Rodericus tempore priſco,
Praedia diſtribuit Wallica iure ſuo.
Rodric of old 'monſt his three Sons by right
Shared the Lands in Wales; and not by might.

argument.p: The 12 Shires or Counties of Wales-Principality, as Henry the eighth ſetled it; annexing Monmouth to England.

lg.l: Bis ſex nunc numerat comitatus Wallia tantum:
Nomine quae priſco Cambria dicta fuit.
Wales numbers now twelv only Shires of fame:
Which Country was cald Cambry by old name.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Cambria bis ſenos Comitatus continet, una

l.hi: Undique distinctos ſub ditione ſua.

lg.l: Cambry twelv Shires contains under one dition,
Ech way diſtinguiſh'd by their Juriſdiction.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Wallica terra tenet duodenos nunc Comitatus

l.hi: Diſtinctos; una ſub ditione tamen.

lg.l: Wales now contains twelv Shires in Signiory,
Yet diverſly diſtinct in Soveraignty.

argument.p: The 2 renowned rarities or ſingularities, which Nature produceth in Cambria, now Wales.

l.hi: Naturae Tellus oſtentat Opuſcula rara

lg.l: Cambrica, quae valde prodigioſa canunt.
Wales boaſts ſom works of Nature very rare,
Which they ſet forth for famous wondrous ware.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Penlinus Lacus eſt, & Fons Nova Villa vocatus:
Quae Vulgus reputat Cambrica Miraduo.
Ther's Pimble Meer, and Newton Wel ſo named:
Which People hav for Wales two wonders framed.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Wallica praecipue duo Gens miranda recenſet:
Penlinumque Lacum, Fonticulumque Novum.
The Welſh to th' World doth two chief wonders tel:
Both Pimble Meer, and Sandfords Newton Wel.

argument.p: The 145 ſmal Ilands (commonly caled Sillies or Sorlings) belonging to Cornwal in England.

lg.l: Inſulae in Occiduo variae, cognomine Sillies,
Oceano prope ſunt Cornubienſe ſolum.
In the Weſt Ocean, divers Iles ther are
Cald Sillies; which from Cornwal ly not far.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Centum, quadraginta jacent, & quinque Silures
Inſula in Oceano: Cornubiamque colunt.
Sevnſcore and fiv Iles, by name Sillies hight
Ly in the Sea: and Cornwals are by right.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Hesperides medio ponuntur in aequore multae:
Sed nomen proprium ſolum habuere decem.

lg.l: Many weſt Iles in midſt of Sea doo ly:
But ten alone hav names to be known by.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Sunt Caſsiterides variae, dictaeque Silurae:
Quae reſident ultra Cornubienſe Solum.
Sundry Caſſiterids cald Sorlings ther be:
Which beyond Cornwal ly in view to ſee.

argument.p: The 2 Land-waters or Rivers wonderfully divided; the higher parts abov from thoſ below.

lg.l: Retro repercutitur Jordanus & Ouſeu samnis:

l.hi: Quorum utrinque stetit ſciſſa parumper Aqua.

lg.l: Jordan and Ouſe two Rivers were retunded:
Whoſ waters ſom ſpace ſtood on both parts ſundred.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Jordanus Fluvius dudum retroibat, & Ouſus:

l.hi: Unda utriuſque brevi diſſociata fuit.

lg.l: Jordan long ſince, and Ouſe ſtream back retreated:
For both their waters were a while diſſeated,

argument.p: The 2 Rivers which riſe neer together (ſom ſay under one Ruſh-Buſh) in Devon: which fal into two oppoſit Seas.

lg.l: Flumina Devoniae duo Campo oriuntur in uno:

l.hi: Quae procul oppoſitis curſibus ambo fluunt.

lg.l: Two Denſhire Rivers in one field doo riſe:
Both which run far and neer contrariwiſe.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Sunt duo Devoniae (Tamer & Touridgia) Rivi:

l.hi: Qui ſimul ex uno fonte fluente ſcatent.

lg.l: Two Denſhire Rivers neer contermining,
(Tamer and Touridg) from one quick ſource ſpring.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Flumina ſunt duo Devonia (Touridgia, Tamer:)

l.hi: Contiguiſque ſimul Fontibus ambo fluunt.

lg.l: Two Denſhire Rivers (Touridg, Tamer) are:
And both from Fountains riſe diſ-joind not far.

argument.p: The 4 noted names which hav bin aſcribed or aſſigned to Exceſter City in Devonſhire

l.hi: Iſcia in Occiduo jacet Ʋrbs celeberrima Regni:
Quae variis ſeclis nomina mul ta tulit.

lg.l: Weſt in this Realm fair Exter City's placed:
With ſundry names in ſeveral ages graced.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Occiduis urbs eſt Anglorum partibus alma:
Quae ſita juxta amnem eſt, Iſcaque nomen habet.
In weſt of England is a City of fame:
Which lies neer to a River, Ex by name.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Quatuor Exoniae data n • mina nota fuere:
Quae prope Rivum urbs eſt, Iſcia dicta prius.
Four names of note to Exon were aſcribed:
Which of Ex River Exton of old was ſtiled.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Iſcia, Pencaira, urbs Monachorum, Exceſtria: dudum

l.hi: Nota his nominibus quatuor uſque fuit.

lg.l: Iſc, Pencair, Moncton, Exceſter: of old
Were four names wel known givn, which ever hold.

argument.p: The 10 ſeveral ſieges of Exceſter: with the various ſucceſſes, agitations, and events of ech.

lg.l: Partibus occiduis • acet Urbs Exceſtria dicta:

l.hi: Obſita quae decies obſidione fuit.

lg.l: Exter a noble City is in the weſt:
Which hath ten times with ſtrong ſiege bin oppreſt.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Ʋrbs ſita Devoniae in medio, cui Exceſtria nomen:

l.hi: Cincta fuit decies obſidione gravi.

lg.l: In midſt of Devon Exter City ſeated
Hath with ten ſieges grievouſly bin ſtreited.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Clara decem vicibus, variis aetatibus arcta

lg.l: Occluſa Exoniae Urbs obſidione ſtetit.
Ten turns was Exon a City renowned,
In ſeveral ages with ſtrict ſiege ſurrounded.

lg.head: Ephiphonema.
lg.l: Exoniae Ʋrbs decies aetatibus obſita priſcis:

l.hi: Bis spoliata fuit, ter tradita, ſaepe redempta.

lg.l: Exter in former ages ten times ſieged:
Was twiſe ſpoild, yeelded thriſe, fiv times relieved.

argument.p: The 4 uſual Terms of Law, held every yeer at Weſtminſter, London, or elſwher in England.

l.hi: Quatuor Angligenis exiſtunt Termini in anno:
Lana quibus rixas ſaepe caprina ciet.

lg.l: Four terms are held in England every wher:
Wher brabbles oftimes for Goats wool appeer.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Terminus eſt Hilari, Paſchae, Triadiſque ſupremae:
Ʋltimus inter eos ſed Michaelis erit.
Thers Hilari, Easter, and high Trinity: So ſom comput.
But laſt of theſ Terms Michaels courſ wil be.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Terminus a Michaele praeeſt: Hilarique ſecundus:
Tertius a Poſcha eſt: ultimus a Triade.
Saint Michaels Term is Father: next Hilari: So others reckon.
The third is Eaſter: the laſt Trinity.

argument.p: The 2 chief Laws (Civil and Common) practiſed in England, til one devoured another.

lg.l: Jus Civile Anglis & Municipale ſuperſtat:

l.hi: Sed prius areſcens invalidumque manet.

lg.l: England the Civil and Common Law retains:
But the firſt withring and infirm remains.
Hoc Vacca est gracilis Pharaonis, illud obeſa:

l.hi: Praepinguem demum ſed macilenta vorat.

lg.l: This Pharaohs lean Cow ſhapes, that fat aſſumed:
But the lean Cow at length the fat conſumed.

argument.p: The 365 dais, and 6 hours; wherof a Julian Solar yeer in England yet conſiſts.

l.hi: Quinque dies totos, decies ſex, ter quoque centum;

lg.l: Praeter ſex boras, Julius annus habet.
Three hundred ſixty fiv ful dais appeer,
Beſide ſix hours; in every Julian yeer.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Saxaginta dies, ter centum, & quinque viciſsim,

lg.l: Sexque horas ſolidas Anglicus annus habet.
Three hundred ſixty and fiv dais amain;
And ſix whole hours doth th' Engliſh yeer contain.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Ter centum bis terque decem, cum quinque diebus
Sex itidemque horas integer annus habet.

lg.l: Three hundred, ſixty, and fiv intire dais,
And eke ſix hours an intire yeer doth raiſ.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Ter centum ſolidos, decies ſex, quinque dieſque,

lg.l: Sexque Soſigineus fine horas continet annus.
Soſigenes yeer doth with ſix hours at th' end,
Three hundred, threeſcore, and fiv dais compr'end.

div.head: EPIG. XVI. Decimae duplici jure ratae.

argument.p: The 2 main rights which the Engliſh Clergy hath (beyond others) to Tiths or Fruits of the Land.

l.hi: Debentur Decimae duplici diplomate Clero:
Scilicet Humano jure, ſacroque Dei.

lg.l: Tiths du to th' Engliſh Clergy rightly be,
By duple Chart of God and Mans Decree.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Praesbyteris Decimas Deus appropriavit, eaſque
Angliaci Reges sponte dedere ſua.

lg.l: Tiths are Prieſts rights by Gods appropriation,
And Engliſh Kings made of them free donation.

div.head: EPIG. XVII. Nomina huic Inſulae ominoſa.

argument.p: The 16 proper Names beginning with one Letter (H) which hav bin ominous to this Ile for good or bad.

lg.l: Apropria Heroum Brytannis nomina quondam

l.hi: Bis octo incipiens, omnia magna tulit.

lg.l: Of ſixten great names H firſt Letter was,
Which in Great Brytain brought great things to paſſ.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Historias veterum varias H litera pandit:

l.hi: Nominibus propriis quae patefacta jacent.

lg.l: Diverſold Stories H letter doth deſcry:
Which doo in proper Names diſcloſed ly.

argument.p: Humbar, Helena, Hengiſt, Horſa, Hungar, Hubba, Harold, Hardicnut before the Conqueſt; and 8 Henries Kings of England ſince. Al which brought ſom memorable mutations to Great Brytain.
The 10 Protoprimats of Canterbury, who had Funeral Eulogies or Elegies made upon them.

lg.head: 1. Auſtin.
lg.l: Inclitus Anglorum Praeſul pius, & decus altum
Hic Auguſtinus requieſcit corpore ſanctus.

l.hi: Ad tumulum charo Patris almi ductus amore,

lg.l: Abbas hunc Tumulum Thomas dictavit honore.
Here holy Auſtins Body reſts inſhrined,
Englands chief Prelat for zele moſt admired.
This Tomb t' his honor Abbat Thomas did raiſ,
For that dear Fathers lov to ſound his praiſ.

lg.head: 2. Laurence.
lg.l: Hic ſacra, Laurenti, ſunt ſigna tui Manumenti:

l.hi: Tu quoque jucundus Pater, Antiſteſque ſecundus.
