Pro populo Chriſti ſcapulas dorſumque dediſti:
Artubus hunc laceris multa vibice mederis.

lg.l: Laurence, thy ſacred Monuments ly here:
Thou jolly Father, ſecund Primat dear.
For Chriſts Flock thou thy back & ſhoulders gaveſt
whom by thy torn limbs wth thoſ ſtripes thou ſaveſt

lg.head: 3. Mellitus

l.hi: Summus Pontificum Flos tertius, & Mel apricum;
Hac titulis clara redoles, Mellite, ſub Ara.

lg.l: Laudibus aeternis te praedicat urbs Dorovernis:

l.hi: Cui ſimul ardenti restat virtute potenti.

lg.l: Mellit, third Flour of Prelats, Hony cleer;
With titles thou ſmelſt ſweet under th' Urn here.
Canterbury ſounds forth thy ſtil laſting praiſ,
Which thou by flaming power of zele dooſt raiſ.

lg.head: 4. Juſtus.
lg.l: Iſtud habet bustum merito cognomine Juſtum:

l.hi: Quarto jure datus cui ceſsit pontificatus.

lg.l: Pro meritis Juſti ſancta gravitate venuſti

l.hi: Gratia divinam divina dat huic medicinam.

lg.l: This Grave holds Justus, worthily ſo hight:
Who was fourth Primat of this Church by right.
For Juſtus merits adorn'd with gravity,
Gods Grace to him gav divine remedy,

lg.head: 5. Honorius.
lg.l: Quintus honor memori verſu memoraris, Honoti:

l.hi: Digna ſepuitura, quam non tenet ulla litura.
Ardet in obſcuro tua lux vibramine puro:
Haec ſcelus omne premit, fugat umbras, nubila de mit.

lg.l: Honorius, fifth honor art in du verſ framed:
Thy Grav is worthy not to be defamed:
Thy light in Darknes ſhines with luſtre pure:
Wch lewdnes quels, drivs ſhades, rids clouds obſcure

lg.head: 6. Deuſdedit.
lg.l: Alme Deuſdedit, cui ſexta vacatio cedit;

l.hi: Signas hunc Lapidem, Lapidi ſignatus eidem.
Prodit ab hac Ʋrna Virtute ſalus diuturna:
Qua melioratur, quicunque dolore gravatur.

lg.l: Rare Deuſdedit, ſixth Primat of this Place:
Thy name this ſtone bears, thou ye ſtone dooſt grace
From this Urn healing Virtu flows, whence he
That's il diſpoſed, may much bettred be.

lg.head: 7. Theodorus.

l.hi: Hic ſacer in tumulo pauſat cum cor pore Praeſul,

lg.l: Quem tunc Theodorum lingua Pelaſga vocat.

l.hi: Princeps Pontiſicum, foelix ſummuſque Sacerdos
Limpida Diſcipulis dogmata diſſeruit.

lg.l: Nempe diem nonum decimum September habebat,

l.hi: Cum carnis claustro Spiritus egreditur.
Alma novae ſcandens ſoelix conſortia vitae,
Civibus Angelicis junctus in arce Poli.

lg.l: Here lies a ſacred Primat clos'd in Grav,
To whom the Greec toung name of Theodor gav.
He ſoveraign title had of ech Degree,
And Chriſts Flock fed with Doctrins, as men ſee.
His Soul was freed from Iumpiſh Cage of clay,
When nineten dais September paſt away.
Who ſeeking mens ſociety of good life,
Sings hymns with Angels void of care or ſtrife.

lg.head: 8. Brithwald.
lg.l: Stat ſua laus feretro Brithwaldi, ſtat ſua metro:

l.hi: Sed minor eſt metrilaus omnis laude feretri.
Lande frequent andus Pater eſt, & glorificandus:
Si prece flectatur, det ei qui digna precatur.

lg.l: Du praiſ hath Brithwalds Herſ, like hath his Verſ:
But Verſes praiſ is leſſ then that of Herſ.
This Father muſt be prais'd and glorified:
If praier prevail let him be dignified.

lg.head: 9. Tarwin.
lg.l: Pontificis Glebae Tatwini Cantia praebe

l.hi: Thura, decus, laudes; in cujus dogmate gaudes.
Hujus doctrina caruiſti mente ferina,
Et per eum Christi portare jugum didiciſti.

lg.l: To Primat Tatwins Tumb Kent Inceſ bring,
Honor, and Praiſ, whoſ Doctrin thou dooſt ſing.
His teaching thee from Bruitiſh mind did rear,
And by his means thou learnſt Chriſts yoke to bear

lg.head: 10. Nothelm.
lg.l: Hac ſcrobe Nothelmus jacet Archiepiſcopus almus:

l.hi: Cujus vita bono non est indigna Patrono.
Omnibus iſte bonus par in bonitate Patronus,
Protegit hic Juſtos vigili munimine cuſtos.

lg.l: Nothelm brav Archbiſhop lies in this Grav:
Whoſ life deſervs a Patron good to hav.
Like Patron he in bounty was to al,
Who with good guard the Juſt did ſhield from fal.

lg.head: Concluſio.
lg.l: Primates bis quinque Epicedia Canturienſes

l.hi: Haec memorant, primas qui tenuere Vices.

lg.l: Theſ Epitaphs fram'd on ten firſt Primats be:
Which held the ſtern of Canterbury See.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Condecorat dudum Dorobernia Metropolitas,

l.hi: Funereo primos carmine priſca decem.

lg.l: Whilom old Canterb'ry with Funeral Verſ,
Jointly adornd their firſt ten Primats Herſ.

argument.p: The 3 Epitaphs framed or compoſed on 3 Queens of high degree and dignity in England.

lg.head: Matilda Imperatrix
lg.l: 1. Ortu magna, Viro major, ſed maxima Prole:
Hic jacet Henrici Filia, Sponſa, Parens.
Great, Greater, Greateſt; by Birrh, Match, Son dear:
Daughter, Wife, Mother of three Henries lies here.

lg.head: Jana Regina Angliae
lg.l: 2. Phoenix Jana jacet nato Phoenice: dolendum,

l.hi: Secula Phoenices nulla tuliſſe duos.

lg.l: Phenix Jane died a Phenix born: ſad thing,
That no Age two ſuch rare Birds once did bring.

lg.head: Maria Regina Scotiae
lg.l: 3. Regibus orta, auxi Reges, Reginaque vixi:

l.hi: Ter nupta, & tribus orba viris, tria Regna reliqui.

lg.l: I born of Kings, advanc'd Kings, a Queen lived
Thriſe wedded, Widow thriſe, three Kingdoms quited

l.hi: Tres ergo quindenos obii prognata per annos
Ter conjux, tribus orba Viris, tribus orbaque Regnis.

lg.l: At fourty fiv yeers I of life bereft,
Thriſe Wife, thriſe Widow was, three Kingdoms left.

lg.head: Epilogus.

l.hi: Tres ſuper illuſtres tria ſunt Epicedia ſcripta
Reginas, meritis undique digna ſuis.

lg.l: On three great Queens, three Epitaphs were writ:
Which to their merits every way did fit.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Matildae, Janae haec Epicedia, itemque Mariae

l.hi: Reſpondent meritis appropriata ſuis.

lg.l: The forewrit Threnes on Mawd, Jane, Mary filed;
Are to their merits properly compiled.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Nomina Reginis ſunt Jana, Matilda, Maria

l.hi: Aſsignata tribus; quae patuere prius.

lg.l: Mawd, Jane, and Mary are the names aſcribed
To thoſ three Queens, which are before deſcribed.

argument.p: The 24 yeers which the firſt Major of London (Fitz-Alwin) held his Office continualy til his death.

lg.l: Londini primus Fitz-Alwin Praetor in Urbe eſt:

l.hi: Annos ſexque quater Praetor in Ʋrbe manet.

lg.l: Fitz-Alwin was firſt Major in London Town:
And twenty four yeers wore the Pretors Gown.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Fitz-Alwin celebris fit primus in Urbe Nomarcha:

l.hi: Qui quater & vicies continuabat Opus.

lg.l: Famous Fitz-Alwin was firſt Major ordained:
Who twenty four turns th' Office ther ſuſtained.

argument.p: The 2 late calamitous Contingents at London, which cauſed the ſudden deaths of diverſ Perſons.

lg.l: Londonii ſtrages forte obvēnere cruentae,

l.hi: Cum multorum hominum perditione, duae.

lg.l: At London two ſhrewd miſchiefs did betide:
Wherby two hundred men untimely died.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Londini obtiger ant clades inceſtiſtimae in Urbe,

l.hi: Quae varios homines enecuere, duae.

lg.l: Two ſad miſhaps in London City fel,
Which ſundry Souls with ſudden death did quel.

l.hi: Una ruina domus multos ſimul obruit: atqui
Pulvero plures comperiere nitro.

lg.l: One Houſes fal cruſh'd many men together:
But more at once were burnt to death with Powder.

argument.p: The 7 chief Gates of name and note leading into London: beſide three leſſer of no mark.

lg.l: Septem praecipuas habet urbs Londonia Portas:

l.hi: Praeter tres alias famaeque notaeque minoris.

lg.l: London ſevn Gates hath of chief note and name:
Beſide three others of leſſ mark or fame.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: U • bs datur Heptapolis Londini, uti pristina Thebe:

l.hi: Quae totidem Portis hodie stabilita ſuperbit.

lg.l: London, like old Thebes, is a City ſevnfold:
Which ſtrengthned with ſevn Gates is ſtrong & bold

argument.p: The 2 great Queens (Forren born) both of one name, but clean contrary in conditions.

lg.l: Reginae duae erant Elinorae nominae dictae:

l.hi: Sed nimis una ſalax, altera caſta ſatis.

lg.l: Ther were two Queens cald Elinors by name:
But one too lewd, th' other of known chaſt fame.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Gallica prima fuit, poſtrema Hiſpanica natu:

l.hi: Queis mala vel bona erat Foemina nulla magis.

lg.l: The firſt was French the laſt Spaniſh by birth:
Then whom none worſ or better livd on Earth.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Illa procax Meretrix Henrico nupta ſecundo:
Haec primi Edvardi Sponſa pudica fuit.
That a luſtful Harlot ſecund Henry's Wife:
This was firſt Edwards Spouſ of moſt chaſt life.

argument.p: The 2 perſons that fel into deep ſleeps, for ful fortnights ſpace together without waking.

l.hi: Vir Mulierque gravi cum ſint data memora ſapori;
Bis ſeptem in lectis decubuere dies.

lg.l: A Man and Maid to deep ſleep did betake
Ful fourten dais in bed, and never wake.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Foemina Maſque Angli ſomno inceſſante ſepulti,
Ʋſque per hebdomadas conticuere duas.

lg.l: An Engliſh Male and Female without ceaſing,
Slept two whol weeks not waking, nor once ſpeaking

lg.head: Alias

l.hi: Vir fuit & Virgo ſani ſolidique, profundum
Qui per bis ſeptem ſomnum iniere dies.

lg.l: Ther was a Man and Maiden ſtrong and ſound,
Which for ful fortnight fel to ſleep profound.

argument.p: The 2 great Counſilors of State to 4 Soveraigns, who died very aged in one yeer 1572

lg.l: Poulettus Petruſque Senes, qui quatuor ambo

l.hi: Servierant Dominis, interiere ſimul.

lg.l: Poulet and Peter died old men together:
Who ſervd four Roial Maſters both and either.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Principibus Petrus & Poulettus quatuor, uno

l.hi: Aevo in Conſiliis ſuppetiere ſacris.

lg.l: Petre and Poulet in one Age of late,
Four Princes ſerv'd as Counſilors of State.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Poulettus Petruſque Sophi viguere coaevi,

l.hi: Et ſub eodem anno comperiere Senes.

lg.l: Sage Poulet and Petre in one age floriſhed,
And in one yeer old men together periſhed.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Mortuus eſt uno Petrus & Poulettus in anno:

l.hi: Principibus fuerant quatuor hi Famuli.

lg.l: Petre and Poulet died both in one yeer:
They ſervd four Princes as chief Statſmen here.

lg.head: Sive.
lg.l: Henrico, Edvardo, Mariae, Elizabethae in eodem
Tempore Poulet • us ſerviit atque Petrus.
Poulet and Potre at one time til death
Servd Henry, Edward, Mary, Elizabeth.

argument.p: The 2 worthy Cammanders in war, who made two memorable Retraits much magnified.

l.hi: Ancipiti inſignes olim duo Marte Receptus,
Cum decore incolumes expediere Duces.

lg.l: Two famous Chieftains ſafe Retraits attained
With honor, being in doubtful war aſſ • iled.
Prudentes celebri Xenophon Norriſque Receptu,

l.hi: Hoſtibus e mediis eripuere ſuos.

lg.l: Wiſe Xenophon and Norris by brav Retraits,
Preſervd their Souldiers from the Foemens baits

argument.p: The 2 golden Voiages of Sir Francis Drake a Devonſhire Man, to get wealth.

lg.l: Drachus ab Hiſpanis Aurum arrcpturus, ad Indos.

l.hi: Bis terve occiduos vela ſecunda dedit.

lg.l: To the Weſt Indies Drake ſaild twiſe by Sea
From Spaniſh Dons to take their Gold away.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Per Mare, per Terras furtim bis Drachus ad Indos

l.hi: Ivit, & innumeras inde reduxit Opes.

lg.l: Drake twiſe through Sea & Lands, by way of ſtealth
To th' Indies went, and brought thence wondrous wealth.

argument.p: The 2 Engliſh Mariners or Souldiers, who ſuffred ſundry miſeries abroad many yeers

l.hi: Per Maria & Terras, per multa pericula Nautae,
Innumeras Clades ſuſtinuere duo.

lg.l: By Seas and Lands through ſundry jeopardies,
Two Sailors ſuffred numberles miſeries.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Carder uti perhibent. & Knevet nomine dicti

l.hi: Angligenae, miſere dira tulere mala.

lg.l: Carder and Knevet Engliſhmen ſo named,
Endurd long direful dangers, as 'tis famed.

argument.p: The 8 Engliſhmen, which were left a whol yeer in Greenland, expoſd to many miſeries.

l.hi: Ter tribus ex Hominum modulamine menſibus, Angli
Clauſi continuis octo fuere Viri.

lg.l: Eight Engliſhmen nine months together pin'd,
Shut up from al ſweet melody of Mankind.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Octo Viri in Terra viridi, cognomine Greenland;

l.hi: Fortuito expoſiti mille fuere malis.

lg.l: Eight men from England to Greenland tranſpoſed,
Were by hard hap to thouſand ils expoſed.

argument.p: The 3 learned Clercs or great Divines, trained up together at Corpus Chriſti College in Oxon.

lg.l: Coenobium Corpus Chriſti cognomine notum,

l.hi: Tres aluit doctos eximioſque Viros.

lg.l: The College Corpus Chriſti cald by name,
Bred in one Age three Scholars of high fame.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tres docti Hookerus, Rainoldus, itemque Juellus.
Devoniae nati, non habuere pares.
Juel, Hooker, Rainolds, men neer of yeers
In Devon born, for learning had no Peers.

argument.p: The 12 Doctors of ſeveral Profeſſions born in Exceter, who lived latly divers yeers at once.

lg.l: Bis ſex Exoniae ſunt intra moenia nati Certiſſimum eſt.

l.hi: Doctores, pariter qui viguere diu,

lg.l: Ther were twelv Doctors born at Exceter
Within the wals, who lived long together.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Theiologi quinque, & medici ſunt quatuor ex his:
Sed tres Juridici, qui viguer ſimul.

lg.l: Of thoſ were fiv Divines, and four Phiſitions;
Which liv'd together: but three ſole Civilians.

argument.p: The 2 unnatural Parents, which more then brutiſhly Butchered the Iſſu of their own bowels.

l.hi: Damone ſeducti, Natura obſtante, Parentes
Filiolos proprios enecuere duo.

lg.l: Two curſed Parents by the Devil wrought,
'Gainſt Natures lore to death their Children brought.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Immanis Pater, & Mater magis improba: Natos
Qui manibus propriis enecuere ſuos.

lg.l: A Savage Sire, and Mother much more fel:
Who with their own hands did their Children quel.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons that were ſuddenly ſiderated or ſlain and ſcorched in bed together with Lightning.

l.hi: Fulmine percuſſi Genitor cum Prole jacentes
In lecto, rapida comperiere nece.

lg.l: Father and Child with Lightning ſtruck in bed John Hichel.
By ſudden flaſh, were found together dead.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sidereo Pater & Natus fuit Igne peremptus:
Sed Pater in cineres prorſus aduſtus erat:

lg.l: A Father and Son by Lightning blaſt were burned:
But Fathers Body quit to aſhes turned.

argument.p: The 2 Women of Boſton in New-England, which brought moſt miſhapen inhuman Births.

l.hi: Schiſmaticae nuper Mulieres, Monſtra nefaſta
Sedibus externis exeruere duae.

lg.l: Two Women latly which Sects and Schiſms wrought,
In forren parts Monſters of ſtrange forms brought.

lg.head: Aliter:
lg.l: Horrida Monſtra ſimul nova protulit Anglia nuper:

l.hi: Quae Faemellae ibidem parturiere duae.

lg.l: New-England latly horrid Monſters yeelded:
Which ther two Women neer at one time breeded.

argument.p: The 2 cheating Aſtrologers (Forman of Lambeth, and Lamb of London) who lived under King James.

l.hi: Falfiloqui Aſtrologi Prognoſtica vana recudunt:
Ut fatuos fallant, retia mille ſtruunt.

lg.l: Falſ-toungd Aſtrologers vain Prognoſticks vent:
Who to chear Idiots, thouſand tricks invent.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Bini Impoſtores Populum, regnante Jacobo,

l.hi: Mentiti Aſtrologos, implicuere dolis,

lg.l: Two cheating faind Aſtrologers, when James reigned
The Vulgar ſort with thouſand wiles deceived.

argument.p: The 2 Mimics or Buffoons, which ſerved as Anvils for the wits of thoſ late times to break Jeaſts on.

lg.l: Par Joculatorum nuper reſidebat in Anglis:

l.hi: Qui noſtro hoc aevo non habuere pares.

lg.l: A brace of Pantimoms lived of late yeers
In England: who in our Age had no Peers.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Brownus in Oxonia, Coryatus in Ʋrbe ſuprema;

l.hi: Inter Laurigerous exciere jocos.

lg.l: In Oxford Brown, Coryat in London Town;
Made ſport for learned wits of much renown.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Dicitur hic Thomas Coryat, Brown ille Joannes:

l.hi: Qui ſoliti aſcitos, ſaepe movere jocos.

lg.l: One Thomas Coryat, th' other John Brown named:
Who being ſent for, mad Jeaſts often framed.

argument.p: The 2 great Sea fights waged An. 1653. betwixt the Engliſh and Holland Fleets.

l.hi: Pugna duplex dudum eſt, nullos habitura triumphos:
Quam cum Anglis Batavi conſeruere Mari.

lg.l: Two fights that hold no Triumphs, lat were waged:
Which Dutch men with th' Engliſh at Sea ingaged.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Contiguae Gentes Terraque, Marique potentes:
Si poterint jungi foedere utraeque pari.

lg.l: Both Neighbour Nations, ſtrong by Sea and Land:
If they conjoind could be in one leagues band.

l.hi: Contendunt Angli & Batavi: miratur & Orbis

lg.l: Neptunum Imperium deſeruiſſe ſuum.
Engliſh and Dutch ſtrov for Seas maſtery,
'Tis wondred how Neptune quitted his Signiory.

div.head: EPIG. XXXVIII. Dracones Vivi in Anglia viſi.

argument.p: The 3 flying (not firy) Serpents denomined Dragons, which hav bin ſeen in this Engliſh Land.

lg.l: Anglia tres olim ſub aperto Sole Dracones

l.hi: Vidit, qui ad ſolitos retro adiere locos.

lg.l: England long ſince three Dragons in open day
Beheld, which to their Dens ſoon went away.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Quartus in Exonia aſpectus, moriente Maria:

l.hi: Ʋt quidam ante obitum vera tulere mihi.

lg.l: A fourth appeer'd at Exter, when Mary died: Nov. 17. 1558.
As ſom in death bed told me of truth tried.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Vivi apud Anglicolas aliquando fuere Dracones
Viſi: qui volitant trans mare retro brevi.

lg.l: Life Dragons were ſomtimes in England ſeen:
Which to their homes yond Sea did ſoon conveen.

div.head: EPIG. XXXIX. Homines Marini in Anglia capti.

argument.p: The 3 Tritons or Mairmen (the Females caled Mairmaids) taken in England: beſide others ſeen here.

l.hi: Tres apud Angligenas homines (fera Monſtra) Marini
Sunt prope captivi littora caluſa Maris.

lg.l: Three Mairmen (Monſters) were in England ſpied
And in Sea-harbors neer the Shores captived.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Temporibus variis, apud Anglos Monſtra Marina

l.hi: Humana ſpecie, capta fuere tria.

lg.l: In Human ſhapes three Monſters of the Sea,
On Engliſh ſhores were caught long hence away.

argument.p: The 2 Neighbour Nations (Engliſh, French) moſt addicted to ſtrife or Law-brabbles of al others.

l.hi: Jurgia Vicinae per plurima ſecula Gentes,
Sumptibus immodicis binae aluere Fori.

lg.l: Two Neighbour Nations Law-ſuits maintain'd moſt
For many ages paſt with immenſ coſt.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Litigioſa nimis fuerat Gens Gallica ſemper:
Anglica Gens nuper fit querulenta magis.
France givn to ſtrife too much was ſtil of yore:
England of late Law-wranglings lov'd much more.

argument.p: The 2 great Bodies of the Univerſ, which ſom tranſverſly turn from the uſual Tenets.

l.hi: OMnia ſuſque malo vertuntur deque tenore:
Luna novus Mundus, Terra Planeta novus.

lg.l: Al things turnd upſidown are in il frame:
The Moon a new World, th' Earth a Planet came,

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ordine tranſverſo novus Orbis Luna vocatur:
Mobilis, at Tellus fixa, Planeta datur.

lg.l: The Moons prepoſtrouſly a new World named,
But the fix'd Earth a moving Planet famed.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Luna recens Mundus, Terra eſſe Planeta videtur:
Si Paradoxa ſatis dogmata vana probent.

lg.l: The Moon a new World, th' Earth a Planet ſee:
If Paradoxes for vain doctrins firm proofs be.

argument.p: The 2 conſtant, contrary, continual courſes of the Ocean, by turns and returns of Ebbing and Flowing.

l.hi: Cernimus Oceanum huc, illuc per littora volvi:
Attamen incerti nos ſumus, unde venit.

lg.l: The Sea roles to and fro through ſhores we ſee:
Yet whence it doth proced, incertain bee.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Dum fluit aequoreas Pelagus refluitque per Oras;
Cauſa rei quam ſcit nemo, ſecreta latet.

lg.l: While through his plain Strands the Sea ebs and flows;
The ſecret Cauſlies hid, which no Man knows.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Bis fluit ac refluit vastum Mare luce ſub omni:
Certa ſed ejuſdem non bene cauſa patet.

lg.l: The vaſt Sea flows and ebs twiſe every day:
But certain cauſ men cannot wel diſplay.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Inviolabiliter fluit huc, & refluit illuc
Oceanus: ſed vix propria cauſa micat.

lg.l: The Sea flows forth, and ebs back conſtantly:
But the tru cauſ none hardly can deſcry.

argument.p: The tenth wave ſaid to be greater and flow farther into the Land then any former Sea-billow.

l.hi: Dum fluit ac refluit ſinuoſo gurgite fluctus,
Proximus a nono maximus eſſe ſolet.

lg.l: While the Sea flows and ebs with crooked wry,
The tenth wave greateſt is moſt commonly.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Maximus aequoreos fluctus (uti creditur) inter
Eſt decimus, curſu littore quiſque ſuo.

lg.l: Among Sea-waves, ech tenth in turn is deemed
The greateſt, and ſo vulgarly eſteemed.

argument.p: The 4 moſt noxious paſſions or perturbations of Mind, which doo much miſchief to many Men.

l.hi: Quatuor exiſtunt Humana in mente nocivi
Motus▪ corporibus qui mala multa creant.

lg.l: Four noiſom motions in mans Mind ariſe:
Which bring to Bodies many maladies.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Gaudia, Moeror, Amor, Timor atra pathemata mentis:
Corpora queis hominum plurima damna ferunt.

lg.l: Joy, Grief, Lov, Fear are Paſſions of Mans mind:
Wherby their Bodies ſundry miſchiefs find.

argument.p: The 2 oppoſit operativ perturbations of Mind which hav killed many in a moment.

l.hi: Laetitia & Moeror ſunt bina pathemata mentis:
Quae varios homines ſaepe repente necant.

lg.l: Gladnes and Grief the minds two paſſions be:
Which oftimes many men kil inſtantly.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Gaudia quae ſubito obveniunt poſt ſumma pericla,
Saepe interficiunt; immodicuſque dolor.

lg.l: Both ſudden Joy after great perils paſt,
And Grief exceſſiv oft kil men in haſt.

argument.p: The 3 principal Entrals or Organical Parts of Mans Body: with their faculties and functions:

l.hi: Cor, Jecur, & Cerebrum tria praeſtantiſſima membra
Corporis Humani, munia multa gerunt.

lg.l: Heart, Liver and Brain mans Bodies chief parts be;
Which ſerv for ſundry functions al three.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Fons Senſus Cerebrum, Cor Vitae, Hepar eſt Alimenti:
Dant reliquae ſummum Partibus hiſce locum.

lg.l: Brain Senſ, Heart Life, Liver breeds blood to nouriſh:
Theſ be three chief parts, which the reſt doo cheriſh.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Nos Cerebrum ſentire facit, Cor vivere praeſtat,
Dat (Medici ut referunt) ſanguificare Jecur.

lg.l: Brain makes us hav Senſ, Heart performs to liv,
Liver (as ſay Phiſitions) Blood doth giv.

argument.p: The 2 ſpecial Inſtruments of Touch (both Hands) which are of like ability and activity.

l.hi: Natura impertit membris dona omnibus aeque:
Nec dextra inferior parte ſiniſtra ſubeſt.

lg.l: Nature t' al parts hir gifts doth evnly plight:
Nor is the left half weaker then the right.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Dextra manus laeva ſolo fit fortior uſu:
Namque vigore pari pollet utrumque latus.

lg.l: For both ſides with like vigor doo abound.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Dextra & laeva manas Naturae viribus aequa eſt.
Fit tamen ex uſu dextera Dextra magis.

lg.l: Right hand and left by Natures ſtrength's the ſame:
Yet right by uſe more ready ſtil doth frame.

argument.p: The 3 diverſkinds of Dreams in general, wch occur or obven in ſleep by day or night.

l.hi: Divina exiſtunt, Humana Inſomnia, necnon
Infidiae Satanae: ſic triplicata patent.

lg.l: Dreams Divine, Human, and eke Diveliſh be:
So they appeer divided into three.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Triplicia apparent Divina Inſomnia, itemque
Humana, & Satanae condita mente mali.

lg.l: Dreams are Divine, Human, and Diveliſh ſaid
Threefold to be: the laſt by Satan laid.

argument.p: The 2 chief Coordinations (caled Predicaments) of al created Entities.

lg.l: Finxit Ariſtoteles (ſed falſo) altiſſima Rerum,
Doctus ab Archita, Praedicamenta decem.
Ariſtotle by Architas taught, hath framed
Ten higheſt heads of Things: but falſly named.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Vera duplex Rerum eſt Claſſis: Subſtantia nempe
Et Quale: at reliquae plu • ſatis octo datae.

lg.l: Two Heads of Things be, Subſtance and Quality:
But th' other eight hav no Reality.

argument.p: The 2 great Lights or Luminaries, whoſ Images (caled Dogſtars) ſeem ſomtimes three or mo.

l.hi: Tres Soles aliquando videntur in aethere ficti,
Et tria ſunt Lunae spectra reflexa ſimul.

lg.l: Three Dog-ſtar Suns in Sky ſomtimes are ſeen,
And three mock-Moons at once reflex'd hav bin.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Solis Imago triplex interdum apparet in Aura,
Et Lunae Species tres aliquando micant.

lg.l: Three ſemblant Suns in th' Air ſomtimes appeer,
And the Moons three ſhapes now or then ſhine cleer

argument.p: The 2 turbulent Meteors, wch are ingendred of like dry exhaled fume or matter.

l.hi: Hallitus eſt calidus, prima ac cauſa unica, Ventum
Et Terrae-motum quae gener are ſol •• .

lg.l: Hot Fume the firſt and ſole cauſ is, which Wind
And Earthquake wontly breeds, as we ſtil find.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Phaenomena ex calida & ſicca pendentia cauſa
Sunt duo, quae radiis Sol trahit ipſe ſuis.

lg.l: Two Me • eors made of matter hot and dry,
Ther be drawn up by Suns beams energy.

lg.head: Alias

l.hi: Ventus conveniunt & Terrae-motus eadem
Materia: ex halitu fervido uterque jatus.

lg.l: In one ſame matter E ••• hquake and Wind agree.
For both of hot dry fume ingendred be.

argument.p: The 2 firy fearful Meteors, which oftimes kil, & ſtil ſtrike moſt affright into Mens Minds

l.hi: Par Meteororum, Tonitru atque volatile Fulmen;
Humana ingenti corda ſtupore replet.

lg.l: Two Meteors, Thunder and Lightning volatil;
Mens hearts with huge aſtoniſhment doo fil.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: In mentes hominum Tonitru cum fulmine ſummum
Terrorem incutiunt; omina dira mali.

lg.l: Thunder and Lightning mens minds with fear fil;
As dire preſages of enſuing il.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Fulmina percutiunt homines formidine grandi:
Sed Tonitru mentes obſtupuere magis.

lg.l: Lightnings doo men moſt grievouſly affright:
But thunder ſtrikes their minds with much more might

argument.p: The 2 kinds of freſh Waters, which flow immediately out of the Earth, but originaly from Sea.

l.hi: Quae paſsim in Terris viſuntur, primitus omnes

lg.l: A Mare, ait Solomon, exortuntur Aquae.
Al Waters on Earth ſeen, doo primitivly,
Saith Salomon, riſe from Seas immenſity.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Viſceribus Terrae Fontes & flumina conſtant.
Prima ex Oceano ſed ſcaturigo fluit.

lg.l: Fountains and Rivers in th' Earths Entrals ly:
But Seas the prime Source are of their ſupply.

argument.p: The 2 Foſſils or Earth-bred Inanimats (a Mineral and Metal) which hold mutual amity.

l.hi: Mutuus eſtinter Magnetem affectus & atrum
Ferrum: nam ſimili gaudet uterque toro.

lg.l: Magnet and Iron hav like ſympathy:
For both deſire ech others company.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ferrum Magnetem, Magnes Ferrum allicit ultro:
Mutua quippe illis vis ſociata ſubit.

lg.l: Loadſtone draws Iron, this that allures together:
For mutual force reſides in both and either.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Non Magnes Ferrum trahit, hoc neque pertrahit illud:
Fraterni affectus vi ſed uterque coit.

lg.l: The Magnet draws not Iron, nor this the other:
But both with like lov meet, ech as joint Brother.

argument.p: The 2 odious offenſiv Creatures, which are moſt perilous and pernitious to Mankind.

l.hi: Hoſtes praecipui, Cacodaemon & Lupus atrox,
Humano generi damna nefanda struunt.

lg.l: The Devil and Wolf, mans chiefeſt Enim'es,
To mankind work moſt hidious maladies.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Jure homines odere Lupum & Cacodaemona: ſtrages
Quippe ferunt miſeris nocte dieque viris.

lg.l: Men hate the Wolf and Devil deſervedly:
For they bring moſt harms to men jugialy.

l.hi: Quaſſa jacet pietas, & commiſeratio merſa eſt:
Est homini Lupus, & Daemone pejor Homo.

lg.l: Piety lies queld; and Chriſtian pity drownd:
Men Wolfs to Men, and worſ then Fiends are found.

argument.p: The 2 greateſt Quadrupeds, which bear mutual mortal enmity one againſt another.

l.hi: Obvius est quoties Elephantus Rhinoceroti,
Belluae utraeque ſibi mutua bella gerunt.

lg.l: So oft as Elephants with Rhinocerots meet,
Both Beaſts with mutual fight ech other greet.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Rhinoceros Elephaſque gravis, cum forte ſuberrant,
Flagrantes odto bella nefaſta fovent.

lg.l: Rhinoceros and Elephant, burning with great hate,
When they by chance meet fal to fel debate.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Bella cruenta Elephas cum Rhinocerote faceſsit:
Sic inter ſe Homines jurgia dira movent.

lg.l: Elephants, with Rhinocerots wage bloody wars:
So Men with Men maintain moſt direful jars.

div.head: EPIG. LVII. Equi & Ʋrſi aequum Odium.

argument.p: The 2 ſtrong Beaſts, that bear equal reciprocal hatred or mutual mortal fend one with the other.

l.hi: Inter Equum hoſtilis diſcordia conſtat & Urſum:
Natura queis lis exitialis inest.

lg.l: Stone-Horſe and male-Beat hold deadly enmity:
Who hav by Nature fel antipathy.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Ʋrſus Equuſque odio crudeli intrinſecus ardent:
Mortifera, & ſecum mutua bella ferunt.

lg.l: With cruel inbred hate Horſ and Bear rage:
Which mortal mutual fights with themſelfs wage.

argument.p: The 4 ſorts of Animals, which liv upon prey: wherof the ſtronger raven or devour the weaker.

l.hi: Vivitur ex rapto: majora Animalia parva,
Fortiaque obnixe debiliora vorant.

lg.l: Al liv on prey: greater Beaſts leſſer e • t,
And ſtrong on weak by force or fraud make cheat.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Omnia praedae inhiant Animalia: ſcilicet Angues,
Piſces, & volucres, Carnivor aeque Ferae.

lg.l: Serpents, Birds, Fiſhes, and Fleſh-ravning Beaſts
Of al ſorts, make one on ech other Feaſts.

argument.p: The 2 ſeeming ſuppoſed Animals (wherof one hath no life) which are bred from the Sea and Earth.

l.hi: Materia ex putri ſimulata Animalia creſcunt:
Piſci avis, Agnus humi (fungus uterque) duo.

lg.l: Two ſeeming Animals of putrid ſtuf ſpring:
A Bird-Fiſh, Lamb-Plant (Muſhroms both) men ſing. Barnacles.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Inveniuntur Aves genitae ex putredine Conchis:
Agno etiam ſimilis Planta reſurgit humo.

lg.l: Birds bred of putrid ſlime in ſhels are found:
And like a Lamb a Plant grows from the ground.

argument.p: The 3 degrees of different kinds of Wolf-men, which ſeem ſo to themſelfs, or to others.

l.hi: Quoſdam aluere Lupi, quidam hos ſe exiſtere credunt:
Aſt alios vulgo creditur eſſe Lupos.

lg.l: Wolfs foſter ſom men, ſom themſelfs Wolfs deem:
But others to the vulgar ſort Wolfs ſeem.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quoſdam aluere Lupi, varii ſeſe eſſe put ârunt
Tales: aſt al •• formam habuere Lupi.

lg.l: Wolfs bred ſom Men, ſom ſuch themſelfs ſuppoſe.
But Devils ſom into Wolfs ſhape tranſpoſe.

argument.p: The 9 learned Women of old (commonly caled Muſes) graphicaly pourtraied.

l.hi: Doctae apud Antiquos Mulieres, nomine Muſae
Dictae, quas celebrat fama, fuere novem.

lg.l: Nine learned Women, Muſes cald by name,
Floriſh'd of old; which are renownd by fame.

lg.head: Aliter:

l.hi: Muſa novem Muſas uti Virgiliana recenſet:
Sic mea Virgilii Muſa recudit Opus.

lg.l: As Virgils Muſe the Muſes nine deſcribeth:
So my poor Muſe Virgils rich ſtrains tranſcribeth.

argument.p: The 4 famous Factions of Philoſophers, which floriſhed in one Age, and kept School at Athens.

lg.l: Inter Athenarum Pomaria quatur olim,

l.hi: Sectae de ſummo diſſeruere Bono.

lg.l: In Athens Suburbs four learn'd Sects of old,
Of Mans chief Good diverſ diſputs did hold.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Zeno habitu capitur Virtutis: gaudet Idaeis
Plato: Voluptates aſt Epicurus amat:
Actio Ariſtotelem Virtutis mulcet: in iſtis

l.hi: Quatuor hi ſummum constituere Bonum.

lg.l: Zeno lik'd Virtu: Plato: Idea's loved:
But Epicurus Pleaſure moſt approved.
Practiſ of Virtu pleas'd Ariſtotle beſt:
In theſ, thoſ four, Mans chiefeſt Good did reſt.

argument.p: The 2 Juſt Princes which reigned in Theſſaly when a direful Deluge drowned the Country.

lg.l:
Cum fuit Aemathiae dudum undis obruta tellus,
A. M. 2516

l.hi: Rex cum Regina forte ſuperſtes erat.

lg.l: Whilom when Theſſaly with water was drown'd,
The King and Queen by chance eſcaped found.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Pyrrha & Deucalion celebres bonitale, ſuper ſunt

l.hi: Diluvio: cum Gens caetera merſa fuit.

lg.l: Pyrrha and Deucalion for goodnes renown'd,
Survivd a Flood: when People al were drown'd.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Deucalion nulli ſuit integritate ſecundus:
Nec Pyrrhae Muller par pietate stetit.
None match'd Deucalion for integrity.
Nor Woman was Pyrrha's Peer for Piety.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Deucalion Rex juſtus erat, ſincerus, honestus:
Pyrrhaque ſancta ſatis, relligioſa minis.
A juſt, ſincere, good King was Deucalion:
And Pyrrha holy too in ſuperſtition.

argument.p: The 2 trueſt truſtieſt Friends, who are antiently admired by Poets, Hiſtorics, and Moraliſts.

l.hi: Bini apud Historicos fuerant fidiſsimi Amici:
Queis modo nulla Aetas vidit amore pares.

lg.l: Two faithful Friends in ſtories old hav bin:
Who like for tru lov no age ſince hath ſeen.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Sunt priſcis Pylades & Oreſtes optimi Amici

l.hi: Tempo ibus celebres: qui coluere ſimul.

lg.l: Pylades and Orestes in old times lived:
Who were th' intireſt Friends that ever breathed.

argument.p: The 2 Trojan Souldiers that ſerved Aeneas in Latium, being moſt faithful Friends even to death.

lg.l: Trojani temere Rutilorum caſtra petentes,

l.hi: Se gemini comites expoſuere neci.

lg.l: Two Trojan Mates expos'd themſelfs raſhly
To death by entring the Camp of Rutili.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Niſus & Euryalus dum Turni castra feribant

l.hi: In reditu celebri comperiere nece.

lg.l: When Turnus Camp Niſus and Euryal ſpoild,
Both bravly died at once, as they recoild

argument.p: The 2 unhappy Sweet-hearts, who by mutual miſtakes or miſhaps, cam to diſmal diſaſtrous deaths.

lg.l: E Babylone ſati Puer atque Puella venuſti,

l.hi: Se manibus propriis enecuere ſimul.

lg.l: A lovly Youth and Laſſ of Babylon,
By their own hands cam to deſtruction.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Pyramus & Thisbe Babylonica vera propage,

l.hi: Mutuo decepti ſe necuere ſemel.

lg.l: Pyramus and Thisbe born at Babylon,
Themſelfs at once ſlu through meer miſpriſion.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Pyramus enſe cadit, This bem ratus eſſe peremptam:

l.hi: Quae caeſum aſpiciens, protinus enſe cadit.

lg.l: Pyramus himſelf ſlu: deeming Thisbe dead:
Who ſeeing him ſlain, hir ſelf ſoon murdered.

argument.p: The 2 unchaſt Perſons, which cam to untimely ends: the one fool-hardily, the other wilfully.

lg.l: Cum ſit Abydenus mediis puer obrutus undis, In Hellespont.

l.hi: Sponte ſua ex alto Sesta Puella cadit.

lg.l: When' midſts the waves Abydos Youth did by,
The Seſtos Wench fel wilfully from high.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Fluctibus immerſus fuer at cum forte Leander,
Se ſimul e turri praecipitavit Ero.
When by miſchance Leander at Sea was drown'd,
Hero hir ſelf did from a Tower confound.

argument.p: The 2 Pythagorean Lovers or mutual Aſſociats, moſt intirely affectionat one to ech other.

l.hi: Mutuo amicitiae Siculi duo foedere nexi,
Pro ſocio ambo ſuo non renuere mori.

lg.l: Two friends, knit in lovs league, of Sicily,
Both for his Mate ſtrov mutualy to dy.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Damon & Pythias dant pignora mutui amoris,

l.hi: Alter & alterius teſſera mortis erat.

lg.l: Joint pawns of Lov Damon and Pythias gav,
And one was pledg th' other from death to ſav.

argument.p: The 3 Perſons credibly ſtoried to liv ſans ſleep or repoſe diverſ yeers in perfect ſanity.

l.hi: Inſomnes varios ſunt qui vixere per annos,
Sano habitu freti, temperieque bona.

lg.l: Som that livd ſleepleſſ ſundry yeers are found,
Enjoying perfect health and temper ſound.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Moecenas, & Nizolius, Mulierque feruntur

l.hi: Vixiſſe inſomnes, incolumeſque diu.

lg.l: Three liv'd long ſleepleſ • , & health-ſound, ſaith fame
Moecenas, Nizol, and a French unnam'd Dame.

argument.p: The 2 Maids of late times in Europ, which lived diverſ yeers in weak condition without any food.

l.hi: Per plures annos geminae viguere Puellae
Abſque cibo & potu: nec potuere mori.

lg.l: Two Maids without al meat and drink ſurvived
For many yeers: yet not of life deprived.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Binae annis variis nuper vixere Juvencae
Abſque Cibo: Historiis ſi ſit habenda fides.

lg.l: Two Maids not long ago ſundry yeers lived
Sans food: if Hiſtories may be beleeved.

argument.p: The 2 Illuſtrious Women ſaid to ſubſtitut others Children as their own for ſecret ſiniſter ends.

l.hi: Illustres ſimili Mulieres fraude ligatae,
Pro propriis Natis ſubſtituere novos.

lg.l: Women of high birth with poor Folks conſpired,
And ſtrangers Sons as their own births contrived.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Heroinae inſignes vili de plebe feruntur,
Pro pueris, Pueros appropriaſſe ſuis.

lg.l: Two noble Ladies Sons are ſaid t' obtain
Of low birth, whom for their own they ordain.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Heroinas pretio conductos, Fama remonſtrat,
Filiolos geminas ſubſtituiſſe ſibi.

lg.l: Fame ſaith, two Ladies others Sons procured
For fee or price, which they as theirs aſſumed.

argument.p: The 2 middle aged Men, who becam hoary headed in a moment, being condemned to death.

l.hi: Canities geminos invaſit mira Juvencos,
Dum timet inſtantem moeſtus uterque necem.

lg.l: Strange hoary hairs two young men ſoon invaded,
While inſtant death both in great grief much dreaded

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Canitiem Juvenes gemini, formidine mortis
Attoniti, ſubito conciliâre ſibi.

lg.l: Two youthly men with fear of death ſurpriſed,
Hav ſuddenly white hoarines acquired.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Hispalici Proceres canos ſubiere capillos,
Prae male concepta morte repente duo.

lg.l: Two Spaniſh Dons got gray hairs ſuddenly,
Through fear of death taken too tenderly.

argument.p: The 2 Muſitians (a Natural and Artificial, Vocal and Inſtrumental) which ſtrov for Victory.

l.hi: Aemula certabat cantu Philomela ſonoro,
Ʋt Citharam ſtrepitu vinceret ipſa ſuo.

lg.l: A Nghtingal ſtrov with hir loud ſhril noiſ,
T' exced the Lute with high ſtrains of hir voice.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Certabat Cithariſta manu, Philomelaque cantu:
Alter an alterutrum vinceret Arte ſua?

lg.l: A Lutiſt with hand ſtrov, with voice Philomel;
Which ſhould ech other in their skil excel.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Inter Luſciniam lis orta est atque Cheliſtam:
Obſtrepit haec cantu, litigat ille manu.

lg.l: Twixt Nightingal and Luter a ſtrife extended:
In ſinging ſhe, in playing he contended.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Luſcinia infoelix Citharaedum vincere certat:
Sed tandem in plectrum mortua victa cadit.

lg.l: Unhappy Nightingal with a Lutiſt ſtrived:
But on the Lute fel down at length and died.

argument.p: The 365 Mice-like Children, which Margarit Countiſſ of Henneberg brought at one birth in Holland.

l.hi: Parturiit foetus celebris Commitiſſa tot una
Tempore, quot ferias integer Annus habet.

lg.l: So many babes did a great Countiſſ bear
At one time, as be dais in one whol yeer.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quot Venas homo habet, ferias quot continet Annus;
Filiolos peperit tot Comitiſſa ſimul.

lg.l: A Countiſſ ſo many Infants at once bore,
As Man hath Venes, or the yeer dais doth ſcore.

div.head: EPIG. LXXV. Venae in Corpore Humano.

argument.p: The 365 Venes or Blood-Conduits of name and note in Mans Body, according to Artiſts.

l.hi: Tot notae Humano numerantur Corpore Venae,
Quot ſibi quiſque dies integer Annus habet.

lg.l: In ech Mans Body ſo many Venes appeer,
As ther be dais in every complet yeer.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Corpore quot noſtro ſint, ſi vis noſcere, Venae;
Anni etiam debes commemorare dies.

lg.l: Thou likewiſe muſt bear one yeers dais in mind.

argument.p: The 5 Ingredients concurring to the compoſition of a ſingular Artificial Balſamum

l.hi: Balſama miriſice morbos & Vulnera ſanant:
Nec melius quidquam eſt, quam quod ab Arte datur.

lg.l: Balſams Diſeaſes, Wounds, and Ulcers cure:
But ſuch as Art confects, doo it moſt ſure.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Sunt Medicamenta haec internis commoda morbis,
Externiſque malis: quae memorata vides.

lg.l: Thoſ Medicins doo moſt inward griefs remov,
And outward evils: which are nam'd In the great Work. abov.

argument.p: The 8 Materials preſcribed for the preparing of Gooſ-Ointment, good for the Gout and Aches.

l.hi: Unguentum hoc Podagram levat, externoſque dolores:
Si quid opis capias, gloria danda Deo est.

lg.l: This Ointment Gout and outward pains doth eaſ:
If thou find help, giv God al thanks and praiſ.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Si ferat Unguentum hoc Podagrae quodcunque levamen;
Utere, daque bono digna trib • ta Deo.

lg.l: If Gout or Stitch this Ointment ſhal reliev;
Uſe it, and t' our God du tributs giv.

div.head: EPIG. LXXVIII. Lactis, Mellis, & Allii uſus.

argument.p: The 3 Simples of ſingular utility for Mans Body: both in health and ſundry ſickneſſes.

l.hi: Corporibus noſtris tria (Lac, Mel, & Allia) valde
Commoda ſunt, abeis quae mala multa fugant.

lg.l: Three things (Milk, Hony, Garlick) helptul be
T' our Bodies, which from many harms them free.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Lac fovet & ſanat, Mel vulnera terget & opplet:
Allia confortant Ventriculumque juvant.

lg.l: So doth Cream & Butter. Milk feeds and heals, Hony wounds doth clenſ and fil:
Garlick the Stomach helps and keeps from il.

argument.p: The 2 Diſtichs concerning covetous Cormorants and ambitious Cameleons.

l.hi: Creſcit amor Nummi, quantum ipſa Pecunia creſcit:
Quo plus ſunt potae, plus ſitiuntur Aquae.

lg.l: So faſt grows lov of Coin, as wealth doth flow:
The more Men drink, the more their thirſt doth grow.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Creſcit amor Regni, quantum ipſa Potentia creſcit:
Ambitioque Viris inſatiata ſubit.

lg.l: So faſt grows lov of Reign, as power increaſeth:
And Mans ambition grows, which never ceaſeth

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Tan • alus a labris fitiens praeſentat Avarum
Ambitioſum autem Siſyphus ipſe refert.
Stil thirſting Tantalus a covetous Man reſembles:
But Siſyphus an Ambitious Fly diſſembles.

div.head: EPIG. LXXX. Carnis genera diverſa.

argument.p: The 4 ſeveral ſorts of Animals: whoſ Bodily ſubſtance is properly caled Fleſh, even of Fiſhes.

l.hi: Beſtia, Piſcis, Homo, Volucris Caro dicitur aeque:
Sic Carnis ſpecies quatuor eſſo liquet.

lg.l: Man, Beaſt, riſh, Birds are cald Fl • ſh equaly:
So that four kinds of Fleſh appeer to be.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Quatuor enumerat Carnis paradigmata Paulus:

l.hi: Quorum Carminibus nomina ſcripta prius.

lg.l: Four parts or kinds of Fleſh Saint Paul hath ſtiled: 1 Cor. 15. 39.
Whoſ names are in the Verſes before filed.

div.p: Though we according to Vulgar acception or elocution, diſtinguiſh betwen Fleſh and Fiſh; caling ſuch Animals as liv on Land Fleſh; and thoſ that dwel in Water Fiſh; yet in Nature the Bodies of both are Fleſhly.

div.head: EPIG. LXXXI. Lis inter Phaebum & Aeolum.

argument.p: The 2 Contenders fained or fabled to try their Athletic activity on a way faring Traveler.

l.hi: Aeolus & Titan pro palma vincere certant,
Inque Viatorem robur uterque probat.

lg.l: The Wind and Sun ſtrov for a Garland gay,
And on a Traveller did their ſtrength eſſay.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Lis inter Ventum & Solem fuit aemula quondam:
Sed Sol praepropere clara trophaea tulit.

lg.l: The Wind and Sun ſtrov long ſince emulouſly:
But the Sun ſoon gaind a brav Victory.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Aeolus aggreditur Pedetem peſſundare fruſtra:
Sed radiis laſſum Sol facit ipſe ſuis.

lg.l: The Wind in vain to tire a Footman tried:
But the Sun ſoon with's firy rais him tired.

lg.head: Morale.

l.hi: Cum mage praevalidis fruſtra contendere noli:
Nil niſi namque tetrum dedecus inde feres.

lg.l: With ſtronger then thy ſelf ſtriv not in vain:
For thou ſhalt nought but vile diſgrace thence gain.

div.head: EPIG. LXXXII. Mus Ruſticus & Civicus, ſeu Ʋrbanus.

argument.p: The 2 Mice fabled to hold mutual amity and acquaintance one with the other.

l.hi: Ruſticus Ʋrbanum accepit ſub tegmine terrae
Mus Murum hoſpicio, Vere virente novo.
Pro lautis dapibus Frumenta, Legumina, Avenas,
Far, Fabas, Ciceres, Hordea, Mora parat.
Deſpicit Ʋrbanus ſecumque allectat Amicum;
Magnopere invitans accelerare gradum.
In locuplete domo lepide veſcuntur utrique:
Sed ſubito irrepit Promus, eoſque fugat.
Civicus antrum adiit, tremulus ſeſe abdit Agreſtis:
Poſtque domum petiit, non rediturus, ovans.
Diſcimus hinc dapibus vitam praeferre quietam:
Quippe Opibus melior deliciiſque ſalus.

lg.l: A Country did a City Mouſ t' his hole bring
In th' Earth, and welcomd him at prime of Spring.
For curious Cates, he Wheat, Pulſ, Oats ordained,
Meal, Beans, Peaſ, Barly, Berries which him ſuſtained
The Town-Mouſ ſcorns it, and allures his Friend;
Inviting him t' his home in haſt to bend.
In a rich houſ both feaſted pleaſantly:
But ſoon ruſht in the Steward, and made them fly.
One ran t' his Cave. th' other trembling hid,
And went home glad, but would not retroced.
We learn hence quiet to price before fine Cates:
For ſafetv exceds Wealth and Delicats.

argument.p: The 2 Beaſts (baſeſt and braveſt) ſaid to wrangle about littering moſt Whelps at once.

l.hi: Aemula lis inter Vulpem extitit atque Leaenam:
Quae plures Catulos parturiendo daret?

lg.l: A She-Fox with a Lioneſt did contend:
Which us'd moſt Whelps at one birth forth to ſend?

l.hi: Exprobrat illuſtri Vulpecula foeda Leaenae,
Ʋnum quod Catulum parturiiſſe ſolet.
Eſto, Leaena infit, Pol attamen edo Leonem:
Tu varios Vulpes edis, eoſque malos.

lg.l: A Vixen vile did a brav Lioneſſ ſting:
'Cauſ ſhe one only Whelp at once did bring.
Tru, ſaid the Lioneſſ, yet I a Lion breed:
Thou many bringſt, but Foxes of Foul ſeed:

lg.head: Morale.

l.hi: Fabula praemonſtrat, Foetum plus ponderis unum
Ferre bonum, quàm fit mille tuliſſe malos.

lg.l: The Moral ſhews, that 'tis more worth to bring
One brat that's good, then thouſands worth nothing.

lg.head: Aliud.

l.hi: Admonet hoc tenues nos non jactare labores:
Pauca bona excellunt Carmina mille mala.

lg.l: This, not to boaſt, ſmal labors doth us tel:
A few good Verſes thouſands bad excel.

argument.p: The 2 Beaſts (beſt and worſt) fained to drink at a Brook or River together far aſunder.

l.hi: Dum Lupes ad fontis Caput ebibit, inſcius Agnus
Amnem longe infra combibiturus adit.
Quem Lupus aſpiciens, opportunaeque querelae
Praetextu exhilarans, talia dicta dedit:
C • r • mihi potanti conſpurcas, Peſſime, lymphas?
Haud dubie poenas tu mihi jure dabis.
Nil agere agnus ait ſe nec potuiſſe remonſtrat
Commaculare undas; & voluiſſe negat.
Sed magis ille fremens, genus omne incuſat Ovinum:
Et ſpretis precibus dilaceravit eum.
Quàm facile inveniunt Praedones atque Potentes
Anſam, quando Inopes diſpoliare volunt?

lg.l: The Wolf at Spring head drank, a Lamb below it
Sip'd at the Brook far off, and did not know it.
The Wolf eſpying it, glad of a good deviſe
To pick a Quarrel, ſpake words in this wiſe:
Varlet, why dooſt my drinking wate • ſtain?
Surely thou ſhalt juſt puniſhment ſuſtain.
The Lamb ſaid he did nought, & ſhewd he could not
Defile the Waters, and vowd that he would not.
But raging more, he al Sheep-kind accuſed,
And tearing him peece-meal, al praiers refuſed.
How eaſy cauſ can Theefs and great men find.
When they to ſpoil poor innocents hav mind?

argument.p: The 2 litle Animals mytholiged to fight a Duel, til a ſnatching Kite devoured both.

l.hi: Mus & Rana ineunt pugnam: tantaeque paludi
Quis dominaretur, litis origo fuit.
Confligunt valide, & dubiis Victoria pennia.
Haefit, utri palmam neſcia rite daret.
Tunc alto ecce vorax deſcendis ab aethere Milvus,
Acriter inſtantes impavidoſque rapi • .
Hinc caveant Fatui, qui litibus omnia vaſtant;
Ni comedant Corvi parta labore bona.

lg.head: Aliud.

l.hi: Vos etiam Angligenae Civilia po • ite bella:
Ni bello implicitos Gens aliena voiet.

lg.l: A Mouſ and Frog made fight; of ſo great Fray
The ground was, which ſhould ore a •• en bear-ſway?
Stoutly they fought, doubtful ſtood Victory;
Not witting to which ſhe ſhould giv Maſtery.
Then cam a ravenous Kite from Sky aloft,
And them away fighting and fearleſſ caught.
Let Fools which in Law ſpend al, hence take heed;
Leſt Rooks on their Goods by g •• at toil got feed.
And you the Engliſh Civil wars eſchew:
Leſt forren People while ye fight ſpoil you.

argument.p: The 2 ſlow quadrupeds that conteſted in words, which of them was the braver Beaſt?

l.hi: Setigerum petulans Aprum derid et Aſellus:
Qui tamen e contra nil niſi verba dabat:
Dignas cs meritus poenas, ſegniſſime Rerum;
Attamen indignus, quem violaret Aper.

lg.head: Morale.

l.hi: Magnanimi laus eſt opprobria ferre malorum:
Qui maledicentem punit, honorat eum.

lg.l: A ſawcy Aſſ jeered the briſtly Bore;
Who ſom words ſpake in ſcorn, and ſaid no more.
Thou ſloweſt rhing art worthy puniſhment;
Yet far unworthy whom the Bore ſhould rent.
'Tis brav mens praiſ to bear taunts of the baſe:
Who vengeance takes on vile men doth them grace.

argument.p: The 3 Quadruped Creatures, which complained or bewailed their ſeveral wants of Horns, Tail, and Sight.

l.hi: Cornua deeſſe ſibi multum eſt conqueſtus Aſellus:
Simius ob Caudam, quod ſibi nulla foret.
Talpa gemens inquit, queſtus ne fundite vanos:
Quid Cauda aut Cornu • vae mihi, viſus abeſt.

lg.head: Morale.

l.hi: Damna aliena tuis confer, quicunque laboras:
Dumque alius perfert plurima, pauca feras:

lg.l: The Aſſ for lack of Horns did greatly wail:
The Apè complaind, becauſ he had no Tail.
Sighing the Mole ſaid, doo not vainly mone:
What's Tail or Horns? ay me, ſight, I hav none.
Who grieved art, mens harms with thine compare:
If ſom bear many, grudg not a few to ſhare.

div.head: EPIG. LXXXVIII. Aquila & Cornicula.

argument.p: The 2 Birds (Roialeſt and Rudeſt) wherof the weaker cheated the worthier of a Shelfiſh.

l.hi: Praeduram invenit Cochleaem Jovis Ales, & ipſam
frangere non ullo Marte vel Arte valet.
Frangere dum tentat, ſuadet Cornicula in altum
Ʋt vehat, in Saxum praecipitemque daret.
Paruit, & Piſcem fracta Cornicula concha
Abſtulit, atque Aquilam damna dolere jubet.
Omni ne credas, ſunt qui tibi grandia ſpondent:
Sed ſua conſiliis emolumenta ſtudent.

lg.l: An E • gle found a hard Shelfiſh, which ſhe
Could no way break by force or induſtry.
While ſhe doth try, a Crow wils her to knock
Bearing it high, againſt a ſtony Rock.
She did it, and the Crow the Fiſh ſo torn
Snatch'd up, and bid hir wail that loſſ in ſcorn.
Truſt not al men, ſom wil great Friendſhip fain:
But ſuch their own ends ſeek and ſtudy gain.

div.p: By theſ few Patterns or Precedents, any Poetaſters may make the like Mythologies from Eſops Fables or Others.

argument.p: The 2 Things (Sleep and Death) compared to be Coſen Germans: as alſo the Bed and Grav.

l.hi: Omnem Crede diem tibi diluxiſſe ſupremum,
Perpetuo obdu • tum • éque ſopore puta.

lg.l: Deem every day thou livſt to be the laſt,
And into endleſſ ſleep think thy ſelf caſt.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Mortis Imago Sopor vera est, Lectuſque Sepulchri:
Si Rem ferre velis, ne vereare Typum.

lg.l: Sleep doth deaths Image, Bed the Gravs Type bear:
If thou the Thing lov'ſt, doo not the Figure fear.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi:
Somnus Morſ
que Erebi & Noctis tenebroſa propago eſt:
Frater hic, illa Soror; Mortis Imago Sopor.

lg.l: Sleep and dire death, are Brats of night and Hel;
Brother and Siſter: Sleep death reſembles wel.

argument.p: The 3 Heavenly Graces (caled Charites) which were of high eſteem among the old Heathen.

l.hi: Tires Gentilitiae Charites aliquando fuere
Inter Paganos, Virginitate ſacrae.

lg.l: Three Ethnic Graces in times paſt were found
'Mongſt Pagans, for Virginity renownd.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Aglaia, Euphroſyne Charites ſunt, atque Thalia:
Sacra Jovis ſoboles Eurinomiſque ferunt.
Aglay, Euphroſyn, Thaly Graces three;
Joves Daughters by Eurinome are ſaid to be.

argument.p: The 3 Virgin Hours fained to attend thoſ Graces, as Warders or Porters of Heavens Gate.

lg.l: Tres Horae celeres, Irene, Eunomia, Dyrce
Filiolae celebres ſunt Jovis atque Themis.
The three ſwift Hours, Eunomy, Irene,
Joves Daughters were by Themis, and fair Dyrce.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Eunomia, Irene, Dyrce, prae limine Coeli
Tres Horae invigilant, alma propago Jovis.
Eunomy, Irene, Dirce, The Hours three
Heav'ns Porters, Joves fair Of-ſpring ſaid to be.

argument.p: The 3 Siſters ſtiled Heſperides (Daughters to Atlas) ſaid to hav Gardens of golden Apples.

lg.l: Atlantis Natae Heſperidum cognomine nota;

l.hi: Nutrierant bortis aurea poma ſuis.

lg.l: Atlas three Daughters Hesperids cald of th' Weſt,
Had Gardens, wher gold Apples grew of th' beſt.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Aegle, Aretuſa ſuis, atque Heſperetuſa ſub Hortis
Aurea poma, ferunt, Cuſtode habuere Dracone.

lg.l: The three nam'd Siſters had a Dragon bold,
To guard their Gardens and Apples of gold.

argument.p: The 3 forms of a fictious Animal, begot by the Giant Typhon upon Echidna, being a Hil in Lycia.

l.hi: Anteriore Leo, media Capra eſſe Chimaera
Parte celebratur; poſteriore Draco.

lg.l: Chimaera in forepart Lion, in midſt Goat;
Behind like Dragon: ſo doo Poets note.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Mons Lyciae Capreas, Colubros ſimul, atque Leones

l.hi: Summa, ima, media parte Chimaera tulit.

lg.l: A Lycian Mount Goats, Snakes, and Lions fed
Chimaera cald, on top, midſt, bottom bred.

argument.p: The 3 ravenous Fowls with Wom • ns Faces, reported to liv in the Ilands of Stymphalides.

l.hi: Harpyiae dictae, ſimiles Bubonibus albis
Virgineo vultu, tres celebrantur Aves.

lg.l: Three monſtrous Birds much like whit Owls are famed,
With Virgins Viſages, which are Harpies named.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Harpyiae informes tres Ocypite, Aela, Celano:

l.hi: Foemineam faciem quas retuliſſe ferunt.

lg.l: Ocypit, Celano, Aela Harpies three,
'Tis ſaid are Women-like in phyſnomee.

argument.p: The 3 Parcae (ſo caled per antiphraſin, quia minime parcunt) ſaid to ſpin the thin thred of Life.

lg.l: Humanae ſtamen vitae Clotho bajulat: atqui
Dum Lacheſis differt, Atropos occat idem.
Clotho Mans thred of Life bears: but together
While Lacheſis ſpins, Atropos breaks aſunder.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Clotho tenet filum, Lacheſis trahit, Atropos occat:

l.hi: Sic varias Vitae diſpoſuere vices.

lg.l: One holds the Flax, another ſpins, the laſt
Cuts off: ſo they Mans Lifes thred ſpin in haſt.

argument.p: The 3 Furies or Hags of Hel, fained to haunt the Ghoſts of Murderers and Malefactors.

l.hi: Eumenides Barathro, Terris Furia, Aethere Dirae:
Nomina nominibus ſunt data terna tribus.

lg.l: In Hel, Earth, Heav'n Hags are diverſly
Named: which haunt the wicked grievouſly.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tyſiphone, Alecto Furiae ſunt, atque Megaera:
Inter quas itidem regnat Erinnys atrox.
Tyſiphon, Alecto, and Megaera Hags three:
'Mongſt whom Erinnys too bears Soveraignty.

argument.p: The 3 Siſters caled Gorgons, ſaid to hav only one Ey betwen them, which they uſed by turns.

l.hi: In Mare ſunt Piſces vocitati Gorgones olim,
Qui referunt homines corpus in omne feros.

lg.l: Fiſhes at Sea of old termd Gorgons are.
Which wild men ſeem through al the Body rare.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Gorgones humanam referebant corpore formam;
Squamea quam Pontus turba profundus alit.

lg.l: Gorgons in Human ſhape of Body did floriſh▪
A Scaly rout, which the deep Sea doth nouriſh.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Gorgones Euryale, Scheno, atque Meduſa Marina

l.hi: Finguntur lepide Monſtra fuiſſe tria.

lg.l: Euryale, Scheno, and Meduſa three
Gorgon Sea-Monſters featly are fain'd to be.

argument.p: The 3 ſevere Kings (Minos of Cret, Aeacus of Aegina, Rhadamanthus of Lycia) cald Judges of Hel.

l.hi: Tres rigidi Reges olim viguere, Gebennae
Dicti quaeſtores proferitate ſua.

lg.l: Three ſtern Kings, nicknam'd for auſterity
Judges of Hel, floriſhed antiently.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Jura dat Aeacus, & Minos, Radamanthus in Orco:

l.hi: Juſtitiam auſtere qui tribuere ſuis.

lg.l: Minos, Aeac, Rhadamant cald Judges of Hel:
Who to their Subjects miniſtred Juſtice wel.

div.head: EPIG. XCIX. Proteus Verſatilis.

argument.p: The three ſpecial ſhapes, wherto Proteus (a wiſe King of Egypt) is ſaid to turn or transform himſelf.

l.hi: Rex formam in triplicem ſe vertere fingitur olim:
Qui viſus Coluber, Taurus, itemque Leo eſt.

lg.l: Whilom a King in triple ſhape appeered:
Who (as 'tis faind) Dragon, Bul, Lion ſeemed.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Proteus in varias formas ſe tranſtulit: unde

l.hi: Nunc Leo, tunc Taurus, mox Draco viſus erat.

lg.l: Oft Proteus to transform himſelf is deemed:
Who Lion, Bul, and Dragon was eſteemed.

div.p: This Shews, that a King ſhould hav the courage of a Lion, ſtrength of a Bul, and ſubtlety of a Serpent.

div.head: EPIG. C. Herculis Labores ſeu Geſta.

argument.p: The 24 Labors or Acts aſcribed to Jupiters Son by Alcmaena: but ſom atchieved by others.

lg.l: Sex quater Herculeos cantat nova Fama Labores:

l.hi: Sed veteres Vates bis modò ſex memorant.

lg.l: Twenty four Toils of Hercules late Fame prates:
But th' antient Poets only twelv relates.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Sex quater Alcides Alcmaenus geſta peregit:
Aſt ex his Libycum multa tuliſſe liquet.
Hercles Alcmaenas Son hath t' him aſcribed
Twenty four geſts: wherof Libyc fom archived.

div.head: A Poſtſcript. De Libro hoc puſillo.

l.hi: Praelufit Liber hic, prodibit forſitan alter
Altior, & (dextro Numine) majus Opus.

lg.l: This Book's a toy, the next of loftier breed,
And larger bulk (by Gods Grace) ſhal ſucceed.

lg.head: Another.

l.hi: Hic Liber eſt Index, Libri Argumenta parati
Qui tenet: haec Verba, at Res peragentur eo.

lg.l: This Book's a Table of the next ordained:
Here Words, ther Things explaned are contained.

lg.head: Another.

l.hi: Ʋt Pugno Palma eſt contracto expanſa: Libello
Huic in digeſto ſic erit iſte Liber.

lg.l: As the hands Palm is to a Fiſt contracted:
Such is this book to the next at large compacted,

lg.head: Another

l.hi: Continet iſte Liber quingenta Epigrammata parvus:
Sed totidem ſuper eſt addere cuique nova.

lg.l: Fiv hundred Eſſais this ſmal Book contains:
But t' ad ſo many mo for ech man remains.

l.hi: Lector, parce liris; Juvenes Juvenilia poſcunt:
Res levis eſt, quod ſi paucula charta perit.

lg.l: Reader, bear with theſ tois, young men lov ſuch:
For few waſt leafs the matter is not much.

lg.head: Again.

l.hi: Lector amice, meas noli contemnere nugas:
Quod juvet, his aliquid fo •• an ineſſe queat.

lg.l: Kind Reader, doo not my poor lines deſert:
Haply theſ trifles ſom good may inſert.

lg.head: Again.

l.hi: Haec ſi menſures Epigrammata pondere, vili
Venunt: at numero multa talenta valent.

lg.l: Theſ Eſſais valu nought, if by weight ſold:
But if by number, they are worth much gold.

lg.head: Again.

l.hi: Carmina ſi numeres, ſunt hic duo millia: praeter
Plurima, quae abs aliis mutua ſumpta Viris.

lg.l: Verſes, if numbred, to four thouſand mount:
Beſide ſom borowed, which next Book ſhal count.

l.hi: Hic Liber haud Liber eſt, ſed Bibliotheca Metrorum:
Quae luc • brata magis complicat ampla ſtrues.

lg.l: This Book no Book is, but Verſes Library:
Which a large Pile fuller explan'd doth cary.

l.hi: Cum vitare nequis communia Fata Librorum,
Cenſuras hominum: ſcommata sperne, Liber.

lg.l: Book, ſith thou canſt not ſhun Books common Fare,
Cenſures of men: yet ſcorn their ſcoffs and hate.
Zoilus invideat, rumpantur & Ilia Momi:

l.hi: Hic Canis eſt rabidus, fumeus alter Aper.

lg.l: Let Zoilus fret, and Mome burſt his Gaules gore:
One's a mad Dog, th' other a foming Bore.

l.hi: Hoc Opere eſt multis paraſangis doctior Author
Factus: at Incoepti non pudet inde ſui.

lg.l: Th' Author by this Work many ſteps became
More learnd: but of his Empriſe takes no ſhame.

div.head: Mutuatitial Eſſais. The ſixth Claſsis or Century of Mutuatitials: under two univerſal Heads:

argument.p: The 6 Encomiaſtic Verſes compoſed concerning the fertility and felicity of Brytain

l.hi: C Ʋm pareret Natura Parens, varioque favore
Divideret dotes omnibus una locis:

Se poſuit potiora dibi, Matrem
que profeſſa:
Inſula ſis foelix, plenaque pacis, ait.
Quicquid amat luxus, quicquid deſiderat uſus;
Ex te proveniet, ſive aliunde tibi.

lg.l: When Parent Nature teem'd, and t' al parts gav
In favor hir ſpars'd boons, what ech ſhould hav:
She mother-like laid by the beſt for thee:
Bleſt Ile be thou, and ful of peace, ſaid ſhe.
What pomp or pleaſure lovs, what uſe can crav;
From thee ſhal com, or thou elſwher ſhalt hav.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons traditionaly ſaid or ſtoried, to ſupplicat and anſwer by Viſion.

l.hi: Diva potens Nemorum, terreſtria Jura reſolve:
Dic quibus in terris nos habitare velis.
Dic certam ſedem, qua te veneremur in aevum:
Qua tibi Virgineis Templa dicabo Choris.

lg.l: Thou Groves great Goddeſſ, aſſoil Earthly heſt:
Tel what Land we ſhal dwel, wher likes thee beſt.
Point the ſet ſeat wher we may ſtil thee praiſ;
Wher I thy Fanes for Virgins quires wil raiſ.
Brute, ſub Occaſum Solis trans Gallica regna,

l.hi: Inſula in Oceano eſt, Gentibus apta tuis.
Hanc pete, namque libi ſedes erit illa perennis:
Hic ſoboli totus ſubditus Orbis erit.

lg.l: Brute, Weſtward beyond Galle in the Ocean lies
An Ile, that's fit to be thy Peoples prize.
Seek this, for it thy Seat ſhal be for ay:
Here ſhal the World ſom of thy Seed obey.

argument.p: The 2 Champions traditioned to try an athletic Combat at Wreſtling on Plimmouth Ho.

lg.l: Hos, avidum Belli robur Corinaeus Averno

l.hi: Praecipites miſit: cubitis ter quatuor altum

lg.l: Gogmagog Herculea ſuspendu in Aere lucta;

l.hi: Antaeumque ſuum e ſcopulo detruſit in aequor.

lg.l: Thoſ warlike Okes Corin ſent headlong t' Hel:
But Gogmagog twelv cubits high pel mel
In wreſtling he like Hercules lift on high,
And threw the Giant into the deep ther nigh.

div.head: EPIG. IIII. Sabrinae immerſio in flumine.

argument.p: The 2 old Verſes framed on young Abren, who was drowned by hir Stepdame Guendolin.

lg.l: Nomen Abren Fluvio est de Virgine: nomen eidem
Nomine corrupto, deinde Sabrina datur.
A River from the Maid took Abrens name;
Corruptly ſince cald Severn, being the ſame.

argument.p: The 12 Moneths, 52 Weeks, 365 Dais and 6 Hours, contained in a Julian Engliſh yeer.

l.hi: Bis ſenos Menſes habet integer Annus, & idem
Quinquaginta duas continet hebdomadas:
Ter centum, ter viginti cum quinque diebus,
Sexque horas: tot enim Julius Annus habet.

lg.l: Twelv ſolar months an intire yeer contains,
Wherin ful fifty two months ſtil remains:
Three hundred ſixty fiv dais run about,
And ſix whol hours in a Julian yeer throughout.

argument.p: The 12 outletting Gates, 365 Glaſſ-windores, and 8766 Pillars in Saliſbury Church Wiltſhire.

l.hi: Mira remonſtro: dies quos continet Annus; in una
Tot uumeroſa, freunt, Aede Feneſtra micat.
Mar moreaeque extant fuſae tot ab Arte Columnae,
Comp • enſas Horas quot vagus annus habet.
Totque patent Portae, quot Menſibus annus abundat:
Res mira, at vera Res celebrata fide.

lg.l: Wonders I tel: ſo many windores ſhine
In Sarum Church, as the yeer dais confine:
So many marble Pillars ther appeer
By art caſt, as be hours in one whol yeer.
So many Gates as Solar months ope wide:
Strange Things, but tru by faithful number tried.

argument.p: The 3 ſtrange Rarities to be ſeen at Darbyſhire Peak: ſet among Englands 7 Wonders.

lg.l: Mira alto Pecco tria ſunt Barathrum, Specus, Antrum:

l.hi: Commoda tot, Plumbum, G • amen, Ovile Pecus.
Tot ſpecioſa ſimul ſunt, Castrum, Balnea, Chatſworth:
Plura ſed occurrunt haud ſpecioſa minus.

lg.l: In high Peak Hole, Cave, Den, are Wonders three:
Lead, Graſſ, and Sheep, ſo many profits be.
Caſtle, Baths, Chatſworth for rare things are crowned
But many mo obven no leſſ renowned.

argument.p: The 4 jeering Verſes made by a French Poet upon Brytiſh drink, vulgarly caled Ale.

l.hi: • eſcio quod Monſtrum Stygiae conforme paludi,
• erviſiam plaerique vocant: nil ſpiſsius illa
• um bibitur; nil clarius est cum mingitur: unde
• onſtat, quod varias faeces in Ventere reliquit.

lg.l: Of that fel Monſter like the Stygian Lake,
Moſt men cal't Ale; I know not what to make.
They drink it paſſing thick, but piſſ't moſt thin;
Which ſhews that diverſe dregs remain within.

argument.p: The 4 uſual Terms or Times of Law-Courts held at London, Weſtminſter, or elſwher.

lg.l: Terminus a ſancto Princeps Michaele vocatur: Effigies Angeli in nū mo Aureo.

l.hi: Legiſtam inprimis Angelus iſte juvat.

lg.l: Terminus hunc Hilaris ſequitur nec nomine vano:

l.hi: Cauſidicos hilares Terminus iſte facit.
Cauſidicis inſtar
Libri Paſchalis habendus
Tertius, a ſacro Paſchate nomen habet.
Qua tus habet Triadis titulum cur Terminus? omni
Eſt in lite Trias Callida, nulla Monos.

lg.l: The chief Term from Saint Michael his name takes:
That Angel Pleaders hearts moſt joyful makes.
Hilari next folows: Name not in vain or bad:
That Term makes Lawiers merry, blith, and glad.
The third to Pleaders is like Eaſter Book:
That Term his title from holy Eaſter took.
Why is the fourth Term termed Trinity?
In Law three Crafts-men be no unity.

l.hi: Dum mala conſumunt Homines Res litibus omnes:

lg.l: Cauſidicis Hilaris Terminus omnis erit.
While men their Goods in Law-ſuits fondly ſpend:
Ech Term with Pleaders wil in gladnes end.

argument.p: The 2 ordinary ſorts of puniſhments, ordained for breach of Wedlock among ſeveral Nations.

l.hi: Vis ſore Adulterium non dignum morte, Sacerdos?
Haud mirum; Conjux eſt tibi nulla: ſapis.
Vis ut Adulterium ſit dignum morte, Miniſter?
Nil mirum; Conjux eſt tibi bella: ſapis.

lg.l: Prieſt, wilt not for Adultery loſe thy life?
No marvel; thou art wiſe, having no wife.
Presbyter, wilt hav men for Adultery dy?
No wonder; thou a wife haſt moſt comly.

argument.p: The 4 facetious Diſtichs deviſed on a Lawier ſtil ready to comply with the preſent times.

l.hi: Non licuit niſi jurato prius, edere Cauſam:
Fallax juravit, ſumpſit & inde Togam.
Postea non licuit niſi ſacro foedere pacto:
Tunc pepegit Fallax, ſumpſit & inde Togam.
Tandem non licuit niſi Subſcribentibus: atque
Subſcripſit Fallax, ſumpſit & inde Togam.
Credo, ſi Daemon quidquam praeſcripſerit, illud
Perficeret Fallax, indueretque Togam.

lg.l: None could unleſſ firſt ſworn, plead public Cauſ:
Fallax did ſwear and took his Gown of Laws.
Next none might plead, til ſacred Covenant pacted:
Fallax took that, and in his Gown then acted.
At length none ſav Subſcribers durſt preſume:
Fallax ſubſcrib'd, and did his Gown reſume.
I deem, if ought the Devil ſhould impoſe;
Fallax would doo 't and his Gown new compoſe.

argument.p: The 4 Diſtichs compoſed in commendation of London City, and commodities therof.

lg.l: Urbs Auguſta, cui Coelumque, Solumque, Salumque;

l.hi: Cuique favent cunctis cuncta Elementa bonis:
Mitius haud uſquam Coelum est, uberrima Tellus
Fundit inexhauſti germina lauta ſoli:
Et Pater Oceanus Tamiſino gurgite miſtus,
Convebit immenſas totius Orbis opes.
Singula contemplare animo, diligenſque tuere:
Aut Orbem, aut Orbis dixeris eſſe caput.

lg.l: City Auguſtd cal'd, wherto Heaven, Land, Sea;
And Elements al ſhew favors every way:
Th' Air no wher milder is, moſt fruitful Land
Yeelds pleaſant Fruits by Natures liberal hand:
And Father Ocean with Tamis ſtreams conjoind,
Hath ſtore of wealth from the whol World purloind.
Mark al things wel, and take view diligently:
Thou wilt a World, or the Worlds Head it cry.

l.hi: Haec Urbs illa potens, cui tres tria dona miniſtrant

lg.l: Bacchus, Apollo, Ceres; Pocula, Carmen, Ador.
Haec Urbs illa potens, quam Juno, Minerva, Diana

l.hi: Mercibus, Arce, Feris; ditat, adornat, alit.

lg.l: This City Bacchus, Ceres, Phoebus three
Gifts gav, Wine, Corn, and Pleaſant Poetry.
This place Queen June, Pallas, Dian cleer
Inrich'd, adorn'd, fed; with Wares, Towers, Deer.

l.hi: Tot Sylvas, tot Agros, tot Regia tecta, tot Arces

lg.l: Vidimus: ut Tameſis fluvius cum Tybride certet.
Such Woods, Fields, Princely Houſes, Caſtles rare
We ſaw: as Tamis with Tyber may compare.

argument.p: The 4 Panegyrical Diſtichs framed for the fame and in favor of York City.

l.hi: Praeſidet extremis Arcto • finibus Orae
Urbs vetus, ex veteri facta ſubinde nova.
Roman is Aquilis quondam Ducibuſque ſuperba:
Quam poſt barbaricae diripuere manus.
Pictus atrox, Scotus, Danus, Normannus, & Anglus.
Fulmina in hanc Martis det • nuere ſua.

lg.l: Londinum caput eſt, & Regni Ʋrbs prima Brytannis:
Eboracum a prima jure ſecunda venit.
Far in the North ther ſtands as Soveraign
A City old, of old made new again.
Of Roman Enſigns and Captains proud it was:
Which barbarous People ſince deſtroid, alas!
Fierce Picts, Scots, Danes, Normans, and Engliſhmen
Caſt their War-bolts againſt it now and then.
London is Brytains Head and chief Seat ſtiled:
But York next to the firſt by right is filed.

argument.p: The 3 Diſtichs deviſed in the Paraſitical praiſ of Norwich a fair City in Norfolk County.

l.hi: Urbs specioſa ſitu, nitidis pulcherrimae tectis;
Grata Peregrinis, delitioſa ſuis.
Cultus vincit Opes, & cultum Gratia rerum:
Quam bene? ſi Luxus non comitetur Opes.
Omnia ſic adeo ſola haec ſibi ſufficit: ut ſi
Regno ſorte deest, haec caput eſſe queat.

lg.l: A City neatly ſited, built moſt gay;
To Strangers kind, pleaſing t' hir own alway.
Hir Port doth Wealth excel, Grace port tranſcend:
How happy? If Riot did not wealth artend.
She's al ſufficing in hir ſelf: that ſhe
Of al the Realm, if need were Head might be.

argument.p: The 6 Verſes or an Hexaſticon compiled in praiſ of the antient City Durham.

l.hi: Vedra ruens rapidis modò curſibus, agmine leni,
Seque minor celebres ſuſcipit Ʋrbe Viros:
Quos dedit ipſa olim, quorum & tegit oſſa reposta;

lg.l: Magnus ubi ſacro marmore Beda jacet.

l.hi: Se jactent aliae vel Relligione, vel armis:
Haec armis cluit, & Relligione viret.

lg.l: Wear whilom running ſwift, now with ſtreams ſoft
And Chanel leſſ; looks on hir Men aloft,
Which once it bred; whoſ bones it holds included:
Wher under marble Tumb great Bede lies buried.
Let other Cities boaſt in Arms or Piety:
This both in Arms excels and Sanctity.

lg.head: Nechams Diſtich.
lg.l: Arte ſituque loci munita Dunelmia ſalve:

l.hi: Qua floret ſanctae Relligionis apex.

lg.l: Durham al hail, by Art and Nature guarded:
Wher pure Religion highly is regarded.

argument.p: The 3 Diſtichs contrived by the ſame hand, to deſcribe the City Carlile in Cumberland County.

l.hi: Romanis quondam statio tutiſsima ſignis:
Hinc ciet & pugnas, arcet & inde metus.
Gens acri ingenio, ſtudiis asper • ima belli:
Doctaque bellaci figere tela manu.

lg.l: Scotorum Reges olim tenuere potentes:

l.hi: Nunc itidem priſcis additur Imperiis.

lg.l: This ſomtime ſafeſt Roman ſtation was:
Which fights did raiſ, and fears from thence far chaſe
People ſharp witted, to war moſt endured;
And how to handle weapons beſt inured.
The Scotiſh Kings of old held it by might:
But 'tis to antient Crown reduc'd by right.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes or Diſtich briefly writen concerning the large City Lincoln in Lincolnſhire.

lg.l: Lindiſiae columen Lincolnia, ſive columna eſt:

l.hi: Munifica foelin Gente, repleta bonis.

lg.l: Lincoln is Lindſeis prop or pillar ſure:
Which bounteous People bleſſ, and wealthy ſtore.

argument.p: The 3 Diſtichs or 6 Verſes, wherin Newcaſtle is Graphicaly deſcribed or decyphered.

l.hi: Rupe ſedens celſa, Rerum aut miracula spectat
Naturae, aut ſolers convenit illa ſuis.
Sedibus aethereis quid frustra quaeritis ignem?
Hunc alit, hunc tellus ſuſcitat ipſa ſinu.

Eliquat hic Ferrum, Aes, Aurum hic quo
que ductile fundit
Quos non Auri illex conciet umbra animos?

lg.l: She Natures wonders ſet on high Rock views;
Or doth them prudently t' hir own transfuſe.
Why ſeek ye Fire in vain from Heav'n? the Ground
Doth either breed it here, or keep it ſound.
This Fire melts Iron, Braſſ, and makes Gold ſoft:
What dul minds wil not lure of Gold ſet aloft?

argument.p: The 4 Diſtichs touching the various troubles and turnings of Barwick in al Ages.

lg.l: Scotorum extremo ſub limite, meta furoris
Saxonidum; Gentis par utriuſque labor.

l.hi: Mille vices rerum, quae mille eſt paſſa ruinas:
Mirum, qui potuit tot ſupereſſe malis.
Poſtquam ſervitio duriſque eſt functa periclis;
Effert laetitiae ſigna ſerena ſuae.

lg.l: Cujus ab auspiciis unita Brytannia tandem,

l.hi: Excelſum tollit liberain Aſtra caput.

lg.l: In Scotlands utmoſt bound, wher Saxons broil
Did reſt, as of both Nations equal toil
She thouſand turns and overthrows ſuſtained:
Strange 'tis, how ſhe after ſuch ſtorms remained.
When bondage and hard dangers ſhe had paſt;
She cheerful ſigns of gladnes ſhewd at laſt:
By whoſ good hap Brytain being cimented,
Hir lofty head to Heav'n at length hath mounted.

argument.p: The 2 Diſtichs compriſing a curt deſcription of the City Wincheſter in Hantſhire.

lg.l: Guintoniam titulis claram, gaziſque repletam

l.hi: Noverunt veterum tempora priſca Patrum:
Sed tam ſacra fames Auri, tam cacus habendi
Ʋrbibus egregiis parcere neſcit amor.

lg.l: Winchester with Wealth and Titles did abound,
And by our Fathers was of old renownd:
But curſed luſt of Gold, and lov of gain,
From ſpoiling gallant Cities wil not refrain.

div.head: EPIG. XXI. Verolamii vetuſtae urbis cōmemoratio.

argument.p: The 6 Verſes or Hexaſticon compoſed in commendation of the old City Verolam.

lg.l: Urbs inſignis erat Verolamia, plus operoſae

l.hi: Arti; Naturae debuit illa minus.

lg.l: Pendragon Arthuri Patris haec obſeſſa laborem.

l.hi: Septennem ſprevit, Cive ſuperba ſuo.

lg.l: Hic eſt Martyrii Roſeo decoratus honore
Albanus, Civis, splendida Roma, tuus.
Verolam a noble Citie did ow more
To painful Art, but leſſ to Natures ſtore.
Pendragon, Arthurs Sire ſevn yeers hir round
Beſieg'd: which hir ſtout People did confound.
Here Alban thy tru Subject, glorious Rome;
The Roſy red Crown gain'd of Martyrdome.

argument.p: The 5 ſeveral ſorts of Husbands, which in England are commonly caled cornuted Cukolds.

l.hi: Qui capit Ʋxorem macham, ſub vertice Cornu
Ʋnum habet: & qui ſcit diffimulare, duo
Qui videt, & patitur, tria geſtat: quatuor ille,
Qui ducit nitidos ad ſua tecta Procos.
Qui nullo iſtorum ſe credit in ordine poni,
Credit at Ʋxori, Cornua quinque gerit.

lg.l: Who a Whore takes to Wife, doth one Horn wear:
Who weds one, yet diſſembles; two doth bear.
Who ſees and ſuffers, three wears: but four he
Which brings home neat ſpruſe Wooers Helps to be.
Who deems himſelf in none of theſ ranks ſtated,
But beleevs his Wifes words; fiv horns hath grafted.

argument.p: The 6 Heroic Verſes made in praiſ of Glaſſenbury, Brytiſhly cald Inis Avalon the Ile of Apples.

lg.l: Inſula Pomorum, quae Fortunata vocatur,

l.hi: Ex re nomen habet, quia per ſe ſingula profert:
Non opus eſt illi ſulcantibus Arva colonis;
Omnis abeſt cultus, niſi quem Natura miniſtrat.
Ʋltro foecundas ſegetes producit, & herbas;
Nataque poma ſuis praetonſo germine Sylvis.

lg.l: Th' Ile of Apples, which Fortunat men cal;
Becauſ it ſelf breeds Corn, Herbs, Fruit, and al.
Ther need no Clowns to plow or til the Fields,
Nor Husbandry, ſav that which Nature yeelds,
It brings of free accord Corn and Graſſ ſtore;
With Apples in their Woods, if pruned more.

argument.p: The 2 Joſephs of Arimathea in Judea (Father, Son) who converted many Brytans to Chriſtianity.

lg.l: Intrat Avaloniam duodena Caterva Virorum:
Flos Arimathaeae Joſephus primia eorum.
Joſephes ex Joſeph genitus Patrem comitatur:
His aliiſque decem jus Glaſconiae appropriatur.
A troop of twelv men entred Avalon:
Of which th' Arimathean Flour was chief one.
Joſephes Joſephs ſon his Sire attended:
To theſ and ten mo was Glaſſ-Ile commended.

argument.p: The 8 Encomiaſtic or Panegyric Verſes compiled in commendation of Arthur King of Brytans.

lg.l: Hinc celebri Arthurus flos Regum claruit ortu;

l.hi: Cui par nemo fuit, nec erit: quemcunque Priorum
Inſpice, Pelaeum commendaet Fama Tyrannum:

lg.l: Pagina Caeſateos loquitur Romana triumphos:

l.hi: Alcidem domitis attolli • gloria Monſtris.
Sed nec Pinetum Coryli, nec Sidera Solem
Aequant: Annales Grajos Latioſque revolve:
Solu • praeteritis melior, majorque futuris.

lg.l: Hence Arthur Flour of Kings, noble by Birth;
whom none could or ſhal match: See th'Kings on Earth
Great Alexanders name the World doth praiſ:
The Roman Books their Caeſars triumphs raiſ.
For taming Monſters Hercules bore the bel:
But Pinetrees Hazels, as Sun doth Stars excel.
Read Greek and Latin Annals: he better was
Then thoſe are paſt, and ſhal the laſt ſurpaſſ.

argument.p: The 7 firſt Primats or Metropolitans of Canterbury: with this Epitaph writ on a wal.

lg.l: Septem ſunt Anglis Primates & Protopatres:

l.hi: Septem Rectores: to tidem ſuper Aſtra Triones:
Septem Ceſternae vitae▪ totidemque Lucernae:
Septem itidem Palmae regni: totidemque Coronae:
Septem ſunt Stellae: quas haec tenet area Cellae.

lg.head: They were buried in S. Auſtins Church Porch.
lg.l: Sevn Engliſh Primats, and Arch-Prelats hight:
Seven Rulers: and in Heav'n ſevn Trions bright:
Sevn Ceſterns of life: and ſevn Lamps of light:
Sevn Palms of the Realm: and ſevn Crowns of gold:
Sevn Stars they were, which this Cels Arch doth hold

argument.p: The 4 Epitaphial Verſes made on Ceadwal King of Weſt-ſaxons, buried in S. Peters Church at Rome.

l.hi: Culmen, opes, ſobolem, pollentia Regna, triumphos,
Exuvias, Proceres, maenia, Caſtra, Lares:
Quaeque Patrum Virtus, & quae congeſſerat ipſe;

lg.l: Armipotens Ceadwal liquit amore Dei.
Greatnes, Wealth, Children, rich Realms, triumphs, ſpoils,
Courtiers, Camps, Cities, Houſgods, bloody broils:
And what his Fathers, or his power acquired;
The warlike Ceadwal for Gods lov acquited.

argument.p: The 12 Hexameters framed on Elfred, who was a valiant, wiſe, and learned King.

l.hi: Nobilitas innata tibi probitatis honorem,

lg.l: Armipotens Elfrede, dedit; probitaſque Laborem,

l.hi: Perpetuumque labor nomen: cui mixta dolori
Gaudia ſemper erant, ſpes ſemper mixta timori.
Si modo Victor eras, ad crastina bella pavebas:
Si modo Victus eras, ad craſtina bella parabas.
Cui veſtes ſudore jugi, cui ſica cruore
Tincta jugi, quantum ſit onus regnare, probarunt.
Nec tamen aut ferro con • ritus ponere ferrum,
Aut gladio potuit vitae finiſſe dolores.
Jam poſt exactos Vitae Regnique labores,
Chriſtus ei ſit vera quies Regnumque perenne.

lg.l: Thy inbred noblenes gav thee goodnes gain,
Thy goodnes, warlike Elfred, brought thee pain;
Thy troubles fame: whoſ jois were mix'd with woes;
Whoſ hopes ſtil joind with fears of overthrows.
If Victor now, thou dreadedſt n • xt dais rue:
If vanquiſht now, next thou didſt wars renew.
Whoſ garment's ſtaind with ſweat, whoſ ſword with blood;
Shew'd what toil 'tis to reign, tho 't ſeem ſo good.
Though worn with wars, from fight he would not ceaſ;
Yet periſh'd not by ſword, but died in peace.
Now after al the toils of life and reign,
Let him with Chriſt in tru reſt ſtil remain.

argument.p: The 4 Diſtichs deviſed in commendation of Edgar the magnificent King of England.

l.hi: Author opum, Vindex ſcelerum, Largitor honorum;

lg.l: Sceptriger Edgarus regna ſuperna petit.
Magnificus Salomon, Legum Pater, Orbita pacis:

l.hi: Quòd caruit, bellis, claruit inde magis.
Templa Deo, Monachos Templis, Monachis dedit agro:
Nequitiae lapſum, iſtu it iaeque locum.
Novit enim Regno verum perquirere falſo,
Immenſum m • dico, perpetuumque brevi.

lg.l: Founder of Wealth, ſins ſcourge, Honors ſource great;
King Edgar's gon in Heav'n to hold his ſeat.
This ſtately Salomon, Law-father, Rule of Peace;
By wanting wars his glory did increaſ.
Churches to God, to them Moncs, to Moncs he gav
Lands: pul'd down Vice, that Juſtice place might hav.
A Kingdom tru for falſ, by Chriſts blood bought,
Boundleſſ for ſmal, endleſſ for ſhort he ſought.

argument.p: The 2 Diſtichs compoſed on Wiliam the Baſtard Duke of Normanny, who conquered England.

lg.l: Qui rexit rigidos Normannos, ſubdidit Anglos,

l.hi: Et Coenomenſes contudit enſe feros:

lg.l: Rex magnus modica jacet hac Gulielmus in Ʋrna:

l.hi: Sufficit & magno parva domus Domino.

lg.l: Who rul'd the Normans, conquerd th' Engliſh ſtour.
And queld the Manceaux men with al their rout:
Wiliam that great King lies in this ſmal Urn:
A litle houſ muſt ſerv a great Lords turn.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons that had hard hap in hunting a Stag at New-Foreſt, one to kil the other.

lg.l: Rex Cervum inſequitur, Regem Vindicta: Tirellus
