l.hi: Non bene proviſum trans fixit acumine ferri.

lg.l: The King purſued a Stag, Vengeance the King: Wil. Ruſus a French Knight.
Whom Tirel with's ſharp ſhaft to death did b • ing.

argument.p: The 5 Diſtichs framed on the death of Henry 2 commonly caled Fitz-Empreſſ.

lg.l: Rex Henricus eram, mihi plurima Regna ſubegi:

l.hi: Multiplicique modo Rexque Comeſque fui.
Cum ſatis ad Votum non eſſent omnia Terrae
Climata, terra modò ſufficit • cto pedum.
Qui legis haec, penſa diſcrimina mortis, & in me
Humanae ſpeculum conditionis habe
Scribitur hoc tumulo, Rex aurce, laus tua tota
Aurea materiae conveniente nota.
Sufficit hic tumulus, cui non ſuffecerat Orbis:
Res brevis ampla ſatis, cui fuit ampla brevis.

lg.l: I Henry was, who conquer'd many a Land:
And diverſ Dukedoms with Realms held in hand.
When al th' Earths climes could not my mind content;
Within eght foot of gro • nd I now am pent.
Thou that readſt this, deaths dangers weigh in me,
And mans frail ſtate in this bright Myrrhour ſee.
Thy golden praiſ is here writ, golden King,
In golden letters fit for ſuch a Thing.
This Tumb ſervs him, whom th' Earth could not ſuffice
Who thought large Realms but litle, in ſmal room lies

argument.p: The 4 Sicarians (Courtiers) which ſlu Archbiſhop Becket in the Cathedral Church of Canterbury.

lg.l: Angliaca Henricus tenuit cum Sceptra ſecundus,
Sacratus Thomas enſe necatus erat.
Bis duo Morvillus, Tracius, Brito, Filius-Urſi
Primatem Proceres enecuere Thomam.
When ſecund Henry th' Engliſh Scepter wielded,
Thomas the Saint with bloody ſword was killed.
Four Court-Knights Fitz-Ʋrſ, Tracy, Briton, Morvil
Archbiſhop Thomas butcherly did kil.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Morvillus, Tracius, Reginaldus Filius Urſi,
Richarduſque Brito Thomam necuere beatum.
Morvil, Tracy, Fitz-Ʋrſ, and Briton ſlu
Saint Thomas, whom they did in blood embrew.

argument.p: The 2 Eulogiacal Elegies made on Archbiſhop Becket, and William Marſhal Earl of Pembrook.

lg.head: Becket.

l.hi: Pro Chriſti Sponſa, Chriſti ſub tempore, Chriſti
In Templo, Chriſti verus Amator obit,

lg.l: For Chriſts Cauſ, in Chriſts Church, and at Chriſtide,
Chriſts ſincere Lover ſlain by mens ſwords died.

lg.head: Wiliam Marſhal.
lg.l: Sum quem Saturnum ſibi ſenſit Hybernia, Solem
Anglia, Mercurium Normannia, Gallia Martem.
I Irelands Saturn, Englands Sun moſt bright,
Normannies Merc'ry, Mars of France am hight.

argument.p: The 3 Diſtichs compiled on the diſaſtrous death of Richard the firſt, cald Ceur de Lion.

lg.l: Viſcera Carceolum, Corpus Fons ſervat Evrardi,
Et Cor Rothomagum, clare Richarde, tuum.

l.hi: In tria dividitur unus, qui plus fuit uno:
Nec ſupereſt uni gloria tanta Viro.

lg.l: Hic, Richarde, jaces: ſed Mors ſi cederet armis;

l.hi: Victa timore tui, cederet ipſa tuis.

lg.l: Carceol thy Bowels, Corps Font-Everard,
Roan keeps thy Lions heart. noble Richard.
Thus one in three is ſeverd, who was more then one:
And ſuch a one, as like glory is in none.
Thou here lieſt, Richard, but if Death to Arms could yeeld;
Vanquiſh'd with fear of thee, ſhe would fly the Field.

argument.p: The 2 moſt bitter biting Epitaphs framed on King John by malitious Moncs which hated him.

lg.l: Hic jacet Herodes, Herode ferocior: bujus

l.hi: Inquinat Inferntim Spiritus, oſſa Solum.

lg.l: Her • lies a Herod, then Herod far more vile:
Whoſ Ghoſt makes Hel ſtink, and Bones Earth defile.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Anglia ficut adhuc ſordet foetore Joannis:
Sordida foedatur foedante Joanne, Gehenna,
As England ſtil ſtinks with Johns filthy ſmel:
So filthy John berais foul ſtinking Hel.

argument.p: The 4 riming Verſes made upon the death of Edward the third: according to the garb of thoſ times.

lg.l: En decus Anglorum, Flos Regum praeteritorum;

l.hi: Norma futurorum, Rex clemens, Lex Populorum:

lg.l: Tertius Edvardus, complens Regni Jubilaeum;
Invictus Pardus, ſuperans bellis Machabaeum.
Lo Englands Honor, Flour of Kings before;
The Fol • wers patern, mild King, Peoples Lore:
Third Edward reigning in his ful Jubilee;
A peerleſſ Panther, in wars like Machabee.

argument.p: The 2 Religious Orders of Friers and Nuns or Minchins, which lived under one roof or Cel.

l.hi: Sunt Nonnarum aliae ſteriles, aliae parientes:
Sed quae Virgineo nomine cuncta tegunt.
Attamen haud quaevis ſterilis reperitur in illis,
Donec eis Aetas • alia poſſe negat.
Quae Paſtoralis baculi dotatur honore,
Illa quidem melius fertiliuſque parit.

lg.l: The Nuns ſom barren ſeem, ſom bearing ſtil:
But they with Virgins name hide al their il.
Yet 'mongſt them ſearſ one barren can be found,
Til Age their ſtrength of teeming did confound:
Surely more fertil ſhe, and pregnant proved;
Which was with Croiſiers ſtaf bleſt, and beſt loved.

argument.p: The 3 verſes of a dirty Dialog betwixt a Chriſtian and a Jew (which fel into a Jakes) at Tewksbury.

lg.l:
Tende manus, Salomon; ego te de ſtercore tollam:
Anglus. Judaeus. Anglus. A. C. 1128

l.hi: Sabbata noſtra colo, de ſtercore ſurgere nolo.

lg.l: Sabbata noſtra quidem, Salomon, celebrabis ibidem.
Jew, reach thy hand to me; from Draugh I wil thee free
Our Sabbathe I obſerv; and wil here rather ſterv.
Then Jew ſans more adoo, ther keep our Lords day too.

argument.p: The 6 Metrical verſes inſculped in Braſſ on Peter Courteney, Son to the Earl of Devon; at Exon.

lg.l: Devoniae natus Comitis, Petruſque vocatus:

l.hi: Regis cognatus, Camerarius intitulatus:
Callifiae gratus, Capitaneus enſe probatus:
Vita privatus, fuit hic ſuper aſtra relatus:
Et quia ſublatus, de mundo tranſit amatus:
Coela firmatus, maneat ſine fine beatus.

lg.l: The Earl of Denſhires Son, Peter by name:
Kin to the King, Lord Chamberlain of fame:
Captain of Calis for arms wel approved:
Who dying was, abov the Stars removed:
And wel belov'd, went from the World away:
To lead a bleſſed life, in Heaven for ay.

argument.p: The 5 Encomiaſtic Diſtichs compoſed as an Epitaph on Henry the ſeventh, who united the Red and White Roſe.

lg.l: Septimus Henricus tumulo requieſcit in iſto:

l.hi: Qui Regum ſplendor, lumen & Orbis erat.
Rex vigil & ſapiens, conſtans Virtutis amator:
Egregius forma, ſtrenuus, atque potens.
Qui peperit pacem Regno, qui bella peregit
Plurima, qui Victor ſemper ab Hoſte redit.
Filiolas binas qui junxit Regibus ambas,
Regibus & cunctis foedere junctus erat.
Qui ſacer hoc ſtruxit Templum, ſtatuitque ſepulchrū
Proſe, proque ſua conjuge, Prole, Domo.

lg.l: In this Tumb Henry reſts, by name ſeventh hight,
Who glory was of Kings, and the Worlds light.
A wiſe and wary Prince, who Virtu loved:
A goodly Perſon, for ſtrength and valour proved
Who wrought the Kingdoms peace, and wars appeaſed
Who from the Enimy Victor ſtil receded.
Who wth Kings matchd two Daughters in Matrimony,
And with al Kings joind firm league of tranquillity.
Who built this Church. and Monument erected
For Him, his Spouſ, Of-ſpring, and Houſ projected

argument.p: The 2 Panegyrical Diſtichs made on the Picture of Mary Queen of Scots, Mother to King James.

lg.l: Ʋt Mariam finxit Natura, Ars pinxit: utrumque

l.hi: Rarum & ſolertis ſummum opus Artiſicis.
Ipſe animum ſibi dum pingit, ſic vicit utrumque:
Ʋt Natura rudis, Ars videatur iners.

lg.l: As Nature Mary made, Art hath wel framed:
Both the rare work of a chief Artiſt famed.
While he hir mind ſo paints, ſhe both exceded;
That Nature rude, and Art impoliſh'd ſeemed.

argument.p: The 5 Encomiaſtic Diſtichs framed in flattery of Queen Elizabeths Picture, who bore great Majeſty.

l.hi: Cujus Imago? Dcae: facie cui lucet in una

lg.l: Temperie mixta Juno, Minerva, Venus,

l.hi: Eſt Dea, quis dubitet? cui ſie conſpirat amice
Maſcula vis, hilaris gratia, celſus honos.

lg.l: Aut Dea ſi non eſt, Diva eſt quae praeſidet Anglis,

l.hi: Ingenio, vultu▪ moribus aequa Dcis.
Quae manus Artiſicis tria ſic confundit, ut uno
Gratia, majeſtas, & decor Ore micet.
Non Pictoris Opus fuit hoc, ſed Pectoris: unde
Divinae in Tabulam ment is Imago fluit.

lg.l: Whoſ Image is't? a Goddeſſ: in whoſ face
Juno, Pallas, Venus ſhine with mix'd grace.
A Goddeſſ, who doubts? in whom ſo wel conſpired,
Manly force, ſweet Grace, Majeſty admired?
If Goddeſſ none, yet Saint, which England ſwaied;
In wit, face, maners like the Gods diſplaied.
What Artiſts hand ſo three in one combined,
That in one face Grace, Majeſty, Beauty ſhined.
This was no Painters work, but of hir Breſt;
Whence hir divine mind in this Peece doth reſt.

argument.p: The 4 laudatory, adulatory, or gratulatory A. C. 1592 Diſtichs made on the ſame Queen at Oxford.

lg.l: Juno, Minerva, Venus nemoroſae in vallibus Idae

l.hi: Diſcrimen formae cum ſubiere ſuae:
Inter formoſas ſi tu Dea quarta fuiſſes;
Viciſſes reliquas, o Dea quarta, Deas.

lg.l:
Quam
• uno jejuna foret, quam pallida Pallas:
Quam Dea vana Venus: quam Dea ſola fores?

Jun •
jactat Opes, formam Venus, armaque Pallas:
Omnia ſed tua ſunt Juno, Minerva, Venus.
When Juno, Pallas, Venus ſtifly ſtrov
For Beauties Bal, in vale of Ida's Grov:
If you fourth Goddeſſ 'mongſt thoſ Fair had bin;
You O fourth Goddeſſ, would moſt fair be ſeen.
How wan would Juno ſeem, Pallas how pale;
How matchleſſ you; Venus how vain a Stale?
Juno boaſts State, Venus Shape, Pallas might:
But Juno, Pallas, Venus, al's your right.

argument.p: The 2 German Brothers (Rainolds) which twiſe changed Religion ech, yet ſtil contrary ech to other.

l.hi: Bella inter geminos pluſquam Civilia Fratres,
Concitat ambiguus Relligionis apex.
Ille Reformatae Fidei pro partibus inſtat:
Iſte reformandam denegat eſſe Fidem.
Propoſitis Cauſae rationibus, alter utrinque
Concurrere pares, & cecidere pares.
Quod fuit in votis, Frater capit alter utrumque:
Quod fuit in fatis, perdit uterque fidem.
Captivi gemini nullo ducente trahuntur,
Et Victor victi transfuga caſtra petit.

Quod genus hoc pugnae eſt, ubi Victor gaudet uter
que :
Et tamen alteruter ſe ſuperaſſe dole • ?

lg.l: Wars more then Civil raiſd betwixt two Brothers.
For Faith Reformeds part the Elder ſtood: Wiliam and John Rainolds.
The Younger to reform Faith held not good.
When Reaſons for the Cauſ were urg'd by either,
Both jump'd alike; and turnd alike together:
What heart could wiſh, ech Brother th' other takes:
What Fate ordaind, ech his firſt Faith forſakes.
Both, no man leading them, were Captivs brought:
And flying Conqu'rors the Camp of vanquiſhd ſought
What war is this, wher Conquerors both are glad;
Yet ech that he did overcom, is fad?

div.head: EPIG. XLVI. Avunculus & Nepos.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons which diſſembled much mutual affection or compliance ech to either.

lg.l: Falleris aspectu Baſiliſcum occidere, Plini:

l.hi: Namque meae vitae ſpem Baſiliſcus alit.

lg.l: Pliny ſpeaks falſ, that Baſiliſcs kil by ſight:
For to my hope of life this Beaſt givs light.

div.p: The Uncle bore a Cockatrice in his Coat of Arms for Creſt: but diſherited his Nephew.

l.hi: Certe aluit, ſed spe vana; spes vana venenum eſt:

lg.l: Plini, ignoſce mihi; Verus es Hiſtoricus.
He fed me with vain hope, which poiſon is:
Pardon me, Pliny; thou writ'ſt not amiſſ.

div.head: EPIG. XLVII. Proto naves Orbis Circuitores.

argument.p: The 2 firſt Ships which gav a girdle to the Geographic Globe of the World.

lg.l: Dicta Magellani eſt Victoria nomine Navis:

l.hi: Vidit enim & vicit Navis utrumque Polum.

lg.l: Magellans brav Ship Saint Victory had name:
For that Ship ſaw both Poles, and overcame.

lg.head: The Deſire

l.hi: Digna Ratis quae ſtet radiantibus inclita Stellis:
Supremo Mundi vertice digna Ratis.

lg.l: Ship fit with glittering Stars garniſh'd to ſtand:
And to be plac'd on higheſt pitch of Land.

argument.p: The 2 laudatory Diſtichs framed on Sir Fr. Drake, when he compaſd the Earth.

lg.l: Drache, peragrati novit quem terminus Orbis,

l.hi: Quemque ſimul Mundi vidit uterque Polus:
Si taceant Homines, facient te ſidera notum:
Sol neſcit Comitis non memor eſſe ſui.

lg.l: Drake, whom the Worlds end which thou traveldſt knew,
And whom the Worlds both Poles at once did view:
If Men be mute, Stars wil thy fame relate:
The Sun cannot forget his Journy-mate.

lg.head: Aliud.
lg.l: Plus ultra Herculeis inſcribas, Drache, Columnis:
Et magno, dicas, Hercule major ero.
Drake, write on Hercules Poſts plus ultra free:
And ſay, I'le greater then great Hercules be.

argument.p: The 2 Epitaphs framed on Sir Francis Drake, who died at Sea in the Weſt-Indies.

l.hi: Quamvis Relligio Romana reſurgeret olim,

lg.l: Effoderet tumulum non puto, Drache, tuum.

l.hi: Non eſt quòd metuas, ne te Combuſſerit ulla
Posteritas: etenim tutus ab Igne jaces.

lg.l: Though Romes Religion ſhould ſway here again,
Drake it could not dig thy Tumb from the Main.
Thou needſt not fear, leſt late Times ſhal thee burn:
For thou lieſt ſafe from Fire in Watry Urn.

lg.head: Aliud.

l.hi: Te celebrem Fortuna magis clarere volebat:
Namque bona excellis ſorte, malaque ſimul.

lg.l: Quem timuit ſaevis etiam Neptunus in undis,

l.hi: Et rediit toto Victor ab Oceano:
Faedifragos pellens pelago proſtravit Iberos

lg.l: Drachus: huic Tumulus aequoris unda fuit.
Fortune made thee more famous and tenownd:
For thou with good and il luck didſt abound.
Whom Neptune dreaded on the raging Sea,
Who thence did bear the Conqueſt ſtil away:
Drake the falſ Spaniards foild, driving them far
From Sea: his Tumb the brackiſh Waters are.

argument.p: The 2 Epicedial Diſtichs compoſd on Mr. Candiſh, the third Coſmo-Navigator A. C. 1587.

l.hi: Sorte tua poteris ſi tu vixiſſe ſecunda
Contentus, nulli ſors magis aequa fuit.
Fortunam tentando iterum, Fortuna ſecundò
Noluit inconstans eſſe ſecunda tibi.

lg.l: If thou couldſt hav liv'd with thy happy ſtate
Contented, no man had a luckier Fate.
In trying Fortune twiſe, inconſtant Dame
Fortune would not be twiſe to thee the ſame.

argument.p: The 7 Heroic Verſes ſent by Mr. Michelburn to Mr. Criſp for 7 s. which he lent him.

lg.l: Criſpe tibi mitlo verſus tantummodò ſeptem:

l.hi: Est impar numerus, numero Deus impare gaudet.

lg.l: Sunt ſeptem Romae Colles: ſeptem Oſtia Nili:

l.hi: Septem Artes ſacrae: ſeptem mir • cula Mundi:
Hebdomadae ſeptemque dies: ſeptemque Triones.
Altera ſed res eſt, ſeptem ſolidos mihi debes:
Quos ut perſolvas, ſeptem tibi carmina dono.

lg.l: Friend Criſp, I ſend you verſes only ſevn:
The number's od: God numbers lovs unevn.
Sevn Hils at Rome, ſevn mouths of Nilus are:
Sevn ſacred Arts: the Worlds ſevn Wonders rare.
The week ſevn dais, the Heav'ns ſevn Trions ſhow:
But one thing reſts, ſevn ſhillings you me ow:
Which that you'l pay, ſevn Verſes I beſtow.

argument.p: The 2 mournful Threnes inſcribed on a Braſſ-Table in Chriſt-Church at Oxford.

lg.l: Quàm Walronde, tibi es dudum ſine compare dispar?

l.hi: Quam vacuum eſt nuper plenius Arte caput?
De tali nichil eſt niſi talis Imago: datura eſt
Mors tibi nos ſimiles: vix dare vita poteſt.

lg.l: Walrond, how unlike art thou, once ſans Peer?
How void's thy Brain of Art, latly moſt cleer?
Nought but ſuch Image now is left of thee:
Death wil make us like: Life ſcarce like can be.

l.hi: Si mea cum Matris valuiſſent Vota, dediſſes
F • nus idem nobis, quod tibi, Nate, damus.
Sed quoniam Votis nostris Deus obſtetit aequus;
Ante mea & Matris funera, funus habes.

lg.l: Son, if mine and thy Mothers wiſhes could avail;
Thou ſhouldſt our Fate, as we doo thine bewail:
But ſith Juſt God hath our deſires gainſaid;
Thou before us thy debt to Death haſt paid.

argument.p: The 2 jeering Verſes compiled (among many wits mo) on Th. Coryats Travels cald crudities.

lg.l: Ingenium, Coryate, tuum Liber hicce ſepultum

l.hi: Continet: ingenio qui caret, inde pet at.

lg.l: Coryat, this Book thy wit holds hid in it:
Let him go ſeek it ther that wanteth wit.

argument.p: The 2 featy facetious Verſes, framed when King James removed Biſhop Mountain to London.

l.hi: Defenſor Fidei Montem de ſede removit:
M • ra Fides, Montem quae removere poteſt.

lg.l: The Faiths Defender a Mountain raiſd from's place:
Strange Faith which could a Mountain ſo diſplace.

argument.p: The 2 high Offices of Honor and Truſt, which King James conferred on George Villers Duke of Buckingham.

lg.l: Buckinghamus Io, maris eſt Praeſectus, & aequis

l.hi: Qui dominatus Aquis; nunc dom natur Equis.
Sic inter Superos liquidas qui temperat undas

lg.l: Neptunus, rapidis condominatur Equis.

l.hi: Ecquis, cui minime placeat geminata Potestas;
Exemplum ſuperis cum placuiſſe videt?

lg.l: Lo, Buckingham was high Admiral at Sea,
And he that ruld at Sea, did Horſes ſway. Maſter of the Horſ.
So 'mongſt the Gods, the Waters Soveraign
Neptune, doth eke over ſwift Horſes raign.
Can any then ſuch duple power diſlike,
When he ſees that the Gods the ſame doo like?

argument.p: The 3 remarkable Occurrents obvening at London on the three laſt dais of May An. 1630.

lg.l: Dum Rex Paulinas accedit gratus ad Aras,

l.hi: Emicuit medio lucida Stella di • .
Dic divina mihi tractans aenigmata, Praeco;
Quid nobis oriens haec ſibi Stella velit.
Magnus in Occiduo Princeps modo naſcitur Orbe:
Craſque ſub Eclipſin Regna Orientis erunt.

lg.l: When King Charls at Pauls Altar thanks did pay,
A bright Star cleerly ſhin'd in midſt of day.
Preacher, who ſacred Riddles didſt unfold;
Tel what this riſing Star to us foretold.
A great Prince newly born is in the Weſt: Prince Charles.
Next day Eclips'd wil be the Realms of th' Eaſt.

div.head: EPIG. LVII. Strages luctuoſiſſima.

argument.p: The 5 Perſons (a whol Family) which cam to direful doleful deaths within one hour An. 1645.

l.hi: Verveces, Pueri, Puer alter, Sponſa, Maritus:
Cultello, Flamma, Fune, Dolore cadunt.

lg.l: Weathers, Bois, Babe, Wife, Husband died together
By Knife, Fire, Halter, Grief ech after either.

div.p: 'Tis credibly reported, that a poor Butcher of Cambridg, having kild and hung up two Sheep; went inſtantly into Town, and his two litle Sons caried the Knife into the Room, and as their Father did to the Sheep, cut their own throats. The Mother abov in the Chamber hearing their grones, cam haſtily down, and ſeing this ſad ſpectacle ſowned; letting a young Infant fal into the Fire: but recovering hir Senſes, and ſeing the Babs burning, hangd hir ſelf. Preſently cam in the Butcher, who at al theſ ſo hideous ſights, ſowned to death. The Neighbours ſhortly coming in, conceiv this to be the maner.

div.head: EPIG. LVIII. Foeminarum in Anglia venuſtas.

argument.p: The 2 Diſtichs compoſed in praiſ of Engliſh Womens beauties.

lg.l: Anglia quòd pulchras habeat tot ſola Puellas;

l.hi: Nil mirum: cincta est Inſula tota Mari.

lg.l: Ipſa Venus ſpumis fertur prognata marinis:
Hinc totidem Veneres Anglia ſola parit.
That England with fair Laſſes doth abound,
No marvel: 'tis an Ile with Sea cloſd round,
Venus ſhe-ſelf's ſaid of Sea-froth to ſpring,
Hence only England doth ſuch Beauties bring.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes of a Diſtich applied to the French and Engliſh for their inclination to War.

l.hi: Libera Gens, cui liberà mens, & libera lingua:
Sed lingua melior liberiorque Manus.

lg.l: Free People of free mind, and free toung too:
But better Hands then Toungs and freer to doo.

div.head: EPIG. LX. Gentes in diaeta diſſimiles.

argument.p: The 3 Neighbour Nations vulgarly reputed to differ in diet, or eating and drinking.

l.hi: Non comedis, German • , bibis bene: non bibis, Angle,
Sed comedis: Comedis, Flandre, bibiſque bene.
Germani poterant duros perferre labores:
O utinam poterint tam bene ferre ſitim.

lg.l: Germans eat litle, drink wel: Engliſh eat,
Drink ſparing: Flemings lov both drink and meat.
Germans to hard toil doo themſelfs inure:
O that they could long thirſt ſo wel endure.

argument.p: The 6 Parts or Petitions of that peerleſſ incomparable Praier, dictated by our Saviour.

l.hi: Coeleſtis Genitor, tua ſit ſacrata Potestas:
A • veniat Regnum: tua fiat ubique Voluntas:
Da nobis dimenſum hodie: peccata remitte
Nobi • , ſicut nos peccata remittimus ipſi:
Nol • to tentare tuos: ſed protege Sanctos
A Satana: tua namque eſt laus, Regnum, atque potestas.

lg.l: Our Heav'nly Father, thy Power halowed be:
Thy Kingdom com: thy Wil doon in ech degree:
Giv us our daily Food: our ſins remit,
As we forgiv them, that t' us harm commit:
Doo not us tempt; thy Saints from il defend:
For thine is Praiſ, Kingdom, and Power ſans end.

argument.p: The 4 uſual Seaſons of a Solar yeer: in ech of which the Sun peragrats three Signs of the Zodiac.

l.hi: Efficiunt anni communia tempora noſtri.

lg.l: Four times (Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter) frame
The common Seaſons of our yeer by name.

lg.head: Aliud.

l.hi: Ver, Aeſtas, Autumnus, Hyems ſunt quatuor Anni
Partes: quas vario Sol peragrat radio.

lg.l: Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter are of th' yeer
Four parts, which Sol runs through with his beams cleer.

l.hi:
Bruma novi prima eſt, veteriſ
que noviſsima Solis:
Principium capiunt Phoebus & Annus idem.
Vere novo, nitido reparata colore refidget
Terra: reviſensis jubare Solis habens.
Phoebe, quid o tepidi properas in brachia Cancri?
Aestuat indomito Terra calore tuo.
Sol libram ingrediens, Mundi lucem aequat & umbras;
In media Coeli flans regione ſui.

lg.l: Winter begins the new, and ends th' old yeer:
The Sun and yeer one ſelf-ſame ſtation ſteer.
At Spring the Earth with new bright hu doth ſhine:
Which the Sun beams aſcending doo refine.
Phaebus, why haſt's thou into Cancers arms?
Thy ſcorching heat to th' Earth brings ſundry harms.
Sol entring Libra equals day and night
In al the World; darting them from midſt his light.

l.hi: Ver, Aeſtas, Autumnus, Hyems ſunt quatuor: unus,
Quae ſi membra ſimul junxeris, Annus erit.
Poma dat Autumnus: formoſa eſt Meſsibus Aeſtas:
Ver generat Flores: Igne levatur Hyems.

lg.l: Spring, Summer, Autumn, Win • er four make one:
Which wil be a yeer, if you al parts conjoin.
Autumn breeds Apples: Summer ripens Grain:
Spring ſpreads forth Flours: Fire eaſeth Winters pain

lg.head: Brevius.

l.hi: Ver, Aeſtas, Autumnus, Hyems ſtata Tempora ſignant.

lg.l: Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter make
The four ſet Times, as we them take.

argument.p: The 5 Zones or Girdles of the Univerſ: which divide the Earth into two Extrems and a Middle in latitude.

l.hi: Quinque ſitae Coelo Zonae Terram undique cingunt:
Quarum quae media eſt, non eſt habitabilis aestu,
Nix tegit alta duas: totidem inter utramque locavit,
Temperiemque dedit, mista cum frigore flamma.

lg.l: Fiv Zones in Heav'n ſet, doo th' Earth round immure:
The midmoſt for heat none wel can endure.
Deep ſnows hide two: 'twixt both two mo are placed,
And temper hav, heat with cold interlaced.

argument.p: The 4 chief Cardinal Winds, riſing from Heavens capital points: which denominat al the ſubordinat.

l.hi: Aſper ab Axe ruit Boreas: venit Eurus ab Ortu:
Auſter amat medium Solem: Zephyruſque cadentem.

lg.l: Rough Boreas coms from North: Eurus from Eaſt:
Auſter the South-Sun lovs: Zeph'rus the Weſt.

argument.p: The 4 known Parts into which the habitable World is divided: with the rarities of ech.

lg.l: Nobilis auratas producit America Gemmas:
Procreat horrendas Africa terra Feras:
Eſt Aſiae florentis honos formoſa Puella:
Ast Europa Viros fortis ad arma parat.
America Gold and Gems yields of bright hew:
Afric breeds Beaſts and Serpents fel to view:
Aſia fair Wenches boaſts for Venus charms:
But Warlike Europ makes men fit for Arms.

argument.p: The 4 ſorts of chief Prof • ſſors, who in officiating turn their faces toward ſeveral Quarters.

l.hi: Coſmograpbus Boream, ſed Coeli menſor ad Auſtrum;
Praeco Dei Exortum videt, Occaſumque Poeta.

lg.l: Coſmographers North, Aſtronomers South reſpect;
Preachers to th' Eaſt, Poets to Weſt reflect.

argument.p: The 2 Artificial Globes of Glaſſ to preſent Heaven and Earth: deviſed by Archimides

lg.l: Juppiter in parvo cum cerneret Aethera Vitro:

l.hi: Noſter, ait, fragili luditur Orbe labor.
Jura Poli, Rerumque vices, Legeſque Deorum

lg.l: Ecce Syracuſius praetulit Arte Senex.

l.hi: Percurrit proprium mentitus Signifer Annum,

lg.l: Et ſimulata novo Cynthia Menſe redit.
When Jove in a ſmal Glaſſ the Heavns ſurvaid:
Our Work in a brittle World is mock'd, he ſaid.
Th' old Syracuſans Art preſents Heavens hew,
The courſ of Things, and the Gods Laws to view.
The Zodiac conterfets a juſt yeers race:
And forged Cynthia runs hir monthly bace.

argument.p: The 3 Things uſed to rapin: 3 ſorts of Men that can kil by Law: and 3 which may ly by authority.

l.hi: Juridicis, Erebo, Fiſco mos vivere rapto:
Militibus, Medicis, Tortori occidere fas eſt:
Mentiri Aſtrologis, Pictoribus, atque Poetis:

lg.l: Lawiers, Hel, Chequer uſe to rapin ſtil:
Souldiers, Emprics, Hangmen impunely kil:
Aſtrologers, Painters, Poets ly at wil.

argument.p: The 4 principal Moral Virtues moſt magnified: which are commonly caled Cardinal.

l.hi: Juſtus agit juste: Prudens prudenter: Honeſtus
Temperat a vitiis: & Fortis fortiter audet.

lg.l: The Juſt Man juſtly doth: wiſely the Wiſe:
Stoutly the Stout: the Good abſtains from Vice.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes ſet over the Captains Gate at Brixia or Breſcia: to ſhew his ſincerity of Juſtice.

l.hi: Hic locus odit, amat, punit, conſervat, honorat;
Nequitiem, pacem, crimina, jura, bonos.

lg.l: This Place doth hate, lov, puniſh, keep, reverence;
Wickednes, peace, crimes, laws, good mens innocence

argument.p: The 3 learned famous Faculties, which are moſt eminent or excellent in al Chriſtian Common-weals.

lg.l: Theiologis Animam ſubjecit lapſus Adami:

l.hi: At Corpus Medicis, & Bona Juridicis.

lg.l: By Adams fal Divines to Souls pretend,
Phiſitions Bodies, Lawiers Goods attend.

argument.p: The 2 Diſtichs comparing the firſt Adam with the ſecund, touching eating of, and dying on a Tree.

lg.l: Primus Adam letho mutavit ab Arbore vitam,

l.hi: Et ſua Serpentis ſub juga colla dedit.

lg.l: Alter Adam vita mutavit in Arbore Lethum,

l.hi: Serpentiſque ſibi ſub juga colla tulit.

lg.l: Firſt Adam by a Tree for life death gained,
And to the Serpents yoke, his Neck inchained.
Next Adam on a Tree life for death bought,
And to his yoke the Serpents Neck hath brought.

argument.p: The 7 dais of a week, as Aſtrologers ſet them, to ſhew the reign of ech Planet in his proper hours.

lg.head: Latin.
lg.l:
Sol, Luna, & Mavors, Hermes, Jupiter, Venus, at
que
Saturnus Feriis dant nomina certa Latinis.
Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jove, Venus, and
Saturn giv names to Latin dais, as they ſtand.

lg.head: Saxon.
lg.l: Sol, Luna, & Tuiſco, Wodenus, Thor, Fria, Sater

l.hi: Hebdomadae ſeptem dant nomina certa diebus.

lg.l: Sun, Moon, Tuiſc, Woden, Thor, Fria, and Sater
To Saxons weeks ſevn dais giv names in order.

div.head: EPIG. LXXIIII. Planetae in ordine Orbium.

argument.p: The 7 Erratic Stars ſet in order of ſeveral Spheres one abov another under the Firmament.

lg.l: Saturnus prior eſt: hinc Juppiter. inde Gradivus:
Poſt ſequitur Phoebus: Cypria deinde Dea:
Mercurius ſextus: verum infima & ultima Luna eſt:

l.hi: Ordo Planetarum clauditur hocce modo.

lg.l: Saturn is firſt: next Jove: Mars third in place:
The Sun in midſt: fifth Venus runs hir race:
Mercury ſixth: Moon loweſt and laſt in Band:
The Planets in this rank and maner ſtand.

argument.p: The 10 Plagues or Puniſhments, which God inflicted on Egypt by Moſes and Aarons hands.

l.hi: Suanguis, Ranae, Culex, Muſcae, peſtis Pecorū, Anthrax
Grando, Locuſta, Caligo, & mors Primogenitorum.

lg.l: Blood-waters, frogs, lice, flies, Beaſts-murrain: Blain:
Hail, Locuſts, Darknes, and the Firſt-born ſlain.

l.hi: Prima rubens unda: Raenarum Plaga ſecunda:
Inde Culex triſtis: tum Muſca nocentior iſtis:
Quinta Pecus ſtravit: Bubones ſexta creavit:
Deinde ruit Grando: poſt Bruchus dente nefando:
Nona tegit Solem: primam necat ultima Prolem.
Hiſce decem poenis Aegyptus plectitur omnis.

lg.l: Firſt Waters turnd to blood: next Frogs great ſtore:
Then biting Lice: fourth Flies which vexed more:
Murrain of Cattle fifth: ſixth Botches grievous:
Sevnth Hail with Fire: eghth Locuſts moſt miſchievous:
Ninth Darknes thick: the laſt the Firſt-born killed.
With theſ ten plagues al Egypt Land was filled.

argument.p: The 10 Commandments of the Moral Law, which God gav to Moſes on Mount Sinai: as Papiſts ſtate them.

l.hi: Ʋnum
crede Deum: nec
jures vana per ipſum:
Sabbata
ſanctifices: habeas
in honore Parentes:
Ne ſis
Occiſor:
Maechus:
Fur:
Teſtis iniquus:
Ʋxorē
alterius:
nec Rem cupias alienam.

lg.l: Worſhip one God: take not in vain his Name:
Keep Sabbaths holy: honor Parents fame:
No Murdrer be: Whorſter: Theef: falſ Teſtee:
Seek no Mans Wife: nor take Mens goods to thee.

argument.p: The 7 German Princes or Mootmen, which the Pope conſtituted to meddle in electing the Emperor.

lg.l: Moguntinenſis, Trevirenſis, Colonienſis:

l.hi: Quilibet Imperii fit Cancellarius horum.
Marchio praepoſitus Camerae: Dux Portior Enſis:

lg.l: Atque Palatinus Dapifer: Pincerna Bohemus.
Mentz, Triers, Colein Archbiſhops al three:
Ech of theſ Chancelers of the Empire be.
Marquis is Chamberlain: Duke the Sword do • h bring:
And Palſgrav Sewer: Cup-bearer Bohems King.

argument.p: The 7 mightieſt Monarchs in Europ, who lived at one time An 1610; but al dead.

lg.l: Caeſar cum Polano verſantur in Aurifodinis:
Cuniculis fatuus ludentibus adſtat Iberus:
Rex Gallus maechatur: venaturque Brytannus:
Graſſatur Suedus: Danus luditque bibitque.
Th' Emp'ror with Polands King Gold-mines attends:
Spains ſilly King his time 'mongſt Rabbets ſpends:
Wenching the French King: Hunting Brytiſh loved:
The Swed free boot: Dane Dice and Drink approved

argument.p: The 3 Encomiaſtic Diſtichs or Paraſitic Panegyrics compoſed in commendation of Venice City.

lg.l: Viderat Adriacis Venetam Neptunus in undis

l.hi: Stare Ʋrbem, & toti ponere Jura Mari.

lg.l: Nunc mihi Tarpeias, quantumvis Juppiter, Arces

l.hi: Objice; & illa tui moenia Martis, ait.

lg.l:
Sic Pelago Tybrim praefers? Ʋrbem aſpice utram
que :

l.hi: Illam Homines dices, hanc poſuiſſe Deos.

lg.l: Neptune in Adriac waves a City ſaw
Cald Venice, which to al Seas elſ gav Law.
Jove, if thou wilt compare Romes Capitol,
And warlike Wals, ſaid he: this were t' extol
Tyber abov the Main; of both view take:
Thoul't ſay Men Rome, the Gods did Venice make.

div.head: EPIG. LXXX. Ʋxores cum Viris combuſtae.

argument.p: The 2 Diſtichs contrived concerning Women which burn themſelfs on their Huſbands funeral Pile.

l.hi: Hae certamen habent lethi, quae viva ſequatur
Conjugium: pudor eſt non voluiſſe mori.
Ardent Victrices, & praebent pectora flammis;
Imponuntque ſuis ora peruſta Viris.

lg.l: Theſ ſtriv in death, who ſhal accompany
Their Wedlock; 'tis foul ſhame not ſo to dy.
The living burn, and yeeld their breſts to flame;
And on their Mates lay their ſcorch'd lips for ſame.
He muſt be a pithy Orator that ſhal perſwade
Women of theſ times to buy Fame at ſo deer rate.

div.head: EPIG. LXXXI. Ʋxores variae unius Viri.

argument.p: The 3 ſeveral Wifes, which one Man is ſaid ſucceſſivly to wed in ſundry yeers or Ages of his life.

l.hi: Terna mihi nupta eſt variis aetatibus Uxor;
Haec Juveni, illa Viro, tertia deinde Seni.
Prima eſt propter opus teneris mihi juncta ſub annis,
Proxima propter Opes, ultima propter Opem.

lg.l: Three Wifes at ſeveral Ages I hav wedded;
This young, that grown a Man, third when gray headed
The firſt in Youth I took for Childrens lake,
The next for Wealth, the laſt an Help to make.

argument.p: The 2 contrary Poiſons, which a wicked wife gav to hir Husband: yet killed him not.

l.hi: Toxica Zelotypo dedit Ʋxor Moecha Marito;
Nec ſatis ad mortem credidit eſſe datum.
Miſcuit Argenti lethalia pondera vivi,
Cogeret ut celerem vis geminata necem.
Ergo inter ſeſe dum noxia pocula certant;
Ceſſit lethalis noxa ſalutiferae.

lg.l: A Whor-wife poiſon gav t' her jealous Mate:
But thought it not enough to work his Fate.
She mixd of Quick-ſilver a deadly weight,
That dupled force his murder haſten might.
Then while thoſe baneful pots betwixt them ſtrov,
The helpful ſwaying the hurtfuls bane out drov.

div.head: EPIG. LXXXIII. Vir & Ʋxor invicem infeſti.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons which mutualy and mortaly loathed ech others conjugal company or ſociety.

lg.l: Raro domi prandet Lollus, facit idque libenter:
Prandeat ut raro, Caeciliana cupit:
Raro domi coenat Lollus, facit idque libenter:
Ʋt raro coenet, Caeciliana cupit.
Raro domi dormit Lollus, facit idque libenter;
Dormiat ut raro, Caeciliana cupit.
Hanc raro alloquitur Lollus, facit idque libenter;
Id raro ut faciat, Caeciliana cupi • .
Baſiat hanc nunquam Lollus, facit idque lubenter;
Baſiet ut nunquam Caeciliana capit.

l.hi: Hic cum illa nunquam cubat, id facit atque libenter;

lg.l: Ʋtque cubet nunquam, Caeciliana cupit

l.hi: Ʋxorem cupit ille aliam, cupit atque lubenter:

lg.l: Optat haebere alium Caeciliana Virum.

l.hi: O quanta eſt iſtos inter concordia? uterque
Quando libenter idem nolit, idemque velit.

lg.l: Lollus at home dines ſeldom, with his wil:
Caecilian wiſheth, he would doo ſo ſtil.
He ſeldom ſups at home, of his free mind;
She covets him ſtil abſent abroad to find.
He ſeldom in his Houſ ſleeps willingly;
She lovs his room rather then company.
He ſeldom talks with hir, of free accord;
She his talk likes neither at Bed nor Bord:
He never kiſſeth hir, gladly refraining:
She likewiſe glad is of his ſo abſtaining.
He never lies with hir in amorous ſort;
She more deſires his abſence then his ſport.
He greatly longs another Wife to hav;
She a new Husband ardently doth crav.
O how rare Concord 'twixt them is? when both
With like good wil the ſame things lov and loth.

argument.p: The 4 delightful Verſes made on a Woman, that had a white Son in hir Husbands abſence.

l.hi: De nive conceptum quem Mater Adultera fingit,
Sponſus cum vendens lique factum Sole refingit.

lg.l: A Whore-wife faind hir Child by Snow conceived,
Which hir Husband ſold as by the Sun bercaved.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Vir quia quem reperit genitum nive Foemina finxit;
Vendit, & a ſimili liquefactum Sole remonſtrat

lg.l: Becauſ the Wife ſaid Snow hir Son engendred:
The Man ſhewd 'twas by the Sun to Water rendred.

argument.p: The 2 Beautiful Perſons (Brother and Siſter) ſaid to hav ech one Ey contrary to the other.

lg.l: Lumine Acon dextro caruit, Leonilla ſiniſtro:

l.hi: Sed forma potuit vincere uterque Deos.
Parve Puer, lumen quod habes tu redde Sorori:

lg.l: Sic tu caecus Amor, ſic erit illa Venus.
Acon the right, Leonil the left Ey loſt:
But both for Beauty could the Gods accoſt.
Fine Lad, thine Ey giv to thy Siſter free:
So thou blind Cupid, Venus ſhe ſhal be

argument.p: The 7 chief Cities or Common-wealths, which emulouſly ſtrov to be Homers place of birth or breeding.

lg.l: Septem Ʋrbes certant de ſtirpe inſignis Homeri:
Smyrna, Rhodos, Colaphon, Salamos, Pilus, Argos, Athenae
Sevn Cities, not here rightly nam'd contended
From which of them great Homer in right deſcended.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Contendere Ʋrbes ſeptem pro patria Homeri:

l.hi: Cui nulla eſt vivo patria, nulla domus.

lg.l: Sevn Cities ſtrov, whence Homer firſt ſhould com:
Who while he liv'd, had neither houſ nor home.

argument.p: The 2 principal Rulers of Rome (firſt and and laſt) jeeringly compared one with the other.

lg.l: Non ego Romulea miror quod Paſtor in Ʋrbe

l.hi: Sceptra gerat; Paſtor Conditor Ʋrbis crat.
Cumque Lupae Gentis nutritus lacte ſit Author;

lg.l: Non ego Romulea miror in Ʋrbe Lupos.

l.hi: Hac tantum ſuperat noſtrum admiratio captum,
Quomodò ſecurum reddat Ovile Lupus.

lg.l: No wonder, if a Prieſt-Prince ſway Romes Scepter:
A Shepherd-Prince was primitiv Erect • r.
And ſith the Founder was with Wolfs milk fed;
No marvel if many Wolfs be therin bred.
This only wonder doth our reach tranſcend,
How a Wolf can a Sheep-fold ſafe defend.

argument.p: The 2 dainty Diſtichs, which being converted backward, word for word, cary contrary conſtructions.

lg.head: Ad Papam

l.hi: Laus tua, non tua fraus; Virtus non copia rerum
Scandere te fecit hoc decus eximium.

lg.l: Thy Worth, not Wiles; Virtu, not Wealth made thee
T' aſcend the top of this high Dignity.

lg.head: Retro verbatim.

l.hi: Eximium decus hoc fecit te ſcandere rerum
Copia, non Virtus; Fraus tua, non tua Laus.

lg.l: Thy Wealth, not Worth; thy Craft, not Commendation
Brought thee to this prime pitch of exaltation.

argument.p: The 3 Pompeis (Father and two Sons) who were ſlain in three parts of the known World.

lg.l: Pompeios Juvenes Aſia atque Europa, ſed ipſum
Terra tegit Libyae; ſi tamen ulla tenet.

l.hi: Quid mirum, toto ſi ſpargitur Orbe? jacere
Ʋno non potuit tanta ruina loco.

lg.l: Pompeis young Sons, Europ and Aſia hold:
He lies in Afric if in any mould.
What wonder if theſ through the World ly ſlain?
So great a wrack one place could not contain.

div.head: EPIG. XC. Epigrammata contraria.

argument.p: The 2 Epigrams made on Licinus a baſe Barber (but rich) of Rome: who had a marble Tumb.

lg.l: Marmoreo tumulo Licinus jacet, at Cato parvo,
Pompeius nullo: credimus eſſe Deos?
Licin in Marble, Cato in a ſmal Tumb lies,
Pompey in none: can we ther be Gods ſurmiſe?

div.stage: Another Diſtich anſwers, that the Gods regard or reward worthy Men with fame and felicity.

lg.head: Reſponſum
lg.l: Saxa premunt Licinum, vehit alte Fama Catonem,
Pompeium titulis: Cedimus eſſe Deos.
Stones preſſ down Licin, Fame Cato high doth mount,
Titles raiſ Pompey: Gods ther be we count.

argument.p: The 8 Sons and 8 Daughters, which Pope Innocent the eghth begot by ſundry Concubins.

lg.l: Octo Nocens Pueros genuit, totidemque Puellas:
Hunc merito poteris, Roma, vocare Patrem.
Nocent eght Sons and Girls ſo many got:
Rome might him rightly cal Father, why not?

argument.p: The 2 prime Potentats (Emperor and Pope) who contended long one againſt another for ſupremacy.

lg.l: Roma diu titubans variis erroribus acta

l.hi: Corruet & Mundi definet eſſe Caput.

lg.l: Rome tottring long with diverſ errors tainted
Shal fal, and ceaſ the Worlds Head to be Sainted.
Niteris incaſſum Navem ſubmergere Petti:

l.hi: Fluctuat at nunquam definet eſſe Ratis.

lg.l: Thou ſtriv'ſt in vain Peters Ship to o'rewhelm:
She flotes, but ſhal not leav to ſteer the Helm.

l.hi: Fata volunt, Stellaeque docent, Aviumque volatus;

lg.l: Quod Fredericus ego malleus Orbis ero.
Fates wil, the Stars teach, and Birds augury;
That Fredric I the Worlds main Maul ſhal be.

l.hi: Fata jubent Scriptura docet, Peccata loquuntur;
Quod tibi vita brevis, poena perennis erit.

lg.l: Fates bid, the Scriptures teach, thy Sins doo tel;
Thy life ſhal ſhort be, endleſſ thy pains in Hel.

div.head: EPIG. XCIII. Papa & Rex Franciae aemuli.

argument.p: The 2 Enimies (Pope Julius 2, and Lewis 12 King of France) which waged war one with the other.

lg.l: In Gallum Regem bellum geſturus acerbum,
Armatam educit Julius Ʋrbe manum.
Accinctus gladio claves in Tibridis amnem

l.hi: Projicit, & ſaevus talia verba refert:

lg.l: Cum nihil efficiant Claves ad praelia Petti:
Auxilio Pauli forſitan Enſis erit.
Pope July 'gainſt the French King waging war,
Led forth his armed Hoſt from th' City far.
Begirt with ſword, the Keis he fiercely caſt
In Tyber ſtreams, and theſ words ſpake in haſt:
Sith Peters Keys in Wars can doo no good;
Perhaps Pauls Sword ſhal ſerv to ſhed much blood.

argument.p: The 3 Things (Rome, Pope, Luther) which are wittily compared one with another.

lg.l: Roma Orbem domuit: Romam ſibi Papa ſubegit:

l.hi: Viribus illa ſuis, fraudibus iſte ſuis:

lg.l: Quantò iſto major Lutherus, major & illa?

l.hi: Iſtum illamque uno qui domuit calamo.

lg.l: Rome the World conquer'd, the Pope Rome atchieved:
She by hir Forces, he by Fraud acquired.
How much is Luther greater then both accounted?
Who him and hir by his one Pen ſurmounted.

argument.p: The 2 Epicedial Diſtichs, compoſed on Lucius born at Luca, Biſhop of Oſtia, and in fine of Rome.

lg.l: Luca dedit lucem Lucio tibi, Pontificatum
Oſtia, Papatum Roma, Verona mori.
Imo Verona dedit tibi vere vivere, Roma
Exilium, curas Oſtia, Luca mori.
Luca to Lucius life, Oſtia thee gav
A Prelatſhip, Rome Popedom, Veron grav.
Nay Veron tru life, exile Rome conferred;
Oſtia cares, Luca death by birth inferred.

argument.p: The 6 ſelect Verſes, wherin the laſt Iron Age of the World is graphicaly decyphered.

l.hi: Aurea prima ſata eſt: ſubiit Argentea Proles:
Aenea deinde Aetas: de duro eſt ultima ferro.
Protinus irrupit venae pejoris in aevum
Omne nefas: fugere pudor, verumque, fideſque:
In quorum ſubiere locum fraudeſque dolique,
Inſidiaeque, & Vis, & amor ſceleratus habendi.

lg.l: Firſt Golden Age was: Silvern next ſucceded:
Braſen the third: laſt of hard Iron kneaded.
Streight to a worſ Age the web of Villany
Broke in: Shame fled, and Truth, and Sanctity.
In whoſ ſtead Fraud and Foxcraft guil cam amain,
And Snares, and Rapes, and wicked lov of gain.

argument.p: The 20 Things which are reputed noxious or offenſiv to the Eys or ſight of al Men.

l.hi: Haecce nocent Oculis: Sol, Ictus, Acumina, Pulvis,
Balnea, Vina, Venus, Ventus, Piper, Allia, Fumus,
Porrum, Caepe, Ignis, Faba, Lens, Vapor, Ira, Sinapi,
Sed Vigilare magis: ſic ſunt nocumenta viginti.

lg.l: Baths, wines, wind, pepper, garlick, leeks, Smoke, Fire,
Beans, Onyons, Lintels, Vapors, Watchings, Ire,
Sun, Stripes, Duſt, Prickings, Muſtard, Venery:
Theſ hurt the Eys: ſo twenty noiſoms be:

argument.p: The 12 Articles of our Creed: 6 Petitions of the Lords Praier: and 10 Commandments.

l.hi: Sunt credenda tibi bis ſex: orandaque ſex ſunt,
Si ſalvus fies: ſed facienda decem.

lg.l: Twelv things muſt be beleevd: ſix praied of thee:
And ten doon duly, if thou ſav'd wilt be.

argument.p: The 2 Epitaphs compiled on Hector (firſt ſlain) and his Father Priamus jointly.

lg.head: 1 Hectors.
lg.l: Hectoris hic Tumulus cum quo ſua Troja ſcpulta eſt:

l.hi: Conduntur pariter, qui periere ſimul.

lg.l: Qui Priami tumulum quaerit, legat Hectoris ante:

l.hi: Ille meus, Nato quem prius ipſe dedi.

lg.l: Hectoris atque Patris ſimul eſt commune ſepulchrum:

l.hi: amborum quoniam juncta ruina fuit.

lg.l: This Tumb is Hectors, with whom Troy lys dead:
The • thoſ that at th' Siege died, are buried.
Who Priams Tumb ſeeks, muſt firſt Hectors read:
That's mine, which I firſt for my Son did ſpread.
For Hector and his Sire ſervs one joint Grav:
Becauſ their ruins joind in one both have.

lg.head: 2. Priams
lg.l: Hic Priami non eſt Tumulus, nec condor in iſta

l.hi: Sede: Caput Danai diripuere meum.
Ast ego cum lacerum ſine nomine funus haberem,

lg.l: Confugi ad cineres Hectoreos Genitor.
Illic & Natos, Trojamque, Aſiamque ſepultam

l.hi: Inveni: & noſtrum quicquid ubique jacet.

lg.l: This is not Priams Tumb, nor doo I ly,
Therin: the Greecks my Head ſnatch'd ſavagely.
But having a torn Herſ ſans Name ſet down;
I the Sire took t' Hectors of high renown.
Both Sons, and Troy and Aſia inſhrin'd ther
I found: and al whats mine ſparſd every wher.

argument.p: Auſonius made many Epiceds on moſt of the worthy Warriers at Troy (Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ajax, Achilles, Ʋlyſſes, Neſtor, Diomedes, Pyr • hus, Antilochus, Guneus, Euryalus, Proteſilaus, Deiphobus, Astyanax, Sarpedon, Nafles, Amphimachus, Troilus, Polydorus, Euphimis, Hyppotheus, Eunomus, Pylcus, Chromius (beſide Hecuba, Polyxena) with others too ſuperfluous to relat or recapitulat.
The 3 valiant Amazons ſaid to ſlay ſo many gallant Greecs in plain fight and open field.

l.hi: Cum belli ſonuere tubae, violenta peremit

lg.l: Hypolyte Teuthranta: Lyce Clonon: Oebalon Alce.
Oebalon enſe; Clonon jaculo; Teuthranta ſagitta:
Oebalus ibat equo, curru Clonus; at pede Teuthras.
Plus Puero Teuthra • ; Puer Oebalus; at Clonus Heros:
Figitur ora Clonus; latus Oebalus; Ilia Teuthras.
Epicli Teuthras; Deracli Clonus; Oebalus Idae:
Argolicus Teuthras; Moeſus Clonus; Oebalus Arcas.

l.hi: Nominibus propriis quae conſtant carmina, metris
Angliacis facile nemo referre poteſt.

lg.l: Verſes which be of proper names compacted.
In Engliſh rythms can hardly be tranſacted.
Fierce Hippolyt Teuthras, Lyce Clonus ſlu,
And Alce Oebalus; when Wars Trumpets blew.
Oebalus a ſword, Clonus dart, Teuthras ſhaft pierced:
Oebalus on horſ, Clonus coach, Teuthras on foot ſerved.
Teuthras a Youth, Oebalus Boy, Clonus Man:
Clonus at mouth, Oebalus ſide, Teuthras guts ran.
Teuthras Epiclum, Clonus Deraclum, Oebalus Ida had:
Teuthras Argiv, Clonus Maeſan, Oebalus an Arcad.
Nunc Opus exigitur, quod nec Jovis Ira, nec Ignis,

l.hi: Nec poterit Ferrum, nec edax abolere Vetuſtas.

lg.l: The Work's now doon, which nor Joves Ire, nor Fire,
Nor Sword, nor Time ſhal raze: though al conſpire.

l.hi: Poſt te Victurae, pre te quoque vivere Chartae
Incipiant: cineri gloria ſerò venit.

lg.l: Let Books which ſhal ſurviv firſt liv by thee:
Glory or fame when dead, too late wil be.

l.hi: Si laus ſit paucis quamplurima dicere verbis;
Non minor eſt parvis plura referre libris.

lg.l: If't be praiſ, when much in few words is told;
'Tis no leſſ when ſmal Books great things unfold.

l.hi: Parve (nec invideo) ſine me, Liber, ibis in Ʋrbem:
Hei mihi, quòd Domino non licet ire tuo.

lg.l: Smal Book, thou ſhalt to Rome go without me:
Ah, that thy Maſter cannot go with thee.

l.hi: Semper ego Auditor tantum? nunquamne reponam?

lg.l: Shal I ſtil learner be,
And my works never ſee?

l.hi: I Liber, inviſas Domini peramanter Amicos:
Mittere teque refer pignus amoris eum.

lg.l: Go Book, viſit thy Maſters friends freely;
And ſay he ſends thee as pledg of amity.

l.hi: Sci Liber, invenies Inimicos undique tetros:
Omnium at invidias ſpernere diſce: Vale.

lg.l: Know Book, thou every wher ſhalt find Foes fel:
But al their envies learn to ſcorn: Farewel.
My reſolution is, and ſtil ſhal be:
A ruſh for him that carts a ſtraw for me. Withers.

div.head: Ad Lectorem.

l.hi: Plurima, Lector, habes uno hic Theoremata clauſa
Codice, quae variis ſunt memorata libris.

lg.l: Reader, thou haſt here ſundry ſubjects included
In one Book; which through diverſ are diffuſed.

div.p:
Lo here a litle Landskip of goodly gardens, fair
fields, high hils, verdant vallies, and other pleaſing Objects preſented to public view in a ſmal map or model: which thou maiſt paſſ by curſorily, without ſpending time or travel in any curious ſurvey: but it ſhal be by Grace of God more amply and accuratly extended or exhibited in particular Maps, to take up thy ſerious thoughts; ſo ſoon as they can be wel tranſcribed by this tired hand, and finiſhed fitting for the tedious Preſſ.

l.hi: Scriptori ſat ferre dapes, & ponere ſedes:
Si placet,
eſte domi: ſin minus, ite foras.

lg.l: Writers Can but bring Cates, and ſet forth ſtools:
If ye like, eat: if not, you are al—welcom.

div.head: A final farewel to al ſorts of Readers.
div.p: Let none carp, cavil, or complain that I cloſe up this laſt Diſtich in Proſe, contrary to common cuſtom: ſith haply Proſe wil beſt pleaſ palats already tired with harſh Rythms, to cloſe up queaſy Stomachs ready to ſurfet with muſty Metres. Indeed neceſſity inforced it, ſith I wanted a word to my mind of like cadence with ſtools: which if any can ſupply, ther is ſpace left to inſert it. Nor can the phraſe (ite foras) be better rendred then you are welcom: which men uſualy giv their Friends or Gueſts at dores, when they take their laſt leavs for that Viſit one of another.

l.hi: Sic prodeſſe magis quam delectare cupiſco.

lg.l: Thus to doo good I more deſire,
Then with delight mens minds t' inſpire.

div.head: Additional Eſſais. The ſeventh Claſsis of Additionals: containing a Rapſody of Remnents, or Fardle of Fragments ſet at fag end, under two groſſ generalities:
EPIGRAM. I. Zodiaci Partes ſeu Signa.

argument.p: The 12 ſhares or Dodecatemorions (commonly caled 12 Signes) which rule the Solar Months.

l.hi: D Ʋx Aries: Taurus: Gemini: Cancer: Leo: Virgo.
Libraque: Seorpius: Arcitenens: Caper: Amphora: Piſces.

lg.l: Ram: Bul: Twins: Crab: Lion: Virgin: Scales ſevn:
Scorpion: Archer: Goat: Aquary: Fiſhes make ev'n.

div.head: EPIG. II. Solis ingreſſus in Dodecatemoria.

argument.p: The 12 names, which ſhew on what day (by the Vowels in ech) the Sun enters every Dodecatemorion.

div.head: EPIG. III. Menſium nomina breviata.

argument.p: The 12 Roman names of Solar Months, decurted in Words and half words or peeces.

div.p: Jan: Feb: Mart: April: Mai: Jun: & Julius inde Aug: Sept: Octobris: Novembris: itemque Decembris. Thirty dais hath September, April, June, & November Februa twēty eght alone: th' other ſevn ech thirty one

argument.p: The 9 Orders or Degrees of good Angels (cald the Heavenly Hierarchy) expreſſed by ſeveral Letters.

l.hi: Angelicos DƲCTAPSPA choros deſignat amuſsim:
Nomina quorum ibidem Litera prima notat.

lg.l: DUCTAPSPA th' Angels orders doth deſign:
Whoſ names the formoſt letter of ech doth ſign.

p.hi: viz. Dominatus: Virtutes: Cherubini: Throni: Archangeli: Principatus: Seraphini: Potentiae: Angeli.

argument.p: The 7 Stars (cald Pleiades) ſited in the Head or Ey of Zodiacal Taurus: wherof ſix only are ſeen.

lg.l: Alcyone, Meropeque, Electraque, Diva Celaeno,
Taygete, Sterope, praeclaro lumine Maja.

l.hi: Electra, Tayget, Alcyon, Merope,

lg.l: Celaeno, ſhining Maja: Sterope.

argument.p: The 4 Creatures traditionaly (but ſearſ truly) ſaid or ſuppoſed to liv on the bare Elements.

l.hi: Talpam Terra nutrit: Chamaeleon aere vivit:
Halicem Unda fovet: Salamander veſcitur Igni.

lg.l: The Mole on Earth: Cameleon livs on air:
Water is Herrings: Fire Salamanders fare.

argument.p: The 4 ſimple Humors in Mans Body, and al perfect Animals: reſembling the 4 Elements.

l.hi: Quatuor humores animali in Corpore constant:
Sanguis, cum Cholera, Phlegma, Melancholia.

lg.l: Four Humors in moſt living Creatures dwel:
Blood, Choler, Flegm, and Melancholy fel.

argument.p: The 5 Animals reputed to ſurpaſſ Men in the fiv Exterior Senſes: ech in one of them.

l.hi: Nos Aper auditu praecellit: Aranea tactu:
Vultur odoratu: Lynx viſu: Simia gustu.

lg.l: In hearing Hogs: Spiders in touch excel:
Apes in taſt: Lynx in ſight: Vulturs in ſmel.

argument.p: The 5 Intellectual Habits (Sapience, Intelligence, Prudence, Science, Art) couched in SIPSA.

l.hi: Intellectivas Virtutes dat ſibi SIPSA:
Ʋunamquamque etenim litera prima notat.

lg.l: Th' Intellectual Virtues SIPSA doth ſhew:
For ech firſt Letter preſents one to view,

argument.p: The 2 contrary Conditions or Fortunes of Men, in temporal matters of this wretched World.

l.hi: Dum fueris foelix, multos numerabis amicos:
Tempora cum fuerint nubila, ſolus eris.
Nullus ad amiſſas ibit amicus opes.

lg.l: While thou dooſt floriſh, Friends thou ſhalt not want:

lg.head: Vel.
lg.l: When times turn Cloudy, Friends grow ſcarſ & ſcant.
If wealth be loſt, none wil thy company hant.

argument.p: The 17 furnitures or furtherances, to make this loathſom life more pleaſing or propitious.

l.hi: Haec Vitam faciunt beatiorem,
Res non parta labore, ſed relicta:
Non ingratus Ager: focus perennis:
Lis n • nquam: toga rara: mens quieta:
Vi • es ing • nuae: ſalubre Corpus:
Prudens ſimplicitas: pares amici:
Convictus facilis: ſine arte menſa:
Nox non ebria, ſed ſoluta curis:
Non triſtis torus, attamen pudicus:
Somnus qui faciat breves tenebras:
Quod ſis eſſe velis, nihilque malis:
Summum nec metuas diem nec optes.

lg.l: Theſ make mans life happier to be.
Wealth left, not got by induſtry:
A fruitful Farm: perpetual Fire:
No ſtrife: plain Cloths: mind free from ire:
Cleer ſtrength: a Body ful of health:
Wiſe ſimplenes: Friends like in Wealth:
A facil food: • ans art dreſt diet:
No drunken nights, but from cares quiet:
No loathed bed, yet purely chaſt:
Sound ſleeps, which ſpend the nights in haſt:
Wil what thou wouldſt, doo nought unwilling:
Fear not, nor wiſh thy Fates fulfilling.

div.head: EPIG. XII. Artes liberales. Diſticha vulgata.

argument.p: The 7 learned Studies or liberal Sciences, ſet forth in the firſt ſyllables of ech and every one.

l.hi: Gra: loquitur, Dia: vera docet, Rhe: verba colorat,
Mu: canit, Ar: numerat, Geo: ponderat, Aſte colit aſtra

lg.l: Grā ſpeaks, Dia teacheth truth, Rhet words cōmends
Mu ſings, Arith nūbers, Geo weighs, Aſt Stars attends

lg.head: Brevius

l.hi: Lingua: Tropus: Ratio: Numerus: Tenor: Angulus: Astra.

lg.l: Theſ are the Subjects wherin Arts are verſed:
Which hardly are in Engliſh rythms reherſed.

argument.p: The 2 Univerſal Heads or Principles of al Entities in the whol World.

lg.l: Magnus Ariſtoteles trutinando cacumina Rerum,

l.hi: In duo diviſit, quicquid in orbe fuit.

lg.l: Great Aristole ſcanning Things, them divided
Into two Heads, what in the World reſided. Subſtance Accident.

div.head: EPIG. XIIII. Jejunia Aniverſaria. Verſus obſoleti.

argument.p: The 4 yeerly Ember Faſts in joined to preced Clerical Ordination: but now antiquated

l.hi:
Post Cineres: poſt Pente: Crucem poſt: poſt
que Luciam:
Quatuor haec anni Jejunia ſacra colebant:

lg.l: Thoſ four ſet Faſts men antiently ordained
For Clergy Ordination; now diſdained.

div.head: EPIG. XV. Tempora Matrimonialia. Verſus vulgati.

argument.p: The 3 Annual times of prohibiting, and 3 of permitting weddings.

l.hi: Conjugium Adventus prohibet; ſed Hilarius affert:
Septuagena vetat; ſed Paſchae octava relaxat:
Rogamen reprimit; ſed pandit Trina poteſtas.

lg.l: Advent forbids to wed; Hilari allows:
Septuageſ ſtops; but Low-Sunday advows:
Rogation bars; but Trinity long endows.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons fained to be in Hel: whence a kind Husband fetchd his raviſh'd Wife.

lg.l: Orpheus Eurydicem ſemel aſportavit ab Orco:

l.hi: Duxit ab Inferno Foemina nulla Virum.

lg.l: Orpheus from Hel Eurydice once reprived:
But no Wife thence hir Husband back relieved.

argument.p: The 3 moſt eminent Poets (one Grecian, and two Roman) pretily paralleled one with another.

lg.l: Quantum Virgilius magno conceſsit Homero:
Tantum ego Virgilio Naſo Poeta meo.
How far t' Homer great Virgil grants the Field:
So much I Ovid to my Virgil yeeld.

argument.p: The 2 Women at Rome, Poetized to hav Teeth of contrary colors: with the reaſon therof.

lg.l: Thais habet nigros, niveos Lecanea dentes:

l.hi: Quid mirum est? emptos haec habet, illa ſuos.

lg.l: Thais black Teeth: ſnow-white Lecanea bore:
What marvel? one bought, th' other hir own wore.

argument.p: The 2 common Malefactors (both of like guilt in Law) caled the Stealer and Heler.

l.hi: Quod noſti baud recte factum, nolito ſilere:
Ne videare malos imitari velle, tacendo.

lg.l: Concele not what thou knoweſt il doon; leſt thou
By hiding il Deeds, ſhould ſeem bad enow.

argument.p: The 2 oppoſit enormous vices (Riot or Luxury, Avarice or Covetouſnes) briefly dehorted.

l.hi: Luxuriam fugito; nec non vitare memento
Crimen Avaritiae: nam ſunt contraria famae.

lg.l: Fly Riot, and ſhun Avarice for ſhame:
For both adverſare to good name and fame.

argument.p: The 2 Birds (Cock and Capon) wherof one is turned into the other only by caſtration

l.hi: Ex Gallo Capo ſit: fuerint ſi quique Capones.
Galli; Nonne ſoret Gallica rara lues?

lg.l: Cocks are made Capons: if that al French Cocks
Were Capons too, how ſcarſ would be ye FrenchPocks?

argument.p: The 2 Proverbial Names given to Rich and Poor Men, who are Miſers equaly miſerable.

l.hi: Ante obitum nemo ſupremaque-funera foelix:
Irus enim ſubito eſt, qui modo Croeſus erat.

lg.l: None can be happy before his final fate:
For he fals ſoon poor, who was rich of late.

argument.p: The 2 words of like tone or tendence (Librorum & Librarum) which differ in one only Vouel.

lg.l: Eſt tibi Librorum, Line, copia: doctior eſſes,

l.hi: Si tibi Librarum copia tanta foret.

lg.l: Linus, thou haſt Books ſtore: if Pounds ſo many
Thou hadſt, thou wouldſt learneder be then any.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes, which being tranſverſed or turned backward, cary contrary conſtructions.

l.label: Abel.
l.hi: Sacrum pingue dabo: nec macrum ſacrificabo:

l.label: Cain.
l.hi: Sacrificabo macrum, nec dabo pingue ſacrum.

lg.l: Abel. I'le giv fat Offrings, not lean ſacrifice:
Cain. I'le no fat Offrings giv, lean ſhal ſuffice.

argument.p: The 2 rare Verſes, wherof ech by it ſelf is tranſverſible letter by letter, with ſom ſmal ſenſ.

l.hi: Signa, te ſigna: temere me tangis, & angis.

lg.l: Roma, tibi ſubito motibus ibit amor.
Sign, ſign thy ſelf: thou raſhly troubleſt me.
O Rome, lov wil with ſudden fits touch thee.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes compoſed ech of two words: which ſound with a ſad tone and ſorowful tune.

lg.l: Excruciabautur Conſtantinopolitani, Innumerabilibus ſollicitudinibus.
Conſtantinople Men being cloſe beſieged,
With cares and croſſes numberleſſ were grieved.

argument.p: The 2 bloody Verſes, which Septimius Severus denounced, and Kenneth King of Scots executed on the Picts.

l.hi: Nemo manus fugiat veſtras, caedemque cruentam:
Non foetus gravida quem Mater geſtat in alvo.

lg.l: Let none ſcape your hands, nor fel ſlaughter fly:
Not th' unborn Babes in Mothers wombs that ly.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes fit for al Perſons to ponder, ſpecialy in times of public perplexities.

lg.head: Conſolatio.

l.hi: Tu ne cede malis, ſed contra audentior ito.

lg.l: Yeeld not to il Mens ſpight,
But them reſiſt in right.

lg.head: Reſolutio

l.hi: Durate, & voſmet rebus ſervate ſecundis.

lg.l: Endure, your ſelfs reſerv,
Til better times ſhal ſerv.

argument.p: The 2 ominous Verſes inſcribed on the back of the Scotiſh fatal fortunat Chair.

l.hi: Ni fallat fatum, Scoti hunc ubicunque locatum
Invenient Lapidem: regnare tenentur ibidem.

lg.l: Unles Fare fail, the Scots ſhal ſway,
Wher ere they find this ſtone to ſtay.

argument.p: The 3 Heroic Verſes, which may be turned or tranſpoſed word by word many wais.

l.hi: Tot tibi ſunt dotes, Virgo, quot ſidera Coelo:
Lex, rex, grex, res, ſpes, jus, thus, ſal, ſol (bona) lux, laus
Mars, mors, ſors, fraus, faex, ſtyx, nox, crux, pus (mala)

lg.l: Such are meer tois for young mens wits to try, (vis, lis.
At leiſure hours; when they can them deſcry:
But 'tis beſt into better things to pry.

div.head: EPIG. XXXI. Chronogrammata metrica.

argument.p: The 3 Chronograms uſualy caried from hand to hand: which are couched in three Heroic Verſes.

div.l: Occubere Aquilae tria Lilia Luce Mathiae. Fran: 1. Rex Franciae captivatus a Carolo 5 Imperatore. Strages Pariſienſis
div.p: MCCCLLLLVVVVIIIII. 1525.
div.l: Bartholomaeus flet, quia Gallicus occubat Atlas.
div.p: MCCCLLLLLVVVVII. 1572.
div.l: Three Flours ſtoopd to th' Eagle on Matthias day.
Barth'lomew wept, cauſ the French Atlas dead lay.
div.p: A third was haply found in Ovid by Opmerus: but applied to Don Carolo Prince of Spain,

l.hi: Filius ante diem Patrios inquirit in annos.
l.note: His Father put him to death, for fear of aſpiring.

div.p: MDLVVIIIIIIII. 1568.
div.l: The Son ſeeks yer his time,
His Fathers Throne to clime.
div.p: A fourth is added of King Charls decollation: De tempore & modo mortis.

l.hi: Ter deno Jani, labens Rex Sole cadente
l.note: Securi makes one yeer more 1649 according to forren Accompt.

div.l: Carolus exutus ſolio ſceptroque ſecure eſt.
div.p: DDCCCCLLLLXXVVVVVIII. 1648.
div.l: King Charls on Janes thirtieth, when Sun declined;
Of Throne and Scepter was by th' Ax deprived.

argument.p: The 306 Fabii of one Family, that fel by the Sword, in attempting to win the City Veii.

lg.l: Ʋna dies Fabios ad bellum miſerat omnes:
Ter centum Fabii ter cecidere duo.
One day ſent to war the Fabii al away:
Three hundred ſix Fabii fel in one day.

argument.p: The 365 Children which a Belgic Countiſſ brought at one birth by a Beggers imprecation.

l.hi: En tibi monſtro ſum partum, & memorabile factum:
Quale nec a Mundi conditione datum.

lg.l: Lo a ſtrange birth, and fact worth admiration:
Such as was not known ſince the Worlds foundation.

l.hi: Haec lege: mox animo ſtupefactus, Lector, abito.

lg.l: Reader, theſ things peruſe:
Then go, admire, and muſe.

argument.p: The 3 Neighbour Nations, which are noted to be of diverſ different diſpoſitions.

lg.l: Scire Anglis ſitis eſt: ſitis eſt neſcire Brytannis:

l.hi: Faſtus Normannis creſcit, creſcentibus annis.

lg.l: Th' Engliſh for knowledg thirſt, wch Brytons deſpiſe:
Normans grow proud, as yeers and riches riſe.

argument.p: The 4 antient Monuments of moſt mark, in or neer the Cathedral Church of Ely.

lg.l: Haec ſunt Eliae: Lanterna, Capella Mariae,

l.hi: Atque Molendinum, necnon dans Vinea vinum.

lg.l: Lantern, our Ladies Chappel, with Mil are,
And Vineyard yeelding Wine Elies ſights rare.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes which a Divine made in deathbed, and cauſed to be inſcribed on his Picture.

l.hi: Quid facis, O demens? cur or a fugacia pingis?
Aut novus, aut nullus cras tibi vultus erit.

lg.l: Madman, what dooſt? why paintſt thou flitting hew?
Thy face to morow wil be none, or new.

argument.p: The 3 Perſons, that brought much miſchief to Rome in ſeveral ages: al caled Sexti.

lg.l: Sextus Tarquinius, Sextus Nero, Papaque Sextus:
Saepius a Sextis perdita Roma fuit.
Sext Tarquin, Nero Sixth Emp'ror, by name
Sixth Alexander Pope: by Sixts Rome bore ſhame.

argument.p: The 2 vulgar Verſes, which contain a Queſtion and Anſwer about Gods abode before he made the World.

l.label: Quaeſtio.
l.hi: Dic ubi tunc eſſet, cum praeter eum nihil eſſet?

l.label: Reſponſio.
l.hi: Tunc ubi nunc, in ſe: qui potulit omnia de ſe.

lg.l: Quaeſtio. Tel, wher liv'd God when nought beſide him was?
Reſponſio. Ther, wher now, in himſelf: who brought al to paſſ.

div.head: EPIG. XXXIX. Dei Opus ante creationem Mundi.

argument.p: The 4 Diſtichs framed in Anſwer to an Atheiſtic Queſtion, what God did, before he created the Univerſ?

lg.l: Dum Populum Lybicis docet Auguſtinus in Oris,

l.hi: Eſſe probans manibus cuncta creata Dei:
Impius aſſurgit, verbisque procacibus Afer
Ergo Opifex rerum quid facicbat, ait.
Et quibus intentus fallebat tempora curis;
Mundus adhunc nondum cum fabrifactus erat?

lg.l: Praeſul adhaec Lybicus, fabrifecit Tartara, dixit

l.hi: His quos ſcrutari talia mente juvat.

lg.l: When Auſtin People taught in Lybic Land,
Proving al things were wrought by Gods high hand:
A wicked Moor ſtep'd up, and ſawcily
Ask'd, What the Maket did from al Eternity?
And with what works he did the time beguile,
When as the World was not yet fram'd the while?
The Lybic Prelat ſaid, He made Hel below
For buſy brains which ſuch things ſeek to know.

argument.p: The 2 chief Commanders or Managers of A. 1647. Englands Militia in Warfare, both by Sea and Land.

lg.l: Corolus ecce Salo, inque Solo regit omnia Fairfax:

l.hi: Diviſo imperio Rex Populuſque ruunt.

lg.l: Lo, Charls at Sea, Fairfax by Land rules al;
By power divided King and People fal.

div.head: EPIG. XLI. Regulae Academicae.

argument.p: The 2 Cautions or Counſils fit for al Academic Students to take into ſerious conſideration.

lg.l: Oxoniam quare veniſti, praemeditare:

l.hi: Nocte dieque cave tempus conſumere prave.

lg.l: Take heed • ul care, why t' Oxford thou wert ſent:
And ſtil beware thy time be not il ſpent.

l.hi: Invigilate Libris: quid non ſolertia vincit:
Namque labore Deus Mortalibus omnia vendit.

lg.l: Apply your Books: what cannot ſtudy gain?
For Men from God ſhal buy al things by pain.

div.p: God injoind Man to get his living with the ſweat of his brows: but Scholars gain learning with the ſtudy of their brains: which is an eaſier task, and ſhould not ſeem irkſom to any ingenuous Spirit.

div.head: EPIG. XLII. Carmina diverſimoda.

argument.p: The 2 forms or faſhions of Latin Verſes, much uſed among young School-bois in Grammar Schools.

l.hi: Aurea quaedam ſunt, Argentea Carmina quaedam:
Grammaticis varie ſic vocitata Scholis.

lg.l: Som Verſes Golden, ſom are Silvern filed:
Which ſo in Grammar Schools are diverſly ſtiled.

div.p: Golden contain two Adjectiv Epithets, and two Subſtantivs; with a Verb copulativ in midſt of al: as Aurea purpuream Connectit ſibula veſtem. Silvern conſiſt of three Dactyls and three Spondees alternatly placed one after another: as Si mea cum veſtris valuiſſent vota, Pelaſgi: but this kind is reputed more authentic or artificial, if ther be juſt ſix words like the former, conjoind one with another in ech foot: as, Scilicet Argentum reputatur vilius Auro

argument.p: The 2 Principal Laws, which Nature writes in Mens hearts: yet too many blot out al ſuch characters.

l.hi: Cordibus Humanis inſcriptae ab origine Leges,
Numine divino flante, fuere duae.
Fac mihi, quod tibi vis fieri; quòd non tibi, noli:
Sic Natura docet, Chriſtus idemque jubet.

lg.l: Two Laws ther were into Mens hearts inſcribed
At firſt beginning; which th' Holy Ghoſt inſpired.
What thou'lt hav doon doo; what not, doo not to me.
So Nature Wils, and Chriſt the ſame bids thee.

div.head: EPIG. XLIIII. Regina Rex: Rex Regina.

argument.p: The 2 Engliſh Soveraigns lately, of ſeveral Sexes, and diſparat diſpoſitions for Warmatters.

lg.l: Elizabetha fuit Rex, ſed Regina Jacobus:

l.hi: Ordo Naturae ſic in utriſque jacet.

lg.l: Elizabeth was a King, but James a Queen:
So Natures courſ changed in both was ſeen.

argument.p: The 2 Funeral Verſes which Robert Groſthead Biſhop of Lincoln cauſed to be ingraven on his Tumb.

l.hi: Quis ſim, noſſe cupis? caro putrida, nil nifi vermis:
Quiſquis es, haec de me fit tibi ſcire ſatis.

lg.l: Dooſt long to know who I am? rotten fleſh, worms food
Who ere thou be, know this of me; 'tis good.

argument.p: The 5 Utenſil Implements or Inſtruments pertaining to al pennulary Profeſſions.

l.hi: Scalpellum, Calami, Atramentum, Charta, Libelli
Sunt Semper ſtudiis arma parata bonis.

lg.l: Penknife, Pens, Ink, Paper, Books alwais are
Fit for good Studies, as arms apt for War.

argument.p: The 2 Lovers or Sweet-hearts, wherof one was hot as fire, the other cold as Ice in Loving.

lg.l: Me nive candenti petiit modò Julia: rebar

l.hi: Igne carere nivem; nix tamen ignis erat.
Quid nive frigidus? noſtrum tamen urere pectus

lg.l: Nix potuit manibus, Julia miſſa tuis.

l.hi: Quis locus infidiis dabitur mihi tutus amoris,
Frigore concreta ſi latet ignis aqua?

lg.l: Julia ſola potes noſtras compeſcere flammas:

l.hi: Non nive, nec glacie; ſed potes igne pari.

lg.l: Julia with burning Snow my breſt once hurted:
I thought Snow had no Fire, but Fire ther lurked.
What then Snow colder? yet Snow as Firy brand
My breſt could burn caſt, Julia, by thy hand.
What place ſhal then from Lovs ſnares me ſafe hold,
If Fire in Water lies congeld with cold?
You Julia, ſoly can my Flames aſſwage;
Not with Snow, nor Ice; but with like Fires rage.

argument.p: The 8 material Ingredients, which concur to confect Gooſ-Ointment, put in equal weight ech.

l.hi: Anſer ſumatur, veteranus qui videatur:
Mox deplumetur, penetralibus exoneretur:
Trita caro tota; triti mox pelle remota;
Intus ponantur, quae ſubterius numerantur.
Ʋnctum Porcinum, Thus, Ceram, Sanguinem Ovinū,
Pondere pone aequo: Sal, Mel, Faba, ſitque Siligo.
Post haec aſſetur; tamen aſſus non comedetur:
Vas ſuppanatur, ſic ut liquor accipiatur.
Quo membris unctis, Artbritis ſolvitur Omnis:
Certe hoc Ʋnguentum praeſtat ſuper omne Talentum.

lg.l: Take an old Gooſ: pu • him: his Guts draw cleer:
Bruiſ him: skin him: put in theſ things namd here.
Put hogſ-greaſ, bean-meal, frankincenſ, wheat-flower
Hony, Wax, Sheepſ-blood, Salt in equal dower.
After this roſt him; yet eat not the Fleſh:
Set a Pan under, to ſav the liquor freſh.
Which nointed helps the Gowt and Aches old:
Certes this Unguent is more worth then Gold.

argument.p: The 2 Verſes of a Diſtich, touching a tru honeſt Man, who continues conſtant in evil times.

l.hi: Vir bonus eſt, Patrias qui leges Juraque ſervat:
Temporibuſque malis auſerit eſſe bonus.

lg.l: Hee's a Good Man, who his Country Laws keeps here;
And in il times durſt ſtil good to appeer.

div.head: EPIG. L. Muſarum Proſopographia.

argument.p: The 9 Muſes or learned Women (Daughters to Jupiter by Mnemoſyne of Helicon) briefly charactered.

lg.l:
Clio geſta canens, tranſactis tempora reddit:
Virgils Epigrams.
Melpomen: Tragico proclamat moeſta boatu:
Comica laſcivo gaudet ſermone Thalia:
Dulciloquis calamos Euterpe flatibus urget:
Terſichore affectus Citharis movet, imperat, auget:
Plectra gerens Erato ſaltat pede, carmine, vultu.
Carmina Calliope Libris Heroica mandat:
Urania at Coeli motus ſcrutatur, & Aſtra:
Signans cuncta manu, loquitur Polyhimnia gestu:

l.hi: In medio reſidens regit omnia Numine Phoebus.

lg.l: Clio ſings Geſts and Times in Hiſtory:
Melpomen vents ſad things in Tragedy.
Thaly with wanton ſtrains lovs Comedy:
Euterp with Pipes ſweet ſounds makes melody:
Terpſichor with Harps and Songs movs harmony:
Erato with feet and voyce keeps meaſures ſymetry:
Calliope frames Heroic Verſ in Poetry:
Ʋrania ſtudies th' Heav'ns and Stars property:
Polymny by hand and geſture ſpeaks jointly
Phoebus in midſt rules al by his Deity.

div.p: Clio invented Hiſtory; Melpomene Tragedy, Thalia Comedy, Euterpe Pipery, Perpſichore Pſaltery, Erato Geometry, Calliope Grammar and Poetry, Ʋrania Aſtronomy, Polyhimnia Oratory.

argument.p: The 143 Heroic Verſes made on the worſt wickedſt ſort of Women kind. Buclo. Eclo. 4.

l.hi: Foemineum ſervile Genus, crudele, ſuperbum;
Lege, modo, ratione vacat: confinia recti
Negligit, extremis gaudet, facit omnia voto
Praecipiti, vel lenta jacet, vel concita currit.
Aut Canis ardentes contristat ſydere terras:
Temperiem nunquam, nunquam mediocria curat:
Vel te ardenter amat, vel te capitaliter odit.
Si gravis eſt, moeret torvo nimis hernica vultu:
Si ſtuedeat comis fieri, gravitate remiſſa
Fit levis: erumpit blando laſcivia riſu;
Et lepor in molli radiat meretricius ore.
Flet, ridet, ſapit, inſanit, formidat & audet:
Vult, non vult, ſecumque ſibi contraria pugnat.
Mobilis, inconstans, vaga, garrula, vana, bilinguis,
Imperioſa, minax, indigna abunda, cruenta,
Improba, avara, rapax, querula, invida, credula, mendax,
Impatiens, oneroſa, bibax, temeraria, mordax,
Ambitioſa, levis; Maga, Lena, ſuperſtitioſa,
Deſidioſa, vorax, ganeae, ſtudioſa, palatum
Docta, ſalax, petulans, & dedita mollitiei,
Dedita blanditiis, curandae dedita formae:
Irae odiique tenax, in idonea tempora differt
Ulciſcendi animos, inſida, ingrata, maſigna,
Impetuoſa, audax, fera, litigioſa, rebellis;
Exprobrat, excuſa • tragica ſua crimina Voce:
Murmurat, accendit rixas, nil foedera pendit.
Ridet amicitias, curat ſua commoda tantùm,
Ludit, adulatur, defert, ſale mordet amaro;
Seminat in vulgus nugas, auditaque lingua
Auget, & ex humili tumulo producit Olympum.
Diſsimulat, ſimulat, doctiſsima fingere Cauſas,
Ordirique dolos, fraud que accomodat ora,
Ora omnes facili caſus imitantia motu.
Non potes inſidias evadere, non potes astum
Vincere tantae Artes, ſolercia tanta nocendi:
Et quanquam videaes oculis praeſentibus, audet
Excuſare nefas: potis eſt eludere ſenſus
Sedulitate animi: nibil eſt quod credere poſsis;
Et nihil eſt quod non, ſi vult, te parcere coget.
His facient exempla fidem: quae crimina non ſunt
Foeminea tentata manu? dedit hoſtibus Arcem

div.l: Decepta ornatu brach Tarpeia ſinist • i:
Saeviít in Natos manibus Medea cruentis:
Tyndaris Aegeas oneravit navibus undas:
Scylla hoſtem ſequitur, Patri ſurata Capillum:
Fratrem Biblis amat: ſubicit ſe Myrrha Parenti:
Conc • bitu Nati longaeva Semiram is ardet:
Cauſa necis Vati conjux fuit Amphiarao:

l.hi: Occidere viros nocturnis Belides armis:

div.l: Orphea membratim Cicones ſecuere P • ctam:
Cognita luxuriae petulantia Paſiphaeae:
Phaedra pudicitiam contra crudeliter auſa eſt:
Decepit Judaea Virum Rebecca, ſuamque

l.hi: Progeniam, velans hircino guttera tergo.

div.l: Porrigit Alcidae conjux fatale Venenum:

Decipi •
Hippodame Patrem: Lavinia Troas
Implicat ancipiti bello: Bryſeis Achillem
Depulite Caſtris: demens Chryſeide factus
Fulminat Atrides, & ſentit Apollinis iras:
Eva genus noſtrum foelicibus • xpulis arvis.

l.hi: Credite Paſtores, per ruſtica Numina juro;
Paſcua ſi Gregibus vestris innoxia vultis,
Si vobis Ovium cura eſt, ſi denique vobis
Grata quies, pax, vita; leves prohibete Puellas,
Pellanturque procul veſtris ab Ovilibus omnes:

div.l: Theſtilys, & Phyllis, Galataea, Neaera, Lycori • .

l.hi: Dicite, quae tristim Mulier deſcendit ad Orcum
Et rediit? potuit ſi non maleſana fuiſſet,

div.l: Eurydice revehi per quas deſcender at umbras
Rapta ſequi renuit feſſam Proſerpina Matrem.
At pius Aeneas redit, remeavit & Orpheus,
Maximus Alcides, & Theſeus, & duo Fratres;

l.hi: Unus equis, alter pugnis bonus atque paleſtra:
Et noster Deus, unde Salus & Vita reſurgit.
Haec ſunt, Paſtores, haec ſunt myſteria nobis
Advertanda: animi fugiunt obſc •• a Vir • les;
Foemineas loca delectant infamia mentes.
Ʋt ſemel in ſcopulos vento contortus & unda,
Nauta ſit incautis monſtrare pericula Nautis:
Sic ſenior longo factus prudentior uſu,
Praeteritos meminit caſus, aperitque futuri
Temporis eventus, vitaeque pericula monſtrat.
Si fugiant Aquilam Fulicae, ſi retia Cervi,
Si Agna Lupum, ſi Dama Ca • em: muliebira cur non
Blandimenta fugis tantum tibi noxia, Paſtor?

div.l: Et in eis pietas Crocodili, aſtutia Hyaenae:

l.hi: Cum flet & appellat te blandius, inſidiatur.
Foemineos, Paſtor, fugito (ſunt retia) vultus:
Non animis, non virtuti, non viribus ullis

div.l: Fidito: non Clypeo cujus munimine Perſeus
Vidit ſaxifica coluhros impune Meduſae.

l.hi: Monſtra peremerunt multi, domuere Gigantes,
Evertêre urbes, legem impoſuere marinis
Fluctibus, impetui fluviorum, & montibus aſpris;
Sacra coronarunt multos cartamina: ſed qui
Cuncta ſubegerunt, ſunt a muliere ſubacti.
Rex qui Pastor erat, funda spolioque Leonis

div.l: Inclytus; & Natus qui Templa Sionia fecit,
Primus & excellens invicto robore Samſon,

l.hi: Foemineum ſubiere jugum: minus officit ignis,
Saxa minus, rhomphaea minus, minus haſta, minus mors.
Nec formae contenta ſuae splendore, decorum
Auget mille modis mulier: frontem ligat auro,
Purpurat arte genas, & collocát arte capillos:
Arte regit greſſus, & lumina temperat arte.
Currit, ut in latebras ludens perducat Amantem:
Vult dare, ſed cupiens ſimplex & honeſta videri;
Denegat, & pugnat, ſed vult ſuper omnia vinci.
Foemina Caeciaco (res mira) ſi • illima vento eſt,
Qui trahit, expellens mendaci nubila flatu.
Quiſquis es (expertus moneo) tentare recuſa
Dum licet, haec fragilis quot habet ſaſtidia Sexus.
Immundum Natura animal, ſed quaeritur Arte
Mundities: id luce opus eſt, ea ſomnia nocte.
Deglabrat, atque levat, pingit, ſtriat, ungit, & Ornat:
Tota dolus, tota ars, tota hiſtrio, tota venenum.
Conſilio speculi gerit omnia, labra movere
Diſcit, & inſpectu vultum componere Vitro:
Diſcit blandiri, diſcit ridere, jocari;
Incedens humeros diſcit vibrare, nateſque.
Quid ſibi vult nudum pectus? quid aperta ſuperne
Rimula, quae befidam deducit in ubera vallem?
Nempe nihil niſi quo virus penetrabile ſenſum
Plus premat, & Stygiae rapiant praecordia flammae.

div.l:
Hi Juvenū Scopuli, Syrtes, Scillae, at
que
Charybdes:
Hae immundae Phinei Volucres, quae ventre ſoluto

l.hi: Proluvie foeda thalamos, canacula, menſas,
Compita, Templa, vias, agros, mare, flumina, montes

div.l: Incaeſtare ſolent: hae ſunt Phorcynides ore
Monſtrifico extremis Lybiae quae in finihus olim

l.hi: Aſpectu mutare homines in ſaxa ſolebant.
Carmina doctiloqui curſim recitavimus Umb • i:
Quae ſi viſa tibi nimium prolixa, memeuto
Ipſius eſſe rei vitium, non carminis illud:
Non longum eſt Carmen, mulierum amentia longa eſt.
O memorande Senex, quo ſe vetus umbria tantum

div.l: Jactat, & ipſe tuae Tyberis conterminus urhi:
Martia non abs re tantum te Roma vocabat;

l.hi: Ipſa tuas artes, & non trivialia norat
Carmina: te vita functum flevere Latinae
Naiades, & Graiae: tua molliter Oſſa quieſcant
Semper & in ſummo mens aurea vivat Olympo

div.l: Women a ſervil, ſavage, proud Kind be,
From meaſure, law, reaſon, and right bounds free:
She lovs extreams, doth al by head-long wil,
Either runs fiercely, or lies grovling ſtil.
She's froſty Winter, and cold not to be felt;
O • Dogſtar-like, the Earth with heat doth melt:
She likes no temper, nor mediocrity:
But lovs too dearly, or hates thee mortaly.
If ſhe be grav, ſhe wails with rough aſpect:
If ſhe ſeem mild, hir ſternnes ſhe'l reject,
And becom light; lewdnes with laughing mixed
Breaks forth, and whoriſh mirth in looks is fixed.
She weeps, laughs, grows ſad, mad, fearful, and bold:
Wils, nils, and with her ſelf doth ſtrife ſtil hold.
Light, wavring, wandring, pratling, vain, two tounged,
Imperious, wrathful, threatning, bloody minded,
Vile, covetous, ſcraping, cruning, envious, credulous,
Lying, fierce, bibbing, biting, raſh, ambitious,
Light, troublous, Witch, Bawd, and ſuperſtitious,
Slow, ravenous, brothel-haunter, luxurious,
Lecherous, malepert, givn to al wantonnes;
Ful of inticings, givn t'adorn hir fairnes.
Holdfaſt of wrath and hate, revenge puts over
Til fit times, faithleſſ, ingrat, ſpite doth ſmother;
Bold, violent, cruel, wrangling, rebellious,
Upbraids, defends hir faults with words moſt trecherous:
Repines, makes ſtrife, al compacts vilipends.
Friendſhip derides, and hir own gain attends,
Sports, flatters, dallies, jeaſts moſt bitterly,
Sows tois abroad, and tales doth amplify,
And a litle Hillock t' Olympus magnify.
Diſſembles, fains, apt t' invent cauſ demure,
Apt to make wiles, and frames hir face t' allure;
Hir looks that can beleef at al points procure.
None can their ſnares eſcape, nor ſhun their guile:
Such Arts they hav and cunning to beguile.
Nay though one ſee hir ſin, ſhe hath impudence
T' excuſe hir crime, and can delude ones ſenſ,
With ſubtlety: ther's nought thou canſt beleev;
Nor ought but ſhee'l compel thee to forgiv.
Exemples ſhal make cleer: what crimes hav not
Bin doon by Women? Tarpey with foes did plot,
To yeeld the Capitol; by their chains deceived:
Bloody Medea hir Sons life bereaved:
Helena with Ships the Egean Seas did fil:
Scylla hir Fathers hair for his Foe did ſpil:
Biblis hir Brother lov'd: Myrrha lay with hir Sire:
Semiramis t' hir Son burnt with luſtful fire:
Poet Ampharaus by his wife was ſlaughtred:
Danaus Daughters their Husbands in bed mu • dred:
The Th • acian Hags Orpheus in peeces tore:
Paſiphaes beſtial luſt is known of yo • e:
Phoedra defil'd with luſt, us'd cruelty:
Rebecca deceivd hir Husband and Progeny;
By binding a Kids skin on neck and hands drild:
Hercules his Wife with deadly bane him kild:
Hippodam beguild hir Sire: Lavinia with war
The Trojans tangled: Bryſeis Achilles far
Drew from his Camp: Agamemnon waxing wood
With Chryſeis lov, felt Phoebus his angry mood:
Evē Mankind d • ov from Edens Garden fair.
Shepheards beleev't, by ruſtic Gods I ſwear:
If you'l hav Paſtures to feed Flocks harmleſſ be;
If you take care of Sheep, if you finaly
Lov quiet, peace, or life, light Wenches fly:
And from your Sheepfolds chaſe far wantons al:
Thyſtel, Phyllis, Galatee, Neaer, Lycor great and ſmal.
Tel me, what Woman to ſad Hel deſcended
And cam back? Eurydice might hav reaſcended
Ha • ſhe bin wiſe, the ſame way ſhe went thither:
Raviſh'd Proſerpin would not folow hir Mother:
But holy Aeneas, and Orpheus back retired,
Great'ſt Hercules, Theſeus, and two Brothers admired;
One for Horſ-fight, th' other for wreſtling famed:
And our Lord God; whence Health & life was framed.
Shepherds, theſ myſteries we muſt wel obſerv:
For manly minds from al obſcene things ſwerv:
But Women in filthy places their luſts ſerv.
As Mariners driv'n on Rocks by tempeſts rape,
Can ſhew to others thoſ perils how t' eſcape:
So by long uſe a man made wiſe and old,
Minds paſt miſhaps and future doth unfold:
Who times events, and lifes dangers hath told.
If Sea-Bitds Eagles ſhun, if Har • s Toils fly:
If Lambs Wolfs, Deer Dogs: why art not thou ſhy
Shepherd, of Womens lures thy chiefeſt Enimy?
They Crocadiles tears hav, Hyenas ſubtle wiſe
To weep, and flatter, that they may beguile:
Shepherd, ſhun Womens looks, as nets the while.
Truſt not thy courage, valour, nor confide
In ſtrength, nor in the Shield which did Perſeus hide,
When he Meduſa's Snakes ſafely eſpied.
Many ſlu Monſters, and ſtrong Giants tamed,
Sack'd Cities, and o're Sea-billows were famed:
Stop'd Rivers rage, and rough Mountains o'recame:
Som Crown'd with Laurel garlands were, but ye ſame
Who ſubdued al, by Women were made tame.
And his Son who firſt Sions Temple builded:
And Samſon who in matchleſſ ſtrength excelled;
