By Women were brought under yoke and quelled:
No fire, ſtones, ſwords, ſpears, nor death ſo many felled
She not content with hir own beauties hew,
Augments it thouſand wais for Men to view.
She decks hir head wth gold, paints cheeks, plaits hair
Frames pace, and looks by Art for to ſeem fair.
Skips out, hir Lover into dark t' allure;
Would giv fees, ſav to ſeem chaſt and demure;
Denies and ſtrivs, but wil be vanquiſh'd ſure.
She's like the Northweſt wind, ſtrange thing to tel
Which draws clouds, yet ſeems falſly to diſpel,
I having tried, warn thee to try forbear,
What loathſom things this frail Sex in them wear.
By Nature unclean Creatures, but by Art
They ſeek to mend it, and in dreams oft ſtart.
She ſhavs, plains, paints, makes rough, noints and perfumes;
Al guil, art, Plaier-like, al Venom aſſumes.
She frames al by hir Glaſſ, learns lips to form;
And looks by looking in it to conform;
She learns to flatter, ſmile, and jeaſts deviſe,
Learns in hir gate to jet with arms and thighs.
What means hir naked Breſt, what th' open chink,
Which 'twixt hir Dugs a cloven Vale doth ſink?
Sure nought but that hir poiſon may pierce longer,
And Helliſh flames thy heart-ſtrings burn ye ſtronger.
Theſ are Youths Rocks, Syrts, Scilla & Charybd vile:
Foul filthy Harpyes, which with ordure defile
Bed-chambers, dining-rooms, table-bords, high-wais,
Churches, ſtreets, fields, Seas, rivers, hils, and Bais:
Theſ are the Gorgons ugly to behold,
Which dwelt in utmoſt Lybic coaſts of old;
And with their ſight turnd men into ſtones cold.
We hav th' Italian Poets verſes cited;
Which if they ſeem too tedious, let be minded,
That 'tis the Things fault, not the Poetry:
The Verſ is ſhort, but too long Womens folly.
O renownd Man, in whom old Italy
Boaſted ſo much, and Tyber neer the City:
Whom Martial Rome not without cauſ accited:
She knew thy skil and Verſes moſt admited.
The Latin and Greek Muſes bewaild thee
After death: let thy bones reſt quietly;
And thy ſublime Soul liv in Heav'n on high.

argument.p: This railing Mone haply learnd this of common Curtezans; as ther hav bin and are ſo bad Men (both Pagans and Chriſtians) in al ages. In the Aſſyrian Monarchy was a luſtful Semiramis, and far lewder Sardanapalus: in the Roman Empire a monſtrous Meſſalina, and more prodigious Heliogabalus: nor can Whordom, Adultery, or Inceſt be committed unles both Sexes concur, being more inſatiat in their luſt then Beaſts. 'Tis a tru ſaying, If Mens Virtues be conceled and Vices diſplaied a Saint wil ſeem a Devil: or contrarily: But charity covers a multitud of ſins. For ther hav bin Women of moſt admired Virtues, and exemplar perfections; though mixed with ſom natural infirmities liable to that Sex.
The 2 Muſicians (a Natural Vocal, and Artificial Inſtrumental) which contended for Maſtery.

l.hi: Jam Sol e medio pronus deflexerat Orbe,
Mitius a radiis vibrans crinalibus ignem:

div.l:
Cum Fidicen juxta
• iberina fluenta, ſonanti

l.hi: Lenibat plectro curas, aeſlumque levabat
Ilice defenſus nigra, Scenaque virenti.
Audiit hunc hoſpes Sylvae Philomela propinquae,
Muſa Loci, nemoris Siren, innoxia Siren:
Et prope ſuccedens stetit abdita frondibus, alte
Accipiens ſonitum, ſecumque remurmurat; & quoz
Ille modos variat digitis, has guttere reddit.
Senſit ſe Fidicen • hilomela imitante referri,
Et placuit ludum volucri dare: plenius ergo
Explorat Citharam, tentamentumque futurae
Praebeat ut pugnae; percurrit protinus omnes
Impulſu pernice fides: nec ſegnius illa
Mille perexcurrens variae diſcrimina vocis,
Venturi specimen praefert argutula Cantus.
Tunc Fidicen per fila movens trepidantia dextram,
Nunc Contemnenti ſimilis diverberat ungue,
Depectitque pari chordas, & ſimplice ductu:
Nunc carptim replicat, digitiſque micantibus urget
Fila minutatim, celerique repercutit ictu;
Mox ſilet: illa modis totidem reſpondet, & Artem
Arte refert; nunc ceu rudis aut incerta canendi,
Projicit in longum, nulloque plicabile flexu
Carmen init; ſimili ſerie certoque tenore
Praebetur liquid m • labenti pectore voci.
Nunc caeſim variat, moduliſque canora minutis
Delibrat Vocem, tremuloque reciprocat Ore.
Miratur Fidicen, parvis e faucibus ire
Tam varium tam dulce melos; majoraque tentans
Alternat mira arte fides: dum torquet acutas,
Inciditque graves operoſo verbere pulſat,
Permiſcetque ſimul certantia rauca ſonoris;
Ʋt Tuba ſocordes clangore ad bella laceſsit.
Hoc etiam Philomela canit, dumque ore loquenti
Vibrat acuta ſonum, moduliſque interplicat aequis;
Ex inopinato gravis intonat, & leve murmur
Turbinat introrſus, alternantique ſonore
Clarat & infuſcat, ceu Martia Claſsica pulſet.
Scilicet erubuit Fidicen, iràque calente
Aut non hoc referes (inquit) Citharistria Sylvae,
Aut fractae cedam Cithara: nec plura locutus
Non imitabilibus plectrum concentibus urget.
Numque manu pe • fila volat, ſimul hos, ſimul illos
Explorat numeros, chordaque laborat in omni:
Et ſtrepit & tinit, creſcitque ſuperbior, & ſe
Multiplicat relegens, plenoque Choreumate plaudit.
Tunc stetit expectans, ſi quid paret aemula contra.
Illa autem quamvis vox dudum exercita fauces
Asperat, impatiens vinci ſimul advocat omnes
Ne quicquam Vires: nam dum diſcrimine tanta
Reddere tot fidium nativa & ſimplice tentat
Voce, canaliculiſque imitari grandia parvis;
Impar magnanimis auſis, imparque dolori
Deficit, & vitam ſummo in certamine linquens,
Victoris cadit in plectrum, par nacta ſepulchrum:
Uſque adeo & tenues Animas ferit aemula Virtus.

div.l: The Sun now from the Heavens mid-day line,
Sending forth milder rais, 'gan to decline:
When neer to Tibers ſtreams, a Lutiſt eaſed
His cares with ſounding charms, and th' heat appeaſed
In a green ſeat, under a black Oke ſhaded.
A Nightingal of next Grov hearing invaded:
Muſe of the Place, ſly Siren of the Wood;
And drawing nigh, hid in the leafs, cloſe ſtood.
His ſounds ſhe cond t' hir ſelf, and ech high ſtrain
His fingers plaid, hir throat beat back again.
The Minſtril found th' imitating Bird reply,
And was pleaſd to giv play; therfore more fully
He tries his Lute, and to tender a taſt
Of th' inſuing conflict, runs through in haſt
His ſtrings with ſwift ſtrokes: She a thouſand keys
As nimbly warbleth with ſweet Voices lays;
Giving a warning ſharp and ſhril of their plais.
The Luteniſt with's hand then the ſmal threds plies,
And ſtrikes the quavering ſtrings in ſcornful wiſe:
Which he combs equaly, now in ſeveral;
Somtimes retouching with his fingers al
The ſtrings in order, and with ſwift ſtroke plais;
Streight ſtops: She anſwers with ſo many Lays,
And Art with Art pais: next as one in doubt
How ſhe ſhould ſing, hir tone in length draws out;
And ſings a ſolen ſtrain with conſtant Note,
Cleering the Lung-pipes with hir moiſtned throte:
Then ſings diviſion and with loud ſhril ſtrain
Poiſeth hir wavering Voice and fals again.
He wondring how ſuch ſtrange ſweet melody
Could from ſo ſmal throte com; would more ſtrings try
And with rare skil varies the ſtrings, while he
The Treble and the Baſe ſtrikes painfully:
Mingling the hoarl and ſhril with mutual ſtrife;
As Warlike Trumpets giv to Cowards life.
This too She tunes, and while with melting voice
She mingles middle meaſures with deep noiſ,
Suddenly thunders, jugging inwardly
With gentle murmur, and alternatly
Sings cleer and dark, as Wars alarms doo cry.
Surely the Minſtrel bluſhd, and in fierce mood,
Thou ſhalt not triumph, Chantreſſ of the Wood;
Or vanquiſh'd (ſaid) I'le break my Lute: ſtreight wais
He ſtrains his inſtrument to matchleſſ Lays:
His hand flies o're the ſtrings now here, now ther
In diffring numbers, laboring every wher.
Both flat and ſharp he ſtrikes, and becoms proud;
Cloſing his doubled ſtrains with Conſort loud.
Then looking ſtood, if 's Rival would reply:
But tho hir ſtraind Voice had hir throat made dry,
She loth to yeeld, hir whol ſtrength tries in vain:
For while ſhe ſtrivs with nativ ſimple ſtrain
Of Voice t'expreſſ ſuch diverſ lofty Lays,
With ſlender Pipes to reach high Notes like theſ:
Out-matchd with daring deeds, out-matchd with wo,
She faints and dies at laſt bout of hir Foe:
On Victors Lute ſhe fel, being a fit Grav:
Ev'n ſo ſmal Souls ſuch emulous Virtu hav.

argument.p:
The Author Strada (a Belgic Jeſuit in his Academical
Proluſions or Sports, framed this Fancy in 58 Heroic Hexameters: which Dr. Strode of Christ-Church at Oxford, elegantly tranſlated into 80 Engliſh metres; being 22 mo then the Latin: but are here rudely rendred in equal numbers or meaſures verſ for verſ, and very neer the letter, according to my plain Pedantic garb or guiſe, who never drank at Parnaſſus.
The 52 chief Cities of Italy conciſely charactered in ſo many Heroic Verſes.

div.l: Sancta est Sanctorum celeberrima ſanguine Roma:
Cingitur Ʋrbs Venetum pelago, ditiſsima nummis.
Inclita Parthenope gigxit Comiteſque Duceſque:
Est Mediaolanum jucundum, nobile, magnum.
Excellit ſtudiis foecunda Bononia cunctis:
Splendida ſolertes nutrit Florentia Cives.
Genoa habēt portum, merceſque domoſque ſuperbas:
Exhaurit loculos Ferraria ferrea plenos.
Verrona humanae dat ſingula commoda vitae:
Extollit Paduam Juris ſtudium & Medicinae.
Illuſtrat patriae Senas facundia linguae:
Maximapars hominum clamat miſeram eſſe Cremonam
Mantua gaudet aquis, ortu decorata Maronis:
Vina Utini varias generoſa vehuntur ad Ʋrbes.
Brixia dives opum parce ſuccurrit Egenis:
Italicos Verſus praefert Papia Latinis.
Libera Luca tremit Ducibus vicina duobus:
Flent Piſae amiſſum dum contemplantur honorem.
Commendant Parmam Lac, Caſeus, atque Butyrum:
Non caret Hospiciis perpulchra Placentia claris.
Taurinum exòrnant Virtus, pie • aſque, fideſque:
Militibus validis generoſa Placentia claret.
Vercelle lucro non delectantur iniquo:
Mordicus Ʋrbs Mutinae Ranas tenet eſſe ſalubres.
Contemnunt omnes Anconae moenia Turcas:
Latibus imponit, finem Macerata ſupremum.
Urbs Livii celebris nimis eſt proclivis ad arma:
Emporiae in portis conſiſtit gloria clauſis.
Bergomum ab inculta dictum eſt ignob • le lingua:
Omnibus exponit gladios Aretium acu • os.
Viterbi Conventus opem fert ſanctus Egenis:
Civibus humanis decorata eſt Aſta fidelis.
Fructibus, Anſeribus, Pomario Ariminum abundat:
Fanum formoſas Mulieres fertur habere.
Odit mundanas ſincera Novaria fraudes:
Clara parentiquae defecit fama Ravennae.
Anglia habet paucos Comites, Vincentia multos:
Omnes magnificant ficus groſſoſque Piſauri.
Caſtaneis, Oleo, Tritico Paſtorium abundat:
Ruſtica frugales nutrit Dertona Colonos.
Poſtponit Rhegium cornuta animalia Porcis:
Dulcia foeticem cingunt Vineta Ceſenam.
Tarviſium exhilarant nitido cum flumine Fontes:
Imola diviſa eſt; nocet haec diviſio multis.
Urbinum ſtatuit Ducibus clamare, valete:
Nota eſt fictilibus figulina Favenſia vaſts.
Spoletum vocitat, Peregrini intrate, manete:
Urbs pingues Pompeia boves producit, oveſque.
Narnia promittens epulas, dabit ova vel uvas:
Aſſinum ſancti Franciſci corpore gaudet.
Hospitibus Comum piſces cum carnibus offert:
Quaerit opes fragiles, ſtudiis Savena relictis.
Sunt tot in Italia vener andi ponderis Urbis:

l.hi: Quot vagus hebdomadas quilibet annus habet.

div.l: Rome Holy of Holies, renownd for Martyry:
Venice Sea-cloſd, moſt rich in Treaſury.
Moſt noble Naples Dukes and Earls ingenders:
Millain is blith, and hir ſelf ſplendid renders.
Fertil Bonony in al Arts doth excel:
Brav Florence maintains hir Inhabitants wel.
Genoa a Port, Wares, and proud Houſes ſhows:
Ferrary with hir Iron Mines poor grows.
Verona with al needful helps is crowned:
Padua for Law and Phiſick much renowned.
Siena famous is for Language purity:
Cremona (as moſt think) brought to poverty.
Mantua wel watred, with Virgils birth adorned:
Ʋtinas ſtrong Wines to ſundry States tranſported.
Breſcia is rich, yet helps Poor ſparingly:
Papy prefers Italic to Latin Poetry.
Luca being neer two Dukes, trembles with pain:
Piſa having loſt hir honor mourns amain.
Parma for Milk, Cheeſ, Butter, is extolled:
Fair Placence for ſtatly Ins is inrolled.
Taurinum Virtu hath, Piety and Fidelity;
Gallant Placentia ſhines with Art military.
Vercellae litle cares for wicked gain:
Mutinae hold Frogs for wholſom food t' attain.
Ancona from hir wals did the Turcs ſend:
Macerata puts to Law-ſuits a final end.
Great Livies City too prone is to debates:
Emporias glory ſtands in ſhutting their Gates.
Bergamo is held baſe for their language rude:
Aretium their ſharp ſwords to al intrude.
Vilerbums holy Covent abounds with Charity:
Aſta is famous for Citizens courteſy.
Arimin with Fruits, Geeſ, Orchards doth abound:
Fair Women in Fanum are ſaid to be found.
Honeſt Novary hares al worldly cheating:
Ravenna's antient fame is quite defeating.
Vincentia many Earls hath, England but few:
Al Piſaurs Figs and Fruits as beſt doth ſhew.
Pastory hath ſtore of Cheſnuts, Oil, and Wheat:
Derton feeds Clowns, who frugal are to eat.
Rhegium prefers Hogs to horned Cattle ſtore:
Sweet Vineyards compaſſ Ceſena back and before.
Tarviſium ſweet ſprings hath, with a River cleer:
Imola's divided, which is hurtful meer.
Urbin reſolvs to bid their Dukes farewel:
Faventia in making Clay-pots bears the bel.
Spoletum cries, Gueſts enter and make ſtay:
Pompey fat Oxon and Sheep breeds alway.
Narny bids Feaſts, but Egs or Grapes doth giv:
Aſsinum by Saint Francis Corps doth liv.
Comum their Gueſts with Fiſh and Fleſh entertain:
Saven their Studies leav and hunt for gain.
So many Cities hath Italy of high price:
As every wandring yeer doth weeks compriſe.

div.head: EPIG. LIIII. Res hominum incertae.

argument.p: The 8 Heroic Verſes of wicked Mens proſperity, and good Mens adverſity.

l.hi: Saepe mihi dubium traxit ſententia mentem.
Curarent ſuperi Terras, an nullus ineſſet
Rector; & incerto fluerent Mortalia caſu?
Sed cum res hominum tanta caligine • olvi
Aſpicerem, latoſque diu florere Nocentes,
Vexarique bonos; pietas labefacta cadebat,
Fortuna, non Arte regi: quae Numina ſenſu
Ambiguo vel nulla putat, velneſcia noſtri.
Cum rapiant mala fata bonos, ignoſcite faſſo;
Sollicitor nullos eſſe putare Deos.

lg.l: My dubious mind was oft perplexd in thought,
Whether the Gods Earthly affairs hav wrought:
Or elſ no Ruler was, and things by chance fel?
But when Mens Fates ſo darkſom I ſaw wel
Managd to be; and bad Men long to proſper,
And the good vexd: my Piety 'gan to daver,
That Fortune, not Art rules: that Gods none are,
Or ſuch as of us Mortals take no care.
When Good men by il fates fal, pardon me;
I am allur'd to think no Gods ther be.

div.p: Lilies Qui mihi Diſcipulus is tranſlated too: but unnt to be woven into this work.

div.head: EPIG. LV. Bellum Navale contra Turcas.

argument.p: The 3 Chriſtian Stats or Potentats (Pope, Spaniard, Venetian) which joined Seaforces againſt the Turcs:

l.hi: CHriſticolae iu Turcas bellum Navale gerebant
Invictis animis, auſpiciiſque bonis.

lg.l: Chriſtians 'gainſt Turcks maintaind a Naval fight
With matchleſſ valour, and ſucceſ • ful might.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Hiſpani, & Veneti cum Papa foedere juncti,
In Selymum Turcam pugnam iniere mari.

lg.l: Spaniards, & Venetans, wth Pope in League combined,
'Gainſt Turciſh Selym a Sea-ſight atchieved.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Chriſticolae pugnam in Turcas habuere Lepanto
Gurgite, ubi inſignis Baſſa peremptus Hali eſt.
Chriſtians in Lepant gulf did fight darrain
'Gainſt Turcs, wher Hali chief Baſſa was ſlain.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Viginti hoc pereunt Turcarnm millia bello:
Octo quoque ex alia millia parte cadunt.

lg.l: At this fight twenty thouſand Tures in al;
Eght thouſand eke on th' other part did fal.

argument.p: The 3 Churches which quite bar or grant liberty (more or leſſ) unto their Clergy to be maried.

l.hi: Papa vetat Clerum, ſemel at dant nubere Graeci:
Biſque Reſormati, terve, quaterve probant.

lg.l: Popes forbid Clercs to wed, Greecs once advow:
Reformiſts, twiſe, thriſe, or four times allow.

argument.p: The 3 Attributs or appellations aſcribed to our ſacred Saviour or Redeemer the only Meſſias.

l.hi: Officia ut tria ſunt Meſſiae aſcripta futuro;
Sic tria ſunt Chriſto Nomina jure data.

lg.l: As to Meſſias three Offices were preſigned;
So three Names rightly are to Chriſt aſſigned.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Salvator Jeſus, Chriſtus, Dominuſque vocatur:
Quae tribus Officiis Nomina rite quadrant.

lg.l: Our Saviour Jeſus is, Chriſt, and Lord named:
Which titles t' his three Offices are wel framed.

argument.p: The 3 Tentations which the Devil uſed in the Wildernes, to try whether Chriſt were the tru Meſſias.

l.hi: A Satana in Chriſtum facta eſt tentatio triplex:
Ʋt probet, an fuerat Filius ille Dei.
Fac fieri hos Lapides panem: te dejice ab alto:
Omnia Regna tibi, ſi venerere, dabo.
Hiſce modis Chriſtum aggreditur Tentator iniquus:
Illecebris faſtus, ambitione, fame.

lg.l: Satan 'gainſt Chriſt did three tentations plot;
To prov if he was Son of God, or not.
Cauſtheſ ſtones be made bread: caſt thy ſelf from high
Al Realms I'le giv, if thoul't me Deify.
The Tempter Chriſt aflaild by theſ three wais:
Famin, Preſuming, and Ambitious lays.

argument.p: The 2 Things, which are highly valued or eſteemed as pretious comodities in this Life.

l.hi: Pulchrum Aurum eſt, ſed ſana criſis pretiofior Auro:
Quam prece, nec pretio quiſque parare poteſt.

lg.l: Gold glorious is, but Health then Gold more dear:
Which none by praiers, or price can purchas here.

argument.p: The 2 chief rarities of remark or ſtrange ſights (Mount Strella and Anas river) which Spain boaſts of.

lg.l: Venditat in terris latitantem Hiſpania Rivum,

l.hi: Et Montem in cujus vertice vaſta palus.

lg.l: Spain boaſts a River running under ground,
And Hil in whoſ top a vaſt Lake is found.
Admiranda duo nativa Hiſpania jactat:
Strella unum eſt, aliud nomine flumen Anas.
Spain vaunts two nativ marvels of great fame:
Mount Strella one, th' other Anas ſtream by name.

div.head: EPIG. LXI. Monarchae a Servis caeſt.

argument.p: The 2 mighty Monarchs (Melechſala by Mamaluks, and Oſman by Janizaries) Murdered by their Slavs.

l.hi: Gens Dominos Mamalucha fera, & Janizarica turba
Infenſis animis enecuere ſuos.

lg.l: The Mamaluks fierce and Janizaries rout
Their Lords with fel minds kild, and rooted out.

argument.p: The 6 baleful baneful waters in ſeveral parts of the World, caled the Rivers or Pools of Hel.

l.hi: Aſpectu horribiles, variis in partibus Orbis,
Bis tres lethiferae commemorantur aquae.

lg.l: Six baneful waters horrid to behold,
In ſundry parts of th' Univerſ are told.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Inferni tria ſunt ut flumina, ſic tria ſtagna:

lg.l: Styx, Acheron, Lethe, Phlegeton, Cocytus, Avernus
Hels three Brooks, Lakes three are Styx, Acheron,

l.hi: Corcytus, Lethe, Avernus, Phlegeton.

argument.p: The 4 Horſes of Phoebus or Titan, fained to flaſh forth light at their wide Noſtrils.

l.hi: Bis duo Solis Equi, qui Lucem Naribus efflant
Flagrantem patulis, aethera luce replent.

lg.l: The Suns four Steeds, which flaſh forth firy light
At their large Noſtrils, make the Sky ful bright.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Bis duo Titanis, qui lucem e Naribus efflant

l.hi: Per Mundum patulis, enumerantur Equi:

lg.l: Titans four Horſes, which caſt out the light
From their broad Noſtrils, make the whol World bright.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: Bis duo Solis Equi Pyroeis, Phlegon, Aethon, Eous:

l.hi: Qui rutilum effundunt lumen ab ore ſuo.

lg.l: Pyrois, Phlegon, Aethon, Eous four
Suns Horſes from their mouths the bright ſhine pour.

argument.p: The 2 cruel Women, which Poets fain to be turned into two Gulfs or Whirl-pools betwixt Italy and Sicil.

l.hi: In ſcopulos geminae Mulieres eſſe feruntur
Verſae: Navigiis quae fera damna ferunt.

lg.l: Two Women to be turnd into Rocks are fained:
By which Ships hav moſt direful harms ſuſtained.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Naufragiis maledicta fuit Scilla atque Charybdis:

l.hi: Imminet in Siculo gurges uterque ſolo.

lg.l: In Sicil Sea two curſed Gulfs are ſound,
Scilla and Charybd: wher Ships oft are drown'd.

argument.p: The 3 ſhapes of Sphynx a ridling Monſter (Daughter to Tryphon) who was a bloody brutiſh Woman.

lg.l: Foemina in Aonia truculenta aenigmata dudum,

l.hi: Propoſuit variis vix replicanda Viris.

lg.l: A cruel Woman neer Thebes, oft proponed
Riddles to diyerſ Men, hard to b' unfolded.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Sphinx facie Mulier, pedibus Fera, & Ales in alis:

l.hi: Monſtrum informe olim dicitur eſſe triplex.

lg.l: Sphinx Woman-fac'd, Beaſt-footed, wing'd as Fowl
Is faind of old a three-fold Monſter foul.

argument.p: The 12 chief Maſculin Gods, whom the Gentils moſt honored with Temples and ſolen Sacrifices.

l.hi: Bis ſex praecipuos, inter tot usillia pridem
Priſci Idololatrae percoluere Deos.

lg.l: The old Idolaters twelv chief Gods of old
Uſed to ſerv, 'mongſt thouſands manifold.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Juppiter, Alcides, Hermes, Mars, Pluto, Saturnus,
Pan, Uulcanus, Amor, Bacchus: Apollo, Tridens.

l.hi: Saturn, Jove, Pluto, Phoebus, Mars, Mercury,
Neptune, Pan, Bacchus, Cupid, Vulcan, Hercly.

argument.p: The 12 Female Deities of moſt memorable mark, whom Heathen Idolaters principaly adored.

l.hi: Bis ſenas habuere Deas e claſſe ſuprema
Gentiles veteres, quas coluere nimis.

lg.l: Twelv Female Goddeſſes antient Ethnics ſcored,
Of higheſt rank: which they too much adored

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Juno, Minerva, Venus, Thetys, Ops, Proſerpina, Luna
Rhaea, Amphitrite, Veſta, Diana, Ceres.

l.hi: Juno, Pallas, Proſerpin, Ops, Venus Rhaea.
Amphitrit, Dian, Ceres, Thetys, Moon, Veſta.

div.head: EPIG. LXVIII. Deae pro forma aemulae.

argument.p: The 3 Pagan Goddeſſes faind to ſtriv for Jupiters golden Bal, the prize of the beſt Beauty.

l.hi: Contendêre Deae, quae pulchrior eſſet earum,

lg.l: Judice tres olim Paride, Fama canit.
Whilom three Goddeſſes ſtrov for Beauties prize,
Paris being Judg; as Fame doth Poetize.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Tres habuere Deae dubium diſcrimen in Ida
Pro formae imperio. Juno, Minerva, Venus.
For Beauties Bal three Deities ſtoutly ſtrov
(Juno, Pallas, Venus) in the Idan Grov.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons or rather One-two (the Authors Wife, who was with Child) which killed ech other.

l.hi: Dudum ex morbillis Genetrix & Faetus in alvo,
Fato immaturo deperiere ſimul:
Inficit Infantem Mater, Matrem afficit Infans:
Mutua mors illinc ſors utriuſque fuit.

lg.l: A Mother and Chriſm Child in hir womb of late,
Cam by ſmal Pox at once t' untimely fate:
The Mother infects the Babe, the Child the Mother:
Thence mutual death befel both ech from other.

argument.p: The 2 Perſons (Wife and Son to Mr. Fr: Croſſing) who died in one day, and ly buried together.

l.hi: Nobile Par jacet hic, pia, Mater, caelica Proles:
tranſtulit una dies, quos tenet una domus.

lg.l: A noble Pair, good Mother, heav'nly Son
Dying in one day, ly here unneath one ſtone.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Filius & Genitrix obiere diecula in una:
Ʋno itidem tumulo tectus uterque jacet:

lg.l: A Son and Mother in one day expired:
And both ly in one Sepulcher inſhrfned.

argument.p: The 2 noble Perſons (Sir Fr: Acland and his Mother) who died four dais aſunder.

l.hi: Morbillis moritur Natus cum tabe peremptus:
Pulmonis vomica Mater obitque brevi.

lg.l: The Son of ſmal Pox and Conſumption died:
And's Mother with Apoſtem ſoon expired.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Filius expirat morbillis: Mater eodem
Aegra die occubuit, quatriduoque obiit.

lg.l: The Son of ſmal Pox died: on which ſame day
His Mother ſickning, on fourth fel away.

argument.p: The 10 Epicedial Diſtichs compoſed on the death of Thomas Vilvain his Fathers only Child.

lg.head: Monitio.

l.hi: Omnem crede diem tibi diluxiſſe ſupremum:
Sero nimis vita eſt craſtina, vive bene.

lg.l: Eſteem ech day that ſhines as thy laſt day:
To morow coms too late; liv wel alway.

l.hi: Mortalem genui Natum: diſcrimina mortis
Humanae a nobis non aliena reor.

lg.l: A mortal Son I got: no Human dangers
Of death I deem from us to b' any ſtrangers.

lg.head: Inſcriptio

l.hi: Conditur hoc Cippo Juvenis probitate refulgens:
Clarus amore Dei, charus in ore Virûm.

lg.l: Here lies a young Man ſhining in honeſty:
Moſt dear to Men, and ful of heav'nly piety.

lg.head: Deſcriptio

l.hi: Si quis inoffenſum peragebat ſuaviter aevum,
Cui placuit bonitas, & pietatis amor:
Talis erat dum vivus erat, quem flore Juventae
Eripuit celeri mors male grata pede.

lg.l: If any led an harmleſſ ſweet life here,
Who goodnes lov'd, and godlines held dear:
Such during life was he, whom in Youths prime,
Unwelcom ſwift-foot death ſnatch'd 'fore his time,

lg.head: Mythologia.

l.hi: Mors & eoecus Amor mutabant forte pharetras:
Haec validos Juvenes percutit, ille Senes.
Ille quidem caecus, ſed mors mage caeca; ſagittis
Quae teneros Juvenes vere virente rapit.

lg.l: Death and blind Cupid by chance Quivers changed
One ſtrong Young men, th'other old Dotards wounded.
Surely he blind was, but death blinder deemed;
Which tender Sprigs in prime of Spring bereaved.

lg.head: Proſopopaeia.

l.hi: Hunc tibi, Nate, Pater tumulum moeſtiſſimus addo:
Talia ſed ſtrueres tu monumenta mihi.
Tu prius ingrederis Coelos, ego in orbe ſuperstes:
Non ego te, ſed tu deſeris ipſe Patrem.
Per merita & mortem Chriſti, ſuper Aſtra relatus
Te tamen idque brevi tempore. ſpero ſequi.

lg.l: The forlorn Father made this Tumb for thee:
But thou ſuch monument ſhouldſt hav made for me.
Thou firſt Heav'n entreſt, I on Earth yet trace:
I left not thee, but thou me for ſhort ſpace.
Yet by Chriſts death and merits, ſuddenly.
I hope to folow thee 'boy Starry Sky.

argument.p: The 6 Elegiacal Diſtichs, made on the death of Roger Mallack a rich Exter Merchant and his Wife.

l.hi: Naſcimur & morimur, quia naſcimur ut moriamur:
Mors etenim cuivis non fugienda manet.

lg.l: W' are born and dy, becauſ al born to dy:
For death remains to ech infallibly.

l.hi: Vir jacet hic locuples, verus pietatis amator:
Non prece nec pretio parcere Parca ſolet.
Veſicae infecit penetralia calculus ejus:
Ʋlcus enim genuit, quo cruciatus obit.
Si violenta velit validam mors vendere vitam;
Hic velit & potuit pendere mille minas.

lg.l: A rich Man lies here, lover of piety:
But Death ſpares none for praier or bribery:
A Bladder ſtone his Entrals putrified:
For 't bred and Ulcer of which pain he died.
If churliſh Death would ſtrong life ſel or lend;
He would and could a thouſand pound expend.

Anna prius moriens Ʋxor, tumulatur ibidem:
Apr. 6. 1646.

l.hi: Aspectuque Dei gaudet uterque ſimul.
Calculus hanc Renum, Veſica interficit illum:
Amboque ſub Lapide hoc fata ſuprema replent.

lg.l: His Wife An dying firſt, here tumbd doth ly:
And both Gods viſion now enjoy jointly.
Hir ſtone of Kidnies, him of Bladder killed:
And both unneath this Stone their fates fulfilled.

argument.p: The 2 debats (touching Name and Thing) about celebrating Christmas and other Feſts.

l.hi: Sitne ſuperſtitio Natalis feſta ſacrare
Christi? inter varios lis odioſa fuit.

lg.l: Scaurus ait, renuit Varus: utri credere vultis?

l.hi: Tam facile eſt lites conciliare graves.
In dextram potius pietate offendere praeſtat,
Quam laeva opprobriis ſpernere Feſta ſacra.
Diſcite quod verum eſt moniti, nec temnite Chriſtū:
Sed colite aeterno Feſta dicata Deo.

lg.l: Ther's hateful ſtrife 'mongſt ſom, whether to keep holy
Chriſts Birth-day Feſt, be ſuperſtitious folly?
Scaurus ſaith, Varus gainſaith: which wil ye
Beleev? ſo eaſy 'tis great brawls t' agree.
'Tis better, right hand wiſe, by zele t' offend,
Then, left-like, holy Feſts with ſcorns vilipend.
Learn truth that's taught, and doo not Chriſt defy:
But Feſts ordain'd t' Eternal God ſanctify.

argument.p: The 4 Maries, which loved Chriſt intirely, and ſtood by mourning at his crucifixion.

lg.l: Prima fuit Mater, Cleopae Ʋxor proxima, deinde
Peccatrix, Salome quarta Maria ſubit.
Chriſts Mother firſt, Cleopas wife next, third Mawdlin,
Fourth Mary Salome Zebedees Wife hath bin,

argument.p: The 2 Iſraelits (Ioſua and Caleb) which ſurvived fourty yeers, to enter into Canaan the promiſed Land.

lg.l: Jacobi ex ſobole multa inter millia, tantum
In terram Canaan introiere duo.
'Mongſt many thouſands of Jacobs progeny,
Two entred into Canaans Land ſoly.
Carbaſafiſte, Ratis: tibi Cynthia vellicat aures.
Barque, ſtop thy ſails; Cynthia bids ſtay:
Elſ ſhe wil ſole thy ears away.

l.hi: Sexcentum & decies ſeptem hoc Epigrammata, praeter
Carmina mille quater ſunt cumulata, Libro.

lg.l: Six hundred and ſeventy Effais in this Book,
Biſide four thouſand Verſes you may look.

l.hi: Praeluſit Liber hic, prodibit forſitan alter
Altior, & (dextro Numine) majus opus.
Ʋt pugno palma eſt contracto expanſa, Libello
Huic indigeſto ſic erit iſte Liber.

lg.l: This Book's a toy, the next of loftier breed
And larger bulk (by Gods Grace) ſhal ſucced.
As the hands Palm is to a fiſt contracted:
Such is this Book to the next at large compacted.

l.hi: Hic Liber eſt Index Libri argumenta parati
Qui tenet: hoc Verba, at Res peragentur eo.

lg.l: This Book's a Table of the next ordained:
Here Words, ther Things explaned are contained.

l.hi: Hic Liber haud Liber eſt, ſed Bibliotheca Metrorii
Quae lucubrata magic complicat ampla ſtrues.

lg.l: This Book no Book is, but Verſes Library:
Which a large Pile fuller explan'd doth cary.

l.hi: Inchoat hicce Liber primaeva ab origine Mundi:
Cum Mundi interitu terminat iſtud Opus.

lg.l: At the Worlds origin this Book inchoats:
With the Worlds period this Work terminats,

l.hi: Incipit a Mundo primus Liber iſte creato:
Cum Mundi exitio definet hicce Liber.

lg.l: That firſt Book took riſe from the Worlds Creation:
This laſt takes end at the Worlds annillation.

l.hi: Hocce Opere eſt multis paraſangis doctior Author
Factus: at incaepti non pudet inde ſui.

lg.l: The Author many ſteps more learnd became
By this work: but of's Empriſe takes no ſhame.

l.hi: A Mundi exoritur genefi Liber • exitus Orbis
Quando erit, exibit Mandus hic atque Liber.

lg.l: This Book begins at the Worlds Nativity:
Both World and Book end in one nullity.

div.head: An Appendix of Verſes annexed to Centuria Carminum ech of the eght Theological Theſes.

lg.l: Octo a Theiologis Theoremata tradita conſtant:
Quae praeeunte Libro perhibentur mording certo.
1. Humanae Theſis eſt animae productio prima:
2. Qui Deus Adamum praedeſtinat aliera tangit:
3. Tertia, qua forma eſt moderata Eccleſia, pandit:
4. Quarta Prophetei •• de Meſsia explicat omnes:
5. Stemma Genetbliacum deſcribit proxima Christi:
6. Maxima ſexta aperic Myſteria viſa Joanni:
7. Septima agit Chriſti de Regno mille per annos:
8. Extremum Mundi excidium poſtrema remonſtrat.

lg.head: A Summary of eght Theological Theſes.

lg.l: Eght Theories handled by Divines ther are:
Which in ſet rank foregoing leafs declare.
Mans Souls production in firſt file doth proceed:
The ſecund ſhews, how of Adam God decreed:
The third, in what form Church is rul'd, declareth:
The fourth al Prophecies of Meſſiah explaneth:
The fifth deſcribes Chriſts duple Pedigrees:
The ſixth unfolds Johns deepeſt Myſteries:
The ſeventh Chriſts 1000 yeers reign doth debare:
The laſt this Worlds confuſion doth relate.

div.head: Theſ. 1 Whether every Mans Soul ſince Adams be created or generated?

l.hi: Spiritus an jugiter genitus ſit, ſive creatus;
Quem Deus infudit? lis violenta ſubest.

lg.l: Whether Mans Soul, which God breathd, & created,
Be ſtil infus'd or bred? 'tis much debated.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Spiritus Anne hominum genitus ſit, ſive creatus?
Eſt inter doctos lis animoſa Viros.

lg.l: Whether Mens Souls bred or created are?
Among the Learned is fierce furious jar.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Particula in nobis divinae Spiritus aurae,
(Quaeritur an genitus ſive creatus) ineſt.

lg.l: The Souls in us a Part by God inſpired:
(Whether begot or creat?) 'tis inquired.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Neſcit Homo, An ſua Mens generetur ſive creetur?
Se tamen oſtentat noſcere cuncta miſer.

lg.l: Poor Man knows not, if's Soul be bred or moulded?
Yet boaſts that he hath al things elſ unfolded.

lg.head: Sive.

l.hi: In dubio lis eſt, An Mens ex traduce nata
Sit cujuſque hominis, ſive creata magis?

lg.l: 'Tis doubt, whether ech Mans Soul be propagated
From Parents Souls; or rather by God created?

lg.head: Mr. Woolnots Opinion.

l.hi: Noſtram Animam ex nihilo negat Author hic eſſe creatam
Externum efficiens vult tamen eſſe Deum.
Sic Animas potis eſt voce creare novas.

lg.l: Our Soul of nought made, this Author denies:
Yet God external Agent to be implies.
If God aſſiſts al Births when propagat;
He can ſo wel with's word new Souls creat.

div.head: Theſ. 2. Whether Gods Predeſtination reſpects his ſimple Preſcience, or pure pleaſure?

l.hi: Anteaquam decreta ſerat, Deus omnia praeſcit:
Progreditur conſtans ordine namque ſuo.

lg.l: God foreknows al, before he doth decree:
For he proceds in's order conſtantly.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quos Deus aeternum praeſcit, praedeſtinat; hoſque
Eligit aut reprobat, pro bonitate ſua.

lg.l: God foreknows and foredooms eternaly:
And elects or rejects for's clemency.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Vult ſalvare aliquos, reliquos damnare Jehovah:
Sed cur ſic voluit, non bene cauſa patet.

lg.l: God ſom wil ſav, and the reſt damn to Hel:
But why he wil, the cauſ appeers not wel.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Scire praeit, ſed velle ſuo venit ordine certo:
Decr • tum ſequitur velle perenne Dei.

lg.l: To know preceds, but to wil coms orderly,
Gods Decrees folow his Wil continualy.

lg.head: Sive.

l.hi: Simplici in intuitu certo omnia praeſciit, ante
Quam ſtatuit Mundum fabrificare Deus.

lg.l: In ſimple Intellect God al foreknew,
Yer he would make the World, what ſhould inſu.

lg.head: Aut.
lg.l: An lapſu praeviſo Elohim praedeſtinet Adae,

l.hi: Aut mero ex libito? lis gravis orta stetit.

lg.l: Whether God predeſtind knowing Adams fal,
Or of free Pleaſure? great ſtrif did befal.

lg.head: Vel.

l.hi: Jacta prius quam ſunt Mundi primordia, quoſdam
Eligit, at reliquos rejicit ipſe Deus.

lg.l: Before the World was laid, God ſom did chuſe;
But from eternity did the reſt refuſe.

lg.head: Seu.

l.hi: Novit ab aeterno Deus omnia tempore danda:
Postea decrevit quae fabricare velit.

lg.l: God knew eternaly al that in Time ſhould be:
And decreed after what he would frame free.

lg.head: Secius.

l.hi: Ordine Naturae Omniſciens prius omnia vidit;
Quam quid decrevit mente Create Deus.

lg.l: Al-knowing God did al in Nature ſee,
Yer he in mind to make ought did Decree.

div.head: Theſ. 3. Whether Church Government is to be Monarchic, Ariſtocratic, Democratic, or mix't?

l.hi: Quale ſita Mundigeneſi, per ſecula Cleri
Continuum regimen; praevia ſcripta probant.

lg.l: What Church rule from ye Worlds birth ſtil hath bin
Through al times; may by previous proofs be ſeen.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Hiſtoria haec recitat; qua recta Eccleſia forma,
Praeſidibuſque quibus tempus in omne ſuit.

lg.l: How through al times the Church was governed,
And by what rules in ſtory is regiſtred.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Spirituale ſuit Regimen pro mo • e Monarchae:
Sic Deus inſtituit, Chriſtus idemque tenet.

lg.l: Church Government founded was in Kingly frame:
So God ordaind and Chriſt upheld the ſame.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Antiſtes caput eſt Cleri, ſed Praesbyteratus
Corpus Epiſcopii: Jus utriuſque patet.

lg.l: A Biſhop is Clergies Head, but Presbytry
(Boths right is cleer) Body of Epiſcopy.

lg.head: Sive.

l.hi: Praesbyteris in Clero aſcitus Epiſcopus omni,
Semper Apoſtolico jure ſupremus erat.

lg.l: Biſhops in al Clergies were ſet ſuperior
To Prieſts, by Apoſtolic right ſtil inferior.

lg.head: Vel.

l.hi: Coetui Apoſtolico ſuccedunt jure ſacrato
Pontifices; Clerum qui Populumque regunt.

lg.l: Biſhops ſucced th' Apoſtles ſacredly
Who Clergy ruld, and People rightfully.

lg.head: Epiphonema.

l.hi: Sch • ſmatici cuncti rite Haereticique vocantur.
Qui male Praelatis oppoſuere ſuis.

lg.l: Al that oppos'd their prelats wrongfully,
Are Schiſmatics and Heretics cald juſtly.

div.head: Theſ. 4. Whether al Prophecies in the old Teſtament of the Meſsiah to com, were fulfilled by or in Chriſt?

l.hi: Quae de Meſsiae adv • ntu cecinere Prophetae
Praeſtita per Christum Cuncta ſuere bene.

lg.l: What of Meſſias Prophets did foretel,
Were by Chriſts coming al performed wel.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Quae de Meſsia veteres retulere Prophetae,
Perſpicue im Chriſto praestita quaeque patent.

lg.l: What Prophets old of the Meſſiah informed,
Doo cleerly al appeer in Chriſt performed.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Ordine resrogrado: quae Chriſtus facta peregit,
Cuncta Libris Vates praemonuere ſuis.

lg.l: Backward again: al things which Chriſt atchievd,
Were by the Prophets in their Books premiſed.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Quam bene conveniunt praemiſſa Prophetica Chriſio?
Quam bene complevit ſingula Chriſtus item?

lg.l: How wel to Chriſt thoſ Prophecies agree?
How wel by Chriſt al things accompliſh'd be?

div.head: Theſ. 5. Whether Chriſts two Genealogies (Legal and Natural) be rightly recorded by S. Matthew and Luke?

l.hi: Stemma Genethliacum Chriſti, per ſacula cuncta
panditur a Mundi conditione prius.

lg.l: Chriſts Genethliac Stock is afore dilated
Throughout al Times, ſince ye world was firſt created.

lg.head: Aliter.
lg.l: Matthaeus varie & Lucas ſata ſtemmata Chriſti,

l.hi: In Geneallogiis explicuere ſuis.

lg.l: Matthew and Luke hav expreſs'd diverſly
Chriſts tru deſcent in their Genealogy.

lg.head: Alias.
lg.l: En Geneallogiam Chriſti de ſtirpe Davidis:

l.hi: Qui Deus ex pura Virgine factus Homo eſt.

lg.l: Lo Chriſts deſcent from Davids Linage ſure:
Who tru God was made Man of Virgin pure.

lg.head: Secus.
lg.l: Symmetria inſignis, Chriſtum de ſtirpe Davidis:

l.hi: Est in Evangelio, rite fuiſſe ſatum.

lg.l: That Chriſt from Davids Stock drew his Proſapy,
Ther's in the Goſpel a moſt cleer ſymmetry.

lg.head: Sive.
lg.l: Matthaeus varie Chriſti, Lucaſque recenſent
A Davide, ſuo stemmata quiſque modo.
Matthew and Luke Chriſts Pedigree doo diſplay
From Davids Loins ech of them his own way.

lg.head: Cataſtrophe.
lg.l: Flos de Jeſſe fuit, Davidis ſanguine Chriſtus:

l.hi: Sicut Evangelii Biblia ſacra probant.

lg.l: Chriſt Jeſſes Flower, from Davids blood did ſpring:
As Goſpel ſacred Books plain proofs doo bring.

div.head: Theſ. 6. Whether the Book of Revelation can certainly be explaned, before the event make things evident?

lg.l: Medus Vir celebris, nulli bonitate ſecundus; Mr. Medes Comment.

l.hi: Artibus, Ingenio, Judicioque pr • it.

lg.l: Quaeque revelavit myſteria magna Joanni

l.hi: Chriſtus, in illius ſunt patefacta Libro.

lg.l: Mede was a rare man, for goodnes next to none;
In Learning, Wit, and Judgment chief alone.
And what high hid things Chriſt to John declared,
Are in his Apocalyptic Book explaned.

l.hi: Multa brevi obvenient, ait Author, tempore mira:
Si modo venturis eſt adbibenda fides.

lg.l: Strange things, ſaith th' Author, ſhortly ſhal befal:
If things to com may be beleevd at al.
Sunt patefact a ſacro mysteria magna Joanni;

l.hi: Quae Deus in ſeclis efficienda docet.

lg.l: To holy John great myſteries were told:
Which to be doon in Times God doth unfold.

div.head: Theſ. 7. Whether Chriſt ſhal reign a thouſand yeers with his Martyrs and ſom Saints on Earth, at the day of Judgment.

lg.l: Impius aſseruit Chriſtum, annis mille Cerinthus

l.hi: Perſona in terris velle manere ſua.

lg.l: Vile Cerinth ſaid Chriſt wil in Perſon reign
One thouſand yeers; and here on Earth remain.

l.hi: Mille annis Chriſtum, Chiliarchae inſomnia produnt,
Hic cum Martyribus velle manere ſuis.

lg.l: Vain Chiliaſts dream, that Chriſt with's Saints wil ſtay
One thouſand yeers, and here on Earth bear ſway.

l.hi: De Christi imperio Chiliaſtae mille per annos
Ante diem extremum, ſomnia vana ferunt.

lg.l: That Chriſt one thouſand yeers on Earth ſhal reign
Before laſt day, Chiliaſts vain dreams doo fain.

lg.head: Secus.

l.hi: Regnare in Terris mille annis velle Chiliſtae
Chriſtum cum Sanctis: dogmata falſa tenent.

lg.l: That Chriſt with's Saints one thouſand yeers wil reign
On Earth, bold Chiliaſts doctrins falſ maintain.

lg.head: Sive.

l.hi: Velle redemptorem regere annis mille Chilarchae
Judicii in Terris aſſeruere die.

lg.l: Chiliſts affirm, that Chriſt on Earth wil ſway
One thouſand yeers at the laſt Judgment day.

div.head: Theſ. 8. Whether this material World being fired, ſhal be renewed, ſubſtituted, or utterly annulled?

l.hi: Judicio extremo, post ultima ſecula, Mundus
Ignibus extinctus materialis erit.

lg.l: At the laſt Judgment, when Time is finiſhed;
This World with fire ſhal be quite extinguiſhed.

lg.head: Aliter.

l.hi: Non renovatus erit praeſens, nec conditus alter
Mundus cum veniet ſero ſuprema dies.

lg.l: This World ſhal not renewd be, nor new formed,
When the laſt day in fine ſhal be performed.

lg.head: Alias.

l.hi: Mundus hic ut perhibent paſsim ſacra Biblia, poſtquam
Vertitur in cineres; annihilatus erit.

lg.l: This World, as Scriptures ſpeak, after 'tis burned
To aſhes, ſhal be into Nothing turned.

l.hi: Quod fuit ex Nihilo factum, post ſecula tandem
In Nihilum hoc Mundi grande redibit Opus.

lg.l: This Worlds huge Work, wch was of nought compounded
Shal into Nought at laſt day be confounded.

l.hi: In cineres Mundi redigetur maxima moles:
In Nihilum cineres mox adigentur item.

lg.l: The Worlds huge Maſſ into aſhes ſhal be brought:
Thoſ aſhes too ſhal ſoon be turnd to Nought.

lg.head: Doxologia.

l.hi: Carmina Centuria hic Theſium recitantur in una:
Gratia, Laus, Ditio, Gloria danda Deo.

lg.l: One hundred Theſial Verſes are here rendred:
Thanks, Praiſ, Power, Glory be to God ſtil tendred.

l.hi: Culleus en ego ſum, mediis illaeſiu in undis:
Temporibuſque malis auſus adeſſe bonus.

lg.l: Lo, I Buoy-like in midſt of waves undrownd:
And daring in bad times good to be found.

l.hi: In re quaque bona, ſumma eſt Conſtantia Virtus:
Nam falſe a vero flectere ſaepe ſolent.

lg.l: In ech good Cauſ, chief Virtu is conſtancy.
For falſ Men oft decline from Verity.

l.hi: Ingenium Puerile meum mala carmina cudit:
Omnes namque Senes bis Pueri eſſe ſolent.

lg.l: My Childiſh wit moſt Verſes bad hath framed:
For al Oldmen twiſe Babes are wontly named.

l.hi: Tam vixiſſe diu haud pudet, aut omnino pigebit
Me cito, ſi Superi ſic ſtatuere, mori.

lg.l: I ſhame not t' hav liv'd thus long, nor griev to dy,
If ſo God hath appointed, ſpeedily.
